column2: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 8 -- The age-old Hollywood boy-meets-girl story was put to football today: Florida met Georgia, Florida led Georgia, Florida fell behind Georgia, Florida tied Georgia, 13-13, as everybody in the record Gator Bowl crowd of 70,862 went home happily ever after.
Over the past two decades there has been growing evidence that our nation's supply of physicians has not been sufficient to meet the health needs and demands of our people.
HOUSTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Bill Montgomery cranked up a sputtering Arkansas offense in the second half today and guided the fourth-ranked Razorbacks to a 30-6 Southwest Conference victory over Rice.

I WORRY a lot about comedy. People do such very cruel things to it. In a recent disaster called "Angela," for instance, the evening had scarcely begun when Geraldine Page, withering under a torture-chamber of a wig only her worst enemy would have imposed on her, picked up a telephone to talk to her husband, a naval officer who hasn't been home in years. She was lonesome.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 8 -- After getting off to a slow start in the first half, Kings Point bounced back to score 14 points after intermission and hand Hofstra its eighth defeat in eight games, 21-13.

In an art, a sport, or life itself, he "who never makes a commitment can't lose. . . . But he can never win." So Barnaby Cole, 15-year-old son of a bitter, alcoholic, former baseball star, learns in this low-key novel set in a Cleveland slum. During Christmas vacation week, Barnaby is deserted by his father (his mother had left five years previously) and gets a job assisting a Hungarian refugee engraver.

NEW YORK TENDABERRY: Laura Nyro. (Columbia KCS 9737). The elusive poetess, the real-life projection of man's hidden fantasies, has been with us for a long time, from Sappho to Edith Piaf. Laura Nyro is the latest.

A dramatic stretch run by Gustave Ring's Ship Leave enabled that Kentucky-bred son of Nasomo to win the $56,900 Roamer Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday in the track-record time of 1:54 4/5. Competing against seven rivals in the 1 3/16-mile contest for 3-year-olds, Ship Leave scored by a neck over the favored Hydrologist, with Neil Hellman's Gleaming Light next.

The police said yesterday that an incendiary device that caused minor damage Friday night in a Bronx store and two other devices discovered before they ignited in a neighboring department store were very much like those that caused damage to merchandise in Macy's Herald Square store last month.

" The Story of Rock," by art historian Carl Belz is not the story of rock 'n' roll. Although no names have been changed to protect the innocent, and there is a crude correspondence of facts and dates to real events, this book and rock 'n' roll have but a nodding acquaintance.

The rich heritage of Russian folk tales has provided inspiration for some of Russia's greatest writers. According to James Reeves, who has translated THE GOLDEN COCKEREL and Other Stories (Watts, $4.95) by Alexander Pushkin, the poet, "bending the folk material to his own purpose," based three of the stories in this collection on tales told to him by his old nurse.
Arthur Schlesinger Jr. in his letter of Nov. 2 deals with an appeal by Acheson, Alsop, Broder and others) to temper criticism of the President at this crucial point of Vietnam negotiations.
The Justice Department has widened its attack here on the infiltration of legitimate business by members of organized crime.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A medical researcher says motorcycle makers should develop safety devices for their product.

AMMAN, Jordan -- A gloating note has been sounding in the anthems and communiques broadcast by Damascus Radio and in the resonant rhetoric of Syria's leaders. One of them, known as "Comrade Malik," said recently with satisfaction that "events have shown that we are serving our cause well."
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8 -- The Giants get one of their last chances to turn the season round tomorrow afternoon when they face the Cardinals at Busch Stadium at 4 P.M. (New York time).

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Bob Anderson, a tailback, sped 12 yards for a touchdown with less than three minutes to play today and led Colorado to a 17-14 victory over Kansas in a Big Eight Conference game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Georgetown halted Fordham's unbeaten streak at 12 today with a 14-7 victory before a rain-soaked crowd of 1,100.
Sooner or later, American consumers will pay more for a carving knife, an airline ticket and a variety of other products and services because of a severe shortage of nickel.

The Water Transport Association, which is a persistently frustrated courtier in seeking joint rail-water cargo rates with its railway competitors, would like to see the Interstate Commerce Commission bring the barge men and railroads together "by diplomatically knocking heads."

The election returns in New York City and elsewhere across the nation last week showed that the urban centers remain, in considerable measure, islands of liberalism amid a generally rising tide of moderate conservatism. There was less polarization between the races within the cities than there was between local and state levels of government. The structural polarization forecasts a mighty political struggle.

WASHINGTON -- Every year the lands, crops and foliage of the United States are doused with 800 million pounds of synthetic organic pesticides. If this annual national "consumption" were distributed evenly -- which it is not -- the total would amount to 220 pounds per square mile of territory, including city and country, lakes and rivers.
FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 8 -- California Democrats, facing an acknowledged crisis, began charting a program here today for the "survival of the party."

As a former student of Miss Constance Welch, I am angered by Stacy Keach's implication in Patricia Bosworth's recent article, that Miss Welch "flunked" him because of her inability to teach acting or to recognize talent. Miss Welch, like any self-respecting teacher in an academic situation, would have little choice but to fail a student who took it upon himself to assume her duties as teacher, thereby absenting himself from the school's curriculum.

JERUSALEM, Sunday, Nov. 9 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said yesterday that recent Egyptian commando raids across the Suez Canal were having no bearing on the wider strategic situation along the active front line.
BATON ROUGE, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Louisiana State, led by Allen Shorey's two touchdowns, beat Alabama, 20-25, today for its first victory over the Crimson Tide since 1958.

TUNIS, Nov. 8 -- A wider use of all available contraceptives to meet the rapid increase in world population was urged this week at the meeting of the International Planned Parenthood Federation being held this year in Gammarth.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 8 -- Wesleyan University, faced with growing tension over the suspension of a Negro student, obtained a court order today restraining an all-black campus group from disrupting "athletic, social or academic events" -- including this afternoon's homecoming football game with Williams.

SIXTEEN years ago a composer and a cosmologist met at a party in New York. Subsequently, when both men were living on the West Coast, they became such good friends that the cosmologist suggested he write an opera libretto for the composer.
I read with great interest -- I'm Spanish -- the article published in your Magazine, "What Spaniards Say When They Think Aloud" (Sept. 28).

SYRACUSE, Nov. 8 -- For the third time this season, Syracuse took the opening kickoff of a game and launched a scoring drive before the opponent had a chance to attack. Today's long march was the only one of the three drives that meant the difference, as Syracuse went on through the mud and rain at Archbold Stadium to beat Arizona, 23-0, before 24,346.

SIEGFRIED LANDAU, conductor of the Brooklyn Philharmonia, comes from a family of rabbis and musicians. Although Landau has chosen music as his career, there is much of the rabbi left in him. The stern voice of Duty, a knowledge of the Truth, and a sense of authority as he pursues his goals, account in great measure for his success.
NEW DELHI -- "We have no power anymore, so we have nothing to lose."

Herman Badillo announced yesterday that he would join a major law firm as a partner when he completed his term as Bronx Borough President at the end of this year, but he said he was not "retiring from public life."

CHICAGO -- The morning after Bobby G. Seale was convicted of contempt of court last week, a new figure rose to carry on the Government's case against the remaining seven defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial.

For young readers the most distinguished brief account to date of the campaign that led to American victory at Yorktown is easily Burke Davis's YORKTOWN (Harper Row, $3.95). It is a sound, graceful narrative of a complex and brilliant campaign.

JACK GOULD'S column of October 12, "Will We All Have to Listen to Big Brother?," is a valuable addition to public debate on the issue of escalating costs of radio and television time for political candidates.

Little reviewed but very popular in England, this novel of Dublin in 1907-1914 is an example of the gap that sometimes exists between the books that get the fanfare and the books people read. Although reviewers usually are not sympathetic to old-fashioned ideas (i.e., sentiment, conformity or the notion of an ideal order behind the appearance of things), many more of the reading public are than one would guess from headlined titles only.

THE first half of the $1,000,000 mail-bid floor auction listed by Harmer, Rooke Numismatists, Ltd., of this city, will take place at the Park Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 56th Street, Nov. 17-22.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. -- As society has grown bigger and more complicated, so too has the executive apparatus surrounding the President. And as the agencies of Government have proliferated, so has the President found them increasingly difficult to manage.

Now that the dust has settled at City Hall, three general conclusions emerge from this book: that Norman Mailer is a good idea man; that Jimmy Breslin, the ex-columnist, should run for office again; and that their proposals for saving New York City from smog, crime, poverty and traffic jams have much to recommend them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A battle between Representatives from New York and New Jersey over the site of a fourth jet airport in the metropolitan area broke out on the House floor this week, and New Jersey won.

LINCOLN, Neb. -- Unlikely as it may seem to travelers who remember Nebraska as a long, flat expanse of prairies, the state has become a water playground. A chain of more than 50 crystal-clear lakes with white, sandy beaches now stretches across much of the state, and there are more to come.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A group of prominent civic and religious leaders, educators, and political figures has endorsed a planned series of "town meetings" across the country next month to discuss military spending.

This is a fascinating book. It takes us from the ordinary experience of a thrown ball curving back to earth to the more stellar performance of planetary satellites. This is accomplished by a route through astronomical observation and theory, an examination of ellipses and conic sections, Galileo's experiments with rolling spheres and pendulums, angular momentum, a discussion of tides, and Einstein's space-time continuum.

Most of the current crop of children's cookbooks are for the sophisticated young teen-ager past the fudge and popcorn stage and ready to take up the spoon for serious food preparation and meal planning. He or she will be happy to find a leavening of interesting geographical and historical culinary facts in many of these books.
EUGENE, Ore., Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Arden Jensen kicked a 43-yard field goal with eight seconds to play today to give Army a 17-17 tie with Oregon in the first football game between the two institutions.

AUSTIN, Tex. Nov. 8 -- Second-ranked Texas, shaking off an epidemic of 24-hour virus, relied on Bobby Callison and a cast of other substitutes to crush Baylor, 56-14, today for its 16th straight victory.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- The authorities today were investigating break-ins at six Boston draft offices last night in which almost 100,000 draft board records were scattered about, mutilated or covered with paint, ink and liquid soap.

" . . . I suppose in 'The Inn' I go to the point more directly and simply, by trying to express sensibly what I consider to be the essence," Turgenev said of his novella. It is indeed a living picture of Russian country life a hundred years ago, but more than that a devastating attack on the institution of serfdom.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- If you must be infected with germs that cause pneumonia, the best time to get them is 4 A.M. if you are a mouse.

THERE will be a concert of music by Kurt Weill tonight in Philharmonic Hall. Lotte Lenya will appear in it, as well she should. She is the composer's widow, and she also created the role of Jenny in the original Berlin production of "Die Dreigroschenoper" -- "The Threepenny Opera" -- in 1928.
We, too, were thrilled with the Sept. 21 article about the Laura Ingalls Wilder books. It is one more memento to add to those I am accumulating about the "Little House" books.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8 -- All week the weather had been bleak, and when the radical students pushed into the narrow street that passes a dingy row of buildings called the Instrumentation Laboratories a cold rain was falling.

" Ivanko and the Dragon," a Ukranian folk tale, is a good yarn -- which is the main reason why it, and all good folk tales, survived long enough to reach the printed page. It is superbly translated by Marie Halun Bloch and enhanced by Yaroslava's crisp decorative illustrations which express its spirit completely.

Jean Giraudoux once regretted wistfully that Germans insisted upon coming to France all at once and on foot instead of one by one in the train. At about the same time, Gen. Ludwig Beck, chief of the German General Staff, was breaking with Hitler over the risk of war with France, whose army he described in 1938 as "the most powerful in Europe."
Anti-spray laws are becoming a fashion. The idea has even penetrated the Department of Agriculture, which drew up a model spray ordinance for optional use in counties of Virginia.

I USED to dig potatoes -- by hand. It was rough work, the kind that makes you wish you had a machine that could do the job quicker and easier. I suspect that if I were still a potato digger back in New Zealand, I'd be trying to develop an even quicker potato digger.

More and more slum residents, almost all of them black or Puerto Rican, are exercising a power they have not had for long: the ability to block an urban renewal project in their neighborhoods, or shape its direction, or get a project where there was none before.

Leading educators and corporation executives agreed last week that this country's economic, social and education issues in the nineteen-seventies will require a close partnership of business and the universities if problems are to be dealt with effectively.

TOKYO, Nov. 4 -- Yukio Mishima, Japan's brilliant and celebrated author and playwright, stood stiffly at attention on the roof of the National Theater, his slim, muscular form encased in a khaki uniform.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Ch. Dan Lee Dragonseed racked up his 29th best-in-show award at the 924-dog Mohawk Valley Kennel Club Show in the State Armory today.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 8 -- Wesleyan's football team did a big job in winning the Little Three title today. Waging an uphill struggle against Williams, the Cardinals closed with a late touchdown that proved sufficient for an 18-17 victory.

IN a recent address delivered at the regional meeting of the Association of Local Transport Airlines in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, Robert T. Murphy, a member of this country's Civil Aeronautics Board, enumerated a "Bill of Rights" for the airline passenger.
A bill to help New Yorkers who get in trouble when they buy on credit, although introduced quietly by a lame-duck City Councilman, was put at the top of the Council's action list yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 8 -- A woman who committed suicide Thursday night by walking into the Atlantic Ocean was identified today as Mrs. Susan Taubes, a Hungarian-born teacher and writer whose most recent novel was published last week.

ALBANY, Nov. 8 -- Republican party leaders, following Governor Rockefeller's lead in the aftermath of Tuesday's elections, are spreading the word that United States Senator Charles E. Goodall will "very likely" be the Governor's choice for re-election next year.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Unbeaten Southern California, leading by only seven points for most of three quarters against six-time loser Washington State, snapped on of its lethargy to whip the Cougars, 28-7, today.
MOSCOW, Nov. 8 -- Driving a car in Moscow is not a simple matter of turning the ignition key on and moving off.

MULDRAUGH, Ky., Nov. 8 -- When they signed the one-year lease last July, H. H. Basham, the 81-year-old Kentucky land owner who is reputed to hold title to most of this one-square-mile civilian enclave in the middle of Fort Knox, said he thought he was renting an old clapboard house on main street to a bunch of clean-cut kids for a G.I. "ice cream parlor."

The U. S. Navy doesn't need a whole fleet in the Mediterranean. All it needs is a 70-foot motorized barge -- LCU-1124 -- commanded by a resourceful boatswain's Mate First Class like Fatso Gioninni. With Fatso on the high seas, the Soviet fleet is in serious trouble and the Egyptians (this is during the Six Day War) learn that it is best to stay in port.

Kilimanjaro Mills, a new company owned by Negroes, announced recently that it would establish a coffee roasting plant on part of the site of the former Brooklyn Navy Yard. The plant, which will specialize in roasting coffee from Tanzania, is expected to begin operations early next year.

John Fowles has always hankered for exile. His chief discovery of the last five years is that "if you're English and you want to go into exile then you live in England. There's nowhere you can feel more alienated from your fellow human beings.

The marching band, brassy and brisk whether or not it is led by an amazing baton-twirler of either sex, is an essential feature of major college football. Its pregame entrance and halftime maneuvers represent a distinctive, indigenous American pop art form.
TWO ABSTRACT artists who won international recognition in the late 1950's and who, in varying degree, have continued to maintain their reputations have been currently exhibiting in New York.

In essence this book is about ecology, the science concerned with the relations between living beings and their environment, from lowest organisms to highest. John and Mildred Teal link their study of salt marshes to conservation, sociology, over-all planning and population growth.

Arthur F. Burns, the economist who is President Nixon's designate for the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve Board, and Joseph Wood Krutch, the writer and conservationist, were named yesterday as recipients of the 1969 Alexander Hamilton Medals, the highest awards of the Association of the Alumni of Columbia College.

Scandinavian Airlines, which opened the first commercial Polar-route service between the West Coast and Europe on Nov. 15, 1954, will celebrate the 15th anniversary in Los Angeles Tuesday through Thursday.

Gary Danback became the Hudson County career scoring champion yesterday as he led Bayonne to a 35-2 victory over Dickinson at Roosevelt Stadium, Jersey City. Bayonne won-lost record is 6-1, Dickinson's is 2-4.
WE TEND to forget the extent to which the careers of certain modern artists have been affected by the violent vicissitudes of modern politics. Consider the case of Kandinsky.

WASHINGTON -- For one of the world's greatest playwrights, Eugene O'Neill has a most disconcerting track record. He wrote three blazingly great plays -- which gave his career its unexpectedly golden and fervent finish -- any number of indifferent or even bad plays, but remarkably few plays that were merely yet satisfyingly good.

In this clutch of recent poetry books for children, traditional subjects are much in evidence and most of the poems are competently constructed. Apprentice Leonard Cohens will go a-glimmering elsewhere, but several of these new volumes with their focus on seasons, sounds and rites of passage will beguile briefly.
EVERY few light years, when the moon is green and the wind seems to be blowing just the right number of knots from the west, someone comes along in the world of music and makes magic happen.

Launched as "a new concept for the study of history and social studies," the Cluster Biographies series focuses on a pivoted historical event, from several vantage points. The series published by McGraw-Hill, is under the Consulting Editorship of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Adams Brown, experienced teachers and historians.

Jay Haley is evidently a "cowboy" therapist: relaxed, happy, competent, brave, and willing for his patients to feel the same way whenever it suits them. He is also one of the few people on Earth who understands Martian.

The time is the War Between the States. Union Lieut. Marcus Catto leads his platoon on a patrol to flush out the enemy. A Reb flushes him first. Watching a vast cloud of pigeons darkening the sky, Catto tardily notices a ragged youngster pointing (it occurs to him fleetingly) a stick in his direction.

MANILA, Nov. 8 -- Officials and private civic action groups are engaged in the biggest effort ever made in the Philippines to insure that voting is fair and tranquil in the presidential and congressional elections next Tuesday.

POST-MORTEM recriminations between partners are often the result of a misfit: the declarer who has struggled unavailingly in a hopelessly optimistic doubled contract and suffered a heavy penalty usually finds fault with his partner's bidding.

" Not Like Niggers" is the story of a young black child growing up in the South during the Depression. His mother's over-riding concern is that her children grow up to be "not like niggers." It is an engrossing story, well-written and accurate in every nuance in its portrayal of the black community.

In these times of conglomeration -- of takeovers of small prestigious publishing companies by large, "diversified" corporations -- it is pleasant to report a kind of mini-merger, the purchase of the Liveright publishing company by Gilbert Harrison, the editor of the New Republic. Liveright is an almost legendary name on the American publishing scene. Horace Liveright, the founder, was a colorful figure of the twenties -- and, a great publisher.

IN one way, this week's election makes very little difference to New York. Every administration becomes the creature of its bureaucracy. Mayors come and go and the municipal machinery -- timeless, civil-serviced, pensioned -- grinds on, reducing progress to a pulp.
George H. Copeland's article about the Coolidge shrine in Plymouth, Vt., (Oct. 12) is doubly interesting to me, since I visited it only a month ago while on a tour of historic spots in New England.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Soviet Union has informed the United States that Vladimir S. Semyonov, a Deputy Foreign Minister, will lead Moscow's delegation in the preliminary discussions on limiting strategic arms, scheduled to begin Nov. 17 in Helsinki, Finland.
IT has been six years since Snowman, the legendary jumper, has competed in a horse show. But he has not been forgotten.

In view of the trend in children's books these days, I wouldn't have been surprised to run across a "Campus Riot Coloring Book," or a "Let's Go on a B-52 Bombing Raid." After all, once upon a time we kids were brought up on tales with such violent and unacceptable behavior as kidnapping, poisoning, plank-walking -- even a brother and sister who shoved an old lady into an oven to burn alive.

Ramapo's hope for a championship in its second year of Public Schools Athletic League play was all but buried in the mud yesterday as Suffern drove to a 12-0 victory. Ramapo's second defeat in six games shoved the Griffins a game back of front-running Nyack, a 39-14 winner over Pearl River.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 8 -- A young University of Miami professor was explaining recently at the Institute of Marine Sciences a series of complex formulas for calculating catch rates of fish.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire accused the Pentagon today of announcing misleading budget reductions while laying the basis for vast spending increases in the next few years.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 8 -- Amherst trounced Trinity, 35-7, today through the accurate passing of John Kehoe and the running of Jeff Morray.
PARIS -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation hopes to become overnight one of the two or three biggest electrical equipment manufacturers of Europe.
Time is running out on the mainspring.

A QUESTION frequently asked is, "What should I look for when I buy a puppy?" John H. Cook of Bordentown, N. J., well-known judge, club member and former exhibitor, tried to answer fanciers at a meeting of the Knickerbocker Dachshund Club last Wednesday at the Building for Brotherhood, 32 West 57th Street.

Retailers are about ready to begin their major effort to achieve the best possible results for the Christmas season, their busiest time of the year. All their forces will be concentrated on window and indoor displays and attractive presentation of a wide variety of merchandise.

Three Westchester teams concluded unbeaten and untied seasons, yesterday, when Horace Greeley of Chappaqua defeated Fox Lane at Bedford Village, 24-14; Scarsdale trimmed Lakeland at Shrub Oak, 14-0, and Somers set back Mahopac, 22-6.

IT IS probably not an original notion that troubadours were the hippies of medieval times. They wandered from place to place, singing songs that were didactic and satirical, that dealt with love, fortune, morals and nature. A sampling of the poems that are in the collection known as "Carmina Burana," reads like a transmutation of the sentiments to be found in some of today's "rock" lyrics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- After three years of sour relations, a distinct improvement in political ties between Communist China and North Korea has taken place in the last month, according to official analysts here.

NEW DELHI -- The tour buses do not normally make a stop at India's National Museum, nor will the guide direct your private sightseeing car to the museum. The guides and drivers are too intent on showing off India's government buildings, fine demonstrations of the British Raj school of official redstone architecture, and the shrines and old forts.

Its readability as well as its packaging clearly indicate it is designed to be read by "ordinary" people, not just statesmen, scholars, or experts.

In an era when youthful distrust of adults is rampant, Miss Fox remains true to the concept that children need adults if they are to grow though they must be fulfilled themselves and accept young people as individuals, not as pawns to be manipulated.

The man from the White House came into New York on Tuesday with a briefcase full of computer print-outs on past city elections. He worked through the night, pushing stacks of returns onto the floor as he plotted jagged lines on graph paper. By 7 A.M. he was on the air shuttle back to Washington and by 9 A.M. a report on the election's national significance was ready for President Nixon.

Jerome Rose believes in himself, obviously, and that is half of any success. This season the gifted young pianist is giving three recitals at Alice Tully Hall, devoted to Beethoven, Schumann and Brahms, respectively. Last night was Schumann's turn, and Mr. Rose took on three of that composer's most problematical works: the "Humoresque" (Op. 20), the Sonata No. 3 in F (Op. 14) and the Davidsbundlertanze" (Op. 6).

As the United States has an uncommonly vital and productive choral singing tradition, it may seem odd that a relatively conventional amateur chorus from another country would be brought to tour here. But it is always nice to know how things are done elsewhere.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 9 -- The coalition Government of Premier Per Borten, re-elected in September with a reduced two-seat majority over the Labor Opposition, is facing delicate political decisions over quickening moves for Scandinavian economic integration.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- With Wilt Chamberlain conspicuous by his absence, the New York Knickerbockers made the most of the opportunity to down the Los Angeles Lakers, 112-102, tonight before a crowd of 12,583 at the Forum.

The Indo-American Dance Company is a group of young Americans trained surprisingly well in Hindu dance styles that is trying to do something quite new under the leadership of Matteo, the well-known ethnic dancer and teacher.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Rolling Stones, the British singing group, started their American tour near here last night with a concert that ended early this morning.
The outlook for the bond market, which thrust upward for most of October and then in the last two weeks or so lost most -- if not all -- of its gains, seems even more clouded than usual.

Billy Steinkraus, the outstanding horseman who won the gold medal for the United States in the 1968 Olympics at Mexico City, put the emphasis on speed at the National Horse Show last night to win the Royal Winter Fair Trophy international jumping class.

Hours past a strike deadline, efforts continued early this morning to avert a walking out by 4,300 milk plant workers and drivers that would halt deliveries in the metropolitan area.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (UPI) -Industry shipments of all electrical products will rise to a record $44.7-billion this year from $41.55-billion in 1968, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association predicted today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -The Securities and Exchange Commission took steps today to clarify its position concerning the obligations of mutualfund managers to return to their shareholders the benefits they are able to reap from certain money-saving ways of handling securities transactions for the funds.

Explosive devices went off in three major office buildings in midtown and downtown Manhattan early this morning.

Walter W. Heller, a former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, faulted the Nixon Administration yesterday for relying exclusively on fiscal and monetary policy in the fight against inflation and suggested that a broad spectrum of other methods be used to supplement them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- In his reluctance to make theater of the Presidency, at least in his first few months in office, Richard Nixon had placed himself in camp with that other antihero of contemporary politics, Eugene McCarthy.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 -- The $150,000 Washington D.C. International, one of the leading thoroughbred races in the world, will have its 18th running tomorrow, with a field of seven competing.
The Armstrong Cork Company announced price increases yesterday on most lines of asphalt, vinyl asbestos and vinyl floor tile, effective Jan. 1.
The World Publishing Company has named Leonard R. Harris executive vice president and publisher, completing a sweeping overhaul of its top editorial team. He will assume the post next Monday.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 10 -- Premier Golda Meir read the appeal of Georgian Jews on television tonight. She described it as "a sincere and heartfelt cry of distress" from Jews seeking to come to Israel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 10 -- The five Central American foreign ministers, meeting as a group for the first time since the war between Honduras and El Salvador in July, have agreed to try to save the region's Common Market through peacemaking in the area.
HARTFORD, Nov. 10 -- It took just 23 minutes for stockholders to vote approval of the largest merger in corporate history here today.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- A 14-year-old boy, holding a young woman hostage at the point of a butcher knife, attempted to hijack a Delta Airlines passenger jet today but surrendered before the plane took off from Greater Cincinnati Airport.

TORONTO, Nov. 10 -- In a front-page dispatch, The Toronto Telegram said Aaron Einfrank had "aroused the ire of Soviet officials with his reports on the Kremlin's policy toward Czechoslovakia, which he described as a 'colony' of the Soviet Union," by articles emphasizing "a severe economic crisis" and by dispatches "on the jailing of dissident intellectuals."

TORONTO, Nov. 10 -- Representatives of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and the United Steelworkers of America initiated a new collective bargaining agreement today, exactly four months after 17,500 union members struck the company's Ontario mines and mills.

SAN DIEGO, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Sid Gillman, the only head coach the San Diego Chargers had ever had since the club was started in Los Angeles in 1960, resigned tonight and was replaced by Charlie Waller, offensive backfield coach.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- An instrument used by eye doctors to diagnose one disease accidentally caused a small outbreak of another illness in an unusual episode a year ago, three New York City Health Department doctors reported here today at the 97th annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.

Bill Boland, who turned trainer following the recent summer meeting at Saratoga after a notable career as a jockey, saddled his first stakes winner at Aqueduct yesterday. The occasion was the 48th running of the Demoiselle Stakes, a $28,700 mile event for 2-year-old fillies in which Hardly Able Stables' Native Fern defeated Harry Gordon's Luci Tee by a head after a stretch drive that left most of the 25,378 damp spectators agog.
HONOLULU, Nov. 10 (UPI) -For Bruce Crampton, it ended four years of frustration. For Jack Nicklaus, it was a disappointing finish in his quest to become golfdom's second million -dollar winner.

THE Oakland-Kansas City contention in the western half of the American League is the only bona fide race remaining in pro football's six divisions. The National League's four division winners have been largely determined -- Rams, Vikings, Cowboys, Browns -- while the Jets are home free in the A.F.L.'s Eastern Division.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. Nov. 10, (AP) -- A tiny television camera worn like a miner's headlamp to give sight to the blind should be ready for testing on human beings in three to four years, an eye research scientist says.

Officials of the city's Department of Social Services disclosed yesterday that they had decided to require narcotics addicts to become affiliated with a rehabilitative program before they will be accepted for welfare assistance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court affirmed today an Interstate Commerce Commission settlement of at long controversy among railroads over the charges they pay for using one another's freight cars.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended slightly lower yesterday in moderately active trading.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Jean Beliveau scored twice within 48 seconds tonight as the Montreal Canadiens put in four first-period goals and beat the Los Angeles Kings, 6-3.
Robert I. Lauter, senior vice president for merchandising at Macy's New York, will become president of W. J. Sloane, New York, a 10-store division of W. J. Sloane. Inc., effective Dec. 1.

ATHENS, Nov. 10 -- Thirty-one Greek politicians, in a joint declaration today, hailed a resolution of the NATO parliamentary assembly denouncing the Greek military regime and calling for the restoration of democracy in Greece.

BUFFALO, Nov. 10 -- Ten plainclothes policemen were called to the State University campus here this afternoon as a precautionary measure during a demonstration of 200 studens who were supporting demands for the admission of more Negroes and Puerto Ricans to the university's Medical School.

Leo A. Larkin testified yesterday that when he was the city's Corporation Counsel in January, 1964, Roy M. Cohn informed him about the alleged bribery of a city appraiser.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Prince Philip's casual remarks on American television about royal poverty and the possible abdication of Queen Elizabeth II produced an excited reaction here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The Senate rejected a $100-million cut in space funds today after Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, said it was worth a thousand times that to watch two Americans -- not Russians -- land on the moon.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A St Louis University doctor says that the drinking of liquor retards production of a hormone that the body needs for chemical and emotional balance, while smoking stimulates production.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- A ninestory scaffolding collapsed in Westminster today, killing Sir David Rose, Governor-General of Guyana. He was 46 years old and was scheduled to relinquish his post next February when Guyana becomes a republic.
MEMPHIS, Nov. 10 -- The police used tear gas tonight to disperse 400 black youths who hurled bricks and bottles at patrolmen armed with riot guns.
Corporate bond prices declined yesterday, sharply in some cases, as this sector of the credit markets reacted to the substantial supply of unsold securities left over from last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Nixon signed a bill today that would authorize the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare to ban sales of toys and other articles for children that present electrical, mechanical or heat hazards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Analysts here believe that the North Korean Government of Premier Kim Il Sung has shifted emphasis from military back to political tactics in its continuing attempt to undermine the South Korean Government and gain control of the entire peninsula.

The official recanvass by the Board of Elections of votingmachine tabulations confirmed for all practical purposes yesterday the re-election of A. Joseph Ribustello, RepublicanConservative, as Councilman at Large in the Bronx.
BUFFALO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A Federal judge gave maximum three-year prison terms today to two men convicted of interfering with law enforcement officers trying to arrest two draft resisters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee gave its unanimous support today to the Nixon Administration's draft lottery legislation, but there was still no assurance that the measure would be enacted.

This extraordinary feat assumes staggering proportions as the football year progresses because no other team has come close to mounting the slightest challenge to the powerhouse from the North. Once again soybean oil made a string of new life-of-contract highs yesterday, under the influence of strong export demand. The oil is used widely abroad in food products as well as domestically.

A 10-car, city-bound Penn Central train carrying fewer than 50 passengers ran off the Harlem Division tracks just north of Chappaqua in Westchester County yesterday afternoon, blocking through service on the line.

New York University's soccer team, which lost three of four games before winning its next eight, gained one of the four New York State playoff berths in the National Collegiate Athletic Association regional championships.

Princeton's chances for the Ivy League football title faded considerably yesterday when Brian McCullough, the Tigers' star halfback, underwent surgery for a shoulder separation at St. Peter's Hospital in New Brunswick, N. J. The Tigers have two games remaining, against Yale and Dartmouth, the team favored to win the crown.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A Federal judge struck down a local law today that prohibited doctors from performing abortions except when the expectant mother's health or life was in danger.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- One of every ten automobile parts tested for compliance with Federal safety standards has failed, the National Safety Bureau reported today. The bureau released its first compilation of 7,644 test results in carrying out a new policy of disclosing both the over-all figures and texts of individual test reports.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Most employes of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation went to their jobs under a contract extension today, but violence marked a walkout at a plant in Columbus. Ohio. where 4,000 workers struck over a local issue.

VIGAN, the Philippines, Nov. 8 -- The intensity of Filipino election campaigns --- traditionally marked by killings, intimidation, vote-buying and falsified poll results -- has been vividly dramatized this year by conditions here in the province of Ilocos Sur.

As if being the most statistically powerful team in the American Football League weren't enough, the Kansas City Chiefs will regain one of their most dangerous offensive weapons, Otis Taylor, for Sunday's showdown with the New York Jets at Shea Stadium.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I. Nov. 10 -- Assemblyman Charles D. Henderson, the chairman of the Temporary State Commission on Campus Unrest, said today that the colleges and universities in the state should be given a chance to deal with student dissent by themselves without further action by the Legislature.

Thalassa Cruso, the classically named lady whose television lectures on gardening have caused a thousand flowers to bloom, may be responsible for a new indoor sport in America. Armed with her book, unnumbered apartment dwellers may now switch from Monopoly and mah-jongg to coaxing a begonia into flower and foliage or to setting up a hanging garden of magenta lantana.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 10 -- A spokesman of the Foreign Ministry said today that South Korean Ambassadors in Washington and London had been instructed to protest the publication of full-page advertisements for a biography of the North Korean Premier, Kim II Sung, recently in The New York Times and The Times of London.

A beautifully balanced program, warmly played, was offered by Donald Anderson, cellist, at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Both Mr. Anderson and his pianist-collaborator, Lawrence Smith, have the solidest sort of professional foundation.

Harry L. Riley has been elected vice president and general manager of the biscuit division and Samuel J. Hamshaw vice president and controller of Sunshine Biscuits, Inc. Both have also been elected directors of the company.

IN Benjamin Harkarvy's "La Favorita", which had its first performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night, the Harkness Ballet has gotten itself a useful work that shows off the company to no little advantage.
SINCE the recent acknowledgment that hunger and malnutrition exist in the United States, food companies and nutritionists have been widening their efforts to solve the problem.

Henry Fried, 70 - year - old Mount Kisco contractor indicted on a charge of conspiracy to bribe former City Water Commissioner James L. Marcus and extort contracts from the Consolidated Edison Company, obtained severance of his trial yesterday because of illness.

A guided tour of the new Juilliard School combined with a wine-tasting party and an organ recital will be held at Lincoln Center on Nov. 28 to raise money for the Women's Architectural Auxiliary scholarship fund and to honor the school's three principal designers: Pietro Belluschi, Eduardo Catalano and Helge Westermann.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Nixon Administration plans to enter into the talks with the Soviet Union on strategic arms next Monday with no specific proposals, but it will be prepared to explore such steps as a moratorium on the testing of multiple warheads for offensive missiles.

NO, Coach Emile Francis does not make Ed Giacomin write "I must not give up a goal" 50 times after a score. But after each game in which an opponent puts one past the Ranger goalie, Giacomin writes it down -who scored, where the shot came from, how the shot beat him.
OMAHA, Nov. 10 (AP) -- About 65 black students were arrested today after they had staged a 90-minute sit-in in the president's office at the University of Nebraska.

Two high-ranking officials of the Johnson Administration agreed yesterday with President Nixon's program to fight inflation, but they suggested voluntary price-andwage guidelines would bolster the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The National Association of Blue Shield Plans said today that a sample study seemed to refute allegations that Blue Shield had allowed physicians higher fees under Medicare and Medicaid than under private plans.

OFFICIALLY, the building at 720 West End Avenue is the Salvation Army Residence for Senior Citizens, where 250 men and women over 60 years of age live. But, for the time being, it's home for a ballet school, too.

THE biggest surprise in the history of world championship bridge was the success of the Nationalist China team in the 1969 Bermuda Bowl contest in Rio de Janeiro. The Chinese lost to the great Italian team in the final, following a qualifying stage in which they had ousted two of the world's strongest teams, representing France and the United States.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A band of American Negroes who call themselves Hebrew Israelites can stay in their wilderness camp in Liberia despite an earlier deportation threat, officials said today.

The Connecticut Development Commission, looking at the controversial idea of a highway bridge across Long Island Sound from the viewpoint of the state's economic interest, has recommended better interstate ferry service instead -- perhaps using fast aircushion craft that skim the surface.

Gus Mauch, trainer of the New York Mets from their very first day in St. Petersburg, Fla., in 1962, has retired, the Mets announced yesterday. His place will be taken by Tom McKenna, trainer of the Washington Senators since 1961, part of that time under Manager Gil Hodges.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 11 -- Prime Minister John Gorton announced tonight a new coalition Government, including a lesser post for the man who had sought to supplant him as Liberal party leader.
Negotiations between the Metropolitan Opera Association and its orchestra recessed late yesterday without any substantial progress toward an agreement.

PARIS -- Farmers have an extraordinary and malign influence on foreign policy and once more it looks as if their problems, in France, are going to hang up British ambitions to join a European Common Market already glutted with farm overproduction.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Nov. 11 -- Despite eating Brad Park's cooking, Billy Fairbairn has made it -- and big -- with the Rangers. The 22-year-old rookie with the longest sideburns on the New Yorkers is sort of surprised he's here.

Loew's Theatres, Inc., reported the highest gross revenues and earnings in its history yesterday for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31. The results, unlike the previous year's, included Lorillard, which the company acquired in November, 1968.

" TANZANITE," said Henry B. Platt, a vice president of Tiffany's, head of its diamond department and a great-great-grandson of the store's founder, "is the first transparent deep blue gemstone to be discovered in more than 2,000 years."

Argentina's anthem rang in Madison Square Garden last night to signal a victory for the country's equestrian team achieved by Dr. Hugo Arrambide and Adaggio in the international jumping of the National Horse Show.

The virtuoso chamber orchestra is a relatively scarce breed, epitomized by such groups as I Musici and the Virtuosi di Roma. Not only is the idea of virtuoso chamber music almost a contradiction in itself, but the repertory tends to be fairly standardized, running heavily to Vivaldi, Manfredini and lesser lights of the Italian Baroque.

MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 12 -- Incomplete but seemingly conclusive unofficial returns this morning gave President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his Nationalist party what appeared to be a winning lead in yesterday's elections for the Presidency and Congress.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11 -- The New Orleans Steamship Association will appeal a Federal District Court decision that longshoremen in New Orleans cannot be forced to load the ship Acadia Forest.

CARTAVIO, Peru, Nov. 5 -- Agrarian reform came five months ago to Cartavio, a small company town in the middle of 19,000 acres of sugar cane. Since that first step in Peru's agrarian-reform program, very little has changed here except the boss.

High above Harlem yesterday, in the newly refurbished office building that was once the Theresa Hotel, 150 people -- black and white -- spent the day talking about "meaningful change for black people."

HELSINKI, Finland -- The Leningrad market, with its 4 million consumers, is being offered as a little icing on the cake in a quickening Finnish drive to attract more foreign investment from the West.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- France gave a strong boost to Western European scientific cooperation by announcing today her agreement to contribute enough to complete construction of a 300-billion-electron-volt atom smasher.

Fewer than half of those eligible to vote participated in last week's mayoral election in New York City. Fewer than half of that half succeeded in electing Mayor Lindsay to a second term. The Stauffer Chemical Company said yesterday that it planned to put up a headquarters building in Westport, Conn., and move from the eight floors of office space it has been renting here at 299 Park Avenue.
For five years, young Sam Shepard -- he just turned 26, and got married -- has been the most prolific and prominent playwright in the underground theater.
