CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 11 -- The countdown for Apollo 12, the nation's second moon-landing flight, continued to run smoothly today toward a scheduled lift-off Friday morning.
Futures prices for eggs and pork bellies, from which bacon is cut, rose to new life-of-contract highs in busy trading yesterday. Eggs reached the highest level in 18 years.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Wheatley Stable's 3-year-old King Emperor, injured late in his 2-year-old campaign and again this spring, won the $28,000 Quaker City Handicap by a neck at Garden State Park today.
Homeward-bound commuters on the Port Washington branch of the Long Island Rail Road were delayed for up to an hour last night as the result of a flash electrical fire.
A Federal judge severely criticized the Government yesterday for having seized $5million in securities held here for a Hong Kong brokerage house.
Council President Francis X. Smith lost 3,214 votes of his unofficial election night Bronx majority of 14,522 votes as the final Board of Elections recanvass was virtually completed there yesterday.
Half the white Protestant ministers in the country earn less than $8,037, according to a study released yesterday by the National Council of Churches.
The Government rested its case yesterday after it had presented 18 witnesses to support its charges of mail fraud, conspiracy and perjury against Salvatore Bonanno and Peter Notaro.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Government troops reported killing 126 enemy soldiers in two battles yesterday.

An airborne oil tanker? It may sound far out, but the Coast Guard has already begun testing a prototype rubber-coated bladder that can be carried collapsed in a plane, parachuted alongside a tanker leaking oil, and inflated to form a 140foot container into which 140,000 gallons of oil can be pumped to prevent the pollution of the sea and shoreline.

IN JAMES BARRIE'S "Peter Pan," Wendy Darling left her Newfoundland to fly to Neverland. Another Wendy -Mrs. Wendy Whiteley -- flew from her native England to California. But she took her six Yorkshire terriers with her.

PISCATAWAY, N. J. -- Although Robert M. Smith 3d is a passionate hunter and angler and spends most weekends and holidays with a gun or a rod and reel, one of the outings he remembers most vividly was a rattlesnake chase in Texas.

The Metropolitan Golf Association has momentarily saved its amateur match-play championship from going into oblivion. Members of the organization's executive committee said yesterday they had failed to acquiesce to recommendations that the tourney, a fixture at match play since 1897, be turned into a stroke-play competition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A blue-ribbon commission, appointed by President Johnson, challenged today the assumption that work was the answer to poverty and urged a universal income supplement based solely on need.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Nationwide crop prospects held unchanged during October for the second straight month, leaving the prospective 1969 harvest at the record level estimated Sept. 1, the Agriculture Department said today.
In 1966 there were six Negro principals in the city's public schools.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The space flight effects that probably killed the monkey, Bonny, in July appear to have also been experienced by men in space, a scientist said today.

NEWPORT, Wales, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Newport handed the South African Rugby Union Springboks the second defeat of their British tour today. The score was 11-6, but the match again provoked anti-apartheid demonstrations by protesters outside the ground.
IT'S usually a pretty safe bet. You search the list of corporations for take-over candidates and buy them on the theory that takeovers usually bring a premium.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The Scientology cult went to court today in a fight to take over Britain's National Association for Mental Health, a respected volunteer organization that disseminates information about mental illness and strives to improve treatment facilities.
Against odds of perhaps a million-to-one, a husband and wife were seated next to each other in a jury impaneled yesterday to try a robbery case in State Supreme Court, 100 Centre Street.

BYZANTIUM lives, and has been ensconced inside a long, narrow, blue, white and gold shop that opened today at 124 East 57th Street. The store is a branch of Fortunoff's, a sprawling home furnishings and accessories emporium in Westbury, L. I. Unlike the Westbury store, however, this "posh pipe rack operation" -- as the co-owner styles it -- is an outlet only for silver holloware, flatware and jewelry.

EVERYONE involved with Johnny Carson's only special of the year, put on last night over the N. B. C. television network, should feel contrite this morning. Especially the guests: Maureen Stapleton, George C. Scott and Marian Mercer.

The Transit Authority police force reversed itself yesterday and rescinded an order that would have withheld death benefits from the widow of a 27-year-old member of the force who was shot dead by a city policeman.
The New York County American Legion said it had "about 40 or 50" men out distributing literature yesterday urging support of President Nixon's position on Vietnam.
The New York Racing Association, which supervises thoroughbred racing at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga, has undergone a changing of the chief.
The city Planning Commission approved plans yesterday for a 39-story office building with a landscaped plaza on the Avenue of the Americas between 41st and 42d Streets.

BONN, Nov. 12 -- The Government of Chancellor Willy Brandt said today that it had received assurances from the Soviet Union and the United States that overcame West German objections to signing the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 12 -- A troublesome hydrogen tank in the Apollo 12 spacecraft sent launching crews into feverish, round-the-clock operations here tonight to keep the moon mission on schedule for a Friday morning lift-off.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -One of Clement F. Haynsworth Jr.'s chief supporters predicted today that a refusal of the Senate to confirm the South Carolinian for the Supreme Court would drive him off the United States Court of Appeals as well.

LAST night I went to the penultimate performance of a ballet, "Songs of Catullus," given by the New York City Opera. I am not quite sure whether it is more presumptuous for the opera company to offer a ballet than it is for me, a ballet critic, to offer an opinion on it.

An attorney for the trustee of R. Hoe Co., a printingequipment manufacturer that has been in bankruptcy proceedings since July, said yesterday that five separate offers for parts of Hoe's operations were expected to be made today.

To the Editor: There are situations in which breaking the law is preferable to observing it. My own thanks go out to those six unfortunate individuals just indicted by District Attorney Burton Roberts for performing 6,000 abortions in Riverdale.

To question some proposals and regret the lack of others, is not to denigrate a generally constructive and imaginative report that could be a historic instrument for rejuvenating this country's relationship to Latin America and for improving that "quality of life in the Americas" that gave Mr. Rockefeller his theme.
To the Editor: If every American soldier were to leave Vietnam today, the war would not end. On the contrary, it would be prolonged, because the two sides would be more nearly equal.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -The New York City Health Department has ordered Chinese restaurants to use MSG, a flavor-enhancing chemical, sparingly when preparing food, two municipal doctors reported today.

One of the city's leading real estate men, Harry B. Helmsley, was charged yesterday by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz with joining with a bank in a "quid pro quo deal" that "deprived and defrauded" 12,000 tenants of the Parkchester apartment complex in the Bronx of interest from $1.2million in security deposits.
Three gunmen held up the crew of a Wells Fargo armored truck in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday and escaped with about $1.3-million in Aqueduct Race Track receipts.

The S.S. Manhattan, the first commercial ship to conquer the legendary Northwest Passage, sailed triumphantly into New York yesterday, to the traditional tears and cheers, along with the fireboat welcome.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Following are excerpts from the introduction and summary to the report of the President's Commission on Income Maintenance Programs released today:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -Famine is an epidemic of starvation that requires the same control methods as do epidemics of infectious diseases, a United States Public Health Service epidemiologist said here today. He applied such techniques in the Nigerian civil war.
Price advances involving metals, chemicals and traffic-signal systems were announced yesterday by manufacturers here and in Canada.
The Board of Higher Education voted last night to create a special blue ribbon citizens commission to study the entire future governmental relationships and financing of the City University.
GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- George Balanchine won an ovation from the opening-night audience at the Grand Theater last night as it presented its first program comprised exclusively of his ballets.

The National Broadcasting Company has received permission from the Federal Communications Commission to cut the volume of sound of its Apollo 12 telecast early next Wednesday morning by approximately half here and in Washington.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Two teen-age hijackers were overpowered by the pilot and co-pilot of a Chilean airliner after a mid-air fight today thwarting an attempt to fly to Cuba.
The Board of Education abruptly adjourned its public hearing last night after sitting for an hour through mounting abuse and obscenities by highschool students.
The Rangers' two top centers, the tenacious Walt Tkaczuk and the whippet-like Jean Ratelle, scored two goals apiece last night and the New Yorkers rolled to another victory.
Roy McMillan, who managed Memphis to the Texas League baseball championship last season, was named yesterday to manage the New York Mets' farm at Tidewater, Va., in the International League.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The White House was reported today to have instructed officials of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency not to appear in closed session before a Senate subcommittee that had asked for a briefing on the forthcoming arms control talks in Helsinki.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- In the Royal Ballet Choreographic Group's performance at the Collegiate Theater tonight, Ronald Hynd established himself clearly as the most promising new choreographer this workshop organization has yet produced.

Julius Rudel, general director of the New York City Opera, and George Balanchine, artistic director of the New York City Ballet, were honored yesterday for contributions in their fields by the Friends of City Center of Music and Drama. The organization was holding its annual luncheon at the WaldorfAstoria.

RICH women with signature scarves flowing from their necks. Poor women in bargain basement dresses. And a lot of women somewhere in between. They all mingled yesterday at what was dubbed a "creative confrontation" on the pros and cons of the woman volunteer.

A jury of nine women and three men was sworn in yesterday at the Federal trial of Carmine G. DeSapio, a former Tammany leader, and Anthony (Tony Ducks) Corallo on charges that they conspired to bribe a former city official and obtain contracts from the Consolidated Edison Company.
The president of the Board of Education said yesterday that pupils and teachers would be expected to attend classes as usual today and tomorrow during the second Vietnam moratorium.
THE National Broadcasting Company devoted its entire evening schedule to specials last night with rather spotty returns.
A correspondence recalling one of Eugene O'Neill's youthful romances has been acquired by the New York Public Library for $16,000.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- As the first post-censorship play to exhibit the figure of Christ on the British stage, Dennis Potter's "Son of Man" at the Round House is at least assured of a niche in our theater history. Otherwise it suggests the present incapacity of our theater to do justice to its subject.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel said today that his department was developing a new approach for long-range financing of efforts to control water pollution. Year-to-year Congressional appropriations are not adequate, he said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 --The Army has retained a 26-year-old first lieutenant on active duty for two and a half months beyond his term of service while it investigates charges that he shot "quite a number" of Vietnamese civilians.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Scansion, a 16-year-old stakes-winning mare in foal to Sir Gaylord, sold today for $27,000 at the Keeneland fall sale of thoroughbred breeding stock.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- The automobile companies reported today that their dealers sold 214,366 new American-made cars from Nov. 1 to 10, up 2 per from 209,306 a year before and the highest early November sales since 1966.

Despite accumulating evidence that the economy is slowing down, undiminished heavy demand for capital at a time of continued tight credit pushed interest rates yesterday to the highest levels in American corporate history.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The Federal Government began today to assemble 9,000 troops in the Washington area to provide security for Saturday's planned peace demonstrations.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- Workers at the struck American Motors Corporation plant at Kenosha, Wis., rejected a company proposal to end a four-week strike.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 12 -- The old-guard faction of the governing Congress party expelled Prime Minister Indira Gandhi from the party today for "grave acts of indiscipline" and directed its bloc in the Indian Parliament to elect a new leader.

The city retreated yesterday from its deadline for requiring stores to post unit prices on meat, cereal, soft drinks and other items instead of unspecific descriptions such as "giant" or "economy size."

The Duke Power Company said yesterday it had ordered from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation two nuclear reactors with equipment and fuel for a new generating station. W. B. McGuire, president of Duke, said in Charlotte, N. C., that the sation would be built at a site to be chosen later.

Congressional advocates of Selective Service reform made the best of a bad situation when they agreed to clear the way for Senate action on President Nixon's request for authority to institute a draft lottery.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- The State Board of Regents announced today that it would ask the Legislature for $2,499billion -- 10 per cent more than the expenditures planned for this year -- to meet the "fiscal crisis in education" in 1970-71.
The Board of Education has asked City Corporation Counsel J. Lee Rankin for an opinion on the legal status of the school system's three demonstration districts under the current decentralization law.

In his long-awaited report on Latin America, Governor Rockefeller has described in stark but vivid phrases the crisis confronting the nations of this hemisphere and the challenge it poses for the United States. If this sharp analysis fires a sense of urgency in the Nixon Administration and gives momentum in both the White House and Congress to essential policy changes, the Rockefeller mission will have accomplished its best possible purpose.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 12 -- The European Economic Community is in a hassle with German farmers over decisions taken to compensate them for losses stemming from revaluation of the mark.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- Western diplomats said today that they believed the Soviet Union and East Germany had agreed on a cautious conciliatory policy to induce West Germany to accede to their long-standing demands.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- This grimy city is settling down for a long winter's strike with a pragmatic attitude: Suffer now, pay later. And hope that later comes soon.

To the Editor: In reply to your Nov. 3 editorial "Nasser Takes the Wrong Road" I should like to make a few points clear. Nasser's speech to his National Assembly represents clearly the feelings of the frustrated refugees of Palestine and the refugees displaced by the 1967 war.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 12 -- An implied slight on the character of Eugene O'Neill has set off a wrangle here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A House Commerce subcommittee opened hearings today on legislation to reduce the charges paid by mutual-fund investors amid signs that the fund industry might resume its fight against enactment of the bill.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The Senate passed today a public works appropriations package for the fiscal year 1970, including $1-billion to help states fight water pollution.
Music by Gustav Mahler and Vladimir Vogel made up the program of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Nov. 12 (Agence France-Presse) -North Vietnamese and Vietcong military observers said today that recent military action in the Central Highlands and in far southern coastal areas of South Vietnam had dealt a "severe blow" to the "plot" of the United States and the Saigon Government to Vietnamize the war.
BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany insisted today he would demand full international recognition by Bonn in future negotiations.

Harmon Killebrew of the Minnesota Twins, leading slugger in the major leagues last season, has beeen named the American League's Most Valuable Player for 1969, it was announced yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America, which conducts the balloting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Federal efforts to provide American Indians with quality education have been marked with near-total failure and haunted by prejudice and official ignorance, according to a Senate subcommittee report.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The Federal Aviation Administration promulgated today the nation's first Federal regulation limiting the noise of jet airliners.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday declined for the third consecutive session in moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Most of us nowadays have probably forgotten the Oliver Orton Osprey whose "Chants for the Disenchanted: A Thin Volume" proved indisputably just a decade ago that there was a new literary presence among us.
Using love to sell products is a common advertising technique. But selling love through advertising -- well, that's a tougher job.
An estimated $1-million in stolen goods was recovered last evening from a Queens warehouse to which a large tractor-trailer had been taken after it was hijacked earlier in the day.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries achieved new highs in sales and earnings for both the September quarter and the nine months ended Sept. 30.

LEXATAY, South Vietnam, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Under a gnarled tree Mrs. Phan Thi Dan wept quietly for her husband. Occasionally she caressed the green plastic sheet tied with nylon cord that contained his remains -a few bones, remnants of his clothing and his skull, with two prominent gold teeth still intact.

A Public Service Commission engineer testified yesterday that performance charts based on customers' complaints showed that New York Telephone Company service began to deteriorate in 1967, before an economic boom created a sharply increased demand for telephone communications.

Democratic district leaders in Queens have been preparing for a battle over the county leadership, but there were indications yesterday they might work out a temporary compromise and delay the real battle until next year.

In one area above all others, the Rockefeller report disappoints. Noting that Latin America's 250 million people will become 643 million in thirty years, it says correctly that no Latin-American problem is more compelling -- "in terms of public health, economic growth and social progress" -- than this projected population increase.

The children at the five day care centers subsidized by the Brooklyn Kindergarten Society are hard at work these days making ornaments for the tree that will preside at the Heights Casino on Dec. 20 when 450 of their benefactors get together for the 49th annual Yuletide Ball.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Funds for construction of the command center for the Safeguard missile defense system were approved today by the House Appropriations Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church reaffirmed their commitment to priestly celibacy today, but the debate produced the first public appeals from the American hierarchy for a study of the feasibility of ordaining married men.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 12 -- The president of the National Committee of Black Churchmen called today for "billions of dollars in reparations on the national level comparable to the blood, sweat, tears and uncompensated toil and labors of our forefathers."
A bomb extensively damaged a part of the fifth floor of the New York City Criminal Courts Building last night in the fourth explosion in a Manhattan public building in two days.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Two lists purporting to confirm the prisoner-of-war status of some of the 928 Americans missing in action in Vietnam were made available by civilian sources today.

DURING the recent International at San Juan, Puerto Rico, Arthur Bisguier, the Hartsdale, N. Y., grandmaster, exploited an early tactical advance by Miguel Colon, a former Puerto Rican champion, and forced resignation after 36 moves.
MANILA, Nov. 12 -- A massive accumulation of problems faced Ferdinand E. Marcos today as he became the first Philippine President to win a second four-year term.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports of changes in holdings by major stockholders, directors, and officers. They include the following:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The North Atlantic Treaty Organization appears to be moving once again toward greater reliance on nuclear weapons to deter any Soviet aggression.
Everybody is talking about the emergence of the great Cashless Society -- not because there isn't much cash around today, but because credit cards seem to be doing away with most needs for it.

HUDDLED in a flimsy duck blind on the shore of a New England salt pond several days ago with rain driven by a sharp southwest breeze stinging my face, I was suddenly and inexplicably amused that I had chosen to spend so many gray November afternoons in a similar fashion, when, with few exceptions, a warm room, a cheerful fireplace, good books and good conversation had been close by.

To the Editor: It was not the great silent majority who threw British tea into Boston harbor. The great silent majority did not winter at Valley Forge. After the rebellious, loud and angry activists won the Revolutionary War and went on to build a nation, it was not the great silent majority who insisted that slavery was morally wrong.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 12 -Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said at a news conference the other day that unless the governing Congress party became more democratic, more attractive to youth and more committed to socialism and the uplift of the poor, "it has a dim future."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The National Education Association called today for a massive increase in Federal funds for public schools, with the states left free to decide how to spend the money.

A lawsuit was brought in State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to unfreeze several million dollars in Medicaid payments that have been withheld from two factoring companies being investigated by the city and the Federal Government on suspicion of fraud.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The ketch Blackfin broke her radio silence on the fourth day of the Long BeachLa Paz yacht race today and reported a man aboard had "a coronary problem."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Budget Director Robert P. Mayo said today that "mandatory increases under existing laws" in a number of programs such as Social Security and Medicare "can easily push" expenditures in the new budget above $200-billion.

THE American Contract Bridge League annually schedules about 700 tournaments, on sectional, regional and national levels. The majority of players limit their participation to tournaments close to home, but a substantial group is willing to travel considerable distances to satisfy the competitive urge.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn was reported today to have repeated his credo, that he was "ready to die" for the truth, shortly before he was expelled last week from the writers union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -"If there were a Congressman Thaddeus Stevens alive today, President Nixon would be impeached," Sidney Lens told a group of reporters today in the ninth-floor headquarters of the New Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- Real estate men from the country's 31 largest cities opened a frontal assault today on provisions of the Federal tax reform bill now before the Senate. They contend it would effectively kill urban renewal.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle, secluded and silent in Colombey-les-Deux-Eglises, continues to cast a long shadow over France's policy, according to diplomats and other observers here.
BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The film "I Am Curious (Yellow)" was ruled obscene today by Chief Justice G. Joseph Tauro in Suffolk Superior Court.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The first race at Garden State Park was delayed 10 minutes today when employes at the track's food concessions refused to cross picket lines set up by restaurant workers who are striking nine restaurants in the area.
The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the nation's largest cigarette maker, has applied for a patent on a process that would increase the filling capacity of tobacco, the company announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A mass rally in "solidarity" with the peace demonstrations scheduled this week here was held in Hanoi last night, the Vietnamese radio reported this morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A juvenile court case that was expected to settle important constitutional questions about juvenile court trials was dismissed today by the Supreme Court without deciding the merits of the issues.

Production capacity for paper and paperboard will increase by almost 6 million tons during the next three years, but the rate of growth will be slightly lower than the industry's long-term expansion pattern, the American Paper Institute said yesterday.

Thirty-six students at Fordham University who had battled campus security guards in a sit-in demonstration fled last night from their barricaded offices in the administration building as the city police arrived.

Chancellor Albert Bowker's compromise plan for open admission to the City University eliminates the most objectionable feature of some earlier plans. This was the possibility that students who at present are assured admission to the senior colleges on the basis of their academic achievement might be crowded out under the new procedures.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Minnesota North Stars of the National Hockey League said tonight they had offered a contract to Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion to coach the West Division team.
The last time the Giants played New Orleans, Bobby Duhon received the game ball. Possibly the only thing he'll get this time is a game uniform.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 12 -- Two hundred delegates from 49 countries are meeting here to define when and how nations may act if their coastlines are threatened by oil pollution resulting from an accident on the high seas.

HAPPINESS Notopoulos is the manager of the largest two - story Holiday Inn motel in the United States. But Mrs. Notopoulos still has to use a shoehorn to squeeze customers into the 311-unit establishment on football weekends at State College, Pa., adjoining the Penn State campus.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (UPI) -The Nixon Administration antitrust chief warned today that the alternative to his policies would be more bureaucratic regulation imposed on big business by the Congress.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Judge Julius J. Hoffman ordered the arrest today of Jerry Rubin, a defendant in the Chicago conspiracy trial.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Irwin Bock is a well-combed, softspoken young Navy veteran who worked himself up to be a member of the steering committee of the National Mobilization for Peace while working as an undercover agent for the Chicago police.

BOURJ EL BRAJNEH REFUGEE CAMP, Lebanon, Nov. 12 -- In the 21 days since fighting broke out between Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanon, 14 of the 15 United Nations refugee camps in Lebanon have been taken over by the commandos, according to officials of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.
A series of 100 etchings by Picasso brought a record price of $140,000 yesterday at an auction of modem prints at the Parke-Bernet Galleries here.
The stock market, caught in the cross currents of tax-selling and tax-switching, moved slightly lower yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 12 -- Lawyers for the United States marine corporal who hijacked an airliner from Los Angeles to Rome on Nov. 1 confirmed today that they would fight to prevent his extradition to face charges in the United States.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 12 -Pan American World Airways was found guilty here today of operating an improperly licensed bus service between this city and Kennedy International Airport.

YONKERS, Nov. 12 -- Laverne Hanover heads for Yonkers Raceway and revenge Saturday night, when he leads a cast of six in the $25,000 Westchester Pace. The mile event is a tune-up for next week's $100,000 Cane Futurity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A bypartisan Congressional delegation joined President Nixon at the White House today in a telephone talk with Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge to affirm their support of the Administration's position at the Paris peace talks.

THE SUDDEN retirement of Sid Gillman, the San Diego coach, came as a surprise to many persons -- "I was shocked," said John Hadl, the Chargers' quarterback. But those close to the coach considered the move a concession on his part at last to let go.

The annual Greenwich House Antiques Show opens today in a super-country store atmosphere at the 67-year-old settlement house, 27 Barrow Street. More than 30 dealers are showing, with valuable items in haphazard companionship with lesser kinds.

The orchestra of the New York City Ballet has rejected the management's offer of a new three-year contract but has agreed to play next Tuesday, the opening night of the company's scheduled season. That performance is a benefit for the Federation of the Handicapped.
DDT is one of the most potent man-made bombs ever to explode in the insect world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The 45th annual convention of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters closed here this evening with an election, a survey and two resolutions, which members predict will significantly affect the future of educational broadcasting in this country.

The United States Court of Appeals affirmed yesterday the conspiracy-stock fraud conviction of three accountants in a major New York accounting concern who were found guilty June 21, 1968, of securities violations in a 1962 financial statement for the Continental Vending Machine Corporation.
Representatives of the 240 uniformed guards in the city's welfare centers said yesterday the men would refuse to wear uniforms or make arrests from now on because of a recent court decision.
ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Republican leaders of the Legislature will ask the State Court of Appeals for the power to reapportion the legislative seats in the session that convenes in January.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 12 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that although Arab guerrillas were creating difficulties in the occupied areas, Israel was maintaining her strategic military superiority over the Arab states.

Eggs and soybean oil have been hitting new seasonal highs recently. Yesterday, shell eggs faltered, making no new highs although they closed above Tuesday's level. Soybeans moved upward again, making new life-of-contract highs for all deliveries and closing higher on the day.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange advanced on a broad front yesterday.
The city yesterday began an investigation of milk distributors to determine whether possible milk price increases may have been the result of "collusive action or other illegal practices."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Donald V. Taverner, the president of Pittsburgh's two educational television stations, was named president of the National Cable Television Association today. He succeeds Frederick W. Ford, who resigned last May after four years in the post.
The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the C K Coal Company of Clarion, Pa., owner of about 18 million tons of coal reserves in Pennsylvania.

Andrew Jackson High School in Queens, the scene of clashes between Negro and white students earlier this year, canceled all classes yesterday when an early morning fire filled the building with acrid smoke.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- The Soviet Communist party called in effect today for more democracy in local party operations.
Jim Turner has the flu.
MONTREAL, Nov. 12 -- For the second time this year the calm progress at the massive Churchill Falls hydroelectric project has been shaken by death.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -An advisory group of the United States Chamber of Commerce has drafted a broad program of voluntary business reforms to meet the challenge of what it called "a new consumerism."

As his first major hiring move since taking over the New York office of MacManus, John Adams, William E. Chambers Jr. has brought in Nadeen Peterson, 34 years old, as vice president and creative director.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 (AP) -Bands of youths tipped over cars, broke windows and set a garbage truck afire today after the police were called to Albany High School to break up what the police termed an illegal sitin by black students.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Nixon Administration plans to ban all but "essential" uses of DDT during the next two years, Robert H. Finch, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today.

JURGEN RUHLE is in for a long night of the critical knives. Indeed, he invites it. His ambition is enormous and his subject is important. The result, however, is a bloated encyclopedia that makes you want to break a bottle and leap to the attack. Yes, the experience of the writer with Communism in the 20th century has been an unhappy one.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Laurence Michelmore, the head of U.N.R.W.A., who returned Thursday from Beirut, where he talked to Lebanese authorities, said today that he was confident that they would be able to carry out their policing responsibility. He stressed that the maintenance of law and order in the camps was the job of the Arab governments; the agency provided food, cooking fuel, and soap and some medical and educational programs.

GREENVILLE, S. C., Nov. 12 -- A close friend of Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. said today that the nominee to the Supreme Court would have removed himself from consideration had it not been for perusasive arguments from the White House.

After a coast-to-coast demonstration of some of the finest basketball in the 24-year history of the National Basketball Association, the New York Knickerbockers will put their extraordinary skills on display tonight before a home audience at Madison Square Garden.

DALLAS, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A Massachusetts scientist reported today the development of a new blood test that promises to be more certain than the traditional blood-cholesterol test for detecting possible candidates for heart attacks.

New Yorkers are so accustomed to higher prices for everything these days that it is no surprise to find the wage-price spiral now reflecting itself in proposals for increases of 2 to 5 cents a quart in the cost of milk. At the tip of Cape Fear, the southernmost of North Carolina's three shipwreck-famous capes, lies Bald Head Island, a 12,000-acre tract of unspoiled dunes, salt marsh and forest. Its nine miles of beaches provide one of the last undisturbed nesting grounds for the huge loggerhead turtle. Tropical palms grow wild and a rare coastal live oak forest thrives on the island's windswept soil.

Stock prices edged lower in relatively quiet trading yesterday as the best gainers on the active list -- R. J. Reynolds Tobacco and Commercial Solvents -- outperformed the traditional glamour Issues.

Apollo 12 took off for the moon yesterday under what were probably the worst weather conditions of any manned American space launching. Washington, Nov. 14 -- The Western allies are actively preparing proposals to the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies for negotiations on reducing conventional forces in Europe. EVEN if he were not the greatest figure in 19th-century French music, Hector Berlioz would still be, through these memoirs, a unique and singular personality. His skeleton was not fleshed out with tissue but with nerve endings. His was a naked sensibility and he records fearlessly and with overpowering conviction the storms and stresses, the periods of exaltation and of despondency, the moments of ecstasy and the moments of despair that made up his life.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Pentagon plans to continue talking about "Vietnamization" of the war in Southeast Asia even though the South Vietnamese President, Nguyen Van Thieu, dislikes the term.

THE Fall National Championships, which begin tomorrow in Miami Beach, will attract players from all parts of North America and a handful from farther afield. The two competitors farthest from home will be from Melbourne, Australia.

WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Pancho Gonzales, the 41-year-old professional, ousted David Lloyd from the British indoor open tennis championship tonight, and then said he had beaten a potential worldclass star.
MRS. RICHARD M. Nixon, the pride of Seventh Avenue because she wears only American fashions, denied this week that she spent around $19,000 on clothes during her first year in the White House.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP) -- North Vietnamese gunners pounded the Special Forces camps at Buprang and Duclap in the Central Highlands today despite massive air strikes against enemy positions.

The crude attempt on the part of the hatchet man of the Nixon Administration, Vice President Agnew, and the even cruder attempts of the newly appointed chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Dean Burch, to impose censorship on the television news media deserves strong, editorial condemnation.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- Soviet authorities have apparently decided to soften the tone of official anti-American propaganda on military matters while the United States and the Soviet Union are discussing arms limitation in Helsinki.
The relentless drive toward higher interest rates continued in even greater force yesterday, pushing yields on most types of fixed-income securities to records.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 -- The Government said today that it had captured a Communist document calling for an intensified political campaign to overthrow the South Vietnamese administration.

The manager of the singer Tiny Tim's, Joseph Kaufman, 40 years old, was arrested yesterday at his Tarrytown home by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with transporting $90,000 in stolen New York City bonds to London.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- A Mohawk Airlines turboprop plane carrying 11 passengers and three crew members crashed and burned tonight in a dense woods 10 miles north of here. There was no immediate report of survivors.

CAIRO, Nov. 19 -- At a time when "mobilization for the battle" has become a rallying cry in the Arab world, the United Arab Republic's chief spokesman carefuly affirmed today that Cairo had not yet turned its back irrevocably on a nonviolent solution of the conflict with Israel.

Columbia University announced yesterday that Dr. Cyrus Levinthal, molecular biologist and chairman of its department of biological sciences, had been named the first holder of the William R. Kenan Jr. chair, a new professorship.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday in quiet trading.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (Reuters) -- The United States Embassy and the United States military command issued a joint statement today disclaiming approval for such actions as an alleged massacre of civilians by American troops at Songmy, south of Danang.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The price of gold in London and Zurich plunged almost a dollar an ounce today to the lowest price since the free-market system was devised in March, 1968. The decline represents a victory for United States policy.

Vine Deloria, in "Custer Died for Your Sins" observes that despite the number of anthropologists who have inflicted themselves on the American Indian and the enormous amount of money spent to fund their projects, the situation of the Indian keeps on deteriorating.

Copeland, the acting president of City College, proposed last night that next year, exceptionally qualified high-school juniors be admitted to the college as part of efforts to "counterbalance the influx of unprepared students" expected under the City University's new open-admissions policy.

William Zeckendorf Sr.,the real estate promoter, has urged Governor Rockefeller to explore the possibility of converting Stewart Air Force Base near Newburgh, N. Y,, into a commercial jetport to serve the New York metropolitan area.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange inched upward 198.698 shares in the month ended Nov. 14 but declined sharply on the American Stock Exchange, according to reports issued by the exchanges yesterday.

When Old Mother Hubbard went to the cupboard, she found if was bare. When Steve Wright went to his locker at Yankee Stadium yesterday, he found it bare, too. A minute later, he found out why -- he had been suspended indefinitely.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Charges of soliciting desertion and sedition were tentatively dismissed today by a Navy judge presiding at a hearing for Roger Lee Priest, a sailor who publishes an antiwar newsletter.

Herb Alpert, whose Tijuana Brass sound is based on an echo effect produced by two closely spaced trumpets, had his echo doubled last night by the built-in echo in Madison Square Garden's sound system.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- A committee of Senate Democrats has called the state's narcotics control program a "failure" that in its three year history has left untouched more than 90 per cent of the state's estimated 60,000 addicts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The supplemental airlines have told the Civil Aeronautics Board they are in serious financial trouble, and they lay part of the blame on the scheduled airlines, foreign as well as United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird reported today that there had been "some increase" in North Vietnamese infiltration into South Vietnam in "the last few weeks."
" The Circus," the noted Charlie Chaplin silent film of 1928, will have its first revival engagement, starting Dec. 15 at the 72d Street Playhouse.

The United Order True Sisters will hold a luncheon Saturday at the Pierre at which Mrs. Herman Richman will be installed as national president of the philanthropic organization. Mrs. Chester Mayers is luncheon chairman.

ED BRADLEY of WCBS radio was doing man-inthe street interviews yesterday morning, seeking reactions to the moon landing. One person, identifying himself as a newlywed, confessed he didn't watch much television.

One year ago Congress approved the Gun Control Act to help make the country a little bit safer from violence and crime caused by the indiscriminate sales of rifles and shotguns and ammunition. It was a long shot away from being a truly effective gun-control law; it fell short of licensing owners and registering their firearms, but it was, as we observed at the time, "a law that can be built on."

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 19 -- A spurt in market demand for Texas crude oil led the Texas Railroad Commission to increase production in December, but there were witnesses at the commission's proration hearing who had serious problems of over-supply.

JOHN W. COLLINS of New York, the versatile chess master, a former New York State champion and a past editor of Modern Chess Openings, played some hard winning games during the recent New York State championship at Corning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A panel of experts has recommended that the Department of Health, Education and Welfare soften its curb on the artificial sweetener cyclamate.
LISBON, Nov. 19 -- Premier Marcello Caetano has announced the abolition of Portugal's secret political police organization.

IT is that time of year when many persons pick an allsomething collegiate football team, which creates more problems than draws approval. But one thing that has been missing is an allsomething team that includes players from both small and major colleges. Many smallcollege athletes can make the grade with the big powers.

THE news from Kansas City yesterday was affirmative. The soap is out of Ed Lothamer's eyes. Johnny Robinson's hand was bruised, rather than broken. Lenny Dawson is fit as a fiddle. These are key characters for the Chiefs, who face the Oakland Raiders in pro football's big game Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -President Nixon and Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan began discussions about the strategic island of Okinawa today in negotiations that American and Japanese officials consider the most important between the two nations since the peace treaty was signed in 1951.

YONKERS, Nov. 19 -- There can be no triple crown winner among this season's 3-year-old pacers, because different colts won the Messenger Stakes and the Little Brown Jug. VIENNA, Nov. 19 -- A Hungarian official, advocated today increased economic contacts with the West while Czechoslovakia stressed closer cooperation with the Soviet Union and "strict centralism" in her economy.

Olivier Long, the director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, told American business leaders yesterday that President Nixon's trade bill was the "best news I have received since assuming my post 18 months ago."

Swift Co., the largest meat packer in the United States, announced yesterday the execution of a contract for the purchase of a 51 per cent interest in TransOcean Oil, Inc., for $83-million in cash and deferred payments.

The board of directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company played Santa Claus yesterday. They voted to increase the quarterly dividend from the present 60 cents a share to 65 cents, effective with the payment of next Jan. 2.

Herbert Itkin testified in Federal Court yesterday that a city official gave James L. Marcus money to bribe "somebody on the Planning Commission" in January, 1966, just after the Lindsay administration took over.

" Olt" is a children's book for adults. That statement needs qualification. It is not a fable or a child's story for grown-ups. Everything in the child's life is involved, and the resulting odyssey has a weight out of proportion to its means.

McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, made it unlikely, although not impossible, that President Nixon's nominee would win Senate approval.

One might think that Fordham, which has won 24 consecutive basketball games at home, would never want to leave the friendly confines of its Rose Hill gymnasium, but the Rams have scheduled two more road games than last season, when they suffered a 5-7 won-lost record away.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 -- A Soviet newsreel cameraman who defected to England nearly two years ago said today that he had returned to the Soviet Union for nostalgic and political reasons.

People who were prevented from using their tickets to the Woodstock Music and Arts Fair in Bethel, N. Y., last August will be able to get refunds up to a total of $15,000, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The Paris Opera reopened last night with a long-anticipated new production of Berlioz's "Les Troyens" that ran head-on into one of the most abusively turbulent audience receptions in recent years here.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- The General Assembly's Social Committee passed a resolution today condemning Israel's policies of "collective punishment" in reprisal for Arab terrorist acts.
PARIS, Nov. 20 -- A new set of problems is being handed to monetary managers of the major Western nations by the rapidly declining gold price in the free market.

A small fire in the Abraham Straus department store at 420 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon was declared "suspicious" by Fire Department officials because of a number of unsubstantiated bomb threats in the area.

SO DAZZLING were the New York Mets last season that they blinded their worshipers to a clear-cut appraisal of the other players in the sport. To them the brightest sun in their Metsian universe was Tom Seaver and the baseball world revolved around him. Since he was the most valuable Met, he therefore was the most valuable player in the National League.

Willie McCovey, the most feared batter in the National League, was named most valuable player yesterday, beating out Tom Seaver of the New York Mets, even though McCovey's San Francisco Giants finished second in the Western Division.

WHEN Outboard Marine Corporation announced recently that it planned to terminate its boat business after the 1970 model year, it shouldn't have caused more than a raised eyebrow. But coupled with a previous unannounced fact that it no longer was competing in national and world championship ocean racing, the raised brow turned into a puzzled frown.

DISTURBED by the increasing numbers of birds of prey that are being shot by hunters in defiance or ignorance of the law, the Nassau County (L. I.) Fish and Game Association is offering a $50 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of anyone destroying certain of these birds, including the rough-legged hawk, red-tailed hawk, marsh hawk, osprey, Peregrine Falcon, short-eared owl, snowy owl and the bald eagle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 --A Senator and a Representative called today for investigations of an alleged massacre of Vietnamese civilians by American troops last year.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 20 -- A rich young Brazilian industrialist named Edson Arantes do Nascimento changed clothes in an underground dressing room here last night and emerged onto the grass of the world's largest stadium as Pele, the world's best soccer player.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Ivan Mikheyev was "a very sick man who found it impossible to settle down in Britain," according to The Daily Telegraph.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 20 -- Israeli police and security authorities announced today the arrest of more than 50 suspected Arab terrorists, some of them Israeli citizens, in connection with most of the major terrorist incidents of the last few months.

YONKERS, Nov. 20 -- Hail to All, a 3-year-old chestnut colt owned by August Kolyno and driven by George Mueller, surprised a chilled crowd of 14,492 tonight at Yonkers Raceway when he took the second division of the $10,000 Late Closer Paces by 1 1/2 lengths from Majestic Michael, reined by Lester Pullen.
A number of prominent persons -- including Dr. Ralph J. Bunche and Arthur J. Goldberg -- have turned down offers or feelers from the Board of Education to become chancellor of the city school system.
HOUSTON, Nov. 20 -- It will have no conceivable military significance, but there will probably be mortar fire on the moon next year.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The South Vietnamese Army lost 479 men killed in action last week, more than four times the United States toll and a reflection of its increasing combat role, the allied command reported today.
The Bronx District Attorney is investigating possible infiltration of local post offices by the underworld to divert unsolicited credit cards mailed in bulk by some banks.
" Museums are running the risk of becoming extinct and have steadily lost contact with the people they purport to serve."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- When the Selective Service System begins using a new draft lottery, probably early next year, draft-eligible Americans will not have precise information about their chances of being inducted.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20 -- A plan to spare some New Jersey homeowners from substantial tax increases when their properties are reassessed at 100 per cent of true value was disclosed here today by Arthur J. Goldberg, the former United States Supreme Court Justice.

HAS anybody previously given a cycle of the seven solo clavier concertos by Bach in this city? Rosalyn Tureck started the series last night in Carnegie Hall, and the sponsors maintain that they have found no evidence of a prior performance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -President Nixon and Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan have agreed on basic conditions for the return of Okinawa to Japan sometime in 1972, informed American and Japanese sources said today.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, one of the three major film producer that has not been involved in a merger or acquisition, has suffered its first deficit in operations since Darryl F. Zanuck became head of the company in 1962.

FREEPORT, L. I., Nov. 20 -- Simultaneous early - morning raids by 180 Nassau County and village policemen resulted in the arrest today of 34 persons on charges of the sale and possession of dangerous drugs. Six others were held at Nassau County Jail where they are awaiting trial on other charges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -Senator Charles E. Goodell brought out stacks of letters, postcards and telegrams today that he said favored his proposal to withdraw all American troops from Vietnam by Dec. 1, 1970.

A buffet supper and dance for 800 will be held Dec. 14 at the Seagram Building after the world premiere of the motion picture "John and Mary" at two theaters here. Bennet H. Korn and Martin S. Ackerman are co-chairmen for the evening, a benefit for the Film Society of Lincoln Center.
PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The Vietcong delegation charged today that United States troops had drowned about 1,200 South Vietnamese men and women early this year at the coastal village of Balangan.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 18 -- The South Vietnamese Army now has new automatic rifles, dozens of new helicopters, fighter - bombers, patrol boats and artillery pieces, and hundreds of new trucks and tanks, and it has undergone untold hours of training. It also has the backing of the world's most powerful nation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -Senate subcommittee investigators today described the operation of international syndicates said to be engaged in black-market currency transactions and war profiteering in Vietnam, starting with the dollars of American personnel and ending up as gold acquired in a Persial Gulf sheikdom.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A spokesman for the Food and Drug Administration said today that no antibiotics had been banned from animal feeds by the Federal Government.
A City Council committee held a hearing yesterday on a proposed local law aimed at abolishing the illegal killing of alligators 1,000 males away in Florida.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20 (UPI) -The St. Louis Cardinals, as had been rumored for several weeks, have traded Vada Pinson, an outfielder, to the Cleveland Indians for Jose Cardenal, also an outfielder.

ON hearing that Jimmy Breslin was writing a novel, one of his admirers is supposed to have remarked, "Why not? He's been writing fiction for years." That may be true, but it's not true enough, because the distinction of Mr. Breslin's newspaper columns -- apart from their tough-guy sentimentality, which some people ate up and others found indigestible -- lay in the unlikely fact that they were not fictional.

WEMBLEY, England Nov. 20 (AP) -- Pancho Gonzales, 41year-old United States tennis professional, was beaten soundly by Tom Okker of the Netherlands tonight, but announced he was not retiring after all.

Following are conversations between flight controllers in Houston and Comdrs. Charles Conrad Jr., Alan L. Bean and Richard F. Gordon Jr. as recorded yesterday by The New York Times. All times are Eastern Standard.

Apartment dwellers, the majority of Consolidated Edison's electricity customers, here would buy no more power even if rates were reduced, an expert witness for the utility told the Public Service Commission yesterday.

With a tradition of leadership that includes exemplary Mahlerites such as Bruno Walter and Leonard Bernstein -- not to mention the composer himself -- the New York Philharmonic can justly assert claim to being one of the great Mahler orchestras of the world.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -The sale of the former Brooklyn Navy Yard to New York City for $22.4-million received its final clearance today.
Three busloads of professional football fans will journey from Youngstown, Ohio, to Municipal Stadium in Cleveland on Sunday, but not to watch Bill Nelson, Fran Tarkenton or Tucker Frederickson.

PARIS -- The big question facing Western Europe currently is what kind of balance will be established in the new situation arising from the end of de Gaulle's governance in Paris and the start of Brandt's governance in Bonn. The fate of Britain's request to enter the Common Market depends on the answer, as does the fate of the Common Market itself.

THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, one of the Brooklyn Academy's three resident dance companies, settled nicely into its home base last night with three works: a premiere by Mr. Ailey, a second work the groupe had previously not danced in New York and Mr. Ailey's masterpiece, "Revelations."

Carlos Ortiz, once not only the world lightweight champion but also a boxer with polish and strength, begins a comeback tonight as a welterweight at Madison Square Garden against a virtually unknown but possibly dangerous opponent, Edmundo Leite of Brazil.

The governing boards of the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange threw their weight yesterday behind the concept of machine-readable stock certificates as a way out of Wall Street's paperwork crisis.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 20 -- The United States presented its opening position at the talks on limiting strategic arms today, outlining possible steps to curb the nuclear arms race.

Federal monetary restraint has affected the profits of some retail merchandise chains, as shown by the performance of six companies that reported yesterday for the third fiscal quarter. These chains are Federated Department Stores, May Department Stores, Associated Dry Goods Corporation, W. T. Grant Company, McCrory Corporation and Dayton Hudson.
PROVO, Utah, Nov. 20 -- Michael Brent Terry, a Vietnam veteran who reportedly took part in the shooting incident, refused to talk to newsmen today on advice of counsel.
DARTMOUTH COLLEGE, an upstart in the eyes of the Big Three, shoots for the Ivy League football championsip and an undefeated season tomorrow against Princeton, at Palmer Stadium.

The resignation of Henry Cabot Lodge as chief United States negotiator in the Vietnam peace talks and President Nixon's apparent intention not to name a successor promptly are disturbing signs that the Administration may be turning away from the Paris talks as a forum for ending the war.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Leon Sikes of Palm Beach, and Norton Harris of Key West, the runners-up last year, advanced to the semifinals in the world four-ball amateur seniors golf championship today.

The presidents and managers of 68 American symphony orchestras opened a two-day conference at Philharmonic Hall yesterday to discuss the increasing financial problems that beset their organizations.

YONKERS, Nov. 21 -- As is customary on a day preceding a big race, all preparatory work for tomorrow night's $100,000 Cane Futurity Pace at Yonkers Raceway was restricted this morning to jogging by the eight starters in the one mile stake for 3-year-old pacers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today to hold public hearings on the Vietnam war. But the committee said the witnesses would probably be limited to Administration officials and Senators who have sponsored a series of Vietnam resolutions.
Traders have been largely ignoring wheat futures for someI weeks, but yesterday they[ jumped into the market to push] prices up about a cent a bushel.

The strike of nearly 150,000 workers at General Electric ends its fourth week in a state of absolute nonmovement. Both sides are dug in for a siege, and the Nixon Administration remains as detached from the conflict as if it involved a small pickle packer.
Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, which reached new highs earlier this week, declined yesterday amid profit taking.
A champagne supper at the Cattleman West will follow Cancer Care's theater party at the Dec. 5 preview of "Coco" at the Mark Hellinger Theater.
The Bridge and Tunnel Officers Union, representing the men who man toll booths and other positions for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority voted last night to strike on Thanksgiving Day.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- United States officials here and in Washington have become deeply pessimistic about the prospects for reaching an agreement with the Soviet Union about the Middle East.

Commando seizure of all but one of the fifteen United Nations refugee camps in Lebanon is a stunning blow to leaders of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) who are appealing to the General Assembly for more funds to carry on their humanitarian work among 1.4 million displaced Palestinians.

A 5-month-old boy suffering from a rare disease that makes him unable to resist infection was flown by helicopter yesterday from a Bronx park playground to Boston for a possible bone marrow transplant from his 2-year-old sister.

Jorge Tejeira fell from a horse yesterday at Aqueduct, but he didn't mind it at all. The 20-year-old jockey from Panama had just won the feature race on the card to round out a consecutive triple, and the slight mishap, immediately after that final success, failed to dampen his elation.
Maurice J. O'Rourke, a longtime advocate of election reform, resigned yesterday from what he called a "frustrating adventure" -- his position as one of four Commissioners on the Board of Elections.
The LTV Aerospace Corporation announced yesterday that it was negotiating for the sale of its subsidiary, Computer Technology, Inc., to the University Computing Company.
One of the four persons indicted Tuesday on charges of plotting to bomb Government property pleaded not guilty in Federal Court yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The allegations of atrocities by American soldiers in South Vietnam will almost certainly be debated in the British House of Commons or before a meeting of the Parliamentary Labor party.
National Bible Week opened yesterday with lunch at the Pierre Hotel and praise for the religious convictions of some daring Americans.
Former New York Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick said yesterday the Federal Government should finance a study of the feasibility of providing addicts with free heroin.
An increase in commission rates paid by small investors on their stock transcations by was called for yesterday by Robert W. Haack, president the New York Stock Exchange.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 -- There are undoubtedly students somewhere this week who are planning sit-ins and protest marches. But Neal Steinbrenner is planning practical jokes and card tricks.

LONDON--One reason given by President Nixon for keeping American troops in Vietnam until an unspecified day when the Thieu-Ky Government can carry on alone is that, otherwise, "Our allies would lose confidence in America." After the terrible news of this past week, the proposition sounds like mockery.
GREENVILLE, S. C., Nov. 21 -- His rejection as a Supreme Court Justice has prompted Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. to consider resigning from the United States Court of Appeals.
ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- Republicans of the Northeastern states were reassured today that the national party was not courting Southern voters at their expense.

HOUSTON, Nov. 21 -- A board of inquiry has pinpointed lightning as the cause of the electrical crisis that alarmed the Apollo 12 crew seconds after lift-off Nov. 14 from Cape Kennedy, Fla.

The Indian dancer Bhaskar is happily physical to an almost cultish degree, and it gives his movements a broad, open look that projects to the farthest reaches of the audience. Last night at Cooper Union, Bhaskar and his company presented a varied program titled "India!, India!"

HOUSTON, Nov. 21 -- The three Apollo 12 astronauts broke out of an orbit of the moon today and took an accurate homeward aim toward the earth.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -The Senate refused decisively today to make Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. of South Carolina an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. The vote was 55 to 45 against confirming President Nixon's nominee.

A "Convocation of the Arts" at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University yesterday featured more than 15 special events, including panel discussions, seminars, recitals, demonstrations and an English-language performance in the evening of Mozart's opera, "Cosi fan tutte," by the Opera New York company.

After 16 months in self-exile at his Bronx nightclub, Carlos Ortiz, once the world lightweight champion, returned to boxing as a welterweight last night. But he heard applause only before and after being awarded a majority 10-round decision over Edmundo Leite of Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Nixon placed three considerations on the line as the Haynsworth controversy played toward its climax today. Delegates to an emergency convention of the International Union of Electrical Workers voted yesterday to provide massive financial support for its 88,500 members on strike against the General Electric Company.

The president of the Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday that the company was engaged in "the largest capital investment program in the history of the forest products industry."

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 21 -- The walls of the staid courtroom in the County Court Building here reverberated to syncopated drum beats today as one of the country's leading jazz musicians tried to show a group of youths the harmful effects of marijuana.

VIENNA, Nov. 21 -- Alois Indra, a leading pro-Soviet conservative, returned to Prague today after a four-day visit to Budapest amid reports that the Czechoslovak Communist regime was seeking Hungarian support against hard-line extremists at home.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- Ewald B. Nyquist, a 55-year-old educator, today was named Commissioner of Education, the highest administrative post in the state's educational system and one of the most sensitive and potentially controversial positions in the state.
The American Stock Exchange took another beating yesterday, although selling pressure was lighter than on Thursday when the number of declines was the largest in almost four months.
FROM a distance, the walls of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's newly installed French 18th-century room appear encrusted from floor to ceiling with gilded snowflakes.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- A Federal Court decision today that ruled invalid the method of electing a Board of Education in New York City may spur a move in the Legislature next year to replace an elected board with an appointed one.

The Senate's refusal to confirm Judge Clement F. Haynsworth, the first such rejection of a Supreme Court appointment in a third of a century, is for President Nixon a political setback of stunning proportions.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The newly decorated residence of the American Ambassador to Britain, which took nine months to finish and cost its tenant, Walter Annenberg, about a million dollars, now looks so grand that it hurts to use an ashtray.

WHEN Pete Hopkins took a job as father to 20 homeless boys aged 10 to 15, his wife resolved not to get involved. He would be provided with someone to cook, do the laundry and clean the 24-room house in the northeast Bronx.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 21 -- Deputy Defense Secretary David Packard concluded a six-day assessment of the war effort today with a prediction that American troop withdrawals would continue.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- The chief of the United States Department of Justice's Antitrust Division said today a formula worked out to allow the British Petroleum Company to expand in the American market might serve as a pattern for settling antimerger cases field against big American oil companies.
BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- Boston has returned to a modified form of rent control for the first time since World War II.

A city commissioner reported to have been involved in an attempt to bribe a member of the Planning Commission has been out of government "for a long period of time," Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

OTTAWA, NOV. 21 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's 1969 wheat crop will reach 684,276,000 bushels despite late-fall harvesting difficulties in the Prairie provinces, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

LEROI JONES'S new play, "Slave Ship," being given by the Chelsea Theater Center at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, raises for a white critic somber and awful problems. It is a strong, strange play that once seen will never be forgotten.

SIMPLE but fine 18th-century English furniture is having increasing appeal for those who shy away from the $50,000 to $100,000 price tags on the most elaborate English and American work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -The Army's top lawyer said today that about 11 persons currently in the Army and about 15 former servicemen were being investigated in connection with the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese civilians by American troops last year.

Important gains have been registered toward protecting the majestic Hudson River Valley, on both a short-term and long-term basis.

The moguls of Wall Street and the captains of industry were wined, dined and roasted last night at the latest version of the annual Financial Follies presented by the New York Financial Writers Association.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 21 -- One of Thailand's top security officials, Lieut. Gen. Saiyud Kerdpol, .told American and Thai officials yesterday that 2,000 terrorists were now active in the country.
HOUSTON, Nov. 21 -- A moon walk lasting nearly five hours without interruption might prove possible on the next Apollo flight if the mission planners decide such a long excursion would be worthwhile.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Dean Burch, the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, appeared today to have answered his own doubts about the fairness of television network news and also to have warned the Nixon Administration against further criticism of the media.

The Metropolitan Opera has scheduled a special meeting of its board of directors and executive and finance committees on Monday at 3 P.M. to consider "recommendations of the officers and management" of written "final" proposals to be submitted to the unions.

Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan arrived here last evening for a largely private two-day visit to the city. The Premier, accompanied by Mrs. Sato and Japanese officials, came on a special Air Force flight from Washington, where he conferred with President Nixon on Okinawa.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 21 -- Cargo rates on inland waterways may increase by up to 15 per cent and the major operators may hold off their investment in even better equipment because of Congressional inaction this week. The carriers have kept rates constant for the past 20 years by introducing new tugs pushing bigger loads.

Ohio State bids for a second consecutive perfect season and Dartmouth chases an Ivy League championship today, and a group of Sacramento State College football players will trade jerseys tonight in a gesture of collegiate good will.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he would fight to retain the 20-cent transit fare but that its retention would depend on the willingness of the state and public agencies such as the Port Authority to provide financial assistance.

" PRUDENTIAL'S ON STAGE," the National Broadcasting Company's prestige drama series, is shaping up as one of the relatively unheralded delights of primetime television. OTTAWA, Nov. 21 -- A language bill guaranteeing Quebeckers their traditional right to choose to have their children educated either in English or in French received final approval by the Quebec Legislature last night.

The eggplant, treasured in Far Eastern cookery for more than 3,000 years, is a relative newcomer to the cuisine of the Western world. Until a few hundred years ago it was linked with the deadly nightshade and known as the "mad apple." Today no such stigma is associated with it. The vegetable has a curious name, but not without reason. There are small, egg-shaped, egg-white eggplants which are available in autumn in New York's Chinatown.
