Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, said yesterday he was investigating grounds for possible court action to compel the Port of New York Authority to sell the World Trade Center and to use the proceeds for public transportation in New York and New Jersey.

The Power of Positive Thinking, preached by the disciples of the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale to Joseph William Namath, penetrated the peer of pessimism last week, the college football coach, with unexpected results.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 23 -The Chinese Nationalist Government has criticized the United States-Japanese agreement on Reversion of Okinawa and the other Ryukyu Islands as having been made without regard for "proper procedure."

CLEVELAND, Nov. 23 -- Leroy Kelly pulled a muscle last summer and he hadn't been himself this season -- until today. A muddy field couldn't stop him and neither could the Giants as he ran for three touchdowns in a 28-17 victory by the Browns.

Pierre Fournier, the French cellist, came to Hunter College Assembly Hall on Saturday night to play sonatas by Francoeur, Beethoven (A major, Op. 69) and Debussy, Bach's Suite No. 3 in C for unaccompanied cello and Paganini's Variations on One String. Leon Pommers was the assisting pianist.
HOUSTON, Nov. 23 -- Besides being an astronaut, an accomplished jet pilot and a restorer of old automobiles, the moderator of the first news conference from space is also a translator of sorts.

Mrs. Caroline Goodman, mother of Andrew Goodman, a slain civil-rights worker, stood in the tiny meditation chapel of Riverside Church yesterday afternoon and slowly read from a list of Vietnam war dead.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 23 -- The Kansas City Chiefs turned the tomahawk upon themselves today and gave away a game plus first place in the American Football League's Western Division to the Oakland Raiders.

ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- One hundred twenty-three years after it was set up as the highest court of the state, the New York Court of Appeals is today so burdened with trivia, legal observers say, that it finds it increasingly difficult to perform its constitutional role.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 23 -- The United States hopes to get a clearer understanding of Soviet views as the preliminary talks on the limitation of strategic arms enter their second week tomorrow.
Television continues to respond, with programs and with speeches by industry spokesmen, to Vice President Agnew's recent criticisms of news coverage by TV and newspapers.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 -The unbeaten Los Angeles Rams defeated the Dallas Cowboys, 24-23, today before 79,105 spectators in Memorial Coliseum.

A family of four "would be better off receiving welfare instead of unemployment insurance benefits" for its breadwinner in New York State, according to a staff study for the State Senate Committee on Labor and Industry.

The Times (Nov. 4) criticized the settlement of black student demands at Vassar College as capitulatory and illegal: conducting "negotiations under duress" and "acceptance of... separatism." The use of such terms tends to reduce the issue to a matter of legal tactics.

PRAGUE, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A Czechoslovak official said today that the Kremlin had told its allies to start buying crude oil in the Middle East and North Africa because most of the Soviet output would be shifting to Siberian fields over the next decade.
While most of New York slept, 80 bicyclists paid their respects to the late President John F. Kennedy in the annual memorial races at Central Park yesterday morning.

The Dance Theater Workshop moved uptown over the weekend to the Manhattan School of Music, Claremont Avenue and 122d Street. Although admission was free, Saturday night's packed auditorium testified as much to the Chelsea-based group's reputation as a systematic proving ground for choreographers as it did to the rising popularity of dance.

Consumers' buying plans, as reported in September and October, have been cut back moderately since last spring, and slightly from those in July and August, according to the National Industrial Conference Board.

GOTEMBA, Japan. Nov. 23 (Reuter) -- Minoru Kawai of Japan, driving a Toyota 7, held off the challenge of nine well-known foreign drivers today and captured the $65,000 second annual World Challenge Cup race. There were 17 starters.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y. -- It's likely that, back in the late 1600's, Frederick Philipse would sit in the fore-room of his manor house, reflect on some of his business dealings, which had made him one of the wealthiest merchants and landowners in colonial New York, and enjoy a hearty but simple repast.

GREEN BAY, Wis. Nov. 23 (AP) -- Errol Mann, a Packer reject, kicked three field goals and the Lion quarterback, Greg Landry, ran for a touchdown today to pace Detroit to a 1610 National Football League victory over Green Bay.

" I don't worry about losing," says Walt Frazier. "I don't look at the schedule anymore. It don't matter where we're playing. I never get excited, I just go along, real passive. The only time I get woke up is at the end when I sense it, the crowd and the noise and I see all the guys running all over the place."

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The film made from Joan Littlewood's "Oh! What a Lovely War" contrasts the vanity of generals and the empty jingoism of politicians with the savage reality of life in the trenches of World War I.

Governor Rockefeller disclosed yesterday that he had applied to the Federal Government for $150-million in interest subsidies and other aid to help bring down costs and rents in a program to build 25,000 low-income and middle-income housing units across the state.
Vice President Agnew decided to speak out against antiwar demonstrators, he says, not at the prompting of the President but because, "like the great, silent majority, I had had enough."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Oscar Robertson, with 39 points, and Tom Van Arsdale, with 29, paced the Cincinnati Royals to a 137-123 triumph over the Phoenix Suns today in a National Basketball Association game.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -Mike Taliaferro tossed three long touchdown passes in the first half, then engineered a 71-yard tie-breaking drive late in the third period today as the Boston Patriots scored a 35-21 American Football League victory over the Buffalo Bills.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Charley Harraway raced 68 yards for the only touchdown of the second half as the Washington Redskins survived a fourth-quarter threat to defeat the Atlanta Falcons, 27-20, in a National Football League game today.

MERANO, Italy, Nov. 23 -- Italian Government proposals to give increased autonomy to predominantly German - speaking Bolzano Province won approval by a narrow margin here early today from the party representing the bulk of the ethnic Germans.

MIAMI, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Pete Beathard threw two touchdown passes and Roy Gerela kicked three field goals to lead the Houston Oilers to a 32-7 triumph over the Miami Dolphins today and virtually clinch second place in the American Football League's Eastern Division.

Announcement of a bistate takeover of the New Haven Railroad is welcome on the simple but despairing basis that any change must be for the better. If nothing else, it will fix responsibility on the governments of New York and Connecticut instead of leaving commuters with no legitimate target for their complaints but the Penn Central, which has seemed to bear them with no visible signs of suffering.

ACRE, Israel, Nov. 23 -- Hundreds of Israeli policemen and soldiers were maintaining a fragile peace here tonight after turning back three attempts by Jewish youths to break into the town's Arab quarter.

HELSINKI -- Marimekko, the flamboyant textile design house that put Finland on the fashion map, is settling down with more business-like methods following an erratic success that produced more praise than profits.

ATHENS, Nov. 23 -- Greece's military-backed Government said today that it had set a firm timetable for the restoration of representative government, which was abolished in a coup d'etat 31 months ago.

The toll of injuries in the National Basketball Association, perhaps greater than at any other time in the 24-year history of the league, continues to mount, especially among players with superstar ratings.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- As a frontier, the mud at the bottom of the world's oceans lacks the obvious glamour of a glowing moon. But it is nevertheless holding the attention these days of a growing number of the world's planners and technicians in government and big business.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Workmen constructing a new press room in the White House basement have uncovered two hidden rooms believed to date from the Jefferson era.

A recent Times editorial on farm policy gives the reader the impression that high prices are in considerable measure the result of inflated farm prices and short-sighted farm policy. It ignores several apparently little-known but very important factors.
The city plans to begin a year-long study in January to learn whether New York's transportation system meets the needs of slum residents at a time of shifting patterns in the city's economy.

Gottschee and New York Hungaria, two of the strongest soccer teams in the area, played for 120 minutes to a scoreless tie yesterday in a United States Challenge Cup match. The teams also played a 3-3 deadlock; after 105 minutes, the previous Sunday and will have to meet for a third time.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 23 -- A boisterous parade of Puerto Ricans marched through the heart of the tourist section of the city this morning, waving Puerto Rican flags and yelling "Yanqui go home!"
ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- The next Legislature will be asked to grant cost-of-living increases for 1.5 million welfare recipients land to equalize the basic payments in all parts of the state.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 23--South African security policemen have been accused of tapping the phones of student leaders, opening their mail and keeping them under constant watch.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Following are excerpts from the statement issued today by the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence on "Violent Crime: Homicide, Assault, Rape and Robbery":

THESE days you have to know what the date is before you can begin using some calendars. Take the clear plastic calendar that arrived from Switzerland at Bonniers last week. The two-part cylinder design is split in half to permit rotating the top to set the date.

On the ground floor of a tenement at 77 East Third Street there is a three-room apartment that is a combination board room, recreation lounge and crash pad for the Nomads chapter of the Aliens, a motorcycle club.

State officials have decided to press a campaign to change a Federal regulation that bars the state from getting the land it says it needs to develop parks properly at historic sites.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 23 -- The two-day convention of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's faction in the governing Congress party concluded here today after severing the final links with the old-guard faction.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, reported today that serious observers of the Helsinki arms talks believed that "sensible and constructive decisions'' were attainable in the negotiations.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 23 -- King cotton long ago abdicated its role as the top cargo in this major Gulf port, but its legacy still plagues the harbor in the form of the wrong kind of marine terminals.

Carnegie Hall was filled with enthusiasm and friends of the Dornan Brothers last night. The brothers, Jeff and Mark, sang a program that ranged from fraternity song ("Lydia Pinkham") to country music ("Green, Grass of Home"), from traditional folk song ("The Golden Vanity") to contemporary pop ("Both Sides Now").

WASHINGTON,. Nov. 23 -- West Germany, whose currency has long been the strongest in the world, is about to make a drawing of $500-million from the International Monetary Fund, it was reported authoritatively today.
A 30-year-old man was held on a homicide charge yesterday in the killing of a Florida man Saturday morning in a bar in Astoria, Queens.
A group of black business and community leaders from New York wants to buy Stewart Air Force Base near Newburgh and turn it into a demonstration city to be called the "City of Man."

Frank Perry, director of two successful current movies, "Last Summer" and Truman Capote's "Trilogy," has signed with United Artists to produce and direct "Doc," a film about the legendary Western gunslinger Doc Holliday. "Doc" will mark the screen-writing debut of Pete Hamill, the New York Post columnist.

Ed Marinaro, Cornell's sophomore back who is bidding to become the national rushing leader, has been named to The Associated Press All-Ivy football team along with Jim Chasey of Dartmouth and Scott MacBean of Princeton, who share the quarterback role.

A 26-year-old employe of a Roman Catholic orphanage was charged yesterday with murdering a patron at a Staten Island luncheonette and then forcing two children to remove their clothes so that they could be held as hostages.

THE Brooklyn Academy of Music has quite a number of visiting troupes for its dance festival, but only three resident companies -Eliot Feld's American Ballet Company, the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and the Alvin Alley American Dance Theater.

DUBLIN -- The Becketteers will find the going much tougher than the Joyceans. They will arrive in years to come by the hundreds -mature pilgrims to pay homage, or postgraduates to write doctorate theses, or students to seek knowledge -just as they have been coming for years past to make devotion to and study of Joyce, Ireland's most lucrative literary industry.

TORONTO, Nov. 23 -- Increases of eightfold in Canada's exports of oil to the United States and of tenfold for natural gas are projected by the National Energy Board in a new study of the energy outlook to 1990.

A fundamental change in France's attitude toward British entry into the Common Market is responsible for the moderate optimism in Brussels and Bonn about next week's six-power summit meeting to discuss the issue.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 -- Order rates of steel mills fell a little more last week at one major mill the level dropped to the lowest point since early September. Most mills were shipping steel out faster than new business was coming in. As a result, backlogs were shrinking for the first time since early summer.
Investment bankers can give thanks this week for something of a respite from the heavy sales schedules so frequent this fall, but they don't have much else to be especially grateful for.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 23 -- The nation's economy is in the first stages of a moderate slowing and is likely to experience a severe recession, Milton Friedman said here today.

MERIDA, Mexico, Nov. 23 -- The election of the governor of Yucatan, a test of effective voting rights in Mexico, was plagued today with irregularities, violence and cries of fraud from the Opposition.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The price of gold plunged 60 cents an ounce in European bullion exchanges today to reach the lowest level since creation of the free market for the metal more than 20 months ago.

Jorge Velasquez picked up considerable ground in his bid for the riding honors in this state when he registered four victories at Aqueduct yesterday for a total of 195. Trans World Airlines announced yesterday the winners of its 32d annual writing and picture competition.

Insurance premiums for homeowners who buy package policies in New York State will go up an average of slightly more than 15 per cent next Monday.
Attorney General John N. Mitchell commented yesterday on his wife's comments about his comments on the antiwar demonstrations in Washington 10 days ago.

MADRID, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Spain's head of state today appointed Alejandro Rodriguez de Valcarcel, an oldguard Falangist, to the important port of president of the Cortes, or legislature.

Millions watched yesterday as television captured the Yankee Clipper's precision return to earth at exactly the time and place that had been planned months ago. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has done so well in its moon shots this past year that everyone took it for granted that the cameras aboard the Hornet would catch sight of the capsule as it drifted toward the sea under inflated parachutes. The expectations were not disappointed.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The Cullberg Ballet from Sweden is a company neatly poised between the American and European traditions. This doubtless helps to explain the success it has been enjoying at this year's Paris International Dance Festival.

ABOARD U.S.S. HORNET, at Sea, Nov. 24 -- When Apollo 11 splashed down in the Pacific four months ago, ending man's first successful expedition to the moon, Ernest Lee Jahncke 3d, of Greenwich, Conn., was in Vietnam's Camau peninsula, fighting off a Vietcong am bush.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -The Nixon Administration has reached its Dec. 15 troop-withdrawal goal three weeks in advance, and according to Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird it intends to continue substantial cutbacks even before another announcement is made.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi called today for more rational use and conservation of the world's natural resources.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Tires certified by four major American manufacturers as meeting Government safety standards failed 25 per cent of tests conducted by independent laboratories, the Department of Transportation said today.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 -- The Chrysler Corporation's mid-November new-car sales ran slightly ahead of last year, but sales at the Ford Motor Company and the American Motors Corporation trailed 1968, the three companies reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Government threatened court action today to prevent the Greyhound Corporation from acquiring controlling interest in Armour Co. In a terse announcement, the Justice Department said Greyhound and the General Host Corporation, which had planned to sell the Armour stock, had been informed the purchase would be considered illegal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- President Nixon today presented the Medal of Honor to three Vietnam veterans who he said displayed "uncommon valor" in action. He likened the feats of the three Army sergeants to the bravery of the Apollo 11 and 12 astronauts who went to the moon.
LISBON, Nov. 24 -- Portugal's new National Assembly will open this week and for the first time in four decades it promises to be an interesting legislature with more than one view.
MIAMI, Nov. 24 (UPI) -The first tropical storm to hit Panama in the 99 years of Weather Bureau recordkeeping poured over 13 inches of rain over the nation's western end today.
The board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association gave approval yesterday to "final proposals'' for submission to choristers, dancers, principals and musicians.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange were slightly lower yesterday. Among leading issues losing ground were Unilever and Imperial Chemical Industries.

The city's Housing and Development Administration directed owners of residential hotels yesterday to roll back recent "excessive rent increases" or be placed under standard rent control.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 24 -- The American and Soviet delegations were reported today to be making slow but steady progress in establishing a framework for future negotiations on curbing the nuclear arms race.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 24 -Madalyn Murray O'Hair, an atheist, asked three Federal judges today to disqualify themselves from hearing her suit against astronauts' saying prayers in space.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 24 -- Yale University has announced plans to phase out its program leading to the degree of master of arts in teaching, part of a major reorganization in its training of secondary - school teachers.
Psychiatrists, social workers, nurses and emotionally disturbed teen-aged patients from Bronx State Hospital picketed Governor Rockefeller's West 55th Street office yesterday.

Michigan's surprising 24-12 victory over Ohio State sent the Buckeyes diving from first to fourth spot in The Associated Press writers' weekly college football rankings and from first to sixth in the United Press International poll of coaches.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Lawyers fighting a move by Republican legislative leaders to reapportion the Legislature in January today condemned the G.O.P. action as an "impulsive whim" that was "all done in the heat of the night."
Vice President Spiro Agnew's attempt to silence TV and newspaper critics of the Nixon Administration should dispel forever the perennially naive illusions about the "New Nixon."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Dr. Richard W. Lyman, the vice president and provost of Stanford University, is the leading candidate to be the next president of Dartmouth College, according to sources both here and in Hanover, N. H.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -President Nixon asked Congress today to authorize an increase of $853-million in the lending activity of the ExportImport Bank in this fiscal year.

Paintings and sculpture will be sold at auction for three hours starting at 5 P.M. on Dec. 6 at the Art Students League of New York, 215 West 57th Street. Proceeds will aid the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N. H., which provides writers, composers and artists with an environment conducive to creative work.
RICHMOND, Nov. 24 -- The Richmond News Leader, the afternoon newspaper in this capital city, today hired its first Negro general assignment reporter since the paper was founded in 1896.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Army is short of drill sergeants -- noncommissioned officers who have the job of transforming civilians into soldiers.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- As you would expect from the play title, and from knowing that its author recently published a comic novel on thalidomide, John Fraser's "Cannibal Crackers" is an addition to the British black farce repertory.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Several windows in downtown Paterson were broken last night after the police peaceably dispersed a crowd of more than 100 who had gathered afer the arrest of a youth on charges of assaulting two policemen.
WASHINGTON, Nov., 24--President Nixon signed the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons today, all but completing formal ratification some seven years after negotiations began on the treaty.

A 35-year-old Long Island bachelor who wants to vote in school-board elections asked a three-judge Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to order new elections for nearly all the 750 school districts in the state.

Theodore W. Kheel, lawyer and mediator, recommended yesterday that police sergeants and lieutenants in the city be granted salary parity with their fire counterparts at the maximum level of each rank.

The city's Human Resources Administrator, Mitchell I. Ginsberg, contended yeaterday that the welfare increases proposed Sunday by the state were merely the "restoration of very unfortunate past cuts" and not the cost - of -living rise announced by the state.
MERIDA, Mexico, Nov. 24 -Contradictory claims of victory and fraud by Government and opposition candidates for Governor of the state of Yucatan left a tense and uncertain situation today.

PHOENIX, Nov. 24 -- The Argus Research Corporation foresees a mild recession in 1970 and a rising stock market after some downward churning in the next two months.

Specialist 4 William Mahalas, a combat medic who is a native of West Germany, was one of 500 G.I.'s flown from Vietnam and other Pacific posts to Hawaii last month to acquire citizenship under an amendment to the immigration act that speeds naturalization for men serving in the armed forces during the Vietnam conflict.

In an experiment designed to explore new fields of profit, each of the 32 divisions of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company have opened at least one food discount store in their areas. No formal announcement of the move was made at A. P. headquarters here.

The New York Life Insurance Company announced plans yesterday to develop a radically new product that would provide for variable -- rather than fixed -- cash values and death benefits. It represents the response of a major life company, which has decided against entering the mutual fund field, to demands by an inflation-conscious public for some hedge against the decline in purchasing power of the dollar.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 ap) -- An injunction was handed down in Suffolk Superior Court today against a group of young people alleged to have led a demonstration against the General Electric Company last Tuesday at Boston University.

Gerry Lindgren, the Washington State harrier for whom winning National Collegiate Athletic Association titles seems to come naturally, captured No. 11 yesterday against some extremely talented rivals.
Interest rates, from shortterm Treasury securities to longterm corporate bonds, continued to climb yesterday, attaining levels that dealers a year ago would have considered incomprehensible.
The Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York opened a $1-million youth servicees fund-raising campaign last night.

ABOARD U.S.S. HORNET, at Sea, Nov. 24 -- Man's second expedition to the surface of the moon ended in triumph today when the Apollo 12 astronauts made a near-bullseye landing in the gale-tossed South Pacific.

The advertising agency dismissed by City Controller Mario A. Procaccino during his unsuccessful mayoral campaign and two of its officers were indicted yesterday on charges of evading Federal corporate and personal-income taxes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -Treasury bill rates climbed to record levels at today's auction, the Government reported late this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -The Army announced today that it had appointed a lieutenant general to "explore the nature and scope" of the original Army investigation into the alleged massacre of Vietnamese civilians by American troops last year.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Judge Julius J. Hoffman denied today another defense motion for a mistrial in the Chicago conspiracy trial.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The American military decision to proceed with a court martial against First Lieut. William Calley Jr. will serve to relieve pressure on the British Labor Government.

NEWARK, Nov. 24 -- Federal District Judge Robert Shaw denied a motion today to dismiss a Federal grand jury extortion indictment against Angelo (Gyp) DeCarlo and set Jan. 5 as the trial date.

SEATTLE, Nov. 24 (AP) -Dave Bristol was named manager of the Seattle Pilots today, succeeding Joe Schultz who was dropped after leading the American League baseball expansion club through its first season.

LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gen. Julian J. Ewell, commander of the III Corps Zone around Saigon, said today that the Vietnam conflict had entered a new phase and Saigon troops would have to learn to fight a "semiguerrilla" war.

KINSHASA, The Congo, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- The Congo River border between this former Belgian colony and the Congo Republic, a former French colony, was shut today as the frequently strained relations between the two African republics took an ominous downward turn.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24--A possibility that the Government might have to put sterility drugs in reservoirs and in food shipped to foreign countries to limit human multiplication was envisioned today by a leading crusader on the population problem.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24--The Senate began debate on the tax bill today and, in its first test votes, defeated decisively one amendment that would have raised slightly the taxes paid by the oil industry and another that would have raised sharply the amount of general tax reduction in the bill.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., raised the price of primary nickel yesterday by 25 cents a pound, to $1.28 a pound. The company -- known as Inco -produces about 60 per cent of the nickel used in the nonCommunist world.

One thing can be said about the Greek junta: its international political maneuvers are entirely predictable. It invariably begins to make noises about restoring freedoms or returning Greece to representative rule when it is facing the threat of international censure or condemnation.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 24 -- Because the United States and the Soviet Union decided to come to Helsinki to discuss the nuclear arms race, Finland, long an incognito nation in Europe, is finding herself thrust -not too reluctantly -- onto center stage as a neutral host, and perhaps even as a mediator, for the superpowers.

TURIN, Italy, Nov. 22--A recent incident in this city, unviolent and unreported, said more about the mood of Italy's industrial workers this fall than the banner headlines on the disruption of the assembly lines, the riots in the streets and the occasional deaths.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 24 -- Only light war action was reported in Vietnam in the last 24 hours, most of it started by United States troops watching infiltration routes northwest of Saigon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by Gabe Pressman, a National Broadcasting Company television reporter arrested on disorderly conduct charges while covering disturbances in Plainfield, N. J., in July, 1967.
Soybeans futures, strong recently, apparently were caught in an ebb tide of selling yesterday. Prices plunged sharply in active trading, with March beans down 4 cents a bushel to close at $2.50.
Traffic on Madison Avenue was speeded up yesterday by the introduction of a new city regulation that cleared a curbside lane for buses between 34th and 59th Streets.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- House and Senate members introduced today bills to create a Federal institute to devise better ways for dealing with juvenile offenders.

Higher interest rates on individual savings accounts, a basic restructing of banking in New York and a higher mortgage lending rate are looming as possibilities, informed financial officials said yesterday.
Hubert H. Humphrey called yesterday for the establishment of a "health coalition," of experts in medicine and health to overhaul the nation's medical system.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 24 -The American Contract Bridge League's fall national championships continued today at the Americana Hotel, with 84 pairs contesting the final stages of the Life Master men's pairs and 60 pairs in the Life Master women's pairs.

BART STARR, the Green Bay quarterback, has a separated right shoulder and may not play anymore this season or ever. The 35-yearold Starr was hurt in the first quarter of Sunday's losing game against Detroit when tackled after running for a 6-yard gain.
NEWARK, Nov. 24 -- The exact fare system for Newark's major city and suburban bus line went into effect today with a minimum of confusion and grumbling.

CARACAS, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- Trans-Atlantic airlines agreed today to reduce round trip passenger rates between New York and London. An excursion ticket would be $250 and group fares $170 each during the winter, the International Air Transport Association announced.

Lou Piniella, traded by Seattle to the Kansas City Royals April 1, was named American League rookie of the year yesterday by a panel of 24 baseball writers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A former Army private who was at Songmy when Vietnamese civilians were allegedly slain by American soldiers last year expressed doubt today about the accurancy of reports of a massacre in the village.
ORIGIN -- On April 30, 1921, the Port of New York Authority was created by a compact between New York and New Jersey.

In the weeks when Bake Turner knew that he wouldn't be playing much, if at all, on Sunday, his concentration would wander during practice. But yesterday, as the Jets' offensive unit began serious preparations for Sunday's game with the Oakland Raiders, the mustached country singer was working with the first team.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office said yesterday that the sentencing of a real estate operator on two counts of attempted perjury that grew out of a possible effort to bribe a member of the City Planning Commission had been postponed.
The American Stock Exchange gave thanks a day early yesterday as the majority of stocks listed ended in the win column for the first time in 14 sessions.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 26 -- Australia's only steel maker, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, Ltd., announced today it would fight an American move to penalize it for alleged dumping of steel in the United States.
The Penn Central Company's directors decided yesterday to omit a dividend payment for the fourth quarter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A plan to upgrade the auto safety program's status in the Department of Transportation has been handed to Secretary John A. Volpe by a special consultant.
ROME, Nov. 26 -- Pope Paul VI once again called upon the faithful today to "prepare" themselves for the "new mass," which goes into effect in Italy Sunday.
MAX FRISCH'S hilarious oneact tragedy "The Firebugs" contrasts the morally neutral caution of an amiable, self-centered middle-class couple with the savage ambitions of two incendiary fanatics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -The White House said today that an incident such as the alleged Songmy massacre "is in direct violation not only of United States military policy, but is also abhorrent to the conscience of all the American people."
For just a moment, the St. Peter's basketball coach, Don Kennedy, was reminiscing about the loss of his star forward, Elnardo Webster, through graduation.
The stock market did something different yesterday. For the first time in 13 sessions, the New York Stock Exchange was able to display more advances than declines.

The equanimity with which we have taken the news of the atrocities committed by our troops at Songmy is a measure of what this war has done to us. Our men in arms have turned into monsters, and the most we can do is to call for an investigation: the guilty parties, we say, must be found and punished.

SOME time ago Barry Mahon, a well-known maker of nudie films, decided to toss in the Mother Hubbard. In a dramatic switch, he transformed his company, Fanny Hill Enterprises, into a maker of children's films.
Three men were arraigned here yesterday, on charges of trying to steal watches at Kennedy International Airport.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Nixon Administration was understood today to be planning to appoint a chief negotiator at the Vietnam peace talks in Paris in the immediate future to succeed Henry Cabot Lodge.

FOR exactly one hour last night, Dick Gregory stood before a capacity house at Carnegie Hall and produced laughter on the whole scale from cachinnation to snickers as though he had learned to play the human lung as surely as an organist plays his pipes.
Judge Inzer B. Wyatt yesterday dismissed a blackmail charge against Roy M. Cohn and one of his former law partners.
VIENNA, Nov. 26 -- In a broad purge of progressives, 62 deputies in the 200 - member Czech state legislature lost their seats today.

For the third time in six years Congress may have to pass a compulsory arbitration law next week to head off a nationwide railroad tie-up. That likelihood arises out of union warnings of whipsaw strikes Wednesday by 48,000 railway shopcraft workers.

A major revision of public broadcasting in New York, designed to conserve limited funds available to noncommercial television, is quietly being discussed by the boards of directors of National Education Television and station WNDT (Channel 13).

The New York Philharmonic, entangled in a racial discrimination hearing since last July, was forbidden yesterday to fill two vacant positions until the city Commission on Human Rights completes its investigation.

Kenneth T. Gordon, who smokes a pipe as he plays golf, has been nominated to be president of the Metropolitan Golf Association. An active member of the organization's executive and rules committee since 1958, Gordon currently is vice president of the M.G.A.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -Young people's demands that President Nixon declare an "environmental emergency" precipitated a parliamentary skirmish yesterday in the final minutes of the 13th national conference of the United States National Commission for UNESCO.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 26 -- A young veteran said today that he had killed about 10 persons, including a woman, during the alleged massacre at Songmy, South Vietnam, on March 16, 1968.
An extra chromosome that mentally retards about 250,000 Americans, afflicting them with Down's syndrome, or mongolism, continues to baffle scientists despite 10 years of intensive research.

NEWTOWN, Conn. -- Nestled under a wooded hill in the outer reaches of Fairfield County is a simple brick and shingle house. Inside the house is an interesting atavism: four generations of a family living together in comparative amity.

NEW CANNAN, Conn., Nov. 26 -- Six private residences and the Little Red Schoolhouse, all decorated for Christmas, will be open to visitors Wednesday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on a tour arranged in behalf of the Garden Center of New Canaan.

Harvey Aluminum, Inc., reported yesterday that its net income for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 was $15,394,901, including a net gain on investment of $5,689,724 and an investment tax credit of $631,430.
The Nippon Light Metal Company, the biggest aluminum producer in Japan, said yesterday it would spend more than $60-million to add 180 million pounds a year to its smelter capacity.
Willie Sutton, the convicted bank robber known as "The Actor," cleared a legal hurdle yesterday in his bid to get out of jail after 17 years.

REGINA, Saskatchewan, Nov. 26 -- In a move that may have repercussions in the United States, Europe and Asia, the province of Saskatchewan told its eight potash producers today that they must sell potash mined after Jan. 1, 1970, for not less than $18.75 a ton in United States funds.

State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday that he thought he could defeat United States Senator Charles E. Goodell for the Republican nomination for Mr. Goodell's post, but he said he had not decided whether to enter the primary.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- The Chamber of Deputies, Italy's lower house, today defeated a last-ditch attempt to block a pending divorce law. The 322-to-290 vote opened the way for the bill's approval Saturday. Never has such legislation been so close to passage in 10 attempts dating from 1881.

SEATTLE, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- A process known as "in-vivo neutron activation analysis" is being used at the University of Washington School of Medicine to determine the quantity of various bodily elements in humans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The House Banking Committee will open hearings next Thursday on proposed legislation designed to curb the use of secret foreign bank accounts to conceal illegally acquired funds, dodge taxes and circumvent securities trading laws.

ALCALA DE HENARES, Spain, Nov. 26 -- Sallow, tousled and hollow-eyed after eight months' imprisonment; the Duchess of Medina-Sidonia came through the metal doors of the women's jail at noon today, a plaid suitcase in each hand.

Thanksgiving, 1969, will be observed across the country today amid religious cermenoies, rich repasts, rock 'n' roll, reunions, spectacle, probably fair weather and the fearsome consequences of careless driving and improper food preparation.

The simultaneous ratification of the nuclear nonproliferation pact by the United States and the Soviet Union makes it virtually certain now that the treaty soon will be in force. The United States has been waiting for Moscow, which has been waiting in turn for West German signature, now assured by the new Brandt Government in Bonn.

WHERE have all the rich hippies gone? All those gypsy skirts and wild colors that had been dominating the fashion scene are back in the closet or on the way to the thrift shop -- where they'll probably be bought by real hippies.
PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Falling temperatures and rising tempers brought a French power strike to a premature end this morning.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 26 -- The State Supreme Court, Westchester County, ruled today that a special meeting of Pergamon Press, Inc., called for this month, cannot be held.

PROFESSIONAL football will allow little time for consuming turkey today. Four games are scheduled and all will be televised here beginning with the Lions-Vikings contest at Detroit starting at 12:15 P.M. over Channel 2.
REGGIO DI CALABRIA, Italy, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- About 240 persons have won an inheritance battle that lasted 101 years and involves land valued in the millions.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- The letter on Coach Tom Cahill's desk was from Daisy, Tenn. and contained a diagram of the play that would beat Navy Saturday in Philadelphia.
At least 12 real estate concerns and salesmen have been charged or are about to be charged by the state with blockbusting in sections of Brooklyn and Queens.

The Grand Ballroom at the Plaza was decorated last night in green and white, traditional colors of the Junior League of New York, for the league's 21st annual Debutante Ball. The event honored 29 of its provisional members and benefited its welfare fund.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--Following are statements on the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese civilians issued today by Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary; by Stanley R. Resor, Secretary of the Army, as presented to the Senate Armed Services Committee and edited by the Army, and by Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Armed Services Committee:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The White House said today that it was closing down 19 consular posts, 17 of them in the Western Hemisphere.
Ernie Koy's plight with the Giants can be summed up in one sentence: He plays less than Pete Gogolak.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 -- Wayne Trimm, the father of Steven Trimm, a 21-year-old sentenced to four years in prison for refusing induction into the armed services and officially listed as "missing," said today that he believed his son had committed suicide.
PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The price of gold on the free market recovered slightly today after sharp drops Monday and yesterday had brought it within 25 cents of the official price of $35 an ounce.

The United Neighborhood Houses, which has administered Neighborhood Youth Corps programs in member settlement houses for the last four years, yesterday criticized the program as too superficial to develop the employability of undereducated and unskilled youths.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -The Office of Education announced today that it was starting an investigation into the administration of Federal school funds for the disadvantaged, following charges that the funds had been widely misused and diverted from the poor in many areas of the nation.
Dick Cavett has been signed by the American Broadcasting Company to take over the latenight show being vacated by Joey Bishop, starting Monday, Dec. 29.
The adult world has begun its holiday trek to the toy counters, with the difficult task of selecting gifts from objects that go ma-ma, bang, boom, whizz and whir.
EAST MEADOW, L. I., Nov. 26 -- A 23-year-old father of three who had been arrested on two felony charges was found hanged in his cell at the Nassau County jail here early today.

" I don't think any country in the Middle East is in the mood to nationalize or move in such a manner as to make operations by the international oil companies impossible," David Barran, managing director of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, said yesterday.

The string quartet that played a Beethoven program last night at the Hunter College Playhouse was not open to the charge of not having played together enough to be a truly homogeneous group. The four members are brothers, and all play in the Philadelphia Orchestra, William and Robert as violinists, Joseph as violist and Francis as cellist.

MANY farmers in the lower Mississippi River Valley are planting fish instead of seeds and are finding it profitable. The crop is the channel catfish, a widely distributed species that can grow to 50 pounds and more.
DETROIT, Nov. 26 -- The automobile industry gave a second and confirming signal today that car sales, a major prop in the economy, are in trouble.

BONN, Nov 26 -- West Germany will sign the treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons on the understanding that it will leave the nuclear capacity of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization unimpaired Conrad Ahlers, the Government spokesman, said today.

SAIGON, Nov. 26 -- American officials who have been studying battlefield activity during the last three weeks say that the enemy appears to be preparing an intensive winterspring campaign designed to wipe out recent gains achieved by the pacification program and to demoralize the South Vietnamese Army.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange turned firmer yesterday after Tuesday's sharp drop. Small buying pushed prices ahead over a broad front, although volume was small.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- United States foreign trade continued to show a surplus of exports in October, although less than it had in September, the Commerce Department reported today.
Dr. Bernard Bucove said last night that he intended to resign as the city's Health Services Administrator by the end of the year.

TOKYO, Nov. 26--Premier Eisaku Sato returned from his visit to Washington today and assured his people that Okinawa would remain free of nuclear weapons after it reverted to Japanese administration in 1972. He also held out an olive branch to Communist China.

William T. Cahill, New Jersey's Governor-elect, said yesterday he opposed the use of any Port of New York Authority surpluses to subsidize the mass transit system here.

Levychkin, met for a long talk described as "more than just a routine visit."

If you're in your 50's or 60's, or perhaps even in your 40's, you should be giving some attention to your insurance coverage after retirement.

A group ministering to the needs of narcotics addicts in Central Harlem is demanding "total community control" over Mount Morris Park, including the soon-to-be-completed outdoor theater and recreation center there to which the composer Richard Rodgers contributed $150,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Government's composite index of "leading indicators" of the economy dipped in October after a surprise rise in September, the Commerce Department reported today.

Officers of the Metropolitan Opera Association repeated their assertion yesterday that the contract offer given musicians and artists on Tuesday was final, and that there was no more money to be offered.

PAUL MORPHY, the New Orleans chess genius, traveled to England in 1858 in pursuit of a match with England's best player, Howard Staunton. Though the Englishman evaded a challenge, Morphy was paired with London's top echelon, among whom was a young bookkeeper, H. E. Bird.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A union official renewed today a strike threat that could precipitate a nationwide railroad shutdown next week.
The Police Department got 66 new sergeants and 21 new lieutenants yesterday in a promotion ceremony at the Police Academy, 235 East 20th Street.
OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Three men, one carrying a shotgun, held up the Old Westbury branch of the Bank of Westbury this morning and escaped with $33,617.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -Siamese twin girls were successfully separated today by a team of pediatric surgeons in an operation that took nearly 10 hours from the preparation to final closing.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- For most of his long life, Sigmund Freud refused to sit for a portrait or sculpture. He thought the process tedious, a waste of time.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Gen. Duong Van Minh was quoted here today as having denied that he had meant to say that the people of South Vietnam should pick a new Government by referendum in preference to any other form of popular consultation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- It may take as long as a year to dispose of the nation's existing stockpiles of bacteriological weapons in accordance with President Nixon's pledge yesterday that the United States would never engage in the use of germ warfare.
A record $33,000 was paid yesterday by Irwin Weinberg of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., for a 24-cent 1918 United States air mail stamp that has its center, a biplane, inverted.
TRENTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A lawyer for two reputed Mafia leaders has charged the State Investigations Commission is using "barbaric" methods on his clients.

ROBERT CASADESUS is 70 years old. When he was half that age, the distinguished French pianist made his American debut as soloist with the New York Philharmonic. Last night in Philharmonic Hall the orchestra observed both anniversaries by presenting him in the dual role of solist and composer.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26 -"What's all the fuss?" someone dared ask today in a room full of Naval Academy football coaches, crewcut athletic directors and ram-rod-spined officers. "Navy has won only one game, lost eight and scored 98 points to the opposition's 280, while Army has won three and made just four touchdowns in its last three games."
HOUSTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A box filled on the moon with rocks by the Apollo 12 astronauts was opened tonight at the Lunar Receiving Laboratory.
Clifford M. Svikhart has been elected senior vice president in charge of the metropolitan division of the Irving Trust Company.

HILTON HEAD, S. C., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus, gunning for the No. 1 spot on the money list, and Arnold Palmer, desperately trying to break a year-old slump, are the heavy favorites in the first Heritage Golf Classic, which starts tomorrow.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 26 -- The United States and the Soviet Union held their fourth working session on limitation of strategic arms today with continued signs of satisfaction on the way the talks are progressing.

A city proposal to combine a 500-car parking garage with public housing in one building in the Lincoln Center area was challenged yesterday as being in conflict with the city's own plans.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 26 -- A 21-year-old Bronx printer was held without bail today on a charge that he murdered a Times Square prostitute, whose beaten and bound body was found floating in Manhasset Bay off Kings Point last month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today on a television program that the United States had been encouraged by the initial discussions with the Soviet Union in Helsinki on possible limitation of strategic arms.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 27 -- The South Vietnamese military command announced today that 567 Government soldiers were killed in action last week, the heaviest weekly toll since the Paris peace talks began 18 months ago.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26 -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia expressed confidence in an editorial today that the Helsinki arms talks and the ratification of the ban on the spread of nuclear weapons would help curtail the arms race.

An ecumenical institute that planning to push for a civilian review board on national defense spending held its first major fund-raising effort at the New York Hilton last night in honor of Cardinal Cooke.

Queen of Peace of North Arlington completed a perfect 9-0 season won-lost record yesterday as Tony Riposta scored three touchdowns and passed for a fourth in a 35-8 victory over Pope Pius at Passaic.
BOSTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) -Bobby Orr scored two goals and added an assist to lead the Boston Bruins to a 6-4 victory tonight.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- Argentina overshadowed a strong United States team today to take the first two places in the fifth race for the world Lightning Class yachting championship.

STARKVILLE, Miss., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Archie Manning scored twice and threw two touchdown passes today as Sugar Bowl-bound Mississippi overpowered Mississippi State, 4822. The Rebels tallied four touchdowns in the final quarter.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The People's Republic of Southern Yemen nationalized 36 foreign concerns today, including four British banks, the chairman of the Presidential Council, Salem Ali Rubaya, announced.
ATHENS, Nov. 27 -- The Greek Government promised that no new taxes would be levied and gave a 5 per cent raise to state employes and pensioners as it introduced its 1970 state budget today.

The Plaza had another of its father and daughter nights last evening, events common to the Thanksgiving and Christmas debutante season. Yesterday's party was the Gotham Ball, an annual benefit for the New York Foundling Hospital.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 28 -- United States military spokesmen reported yesterday that American battle, deaths last week were the highest in two months.

BONN, Nov. 27 -- Communist sources reported today that a high-level Warsaw Pact meeting would begin Tuesday in Moscow, with policy toward the new West German Government of Chancellor Willy Brandt as the main item on the agenda.

Spouting a plume of water 450 feet above the East River at the southern tip of Welfare Island, the city's newest monument -- the Delacorte Fountain -- will be dedicated Monday.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 27 (Reuters)-The Belgian Government has run into stiff opposition from industrialists over a proposal to cut exporters' earnings, informed sources said today. The clash came when Economic Minister Edmond Leburton, outlining a Government package of anti-inflation measures to a meeting of employers and trade unions, said the Government planned to introduce an export tax on an export deposit plan, the sources added.

TOKYO, Nov. 27, (Reuters -- The Federation of Economic Organizations predicted today the Japanese economy will continue to grow at a fast pace in the fiscal year beginning next April, achieving a real economic growth of more than 10 per cent for the fifth consecutive year.

DALLAS, Nov. 27 (AP)--A San Francisco tackle, Charlie Krueger, blocked a Mike Clark field-goal attempt, with 12 seconds remaining, tonight and the Dallas Cowboys had to settle for a 24-24 tie in a National Football League game.
A special mass for Thanksgiving was used by Roman Catholic churches in the country for the first time yesterday.

CAIRO, Nov. 27 -- Waves of Egyptian fighter-bombers, flying low over the desert in formations of 8 and 12, struck at Israeli command positions and other installations in the Sinai Peninsula this afternoon, the United Arab Republic's military spokesman announced.

HOUSTON, Nov. 27 (AP)--Scientists viewed some of the Apollo 12 moon rocks today, and the first close-up photographs of the Ocean of Storms and a spectacular film of the earth eclipsing the sun were released by the space agency.

TEEN-AGERS, who have made their mark on music, fashions, education and politics, are asking for and getting their own thing when it comes to medicine. An increasing number of adolescent clinics are springing up about the country, providing thousands of youngsters with sympathetic medical care.

The turnover of checking accounts at the nation's banks declined slightly during October, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday. The maxicoat, the fashion best-seller of the season, is as dangerous to girls as it is upsetting to girl-watchers, according to the Greater New York Safety Council.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 27 -- Gary Wichard passed up football scholarship offers from Maine and Louisville so he could have days like today in New York. The young quarterback from Halesite, L.I., led C. W. Post to a 30-20 victory over Hofstra in their annual Thanksgiving morning game.

WASHINGTON -- The efforts of the President and the Vice President to arouse support for the Administration's Vietnam policy and discredit the critics of that policy have produced a remarkable response from the people.

Theodore W. Kheel, head of the Mayor's committee to save the 20-cent transit fare, called yesterday for a major reshaping of the Port of New York Authority to force it to put greater emphasis on mass transportation.

With 49 seconds remaining, Brooklyn Tech, undefeated and untied and seeking the Public Schools Athletic League mythical football championship, was stunned into defeat for the first time when Felix Masteller of Far Rockaway caught a 21-yard pass from Mitch Sanders to give the Sea Horses a 28-21 triumph yesterday in the final game of the season for both teams.

The high cost of campaigning has again been demonstrated by the financial reports filed in behalf of Mayor Lindsay and his defeated rivals, Controller Procaccino and State Senator Marchi. Now that all the official figures are in, it becomes clear that the Lindsay edge in campaign funds was even bigger than his edge in votes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Despite a bulge in the third quarter, the indicators of defense activity are still heading downward, the Commerce Department said today.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are follwed by a recipe.
ROME, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A vice president of Trans World Airlines says his company is inspecting passengers' carry-on luggage at random to prevent hijackings.
IF Harold Koenig has his way, the creatures of land, water and air, including man, may survive the onslaught of pollution.
Twenty-two resident professional theater companies in 15 states will be receiving matching grants this season from the National Endowment for the Arts.

MANCHESTER, Conn., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Ambrose Burfoot won the five-mile Manchester Road Race today, for the second consecutive Thanksgiving Day, with a victory by 29.6 seconds over Pat McMahon of Ireland.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Barbara Castle, Secretary of State for Employment and Productivity, urged dockworkers at the Port of London today to lift their eight-month ban on handling container ships at the new Tilbury container terminal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- The average interest cost for conventional home mortgage loans increased for the 11th consecutive month in October to a record 8.12 per cent for new homes and 8.13 per cent for used houses, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.
HILTON HEAD, S. C., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer and George Archer subdued the Harbour Town links with a pair of 68's today and shared the first-round lead in the $100,000 Heritage Golf Classic.

MOSCOW, Nov. 27 -- Mikhail A. Sholokhov, winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1965, added his personal attack today to what has apparently become a campaign of official denunciation of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the author of "A Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovitch," "The First Circle" and "The Cancer Ward."
A sell-out crowd filled Madison Square Garden last night to absorb the rock sound of the Rolling Stones.
The New York Mets signed their fourth regular player yesterday when Jim McAndrew came to terms for 1970. Terms were not disclosed.
ABOARD THE U.S.S. HORNET, at Sea, Nov. 27 -- The Apollo 12 astronauts completed their debriefing today and then sat down to a traditional Thanksgiving dinner.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Sauvinet Gary of New York, Miami Beach and Madeline Island, La Pointe, Wis., gave a supper dance for more than 300 at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof last night in honor of their debutante daughter, Miss Tracy DuVivier Gary.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 27 -- Needing only one victory to set a National Basketball Association record for consecutive victories, the New York Knickerbockers were content today to reflect on the triumph last night in, Atlanta that enabled them to tie the mark of 17.
In an effort to help relieve the housing shortage, the city is seeking court orders to vacate apartments being used illegally by commercial tenants.
The London stock market had a firm tone yesterday with prices pushed upward by small buying in moderate trading.

WINTERTHUR, Switzerland, Nov. 27 -- Charging that Switzerland was pro-Zionist three Arab defendants rejected their court-appointed lawyer and refused to testify when they went on trial here today for their attack on an El Al airliner last February.

Amerigo Lady of the Rokeby Stable indicated her liking for the fast Aqueduct track yesterday when she took the $56,600 Firenze Handicap by beating Mrs. Whitney Stone's Shuvee. Before a crowd of 35,665, many of whom were attracted by the 11 A.M. early post, Jorge Velasquez steered the Rokeby mare to a three-quarter length success in the 1 1/8-mile event for fillies and mares.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The British Government has taken exception to an effort by the Executive Commission of the European Economic Community to establish its jurisdiction over a multinational British chemical enterprise.
EUREKA SPRINGS, Ark., -- This little Ozark town, which took Gerald L. K. Smith into its midst five years ago, is showing the first signs of alarm at his expanding influence over community life.

An experiment in citizen participation in public television designed to show how such involvement might influence fixture national decisions will be undertaken next week in conjunction with the first White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health.
An officer of the private sanitationmen's union whose 2,000 members collect half the city's garbage said yesterday that the strike it had threatened for midnight Sunday was "all but inevitable."
JERUSALEM, Friday, Nov. 27 -- Two Egyptian jets were reported downed yesterday by Israeli aircraft and antiaircraft fire in an exchange of air strikes across the Suez Canal.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Kansas City Chiefs scored on two 80-yard touchdown drives in the first half and on a 45-yard interception by Emmitt Thomas in the final quarter and belted the Denver Broncos, 31-17, in a nationally televised American Football League game today.
A Federal Aviation Administration plan to require a more rigorous heart test for airline pilots has stirred the threat of a walkout by the Air Line Pilots Association, which represents 30,000 pilots.
MOSCOW, Nov. 27 -- The third national congress of collective farmers approved today "model rules" for the operation of the 36,000 collective farms in the Soviet Union.
As only a novelist with a new book going for him can, Jimmy Breslin is on the road rediscovering America and he finds the state of the country worrisome indeed.
AFTER five years of popularity, the Rolling Stones are still the brashest, and consistently, one of the most exciting and entertaining groups one can hear in rock.
PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Premier Jacques Chaban-Delmas denounced the Communist leadership of France's biggest trade union tonight as subversive, then offered to negotiate an agreement with it.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 27 -- Two South Vietnamese Senate committees decided today to conduct a joint inquiry into the alleged massacre at Songmy, in which American soldiers are accused of having killed as many as 567 villagers last year.
Everybody is saying that Seton Hall is on the threshhold of an excellent basketball season, but Coach Richie Regan is not making any rash evaluations and he's keeping his fingers crossed.

President Nixon cited Histadrut, Israel's labor federation, yesterday as sharing the same goals as the United States in desiring "every citizen to be a full participant in the wellbeing as well in the work of our society."

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Nov. 27 -- More than a hundred G.I.'s serving in a field evacuation hospital here boycotted Thanksgiving dinner today in a quiet 24-hour fast designed as a protest against American involvement in the war here.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 27 -- President Gustav Heinemann of West Germany ended a fourday visit to the Netherlands today that Dutch observers feel might help to reconcile the two countries.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- Two Americans, Charlie Pasarell and Stan Smith, reached the quarterfinals today in the men's singles of the Stockholm open indoor tennis championships.
MOSCOW, Nov. 27 -- The Soviet Union and five of its six Warsaw Pact allies issued a statement today calling for "immediate measures" to settle "the grave situation in the Middle East."
SOMERVILLE, Mass. -- The facade of the three-story frame house at 113 College Avenue is an irregular pattern of large sections of dirty gray and freshly painted white.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -Col. Michael Collins of the Air Force, the Apollo 11 astronaut who maintained a lonely vigil in orbit around the moon last July while his fellow spacemen became the first to land and walk on the lunar surface, is expected to become one of the most public figures in the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The nation's gold stock rose moderately further in October, the Treasury reported today. The October increase of $26-million brought the total gold stock to $11.19-billion. The rise so far this year has been $298-million.

Edward Baruch, president of the Hell-Coil Corporation, urged company shareholders yesterday to reject a tender offer of $27.50 a share by the Mite Corporation for Heli-Coil's common stock. He called it "inadequate."

Paul Simon described his concert with Art Garfunkel at Carnegie Hall last night as "a true test of faith" because the Rolling Stones were also in town, at Madison Square Garden. Simon and Garfunkel were well rewarded for their true test: Their concert last night and a second one tonight were both sold out in advance.

It is vitally important that the events which occurred in the Vietnamese village of Songmy on March 16, 1968, be accurately established. The shocking and tragic story reported in The Times on Nov. 17, 1969, which may or may not be accurate, is reminiscent of events in the Second World War which Americans and most of the world overwhelmingly condemned.
BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- An effort by the Jewish Defense League to establish "anticrime patrols" in Boston has aroused vigorous objections among leaders of the Jewish Community Council.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 27--The former commander of the Army's 11th Brigade says he no longer is certain that his troops did not slay Vietnamese villagers at Songmy on March 16, 1968.
DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -Strikes and inventory cutbacks contributed to a 30 per cent cutback in auto production this week compared with last year, the trade publication Automotive News reported today.

In the last ten days of the mayoralty campaign the Transport Workers Union, once a mainstay of the Wagner political machine, came up with a $10,000 contribution for the re-election of Mayor Lindsay. The day after the Mayor won, the T.W.U. presented the Transit Authority with its demands for a fat new subway contract, one that could force abandonment of the twenty-cent fare.
CAPETOWN, Nov. 27 -- The continuing steep decline in the price of gold on the free market has so far failed to halt the quietly confident noises being made here in Government and financial circles.
May I, as a British Labor Member of Parliament attending the General Assembly express a personal view on the current discussion between your country and the Soviet Union on strategic nuclear weapons.

Cardinal Hayes spoiled Mount St. Michael's bid for an unbeaten football season yesterday by defeating the Mounties, 7-0, in the 27th annual meeting between the Bronx schools before 10,000 at Baker Field. It was Hayes's ninth victory in the series. Mount St. Michael has won 13 and five games have ended in ties.

A WEEK ago yesterday Dr. Frederick Logan Stone spoke in White Plains to a group of people who are active in the planned move of New York Medical College to Westchester, where the college would become part of a new, multimillion-dollar medical center.
Massapequa High won a share of Nassau County's South Shore Division I title, whipping Berner, 31-12, yesterday before an estimated 10,000 football fans.
DETROIT, Nov. 27 -- The mighty Minnesota Vikings indicated today they were winterized for the forthcoming playoffs as they beat the Detroit Lions, 27-0, in a snowstorm.

MILDRED DUNNOCK is, to no one's surprise, the joy tonight in National Educational Television's visit to the controversial Yale Drama School, of which Robert Brustein is dean. LONDON, Nov. 27 (UPI) -A British doctor who spent five years in Vietnam said today that he had seen South Vietnamese troops pass through villages and regularly set fires and loot and kill unarmed civilians.
VIENNA, Nov. 27 -- Albania today began celebrating the 25th anniversary of her liberation from her World War II occupiers amid signs of Chinese Communist overtures toward Eastern Europe.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 27 (AP) -- South Vietnamese national policemen accompanied by customs agents and United States military police began a 10day drive against Saigon's flourishing black market today.

The initial success of the curbside no-parking lane on Madison Avenue between 34th and 59th Streets is a welcome help to traffic on that congested thoroughfare as the Christmas shopping season begins. George Balanchine's "La Valse" is an eerie ballet skirting and flirting with death carelessly like a reckless duelist. Last night at the State Theater, New York City Ballet's Patricia McBride added a further chilling twist.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- A new private organization, the Minority Rights Group, announced plans today to try to focus attention on the plight of oppressed minorities around the world.
Fairfield Prep capped an undefeated season with a 36-14 victory over Stamford in the 25th annual Thanksgiving Day game between two Fairfield County powers before 10,000 spectators.
While most people relaxed yesterday morning in anticipation of the friendly family rituals that typify Thanksgiving, the Jets practiced at Shea Stadium in a taut atmosphere.
ROUEN, France, Nov. 27 -- Eskimos and an assortment of specialists about their way of life closed today a grim discussion of the chances for survival of the Eskimo culture.

Many secretaries have long been aware that one of their duties is to help their bosses buy a gift for their wives on birthdays and anniversaries. Today, however, thousands of wives are buying gifts for their husbands' secretaries -- and not only for birthdays and anniversaries.

MADRID, Nov. 27 -- Spanish officials moved today to squelch a growing tide of rumors predicting the imminent resignation of Generalissimo Francisco Franco as head of state and his replacement by Prince Juan Carlos of Bourbon with the title of king.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 27 -- The first jet plane designed, engineered and produced in Israel made its maiden flight today at Lydda Airport.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 28--An extensive Communist spy ring involving ranking members of the South Vietnamese Government was described in testimony today in the opening session of the biggest espionage trial in this country's history.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 28 -- Dr. Ernest Mandel, the Belgian Marxist who was refused a visa for a United States speaking tour this week, said here today the refusal was the result of a previous visit, in which he broke certain rules of which he was not aware.

The defense opened its case yesterday in the bribery-conspiracy trial of Roy M. Cohn and two co-defeendants by calling character witnesses to testify on behalf of John A. Kiser, a former law partner of Mr. Cohn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A little-known six-man committee created recently within the framework of the National Security Council is expected by many Administration officials to play a central role in shaping American military and foreign policy.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 28 -- The United States and the Soviet Union held their fifth working session on strategic arms limitation today and agreed to a three-day recess for analysis of the complex material discussed in the first two weeks of the preliminary talks.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Chicago's second-ranking police official said today that he was attacked by a leader of the demonstrations outside the Conrad Hilton Hotel here Aug. 28, 1968.

HILTON HEAD, S. C., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Tom Weiskopf posted a course record 65 today and barged into a tie with Arnold Palmer for the second-round lead in the $100,000 Heritage Golf Classic.

Emile Francis has a problem, but it is one whose solution can have only a pleasant meaning for the New York Rangers.

THE group of women that trooped into the downstairs hall of the renovated Brooklyn brownstone were not on just another tour of houses. There was something else they had come for as they stood there peering around expectantly, until their hostess, Mrs. Robert Snyder, ushered them into the dining room, where the wide pine planking shone under its new coat of varnish.

JACQUES D'AMBOISE gave Melissa Hayden a hug. Miss Hayden gave Mr. d'Amboise a hug. A sold-out house at the State Theater gave both of them an ovation. Miss Hayden received a bouquet of chrysanthemums and Mr. d'Amboise got a wreath, which he slung over his shoulder like a French brigadier general.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Europeans might be expected to take some grim satisfaction these days at the troubles of their rich and powerful ally across the Atlantic. But the Vietnam massacre reports, on top of all the other recent American tragedies of violence and social conflict, have in fact produced almost no such schadenfreude.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -William E. Schuyler Jr., who took office six months ago as Commissioner of Patents, is reorganizing the Patent Office, effective Monday.
THE New York Antiques Fair opening Monday will be showing Christmas gift possibilities that include a 19th-century English cameo glass vase for $22,000.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Nov. 28 -- The Apollo 12 astronauts and their spacecraft, Yankee Clipper, which took them on man's second voyage to the moon, were delivered to United States soil today by the aircraft carrier Hornet, which lifted them from the Pacific Monday.

WASHINGTON (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration said today the December issue of the magazine Caper was being recalled by its publishers because it contained directions for a test that could prove fatal.
Denny's Restaurants, Inc., the food-franchising organization, disclosed yesterday that it would revise its previously released financial results for the fiscal year ended last June 27.

GENEVA, Nov. 28 -- The World Health Organization said today that over 20 years of experience had proved that the fluoridation of drinking water was the most effective weapon available for preventing tooth decay.
Ted Sizemore, a catcher who became an infielder and then played in 159 games last season for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was voted the National League's rookie of the year yesterday.
HOUSTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) -Geologists reported puzzling differences today between the noon rocks brought back by the Apollo 12 astronauts and those from Apollo 11.
Mrs. Carol Greitzer, a trim brunette with flashing dark eyes, has declared "a women's war" on restaurants that close their doors to women.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 28 -W. E. Durner's Corn Caster and Thomas S. Nichol's Lesjo, each the winner of a division of the Congressional Handicap two weeks ago, will be after their second successive stakes victories tomorrow when they oppose 12 other grass-course specialists in the 1 1/2 miles of the $20,000-added Laurel Turf Cup at Laurel race course.

Systems Engineering Laboratories, Inc., announced yesterday it has agreed in principle to acquire the Spectral Dynamics Corporation of San Diego through an exchange of stock valued at approximately $11.5-million.
The stock market produced its best performance in three weeks in a slow session yesterday that saw the glamour issues steal the show.
VIENNA, Nov. 28 -- A hard-line Communist took over today as chief of the Czechoslovak press agency C.T.K. in a new purge in the communications field.
