WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Railroad, union and Government officials began marathon wage bargaining talks today in an effort to head off the threat of a nationwide shutdown next week.
The Police Department appointed 163 new sergeants last night and cut out nonemergency overtime pay throughout the force to make money available for the promotions.
WELLINGTTON, New Zealand, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- A large turnout is expected tomorrow when New Zealanders vote in the first general election in three years.

NEWARK, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- New Jersey judges now cannot order a defendant out of the courtroom just because he is wearing an African dashiki. In fact, they can not "arbitrarily fix either the required or prohibited courtroom dress," according to a special ruling from the administrator of New Jersey Courts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- The drug industry complained today that proposed new Federal regulations would only cause trouble and would not improve the quality of drugs or protect consumers.
TRENTON, Nov. 28 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ordered the State Banking and Insurance Company today to hold further hearings on its denial of a 20 per cent increase in automobile insurance rates.

It was with some dismay that I read the account in The Times of Nov. 22 of the television appearance of Mrs. John N. Mitchell. What this lady chooses to say on television would be of small consequence were it not for the fact that her husband holds a high and influential office in the Nixon Administration. So her views, one supposes, reflect his opinions. She even expressed comments which she directly attributed to him.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that it had rejected a request by Milton J. Shapp that it deny WFILTV, Philadelphia, a renewal of its broadcast license.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee made public today a committee-sponsored poll showing strong approval of the way Vice President Agnew is handling his job and supporting his attack on the television networks.
COLOGNE, West Germany, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- A press photographer, Heinz Sutterlin, 45 years old, was sentenced to seven years in prison today for having handed over state secrets to the Communists.

SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 28 (AP) -- A Superior Court judge granted today the request of Southeastern Massachusetts University trustees to enjoin the Student Senate from interfering with the holding of classes.
William R. Erbland, oboe, and Richard W. Volpe, piano, presented a program of music for their instruments last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.
GROTON, Conn., Nov. 28 -- Construction began today on the Silversides, the Navy's 100th nuclear-powered submarine.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- Proposals for a three-acre recreation park and an eight-story office building were presented to delegations of the United Nations today as part of an $80,000,000 expansion program for the United Nations enclave.
BONN, Nov. 28 -- The West German Government today signed the treaty sponsored by the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union to prohibit the spread of nuclear weapons.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 28 -- Israeli sources said today that the Greek authorities had been warned of the likelihood that Arab terrorists would bomb the El Al airline office in Athens but had done nothing about it.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Before the first play is run in today's Army-Navy football game, the cadet coach, Tom Cahill, will search John F. Kennedy Stadium for some significant sign to build a dream on.

The Federal Reserve System, in the face of gathering evidence that the pace of economic expansion is slowing substantially, appears to be following a slightly less restrictive credit policy than has been characteristic recently.

The separation of Steven C. Rockefeller and the former Anne-Marie Rasmussen, whose marriage 10 years ago was celebrated as the culmination of a modern Cinderella story, was announced yesterday by a spokesman for the Rockefeller family.

Bronx merchants were warned yesterday by the people who ought to know -- the United States Secret Service and the New York City Police Department -- that they were in for a new flood of counterfeit bills, bad checks and shoplifting with the advent of the Christmas shopping season.

ROME, Nov. 28 -- Tens of thousands of metalworkers from throughout Italy converged on Rome today in a disciplined, orderly demonstration that probably marked the high-water point of an autumn of major agitation by labor for higher wages and social reforms.

CAIRO, Nov. 28 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser will meet with the revolutionary leaders of Libya and the Sudan next month to study measures for strengthening economic, cultural and military cooperation, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -A Philadelphian's method of precasting concrete houses has been used to produce about 5,000 low-cost homes in Jamaica. Kreier Jr., who built the concrete molds for the new Metropolitan Opera House in New York City, was granted patent 3,479,786 this week.

Penn State and six other bowl-bound teams take final tune-up tests today in preparation of post-season competition as college football's 100th regular-season campaign comes to a close.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- At least three women are among those being considered for nomination to the Supreme Court now that Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. has ibeen rejected, Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today.

There is only one viable way out of Italy's worst political crisis of the post-Fascist period. The crucial question is whether the leaders of the democratic parties and factions are yet alarmed enough by the crisis and concerned enough for the fate of democracy to behave responsibly.

An official of the Port of New York Authority charged yesterday that Theodore W. Kheel's call for a major reshaping of the two-state agency was "clearly an effort to find a scapegoat" for an increased subway fare.

TRENTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed a bill today providing a $15,000 salary increase for the next Governor and $11,000 for most state department heads.

IT is rash to speak of certainties in this uncertain world, yet it is safe to say that you can't go wrong with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. New Yorkers apparently have already discovered this.

A recent Associated Press dispatch, based on information from the United States Treasury, disclosed how some oil industry groups have used foundations to deprive the Government of more than $100 million in tax revenues in each of the last two years. A check of the more than thirty foundations involved showed that they had contributed under $150,000 to charity last year, less than one-tenth of one per cent of the money they handled.

The help-wanted index dropped sharply in October, the National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday. The index, which had reached a peak of 235 per cent of the 1957-59 average in September, fell to 227 per cent last month.

YONKERS, Nov. 28 -- Almost any day now the identity of the harness horse of the year will be disclosed. SINCE we have now entered the Thanksmas Season (which used to be two seasons with a lot of things to do in between), it is time to start compiling lists of "outstanding," "bests," "mosts," and year-end reading recommendations. Doing this to books has always seemed to me like lining up a frog, a dugong, a waterbug, and a puma, and telling them, "First one to the outhouse and back is King of the Beasts.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 30 -- Conservationists here took 50 members of Stamford's incoming city administration on a boat tour of the harbor today in an effort to convince them to purchase the city's last remaining stretch of undeveloped shorefront for use as a public beach.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- George C. Wallace, the former Alabama Governor, said on a nationwide television program today that President Nixon must win a military victory in Vietnam to insure re-election in 1972.

LONDON -- When an enterprising tabloid discovered the other day that the Queen's ceremonial horses were being sold off in old age to provide steaks for Continental horsemeat fanciers, there was an almost audible national gasp.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 -- Steel producers are still betting on continued strong demand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -The Los Angeles Rams overcame Sonny Jurgensen, the Redskins' threatening passer; a flag-dropping crew of officials, and the odds against winning 11 straight games in the National Football League today as they beat Washington, 24-13, and clinched the Coastal Division title.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 30 -- The leaders of the six nations of the European Economic Community meet here tomorrow for a two-day conference that is expected to set Europe's pattern for the seventies.

MEXICO CITY -- At a busy street corner in Old Mexico -- where a plaque says that Montezuma Xocoyotzin, lord of the Aztecs, first met Hernando Cortez, the Spanish invader, 450 years ago -- massive machines are removing earth for a subway line.
MOSCOW, Nov. 30 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, attacked today the Israeli contention that Soviet Jews should be free to emigrate to Israel.
Tom Keating's silver football pants lay on the floor of the Oakland Raiders' locker room, blotches of dried blood decorating the material above both knees.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 30 (AP) -- After his team had lost an 18-point lead, Oscar Robertson went on a late scoring spree and brought the Cincinnati Royals back to a 115-107 National Basketball Association victory over the Philadelphia 76ers today.

The decision of the Defense Department to shut down Air Force bases in Suffolk and Orange Counties for reasons of economy offers a splendid opportunity to convert these ready-made facilities into much-needed airports for general aviation. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has properly asked that they be turned over to it for this purpose.

EAST NORTHPORT, L.I., Nov. 30 -- Pat Gibson's Midnight Flight won the Long Island High Score Award Association championship in the regular working hunter division today by finishing as reserve title holder in the Cherry Meadow Horse Show.
HOUSTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Very early scientific data from Apollo 12 indicates the moon may be a much more complex body than scientists at first believed.

THERE is a special joy in a great repertory theater company -- whether it is drama or ballet -- for the regular audience. It is the joy of being a member of a club. The company members become our actors, our dancers and yes, in a way, our friends.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Greece's representative to the Council of Europe described as "shocking and deplorable" today the publication of the confidential findings of the council's Commission on Human Rights.

Jacques Abram gave a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon that was full of solid pianistic virtues. His tone ranged from round and bold to pearly soft, his fingers were equal to the speediest passages, his sense of piano sonority was strong.

LEV POLUGAYEVSKY of Moscow and Alexander Zaitsev of Vladivostok finished in a tie for first in the 1969 Soviet championship at Alma-Ata last July. They were willing, then and there, to settle for a joint title.

MIAMI Beach, Nov. 30 -The Dallas Aces, who will represent the United States in the 1970 world team championship, held a narrow lead today going into the final session of the Reisinger team championship, the concluding event of the American Contract Bridge League's fall national championships at the Americana Hotel here.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 30 (AP) -- F. Lee Bailey said today he wanted Capt. Ernest L. Medina to go on television to tell his story.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell disclosed yesterday that he was suffering from enlarged lymph glands and would enter a hospital this week for a series of medical tests "to determine how serious the disease is."
City Finance Administrator Fioravante G. Perrotta called yesterday for New York State income tax reforms without awaiting Federal action, but a leading business group opposed such a move.
The American Film Institute will begin to operate a 300-seat theater at the National Gallery of Art in Washington for the screening of motion picture classics on Jan. 17.

A fund-raising goal of $10,102,500 for health and welfare programs sponsored by Histadrut, Israel's labor organization, was set here yesterday at the close of a four-day convention of the National Committee for Labor Israel.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 30 -- The Foreign Ministers of Italy and Austria reached agreement here today on an accord to end a long-standing dispute over the Alto Adige, which is administratively known as Bolzano Province.
Carlton Sellers quietly escaped from Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday just after he had been arraigned on a narcortics charge and held in $5,000 bail.
Thirty inmates and six guards at Rikers Island Prison were injured last night during a brawl that broke out during a movie, The Associated Press reported.
SOMETHING that looks like green pea soup in the Fritz Weaver home may be just that -- or it may be a sample of the Hudson River water Mrs. Weaver is studying.

Howard J. Samuels, a former Under Secretary of Commerce, said yesterday he was prepared to wage a primary fight if the Democratic State Committee designated Arthur J. Goldberg as the party's candidate for Governor.

ROME, Nov. 30 -- The agreement in Copenhagen between the Italian and Austrian Foreign Ministers on autonomy measures for the German-speaking province of Bolzano closes, officially at least, a 50-year dispute.

Apollo 11 and Apollo 12 have vividly demonstrated what a huge "lunar gap" now separates the United States from all other countries. A dozen Americans have already orbited the moon and four of them have worked on its surface.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A chance drawing tomorrow night will determine which young men of hundreds of thousands will be drafted into military service and which, by luck of birthday, will be left free to work, study and lead uninterrupted civilian lives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Profits of up to 1,403 per cent were made by a California-based manufacturer in a series of 22 small Air Force contracts, according to a report by the Controller General, made public today.

CHICAGO -- Elementary wisdom sometimes dictates unpleasant conclusions to the novelist Saul Bellow -that the species is mad, or that we are harried by the unworthy, or that we deserve no better fate. But he is in favor of seeking wisdom.

IN this age of spare little knits and pants suits and clingy jersey dresses, there is one group of women that seems to have been forgotten. The larger women of the world.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -November, London's traditional month of pea soup fogs and smog, ended today with a cloudless sky and sunshine.
REGINA, Saskatchewan, Nov 30 -- In a throwback to the money panics of the turn of the century, wheat barter has reappeared in this grain-growing province.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Jerry Hansen and Scooter Patrick, seasoned drivers who alternate between professional and amateur status, won too titles today in the final round of the American Road Race of champions.

DENVER, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Medical authorities called for better equipment and more instruction as means of reducing injuries from increasing popular winter sports today.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Silvino S. Trompetto, maltre-chef of the Savoy Hotel, just turned out his very first batch of brownies. They were nice, too. But it was a bit of a bore, the chef confided, having to work out the British equivalents of the American measurements in the recipe.

ROME, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- A philosophy professor, Aldo Braibanti, accused of brainwashing two youths, has had a nine-year prison sentence reduced to four years by an appeals court. He will be released this week.

Contracts for future construction work in the United States rose in October, but the rebound of this prime economic indicator was regarded by at least one economist as not indicating a failure of the Federal Government's tight-money policy.

TRENTON, Nov. 30 -- Twentyseven men have volunteered to patrol unarmed at night in the streets of this city's North Ward, where three persons have been murdered recently and several others have been mugged.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 30 -- A 10 1/2-pound bundle of rich reddish hair continued invincibly along the show circuit tonight in the third and largest event of the Boardwalk Kennel Club. The dog was the Pekingese, Ch. Dan-Lee Dragonseed, owned and handled by Michael Wolf of North Babylon, L. I. The best-in-show award was made by Theodore S. Gundersen of Ottawa.

Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson exhibits uncommon naivete when he writes (letter, Nov. 24) that the term "war foes" surely includes all of us. It surely doesn't. GEORGE BELLAK'S new play, "Sadbird," is a muddled effort to extract laughter from a young man torn between the uninhibited life of free spirits yearning for a hippie commune and a niche amongst the squares of the Establishment. ROME, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The controversial new Roman Catholic mass, approved by Pope Paul VI but criticized by some church conservatives, went into effect today in all Catholic churches in Italy.

Laura Nyro, a 22-year-old singer and songwriter who has developed an avid underground following during the last two years, emerged from the shadows to give two concerts at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.

The appointment of a special task force by United States Commissioner of Education James E. He was in a mood of bleak despair over the necessity for war, asking Cobb over and over: "What else can I do? Is there anything else I can do?"
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Government has opened a publicity campaign to prepare Argentina's 23 million citizens for the shock of switching their currency.

The debut last evening of the National Broadcasting Company's network correspondent Frank McGee as 6 o'clock news anchorman for N.B.C.'s station here underscores television's constant competition for audience.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Peter Magnus Flanigan is possibly the least known of President Nixon's dozen or so top aides, but, according to sources here, he played a bigger role than any of his Colleagues in what may go down as Mr. Nixon's best known legislative achievement of 1969: the new draft reform law, under which draftees will be chosen by lot for the first time in a generation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Stirrings of discord from opposite directions arose today as nearly 3,000 delegates started arriving for the three-day White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health, which begins tomorrow.
The City Club calls it a failure, the police call it a success, traffic experts say it is an absolute necessity and the Automobile Club of New York calls it an exercise in futility.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- American competitors won six gold medals today during the first day of competition at the Pan-American Wheelchair Games.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, has suffered a partly incapacitating stroke and his condition is considered serious though he is not in danger, his office said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright charged today that the Defense Department was spending millions of dollars on "public relations" programs that promote military activity rather than merely furnish information about it.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 1 -- The New York Mets lost Jack DiLauro, the left-handed relief pitcher who contributed to their triumphant season, and the New York Yankees lost Tom Shopay in baseball's annual draft of minor league players today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The policy board of the largest Jewish campus movement criticized today what it termed "indiscriminate condemnations" of the campus generation.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- A 100-foot-deep canyon stretching five city blocks between the State Capital and the Governor's Mansion is slowly filling with steel, concrete, marble and glass that give shape to the South Mall complex of office buildings Governor Rockefeller has planned for since 1959.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 1 -- The National Rifle Association of America and a world trade association of fur dealers were balked today in their attempt to gain membership in an international conservation organization dedicated to saving wildlife from extinction.
The president of one of New York's largest bookstore chains said yesterday that professional thieves had become an important source of books for some of his fellow dealers.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- Twenty-two black Africans went on trial before the Supreme Court today on a charge of having revived a banned revolutionary organization.
Buck Rogers, for nearly 40 years a syndicated wanderer in space, is flying again because a City College professor and a Manhattan publisher judged his grounding to be premature.

The city's Department of Sanitation will be ordered to pick up refuse at restaurants and other commercial establishments that have been struck by private sanitation-men, wherever the Health Department or Fire Department certifies that an emergency exists.

New York society received an A for deportment and a B plus for matrimony during the year, according to a spot check of the annual report card issued yesterday by the which published the 84th edition of the New York Social Register.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 1 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted today to let the county buy 77 new buses for four county bus lines.
LONG BEACH, Dec. 1 -- An unlikely but coincidental coalition of antiwar groups and home owners is shaping up here to protest napalm production.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 1 -- The militant An Quang Buddhists ended a three-day convention of laymen here today in which they attempted to mold themselves into the sort of potent political force they once were.

TRENTON, Dec. 1 -- High Federal law enforcement officials reported today that alleged ties between Internal Revenue Service agents in Newark and organized crime had help to stall a Federal investigation of the Mafia in New Jersey earlier this year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--With Administration encouragement, it he House began consideration today of a resolution supporting President Nixon's efforts to negotiate a "just peace" in Vietnam.

Charles F. Luce testified in Federal Court yesterday that when he became chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Consolidated Edison Company on Aug. 1, 1967, one of his first undertakings was an effort to obtain city permission to rebuild a transmission line from Westchester.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Federal Trade Commission accused the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today of a broad range of deceptive advertising, including misrepresentation of the safety of some tires.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A statue of Sir Winston Churchill, who once described himself as "a child of the House of Commons," was unveiled today in the Members' Lobby of the House.

The Senate Commerce Committee is scheduled to consider today a bill that would establish the nation's first Federal subsidies for intercity rail passenger service. The bill calls for expenditure of $409-million over the next four years.
Price increases were announced yesterday for nickel-bearing stainless steel, following major advances last week in the quotations for primary nickel.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 1 -- Turkey has excluded planes carrying Communist military aid to Arab countries, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. The Communications Ministry issued an order forbidding shipments last week, he added.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday rejected the "solution" that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority describes as the only way to save the shaky 20-cent transit fare.

NEW PERTH, Prince Edward Island -- Reginald Mellish, a farmer who raises potatoes, tobacco and cattle, barely suppressed a grin when a passerby asked his opinion of this tiny province's new 15-year development plan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Gen William C. Westmoreland, former United States military commander in Vietnam, says the war probably would be over if the United States had continued its bombing of North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- With the new draft system we will eventually have an Army in which everybody has the same birthday. Oh, not quite everybody, of course. In a force of 500,000 men -- the present size of our Vietnam contingent -- the entire group might have as many as nine or ten different birthdays.

The White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health, opening in Washington today, has been a controversial undertaking of uncertain focus. The White House has screened-in some panelists and screened-out others; groups representing consumers and the poor have been alternately outraged and placated. There lingers some doubt that the paradox of hunger in a land fat with agricultural surpluses will receive the emphasis it deserves.

BOSTON -- If you wanted just one signal piece of evidence for the regional theater's ever developing vitality I would offer you Boston's Charles Playhouse and its production of Edward Bond's "Narrow Road to the Deep North."

The appointment of John Elliott Jr. to serve as chairman of the 1970 American Red Cross Greater New York fund-raising drive has been announced by James E. Evans, chairman of the agency's executive board.

Most pianists in the midst of a complete cycle of the Bach Clavier Concertos would stay home and practice between concerts. Rosalyn Tureck, who is decidedly unlike most pianists, came to Carnegie Hall last night and played Bach's Goldberg Variations.

District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens said yesterday that the problems of financing a nine-month campaign had forced him to leave the ranks of "unannounced but active" candidates for Governor.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- Tass, the Soviet press agency, announced today that the leaders of the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies would meet here soon to discuss "topical international problems."

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 1 -- A man who said Bobby G. Seale, head of the Black Panthers, had ordered him to kill a Panther suspected of being an informer for the police pleaded guilty today to second-degree murder in the slaying.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee struck down today a House-passed provision granting $54.5-million to Nationalist China for a full squadron of the most modern United States jet fighter aircraft.

In refreshing contrast to the turmoil elsewhere on the bargaining front is the tentative agreement reached early yesterday in the laundry industry. The pact not only keeps intact 33 years of strike-free relations between the commercial laundries and the Laundry Workers Joint Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers; it also represents a substantial contribution toward raising the standards of the working poor.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- A special grand jury returned indictments today charging 29 persons in connection with Chicago street violence during demonstrations organized last October by the activist "Weatherman" faction of Students for a Democratic Society.
The Council on Foreign Relations, whose discussions have affected foreign policy since its founding in 1921, has decided to admit women to its ranks for the first time.
Mayor Lindsay has been asked to create a new system under which most parking violations would be taken out of Traffic Court and put under the jurisdiction of the Transportation Administration.

His coat size is 50 extra long, his shirt measurements 19 1/2-36. He is 6 feet 5 inches tall, weighs 285 pounds, but talks in soft, sensitive tones about spending autumn afternoons walking alone along a "dinky, old river" around South Bend, Ind.

BESIDES the big, fat cigar that Tommy Williams smokes there is something else that sets him off from other National Hockey League players -- he was born in the United States. Williams, one of three or four Americans among the more than 200 players in the league, said yesterday that warfare among amateur hockey leagues and the colleges was to blame for failing to produce more American players.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers Union, proposed today that defense contractors be required to set aside a quarter of their profits to help them shift from wartime to civilian production after the Vietnam war.
TOKYO, Dec. 1 -- Finance Ministry officials here are concerned that a sharp rise in Japan's foreign exchange reserves may increase speculative pressure for upward revaluation of the yen.

Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's University basketball coach, yesterday urged coaches throughout the nation to rally against the National Collegiate Athletic Association ruling that prevents quintets from playing in foreign countries during the off season.

Creating dances for a vast hall like Madison Square Garden makes special demands on the choreographer. Movements should be vigorous but not so fast as to blur at a distance, gestures open but not woodenly broad.

Gino's, Inc., the fast-food operation based in King of Prussia, Pa., has just finished a week of listening to pitches from half a dozen agencies and has chosen N. W. Ayer Son, Philadelphia, as its new shop. The billings are estimated at from $2.5-million to $3-million.

TRENTON, Dec. 1 -- The overwhelming Republican majorities in the Legislature overrode a veto by the Democratic Governor, Richard J. Hughes, and enacted a head tax tonight of $1 on domestic outbound flights at Newark Airport.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The prosecution and the defense in the pending court-martial of First Lieut. William L. Call Jr. asked the United States Court of Military Appeals today to ban all further pre-trial publication and broadcast of statements and photographs concerning the alleged massacre at Songmy, South Vietnam, on March 16, 1968.

The Nine O'Clocks dance club had its highly publicized "Turn of the Century Party" complete with tiaras, upswept hairdos, enormous hats and extravagant costumes at the Plaza last night, and as Sam LeTulle observed somewhat wryly. "It's clothes, clothes and more clothes -- more for the women than the men."
Prices on the American Stock Exchange posted a modest advance during the first hour of trading yesterday, but the market then swung down and closed with a sharp loss. Trading remained quiet.
This thing about 11 being a lucky number is all relative. Take Iona's basketball team, which had 11 victories and 11 defeats last season. That was bad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The rate on the six-month Treasury bill declined sharply while that on the three-month bill declined only slightly at today's auction from last week's levels, 91-day bills today was 7.453 per cent, down from 7.476 per cent last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Frank Sinatra won a temporary restraining order today to stop the New Jersey Investigation Commission from seeking to indict him for failing to testify in an inquiry into organized crime.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate voted today to reduce the depletion allowance for oil and gas producers to 23 per cent, thus insuring that the final version of the current tax reform bill will cut the allowance to at least that level.
The president of the Haryou-Act Community Corporation, Marshall England, yesterday joined in demands that Mayor Lindsay appoint a black or Puerto Rican as Deputy Mayor.

The Knicks will be starting all over again at the bottom of the hill tonight when they face the Seattle SuperSonics at Madison Square Garden. For only the third time this season, they have no winning streak to protect.
City officials said yesterday that a scuffle between two prisoners with a long-standing grudge set off a panic at a crowded movie showing on Rikers Island on Sunday night.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 1 -- The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the Singapore Government have reached agreement on establishing a major aircraft repair and maintenance facility intended, among other things, to service United States military aircraft from all over Asia.

GENEVA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A further reduction of the trade deficit sluggish purchases by the United States and large exports to the rivaling European Common Market area marked the first nine months of the European Free Trade Association, EFTA, this year.

PARIS, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- A lawyer representing an undentified buyer bid 500,000 francs ($145,000) at an auction today for the old wooden building where the artists Picasso, Matisse and Utrillo, and poets Max Jacob and Apollinaire lived or gathered.

A FORM-FITTING suit for slender, form-conscious swimmers has made the crossing from France to Bonwit Teller's seventh floor. It is the Eres swimsuit -- soft pliable and frequently very brief. The only uplift it is capable of giving is to the morale.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm yesterday despite the paring of early gains. Toward the close of the session, the Financial Times index of 30 industrial stock was up 1.3, to 387.2.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Twelve years ago Frank Norman was released from prison and started to win favor with middle-class readers as a straight-talking guide to the London underworld. Perhaps out of gratitude to the institution that gave him so much material, he has written "Inside Out," a play amounting almost to an affectionate portrait of British prison life.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 2 -- With a storming final session, the team of Ira Rubin of Paramus, N. J., Philip Feldesman, William Grieve and Jeff Westheimer, all of New York, captured the Reisinger team championship that concluded the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals at the Americana Hotel last night.

THE road to the Super Bowl for the New York Jets is strewn with bobby-traps, and the impression keeps growing that the Shea Stadium tenants are alarmingly unaware of the danger they are in. Within the span of 15 days the Jets faced the best in the West, the Oakland Raiders and the Kansas City Chiefs.
CANTON--A Chinese teenager's main course of study is the thought of Mao Tse-tung. His education is, first and foremost, political.

ATHENS, Dec. 1 -- Greece today barred Palestinian Arabs with temporary travel documents from entering Greece. The action followed a terrorist attack on the Athens passenger terminal of the Israeli airline El Al last Thursday, which resulted in the death of a Greek child and injuries to 14 other persons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said today it would put new standards for softwood lumber into effect next March 1. The move will end a long-drawn-out debate that included two unsuccessful attempts to write new guidelines.

State and city officials, joined by lawyers, staged a demonstration in the Bronx yesterday to call attention to the deterioration of the borough's Criminal Court building and to press for immediate construction of a replacement.
Barbra Streisand said yesterday she was considering a complaint to the city's Commission on Human Rights about her being rejected by a Park Avenue cooperative apartment house.

AN accurately forbidding and often heartbreaking documentary on the impotence of the United Nations to outlaw war and protect the human rights of every individual has been put together by Arthur Zegart of National Educational Television.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- An Assembly committee hoping to draft tax reform legislation next year received conflicting advice today from elected officials and representatives of business groups.

FRANKLINTOWN, Pa., Dec. 1 -- Field Trial Champion Dansmirth's Gunshot, 4-year-old male owned, bred and handled by Daniel K. Langhans of Morton Grove, Ill., became the 1969 national amateur champion today in the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association's seventh annual amateur stake.

Jimmy Ellis has changed his mind about a showdown bout with Joe Frazier that would settle the heavyweight title situation, according to Harry Markson, the president of Madison Square Garden's division of boxing.
Pakistan's President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan has set a prudent example for other military rulers with his move to restore democratic civilian rule in his country.

The closing of marginal and losing units plus other operating efficiencies enabled Swift Co. to lift earnings 36 per cent to $21,572,000 in the 53 weeks ended Nov. 1 from operating earnings of $15,825,000 before an extraordinary charge to cover plant-closing costs in the 52 weeks ended Oct. 31, 1968.
Strong prices marked silver and copper futures trading yesterday, and a broker described the push upwards as "a leapfrog effect."

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 1 -- Milton J. Shapp, liberal reformer who upset the Pennsylvania Democratic party organization and its candidate for Governor in the 1966 primary, announced today that he will again seek the Democratic nomination next spring.
High interest rates once again made it difficult yesterday for major states and cities to borrow the money they want.
YOU can never tell what you're going to find in some people's attics or storerooms.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The futures of young men across the country were decided tonight as, one by one, the dates of their births were drawn in the first draft lottery in a generation.
The nation's largest banks have attacked, in the strongest possible terms, the Federal Reserve Board's proposal to block the sale of commercial paper by bank holding companies.
Negotiating committees for musicians and performing artists of the Metropolitan Opera reviewed the management's final offer yesterday and discussed possible counterproposals.
LET'S SAY you are a corporate executive and in spite of tight money you're on the acquisition trail.

DENVER, Dec. 1 -- Meliodosis, a tropical disease that mimics tuberculosis, has infected about 150 American helicopter crewmen, pilots and soldiers returning from Vietnam in the last three years, an Army doctor said here today.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, Dec. 1 -- Saudi Arabian and Southern Yemeni air and ground forces have been battling for the last 24 hours near the border outpost of Al Wadeea, according to reports issued here and Saudi Arabian radio broadcasts.

Aliens in the United States must report their current addresses to the Immigration and Naturalization Service during the month of January. Persons who are out of the country at that time should file their addresses on their return.
Wet snow and chilly rain fell here yesterday causing hazardous conditions on several bridges in the city and on some roads in the suburbs.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Coordination of United Nations aid to poorer lands under a single, powerful authority was urged today in a report that said the present assistance system was as slow and as unwieldy as "some prehistoric monster."

RICHMOND, Dec. 1, (AP) -- Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. will go to Washington this week to confer with President Nixon on whether he will remain as chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit today ordered 16 school districts in six Southern states to have integrated school systems ready for full operation by the fall of 1970.

The United States Department of Labor, badgered for many months by irate women unable to obtain satisfactory domestic help, has decided to ease its restrictions on the entry of available foreign labor.

A "North Vietnamese Army area commander" was captured during the controversial American attack on Songmy village in South Vietnam and admitted his identity after a confrontation with Capt. Ernest L. Medina, the captain's civilian lawyer said yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 -- Black Protestants began a campaign today to elect the Rev. Albert B. Cleage Jr., a Detroit pastor known for his assertions that Jesus was black, as the next president of the National Council of Churches.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Cost overruns of $16.2-billion in the military's 34 major weapons programs have been reported to Congress by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird.

ONE bit of unfinished business remains on the collegiate regular-season football schedule Saturday--the meeting between undefeated Texas and undefeated Arkansas. A number of things such as bowl spots and high or even top national ranking may be decided in the game to be televised by the American Broadcasting Company starting at 1 P.M. (New York Time).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Tomorrow, President Nixon will address the opening session of the three-day White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health, a gathering of nearly 3,000 representatives of those who grow food, make it, test it, buy it, and, most significantly, those who don't get enough of it.
PARIS, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- Young couples in France are planning their families more carefully than ever before, although one child in five is still conceived before marriage.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that his 1970 message to the Legislature would "set forth a 'full-opportunity' program to achieve for every young man and woman graduating from high school in New York State access to a meaningful further higher education."

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- On the eve of a conference of Soviet bloc leaders concerning policy toward West Germany, gloom and tension are reported to prevail in the East German leadership.

In 1836, the Federal Government -- for the only time in its history -- completed the repayment of all of its outstanding debt. Andrew Jackson, then President, signed a bill to re turn remaining cash in excess of the Government's working needs to the states on the basis of popula tion.
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- By a sly maneuver, the city of Paris outbid speculators yesterday to save the Bateau Lavoir, one of the birthplaces of modern art.
Mrs Joan Coates turned on a faucet of the sink in her Harlem apartment then gasped in horror. The water she had drawn appeared to be swarming with tiny worms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The State Department has refused to grant a visa to a Pakistani student activist in Britain, officials announced today, because he burned an American flag in front of the United States embassy in London during an antiAmerican demonstration a week ago.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Big European investors were warned tonight by a Federal Reserve governor, Sherman J. Maisel, that monetary conditions in the United States were expected to remain stringent even if output declined.

Barbara Streisand's exclusion from a Park Avenue cooperative apartment house led State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday to call for the enactment of legislation in Albany to bar discrimination on the basis of occupation.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 -- The Los Angeles grand jury voted today to begin taking evidence Friday in the case against three suspects in the Sharon Tate murders.
PARIS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Charles de Gaulle passes his days writing and thinking of death, according to a man who says he knows the former President well.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Don McGinnis's brilliant goaltending and the all-round play of a defenseman-center, Curt Bennett, led Brown to a 3-1 hockey victory over Boston University tonight.
After rising sharply on Monday, prices of silver and copper futures fell back yesterday in active trading.

SALEM, Mass., Dec. 2 -- In an atmosphere of crisis, the student editors of the campus newspapers at six of Massachusetts' state colleges gathered here recently in the small cluttered office of the Salem State College Log.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, will benefit from a champagne reception and the premiere of "We Want to Live," a multimedia exhibition about children in Israel, at the New York Cultural Center, formerly Huntington Hartford's Gallery of Modern Art, at 2 Columbus Circle, on Tuesday night.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 2 --A small pro-Communist offensive in central Laos has reversed gains made by Government units in September near the Ho Chi Minh Trail of supply routes into South Vietnam.
DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- The automobile industry disclosed today for the first time information o nthe braking and passing ability of its cars.

Western Union International, Inc., announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to purchase for $25-million the telephone-answering services in the United States of International Utilities Corporation, a large holding company with headquarters in Toronto.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Despite the enormous oil discoveries in the Prudhoe Bay Field of Alaska, the international oil industry will remain centered on the tension-ridden Middle East, three prominent oil executives agreed today at the European Institutional Investor Conference.
ALBANY, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A convicted murderer who blurted a confession to the police is not protected under the Supreme Court guidelines against involuntary confessions, a state court ruled today.

A combined study on air pollution and auto traffic that is expected to affect the future design of urban highways in the United States and other heavily traveled parts of the world got under way on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- American Newspaper Guild employes of The Washington Post approved today a new contract that will raise top minimum salaries by $67 a week to $300 over 22 months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The United States Court of Military Appeals declined today to issue an injunction directing the news media to cease publication of statements and photo graphs by witnesses to the alleged massacre of civilians at Songmy, South Vietnam, on March 16, 1968.
LONDON, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -British gold and dollar reserves did so well in November that the Government has repaid some overseas debts before repayment became due, the Treasury announced today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 2 -Al Fatah has embarked on a campaign to explain to the Lebanese the goals and strategy of the Palestinian fight against Israel.

TROY, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- A former president of the Union National Bank of Troy made a spirited attempt here this afternoon to defeat a plan to merge the bank into the Bankers Trust New York Corporation bank holding company system.

DENVER, Dec. 2 -- Children who accidentally swallow a few tablets of a commonly prescribed antidiarrheal drug can get severe breathing difficulty, lose consciousness and sometimes die, a Denver neurologist said here today.

HOUSTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -Eleven persons have been ordered into isolation with the Apollo 12 astronauts after a rubber glove being used to examine moon rocks ruptured under pressure.

Overcrowded conditions at the Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx have resulted in the uncontrolled use of drugs, homosexuality and inadequate recreation and education, a legislative committee was told yesterday.

JOHANN SIMON MAYR, known in Italy (where he spent most of his career) as Giovanni Simone Mayr, was a well-thought-of-composer of his day. He was born in 1763, died in 1845, composed some 60 operas of enormous popularity, and was promptly forgotten.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -In what loomed as an oldfashioned political donnybrook, President Nixon today dismissed Raymond H. Lapin from his post as president of the giant Federal National Mortgage Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The tide of battle over President Nixon's $2.6-billion foreign aid request favored the Administration today as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee temporarily set aside an attempt to scuttle the House-passed $2.2-billion authorization measure in favor of a simple continuing resolution.
LIMA, Peru, Dec. 2 (UPI) -The Indians who live in Peru's high Andes are able to work in cooper mines at altitudes up to 17,000 feet where other people can hardly breathe, much less swing a pick.

Four steel companies adopted a formula yesterday that will result in slightly lower prices for some flat-rolled products, following the lead of the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's biggest producers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Federal Government should assume "full financial responsibility" for all public assistance programs, including Medicaid, the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations urged today.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -- Duplicating machines belonging to the United States Information Service were used to print 2,000 secret documents for use by a clandestine black African nationalist organization, the Supreme Court was told here today.

NEWARK, Dec. 2 -- The Passaic Valley Sewerage Commissioners will take Federal and state officials on a boat tour of the Passaic River Friday in an effort to answer a charge that the agency is responsible for most of the pollution in New York Harbor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -With hundreds of thousands of young men having learned their place in the draft sequence from last night's lottery, draft boards began today preparing for the January call-ups.

THE Polish director Jerzy Skolimowski made "Identification Marks: None," his first film, in 1964. It was shown at the Third New York Film Festival, and in 1968 it opened at the New Yorker Theater, but was not reviewed at that time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Businessmen plan to push their expenditures for new plant and equipment still higher through the first half of 1970, the Commerce Department and Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
RICHMOND, Dec. 2 -- Lawrence Douglas Wilder, a 38year-old lawyer, today was elected as the first Negro to serve in the Virginia Senate since 1890.
TOKYO, Dec. 2 -- Premier Eisaku Sato dissolved the House of Representatives today and scheduled general elections Dec. 27.
A second defendant completed his case yesterday in the bribery-conspiracy trial of Roy M. Cohn and two of his former associates in Federal Court.

TRENTON, Dec. 2 -- Union County Judge Ralph DeVita was summarily suspended today pending a hearing on charges rising out of a sworn statement by the Somerset County Prosecutor and a transcript of a telephone conversation between the two.
PEKING, Dec. 2 (Agence France-Presse) -- New restrictions have been placed on the freedom of movement of foreigners who live in Peking.

Dr. Benjamin Spock, the pediatrician whose antiwar activities have gained him a certain familiarity with law enforcement authorities, met the police again yesterday in a new role: He was a guest lecturer, speaking about dissent to an audience whose members were mostly policemen.

SONGMY, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 -- Riding on Army tanks, three South Vietnamese Senators visited today the site of the alleged massacre of a village by American soldiers. They were accompanied by survivors.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union is helping Cuba equip her armed forces with the "newest weapons and military equipment," the armed forces newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda said today.

BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The growth of a 20-year-old man who had stretched to 7 feet 2 inches and was still growing has been halted with the help of a new technique developed at Massachusetts General Hospital.

YONKERS, Dec. 2 -- For the first time in his 23-year career as a harness-racing driver, John Chapman attained tonight one of the sport's most treasured goals -- 200 winners in one season.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 2 -A young Brazilian former medi cal student, who had gone underground, apparently to join a guerrilla group late last year, was arrested as a ter rorist recently. Four days later his body was returned to his family.

" On Tuesday, June 3, Franz Kafka died in the Kierling Sanatorium near Vienna . . . [He] was 41, a man of ethereal refinement of spirit and crystal clarity of mind, a poet whose fame will only be experienced by posterity, a Jew of deepest bonds with Judaism, a glowing Zionist."
DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- The American Motors Corporation and the Kaiser Industries Corporaiton formally signed an agreement, previously announced, to sell Kaiser Jeep to A.M.C.
A platoon of young and not-so-young men moved into the top executive suites of several major American corporations yesterday in actions designed to broaden management and facilitate company growth.
Christa Ludwig's recital at Carnegie Hall last night was an extraordinary event in the swift-moving, highly charged concert life we take for granted here.

The Bangor Punta Corporation earned $6-million from operations, or $1.44 a share, in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, down from $7.3-million, or $2.40 a share, earned the year before, according to yesterday's preliminary report issued by David W. Wallace.

MUHAMMAD ALI, also known as Cassius Clay for stage purposes, is heavyweight champion of the world, by right and dignity if not by name, and he is beautiful. "Buck White," the new musical that opened at the George Abbott Theater last night, is not quite so beautiful, and this is a pity.
The city has lost $1.7-million in interest payments it was owed by the state because it failed to file a claim on time, a State Court of Claims judge held here yesterday in a rare ruling.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 2 State Senator Ernest P. Kline, Beaver Falls Democrat, became today the second candidate for the party's nomination for Governor in the primary election May 19.

Bernard Zuckerman, the Brooklyn international master, took the lead in the 20th United States Chess Championship when he drew with Larry Evans of Las Vegas, the defending champion, in the second round.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 29 -- The citizenship of more than 250,000 Malaysia residents has been cast into doubt by a recent Government decision to review the original registrations made under a special provision in the Constitution.
COUNT the companies that have raised their dividends every year for 20 years running and you will find slim pickings.

As guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Philharmonic Hall, Stanislaw Skrowaczewski presented a program that was slightly offbeat without being unconventional. He began the evening with the Concerto for Orchestra by his fellow Pole, Witold Lutoslawski.

FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla., Dec. 2 -- An investigation into the importation of foreign guns into the Untied States has centered on an Atlanta businessman and an Air Force lieutenant colonel. One objective of the investigation is to determine if the guns were destined for "subversive elements."

The revelations of indiscriminate killing of civilians by U.S. troops are shocking. But the self-debasing expressions of feelings of shame in the press and in private conversation indicate a fantastic naivete. In which war, especially a modern war, have innocent civilians been spared? [Editorial Nov. 30.]
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -Ignoring Administration objections, a strong bipartisan bloc in the House called today for shifting control of Federal antipoverty programs to the states.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 2 -- The leaders of the European Common Market, with President Pompidou of France in grudging agreement, said tonight they were prepared to open negotiations with Britain and other countries seeking membership.
RICHMOND, Dec. 2 -- A Federal appeals court here ordered today total integration of five school districts in Virginia and North Carolina by Jan. 31.

The power and the glory of the city's Health Department, diminished over the years, will shrink even further next year when it relinquishes its clinics and all other operations that involve direct personal care.

WALT EISENSTARK and Dick Klein of Yorktown Heights, N. Y., are pretty good night owls of a sort. They took the over-all honors in the Outpost Touring and Sportscar Club 300-mile rally that ended early Sunday morning with a total of 74 points.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda said today that West German investment in Austria violated her neutrality.

The simple and specific two-step desegregation order by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit wipes out whatever ambiguities the advocates of "Southern strategy" foot-dragging may have wished to read into the law.

Recalling that back in May he had said "the moment is at hand to put an end to hunger in America," President Nixon proceeded to tell the White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health yesterday that "I not only accept the responsibility -- I claim the responsibility."

Nathan Brand, who made his recital debut last night a Carnegie Recitel Hall, is at the moment a very excited young pianist who could develop into an exciting one. Mr. Brand tended to play as loud and as fast as he could too much of the time.
The 10th annual dinner dance of the Order of Lafayette will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Monday.
Federal programs to build new housing for low-income and moderate-income families have come to a complete halt here, city housing officials said yesterday.

Senator Charles E. Goodell, of New York, who faces a fight for the Republican nomination for re-election, said last night, "I don't know how long I will be in public office, but I will not abandon my principles."

MRS. William P. Rayner and Mrs. Ahmet Ertegun, both members in good standing of the beautiful international people, got their Christmas plum early this year. They have been retained by Saks Fifth Avenue to redecorate the store's fifth floor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Fish and birds such as the bald eagle, peregrine falcon and brown pelican face a continuing threat from DDT residues even though the pesticide is on its way out, according to several wildlife experts.
SAN DIEGO, Cal., Dec. 2 -Mayor Lindsay urged today that small cities join the bigger ones in an effort to win massive aid from Federal and state governments.
The long-delayed plan for a Transportation Administration as the city's eighth super agency and with a special role in mass transit planning neared final approval yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health "sets the seal of urgency on our national commitment to put an end to hunger and mal nutrition due to poverty in America," President Nixon said today in a speech opening the three-day conference.
A major revision in the securities industry's system of compensation is taking shape on Wall Street, and it probably will have a significant impact on brokerage-house profits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller, who described Senator Goodell recently as "one of the brightest, ablest men" on the political scene, said today that this applied not just to New York State but to the national political scene as well.

Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut will receive the Award of Honor of the Foundation for Child Mental Welfare at the group's annual Santa Claus Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Sunday.
Joy tempered by apprehension was expressed yesterday by relatives who learned of the impending release of three American helicopter crewmen downed in North Korea while on a training flight.

A witness wearing a black hood to shield his identity because of a reported $25,000 price put on his head by the Mafia outlined his criminal career yesterday before the State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Army announced plans today for the removal of all lethal chemical - warfare munitions from Okinawa to a storage site in Oregon.
A half-century-old cafeteria in the Municipal Building has come upon hard times because the introduction of coffee carts has resulted in a decline in patronage.
Yields on highest-quality corporate bonds topped 9 per cent yesterday for the first time in American financial history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -"You can't fight every one of these things," the silver-haired Senator told a reporter the other day. "I allow myself just three major issues a year, but on those three I try to count for something."
Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell for the second consecutive session yesterday in light trading. Declines outnumbered advances as 653 issues eased and 232 rose.

HELSINKI -- If you except one arm of northernmost Norway, Finland is the only European country touching the Soviet Union which is not governed by a Communist regime. Its social and economic systems are based on free enterprise; its politics embrace several parties; its trade is diversified; and even its heavy weapons are purchased from both East and West.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 3 -- The nation's railroads and their shopcraft unions were reported close to agreement on a new contract at 3 o'clock this morning.
Thanks to his own ability and some round-the-clock workouts by Dick Strickland's harrows, Rudy Turcotte was able to ride six winners yesterday at thawed-out Aqueduct.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 2 -- Excavations in the Jewish Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City have revealed what is considered to be the earliest depiction of the Menorah that burned in the Second Temple.
DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- Henry Ford 2d said today that "it is abundantly clear that the auto industry needs to develop virtually emission-free vehicles as quickly as possible."
David Black is not inviting New York drama critics to review his next Broadway attraction, "Paris Is Out," a new comedy by Richard Seff starring Molly Picon.

Willie Sutton, who once said he robbed banks "because that's where the money is," stood ashen and frail in a Brooklyn court yesterday as he listened to a decision that could lead to his release from prison next week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2 -One of the most interesting paradoxes in America today is that Harvard University, the oldest institution of higher learning in the United States, in its 333rd year, is now engaged in a serious debate about what a university should be, and whether it is measuring up.
NAHA, Okinawa, Wednesday, Dec. 3 -- Widespread relief was voiced by Okinawans today over the announcement in Washington that "all toxic chemical munitions" on the island would be removed.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange recovered after a weak opening yesterday. Most issues closed around the preceding day's levels.
Channel 13 and the New York business community are working on a plan to train office workers and middle management personnel modeled after the station's school participation program.

The City Council has unwisely bowed to the organized pressure brought on it by the Detectives Endowment Association in voting to grant tenure to men who have spent six years in the detective division. Mayor Lindsay should veto a measure that might seriously impair the efficiency of one of the key crime-fighting units of the Police Department.
PARIS -- Bill Coleman is about halfway through writing a book -- the untitled memoirs of a jazz trumpet player.
PANMUNJOM, South Korea, Wednesday, Dec. 3 -- Three American helicopter crewmen walked back to freedom today after having been held in North Korea since Aug. 17.
With a minimum of fanfare, the stock market sank yesterday to its lowest level in nearly three years, as measured by its most popular barometer.
