SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Zeroing in on 30 targets overnight, enemy gunners killed more Americans than in any 24-hour period since August, the United States command said today.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 2 -- The policy of monetary restraint put into effect about a year ago to check accelerating inflation still has not accomplished its goal and should be continued, Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, said here today.
The Curtis Publishing Company went back into the magazine publishing business yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Senate, for all practical purposes, stopped arguing today over whether to reduce taxes by increasing the $600 personal exemption and agreed to vote tomorrow on how quickly the exemption should be increased to $800.
Sales of new cars fell in the Nov. 21-30 period and during November as a whole, the nation's auto manufacturers reported from Detroit yesterday. It was the second consecutive monthly decline.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Dec. 2 (AP) -- A single-engine plane glided low over a heavily populated area of this Hudson River city today, clipped a utility pole and power lines, then crashed to the ground, killing the pilot as hundreds of homewardbound motorists watched.
Efforts to settle differences between the Metropolitan Opera and its performers broke up last night with both sides suggesting that the situation was almost hopeless.
I wish to take issue with your editorial on the transit question "Subway Shadows" which appeared on Nov. 7.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- The National Council of Churches faces continued cutbacks in its programs because of sagging contributions from member denominations, according to the Rev. A. Leroy Brininger, the council's chief financial officer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -Following is the text of President Nixon's speech today to the White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health at the Sheraton Park Hotel:

To show how inflation has set in since the National Hockey League doubled its size from six to 12 teams at the start of the 1967-68 season, the league awarded conditional franchises to Vancouver and Buffalo yesterday for $6-million each, three times the former entry fee.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Using a pocket knife for a scalpel, a United States Army surgeon removed a live grenade from the face of a prisoner while a demolition expert steadied the patient's head, the Air Force reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The House approved today by a 333-to-55 vote an Administrationsupported resolution endorsing President Nixon's efforts to negotiate a "just peace" in Vietnam.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 2 -- The world was beating a path to the door of the New York Mets today, trying to pry loose some of the young players who staked the Mets to their improbable pennant and world championship.

The Government rested its case in Federal court late yesterday against Carmine G. De Sapio and Antonio (Tony Ducks) Corallo after putting 12 witnesses on the stand during 13 days of trial. The defense will begin presentation of its case today.

EXPERT bidding is sometimes hard to understand even when no artificial conventions are involved. Three of the players were confused by the bidding on the diagramed deal, which gave rise to the funniest story of the fall national championships of the American Contract Bridge League in Miami Beach last week.

With 176 passengers --only about one-half a full load -- moving about in enormous cabin areas and an upstairs lounge, a Boeing 747 flew here from Seattle yesterday in the first public preview of what jumbo-jet airline service will be like.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Army led the nation's college basketball teams in defense for the last two seasons, permitting 53.5 points a game last winter and 57.9 for the 1967-68 campaign. Defense is the Army game as coached by Bob Knight and big signs in the cadets' dressing room proclaim this by saying: "DEFENSE."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France in a joint statement tonight pledged that the Arab-Israeli conflict "must not be permitted to jeopardize international peace" and warned that the situation in the Middle East was getting "increasingly serious and urgent."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- In much of the world's press and for many ordinary citizens the village of Songmy has become the symbol of an American tragedy, even more than a Vietnamese tragedy.
BONN, Dec. 2 -- The leaders of the Soviet-bloc states have been arming themselves with evidence to support their conflicting positions on how to deal with West Germany.
A pay-rise package that pose a delicate political problem for Mayor Lindsay was introduced yesterday in the City Council.

CHATSWORTH, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Here in the barren, boulderstrewn Santa Susanna Mountains, the persons accused of killing Sharon Tate, the actress, and at least seven other victims lived a life of indolence, free sex, midnight motorcycle races and apparently blind obedience to a mysterious guru.
The American Ballet Theater is alive, buoyant and violently living at the Brooklyn Academy of Music -- yet only for two weeks. Don't linger; go tomorrow.

Coach Red Holzman of the Knickerbockers had trouble reaching his seat on the bench last night, but when he did he was able to sit back and watch his team roll to a pleasing 129109 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics at Madison Square Garden.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- The leaders of the Warsaw Pact countries assembled here today for a foreign policy meeting that is expected to focus on a joint policy toward the new West German Government.

Hotels, restaurants and supermarkets in many parts of the city were inundated with garbage yesterday in the second day of the strike by 2,000 sanitationmen against private carters, and no talks were held between the employers and the union.

NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Dec. 2 -- "The big thing," said Ron Stewart, who appeared in the Stanley Cup playoffs 10 times for the Toronto Maple Leafs, "is confidence. Not so much confidence in yourself, as confidence in your teammates. When you know they can do the job, then you feel you can do yours."
Across the land yesterday on college campuses, in workshops and offices, young men of draft age were asking one another, "What's your number?"
SECAUCUS, N. J., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Thirty-two persons were injured today when a truck-tractor jumped a divider on a New Jersey Turnpike bridge and hit a New Brunswickto-New York City commuter bus.

Secretary of Transportation Volpe's approval of a single-runway pilot-training strip a few miles from the boundary of Everglades National Park gravely and needlessly compromises the hope that this unique preserve will be saved.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2, (UPI) -- Interest rates increased this week in the Federal National Mortgage Association's commitments to buy $120-million worth of Government-backed mortgage securities, the association announced today.

Although one of the City Center's mail-order forms now lets' it be known that Alwin Nikolais is to American dance what the Mets are to sport, it is difficult to think of Mr. Nikolais ever having been a loser.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 2 -- While managers and general managers talked over trade possibilities and club owners met privately and informally to line up positions for their business meeting that starts tomorrow, the minor leagues deliberated on technical changes in baseball law today and a host of minor transactions and job shifts were announced.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed yesterday for rate reductions primarily for customers who dial their own out-of-state longdistance calls. The reductions would total $150-million and be effective Jan. 1.

CAMP BEARCAT, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 -- When the first combat troops from Thailand arrived at this base at Longthanh two years ago in a gentle rain, they were greeted by a South Vietnamese navy band blaring out "Colonel Bogey's March."
NOTRE-DAME-DU-LAC, Quebec, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Fire raced through a wooden home for the aged today and the police said 54 persons were believed killed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Members of a panel on food safety at the White House Conference on Nutrition waged a lively debate today on food additives that are termed "generally recognized as safe."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Last Saturday a congregation of Seventh Day Adventists was held up by two gunsels during divine worship in church here. That's Washington these days. Not long ago two hoodlums with guns knocked over a classroom full of third-graders in one of the public schools.

ANGLERS and conservationists who oppose a project that would remove five million cubic yards of sand from Long Island Sound off Kings Point in Great Neck have until Dec. 27 to register their protest with the Army Corps of Engineers.

The National Association of Manufacturers -- the embodiment of the concept that the business of America is business -- was told yesterday it must get involved in solving the major problems that face the nation.

The first defense witness for Roy M. Cohn introduced a diary in Federal Court yesterday as evidence that Mr. Cohn informed the City Corporation Counsel about the alleged bribery of a city appraiser before associates of Mr. Cohn gained control of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines.

Earnings of the Carrier Corporation in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 dipped for the first time in nine years and those for the fourth quarter fell for the first time in seven years, while sales continued to set new records in both periods, according to the results issued yesterday.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 3 -- Relics of a civilization that thrived in southern Sinai 6,000 years ago have been discovered by Israeli explorers, it was reported here today.
LOME, Togo, Dec. 3 (Agence France-Presse) -- Thousands of refugees have been straggling into Togo in the last 24 hours after being ordered to leave Ghana by the Government there.

LEADING parts in television and movies and prominence as models of chic products have contributed to gains in American Kennel Club registrations for Old English sheepdogs of just under 100 to just under 200 dogs a month this year.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Nigerian forces are moving south toward Biafra's vital Uli airstrip and north to the key town of Owerri, ending seven months of lull, military sources said today.

The Board of Education began public hearings on its proposed community school district plan yesterday amid exhortations from a majority of speakers that Ocean Hill-Brownsville and other present demonstration districts be allowed to continue functioning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Federal Trade Commission has asked the Justice Department to sue the makers of Geritol for deceptive advertising.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 3 -- North Vietnamese troops were reported to have suffered heavy losses this morning when they crossed the Cambodian border to storm a South Vietnamese district town. It was the first attack by a battalion-size group -- 600 men -- since troops from the north began infiltrating into the Mekong Delta in May.
When a Trans World Airlines jetliner was commandeered to Havana Tuesday, it was the first hijacking of a United States airliner in 32 days and the first plane diverted to Cuba in 42 days.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 -- Charles Manson, the guru nomad whose followers have been sought for at least eight murders in the Los Angeles area, was bound over today to Superior Court in Independence, Calif., following a pretrial hearing. He faces charges of receiving stolen property and auto theft.
The Public Service Commission warned yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company faced the same shortage of power generating capacity next summer that led to a "brownout" last summer.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 4 -- The negotiations between the nation's railroads and four of their shopcraft unions continued early today after a 12-hour rest break earlier.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 3 (UPI) -An Air France jetliner bound from Santiago, Chile, to Paris crashed into the Caribbean and exploded shortly after take-off from Caracas today, apparently killing all aboard. Air France said the plane carried 62 persons.

The wide-ranging decisions on economic and political union just taken at the Common Market summit meeting will do as much to spur British entry as the agreement to open negotiations with London by July.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 3 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization approved political guidelines today for the tactical, or short-range, use of nuclear weapons in the defense of Western Europe against any aggression. reductions in American forces expected in the next decade, makes the use of tactical nuclear weapons almost inevitable early in any battle.
THESE cold autumn afternoons the streets are dotted with small girls in long coats. The maxi is sweeping the lower grades.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Savings bond redemptions in November exceeded sales for the 12th straight month as savers withdrew a net amount of $61-million, the Treasury Department reported today.
VIENNA, Dec. 3 -- "Our leaders may not believe in God, but they certainly are praying for a mild winter," a Prague resident told a friend here by phone the other day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The United States maintains roughly 7,000 tactical nuclear weapons under special guard within the North Atlantic alliance in the hope of deterring a massive conventional assault by the Soviet Union and its allies.

NAAS, Ireland, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Daniel B. Brewster, the former United States Senator from Maryland who is accused of accepting bribes, is seriously ill in a neurosurgical department of an Irish hospital, his wife said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Capt. Ernest L. Medina, commander of C Company at the time it is alleged to have committed the Songmy massacre, has been summoned to the Pentagon tomorrow to testify before the Army board that is investigating the original Army field investigation.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 3 -- Saudi Arabian military sources announced tonight that the Saudi Army had driven the Southern Yemenis back seven and a half miles and had retaken the border post of Al Wadeiah.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz began an investigation yesterday into the rejection of Barbra Streisand's bid for a $240,000 cooperative apartment at 1021 Park Avenue.
BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- Mayor Kevin H. White of Boston has outlined state legislative proposals for 1970 that are expected to have an impact on his possible candidacy for Governor.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday reported the latest changes in holdings by major stockholders, officers and directors of listed corporations. The reports include the following:

JERUSALEM, Dec. 3 -- Israeli commandos reported today that they had destroyed an Arab guerrilla base in southern Lebanon in response to an attack several hours earlier in the occupied Golan heights of Syria.
Losers outnumbered winners on the American Stock Exchange yesterday by nearly a six-to-one ratio as stocks declined on a broad front in quiet trading.

THE death of Richard Spero in an automobile accident Tuesday deprived the New York bridge world of one of its most popular characters. He was one of the most prominent of a group of experts who reached proficiency in the game while studying at Cornell University in the fifties.

Four gunmen, equipped with pistols and nine pairs of Japanese handcuffs, invaded a Brooklyn pawnshop yesterday, manacled four employes and nine customers and made off with an estimated total of $100,000 in cash and jewelry.

GENEVA, Dec. 3 -- The European Economic Community has replaced the United States as the "mainspring" of the continued strong expansion of international trade, according to the administration of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The State Department has granted an export license for 10,000 M-16 rifles for the Brazilian Air Force, but Brazil now seems uncertain whether she wants them.

Negotiations between Northwest Airlines and Local 550 of the Transport Workers Union, representing about 1,000 stewardesses and pursers, continued yesterday in Minneapolis where the airline has its headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Six or seven years ago, if there had been a report that France might, after all, admit Britain to the Common Market, there would have been loud cheers in Washington and much official comment.
ADEN, Southern Yemen, Dec. 3 -- Southern Yemeni and Saudi Arabian aircraft have reported bombing each other's forces in the desert along their common border for the seventh consecutive day.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 3 -- By coincidence, the oldest and the youngest of the regular tour bowlers entered in the P.B.A. national championship were paired on the same lanes from the start. The 10th annual tourney at Garden City Bowl began yesterday with 192 competitors and will end Saturday with the top 24 battling head to head.
Thirty students identified as members of an "Ad Hoc Committee to Free the Damascus Two" held an hour-long sit-in demonstration yesterday at the Syrian Mission to the United Nations.

NEWARK, Dec. 3 -- The Greater Newark Urban Coalition, from which Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio resigned last week on the ground that it widened divisions between whites and blacks, will receive the Equal Opportunity Day Award Friday night from the Essex County Urban League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The House Appropriations Committee, following the Nixon Administration's lead, applied a heavy economy ax to the military budget today and cut $5.3-billion from the $75.2-billion in appropriations requested for the Defense Department.
LONDON, Dec. 3 (AU) -- Even the disciplined ranks of the Salvation Army are feeling the effects of the generation gap. Some of its soldiers want a less authoritarian form of control.

Regrettably, the thing in shortest supply in Washington is any detailed plan for postwar reconversion.

The minimum salary for a player in the National Basketball Association is $13,500. In one of their most lucrative seasons, the entire Original Celtics' team drew $14,376, including traveling expenses.

NEWARK, Dec. 3 -- Chief Judge James DelMauro of Municipal Court was portrayed today as a "contemptuous witness" after appearing today before a Federal grand jury investigating alleged official corruption here.

Donald McMillan, national commander of the Salvation Army from 1953 to 1957, died yesterday in Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens, after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 435 West 23d Street.
