With Christmas nearing, many taxpayers with parental or grandparental pride may be thinking in terms of gifts to children. Perhaps they are considering a check, a savings account or stock certificates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- President Nixon's attempt to escape from inflation has become at least as risky and dramatic as his effort to withdraw from Vietnam. Though no one is demonstrating about it in the streets, as yet, and the telltale signs of the drama are still scattered through the general and financial news pages, the professional worriers here are now watching the economic front even more closely than Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Group violence in America poses a danger that "extreme, unlawful tactics will replace legal processes as the usual way of pressing demands," the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence said today.
The Sunbeam Corporation, a major producer of household electrical appliances, said yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the John Zink Company for approximately $24-million in stock.

Smiled on by the fates, but frowned upon by the fans, the Rangers put together an overwhelming last half and played a 3-3 tie last night with the Chicago Black Hawks, a club changed in style from an offensive dictatorship to a defensive democracy.
RICHARD VERBER, the Chicago master, playing in aggressive style against expert J. Hechtlinger won a best-game award for his performance in the recent Greater Chicago Open.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Dec. 3 (Agence France-Presse) -- President Albert Bernard Pongo reshuffled his Cabinet today for the second time in four days. Already Minister of Defense and of Information, he becomes concurrently Minister of Planning and of the Interior. Leon Mebiame, who retains his port as Vice President, takes on the justice portfolio.
The clarinetist of the Phoenix Wind Quintet, Aristides Chavez, put a tough question in music theory to his audience: "How do you think 250-year-old music would sound?"

Reflecting the tightness of German capital markets, the spot rate of the German mark advanced to its highest level on foreign exchange markets here yesterday since the upward change in the currency's parity in October.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- No matter how they might feel about Mr. Nixon's policy on the Vietnam war, most Americans probably agree wholeheartedly with that part of his Nov. 3 speech in which he declared that "the American people cannot and should not be asked to support a policy which involves the overriding issues of war and peace unless they know the truth about that policy."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 3 -- Israel today launched her largest attack on southern Lebanon in recent months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Attorneys for Raymond H. Lapin, who was discharged yesterday from his post as president of the quasi-public Federal National Mortgage Association, filed suit in United States District Court today against President Nixon, George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and members of the association's board of directors.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 3 -- South African tennis players have made a concerted appeal that the American Negro player Arthur Ashe be allowed to compete in the South African national championships next year.
Higher prices involving appliances, chemicals, metals and paper were announced yesterday by a number of companies.
New York City's Local Law 14, dealing with air pollution abatement, is a cruel hoax perpetrated upon a gullible public.

Three regional meetings held this week are expected to produce the broad outlines of a national production service for public radio stations across the country, as well as the means by which the stations will become an interconnected network.

Angel Cordero Jr. took over the star's role at Aqueduct yesterday. The rider from Puerto Rico added to his margin as the leading jockey on the New York Racing Association circuit by guiding home three winners, including Native Partner in the feature race.

Vincent D. McDonnell returned to his office from lunch yesterday after he and his aides had spent the morning arbitrating two disputes involving discharged employes and continuing mediation in a monthold strike by chemical workers. He spent an even busier afternoon.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The Court of Appeals rejected today a request by Republican legislative leaders for authority to reapportion the Senate and the Assembly in time for next year's elections.

City sanitationmen began collecting rubbish late yesterday from commercial establishments that had been certified as having fire or health hazards whil erepresentatives of both sides in the private sanitation strike met with state mediators.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 3 -- Jack Langer of Yale, declared ineligible by the Eastern College Athletic Conference in September for having competed in the Maccabiah Games, played well for the Elis tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- One of the last remaining male bastions fell today with the election of 25 women to membership in Lloyd's of London, the world's leading society of private insurance underwriters.

DENVER, Dec. 3 -- The American Medical Association today condemned the identification by Congressmen and Government administrators of doctors reviewing large fees from the Medicare and Medicaid programs.

LANSING, Kan., Dec. 3 -- Fourteen protesting prisoners slashed their arms and legs behind the grim old yellow-stone walls of the Kansas State Penitentiary last night, bringing the number of self-mutilations here to 300 since July 1.

HONG KONG, Dec. 3 -- A move to have the Governor, Sir David Trench, appointed a second term has aroused strong opposition from Hong Kong's two major Communist newspapers, which express allegiance to Peking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- President Nixon, Vice President Agnew and 40 of the nation's Governors sampled movies of simulated psychedelic "trips" and anti-Establishment rock tunes today in a morning-long educational presentation on drugs and American youth.
OCEANSIDE, L. I., Dec. 3 The South Nassau Communities Hospital will hold its 41st anniversary Carnation Bali Saturday night, at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Since the draft lottery was conducted Monday night, the national Selective Service headquarters, local draft boards and newspaper offices have been deluged with telephone calls from persons with questions about their draft status.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 3 -- The New York Mets traded Amos Otis and Bob Johnson to the Kansas City Royals today for Joe Foy in the first significant exchange at baseball's winter meetings.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Manufacturers' inventories continued to rise at a substantial pace in October while new orders declined, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Theater Development Fund, Inc., whose primary function is to help build new audiences for serious theater, has made a commitment to buy $10,000 worth of tickets to each of two forthcoming Off Broadway musicals.
Some organizational changes are in store in the second Lindsay administration for the bright and ambitious people who served as personal aides to Mayor Lindsay in his first four years.

Sarah Smyth Mansfield, retired media director for the C. J. LaRoche advertising agency, died Tuesday in Kingston (N.Y.) Hospital after a long illness. She was 65 years old and lived at 128 Market Street, Saugerties, N.Y.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 3 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotian Premier, visited the Plaine des Jarres in northeast Laos early this week for the first time in five years.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- When the Legislature convenes on Jan. 7 for its 193d session, the Senators and Assemblymen will find more than 6,000 bills ready for legislative action.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- An Edinburgh art teacher sold for $537,600 today a painting that had hung unrecognized in her modest living room for 15 years.
Silver prices eroded in futures trading yesterday, and brokers could find no specific reason beyond concern over the economic outlook.

LISTS of this sort are an exercise in arrogance, but so is book reviewing. Or fatherhood. Or disagreeing with Spiro Agnew. I employ two ground rules. The first is that I have reviewed -- I've even read -- all the books mentioned below. The second is that I feel people who haven't read these books are culturally disadvantaged and maybe even uncivilized.

" Episodes" and "The Cage," one an astringent masque and the other a blood-flecked parable, were presented for the first time this season at the State Theater, as the New York City Ballet showed three of its ranking ballerinas in top form.
McGregor-Doniger, Inc., a leading men's and boys' sportswear manufacturer, is about to name a new president in an effort to move the company more aggressively into new areas of operation.
QUITO, Ecuador -- It is fiesta time in Quito. Terrorist bombs compete with fireworks accidents for newspaper headlines and the cheers of bullfight and soccer fans drown out political oratory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A Seattle physician told Senators today that the fact that the Administration did not request increased health care funds was "playing Russian roulette with the health of the American people."
PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The meeting in the Hague yesterday may mark a turning point in European history.

The New York Times and Arno Press, a subsidiary, will republish all film reviews that have appeared in The Times from 1913 through 1968 in five volumes, with a separate index for the collection. The publication date is March, 1970.

A 500-pound, rust-colored World War II aerial bomb that neighborhood youngsters had been playing on for two years was removed yesterday from a rubble-strewn building site under the Pulaski Bridge in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans met with businessmen in Harlem early yesterday to outline Government plans to bring financial aid to minority groups. Almost immediately he ran into criticism, including a few barbs from Jackie Robinson.

Anthony di Bonaventura, who gave a piano recital last night in Philharmonic Hall, has a very good pair of hands, and one was constantly wishing he would put them to more intelligent use. In music of propulsion, as in sections of Bartok's "Out of Doors" Suite, he was able to achieve satisfactory momentum; and certainly the last movement of the Chopin B minor, Sonata went like the wind.

If you have never been to France but would like to know how a French organ really sounds -- out-of-tuneness and all -- go to St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at 53d Street, when its new rear-gallery instrument is being played.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Environmental problems in the United States were presented to European money managers today as opportunities for money-making investments in the companies that can provide solutions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Senate voted today to reduce income taxes by increasing the personal exemption for each taxpayer and each of his dependents from the present $600 to $700 next year and $800 in 1971.

TURN BINH, South Vietnam, Dec. 3 (AP) -- United States Air Force bombers pursued fleeing North Vietnamese troops into Cambodia after an enemy attack on this district town this morning and killed 65 of them, American sources reported.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Dec. 3 -- The members of the South Vietnamese Senate's fact-finding group said in an interview today that three days of investigation near the scene of the alleged massacre of civilians by American troops at Songmy had led them to believe that many civilians were killed by small-arms fire at close range.
PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The French Government approved a bill today to make stockholders of employes of the nationalized automobile and aircraft companies.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. Dec. 3 -- When George Romney became Secretary of Housing and Urban Development 10 months ago, he pledged to bring the nation the low-cost house, just as he had done with the compact car while he was president of American Motors in the 1950's.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Judge George L. Hart Jr. of the Federal District Court asked the United States Attorney here today to "study carefully" whether W. A. (Tony) Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers Union who faces a strong election challenge next Tuesday, should be prosecuted for obstruction of justice for "implying wrongful action" by the court.
The Atlantic Companies, an insurance group, announced yesterday the election of David A. Floreen as chairman and chief executive officer and Harold A. Eckmann as president, effective Jan. 1.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner has been chosen chairman of a blue-ribbon citizens commission that will study relationships of the City University to the state and city and advise who should pay for its growth. Fifteen othe members have been picked so far.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- William S. Greenawalt, a lawyer in New York City, said today that he would seek the Democratic nomination to run against the "very poor record" of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, a Republican.
Abraham D. Beame plans to drop his private business interests and ask the Board of Ethics for a ruling on any potential conflicts of interest before he is sworn in as City Controller on Jan. 1.

ALWIN NIKOLAIS'S fertile imagination has come up with still another major work. This one is called "Echo," and it had its premiere at the City Center last night. It was commissioned by the National Endowment for the Arts and is quite simply Mr. Nikolais's most sophisticated piece to date.

Guy Lombardo and his Royal Canadians finally reached Carnegie Hall last night. The orchestra arrived in town 40 years ago, and settled down in the Grill Room of the Hotel Roosevelt, where it played every winter for 33 years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Immediate emergency action against hunger won priority tonight over a proposal for a guaranteed income for the poor at the White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health.

I do not know the soldiers who allegedly killed innocent babies, women and men in Vietnam in March 1968, and only now revealed to us. All I know is that these American soldiers have been brutalized by an ungodly war and that they were brought up in our violent society.

QUANGNGAI, South Vietnam, Dec. 3 -- A little boy in a blue jockey cap picked up a toy tommy gun, jammed it low against his side and pointed it menacingly, making the plastic weapon describe an arc before him.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, told European investment managers today that the Nixon Administration was so determined to get results in fighting inflationary pressures that it was prepared to take "reasonable risks."

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A motion was filed in Federal District Court yesterday asking for an investigation, for possible judicial impropriety, of Judge Otto Kerner of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. -- The spectacle of a defiant Government executive refusing to heed a White House order of dismissal may have caught official Washington by surprise, but to those who know Raymond H. Lapin it was no surprise at all.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- Three conservation organizations have called for a moratorium on all development in the Lake Tahoe basin and threatened legal action against any land developer who refused to cooperate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Republican leader of the Senate, Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, stood on the floor of the Senate today and denounced the Administration, whose floor leader he is supposed to be.
Members of the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera voted last night to reject the management's four-year contract proposal but to accept the same offer with the fourth year eliminated.

Dr. Nathan Brown, Acting Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that despite the great amounts of money invested in special teaching programs nobody knew why certain children -- especially those in poverty areas -- were not profiting from the educational program.

As scholars concerned with Japan we feel that the Nixon-Sato communique and Premier Sato's speech at the National Press Club raise profound questions about the future direction of American policy in Asia and United States-Japanese relations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Treasury reported today that the United States made no major gold transactions in the third quarter of this year.

FRED CARR is still unwilling to tell the full story of his decision to leave the Shareholders Management Company, the parent of Enterprise Fund that Mr. Carr helped build into a billion-dollar empire.

ASA BUSHNELL, commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference, sits behind a desk cluttered high with record books, scribbled notes, athletic directories and mail. Only the commissioner knows just where to put his finger on anything on that platform of confusion in the Royal Manhattan Hotel where the conference has its offices.

Elie Siegmeister was born on Jan. 15, 1909, and his 60th year is being celebrated with concerts in various cities. New York's turn came last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, where, among other works, the local premiere of his "Theme and Variations No. 2" for piano and the world premiere of his "Four Songs" were given.

HONORS continue to accumulate for the famous college football stars such as Mike Phipps, the Purdue quarterback; Steve Owens, the Heisman Trophy winner from Oklahoma, and the two huge defensive tackles, Mike McCoy of Notre Dame and Mike Reid of Penn State.
Clare Rawson has been named executive vice president of Alloys Unlimited, Inc. He formerly was manager of the company's electronic packaging division.
The American Broadcasting Company will cancel its series, "The Survivors" in January and replace it with a dramatic show starring a survivor of "The Survivors," George Hamilton.

Franklin H. Williams, director of Columbia University's Urban Center since it was set up 18 months ago, has submitted his resignation, stating that the school was well on its way toward the goal of "turning the university around."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 3 -- United States and South Vietnamese Government spokesmen said today that they were looking into Senator Edward M. Kennedy's recent assertion that 300,000 South Vietnamese civilians had been killed in the war, mostly by American and South Vietnamese troops.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- Seven years ago, Edward Hurley found $4,990 behind a cabinet while remodeling the basement of Sam Moraca's house in Niagara Falls.

The corporate bond market staged a broad rally yesterday, spurred by the quick sellout of Tuesday's giant Pacific Telephone and Telegraph offering that provided investors with a record 9.10 per cent return.
TRENTON, Dec. 3 -- New Jersey's State Board of Education decided today to bring suit in an effort to end the reading of prayers from The Congressional Record at Netcong High School.
In a move that surprised the insurance industry, Robert E. Slater resigned yesterday as president and chairman of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted unanimously today to increase Social Security benefits by 15 per cent, effective Jan. 1.

BEEVILLE, Tex. -- When Patricia Dougherty of this oil-rich territory telephoned a friend in Dallas recently to say she would arrive for a visit with a few dozen hand-made tamales, there was unfettered glee on the other end of the line.

The new NATO guidelines for initial use of battlefield nuclear weapons, adopted by defense ministers in Brussels yesterday, confirm the recent shift to a strategy of "flexible response" emphasizing conventional forces. Long urged by the United States, it is a strategy that can be maintained only if substantial conventional forces are kept in readiness in Central Europe to balance those of the Warsaw Pact.
Robert M. Ockene, executive editor of the Bobbs-Merrill Company, publishers, died of leukemia Tuesday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 35 years old and lived at 901 Washington Avenue.

TELEVISION'S first acceptance of Vice President Agnew's challenge that the public hears too many liberal viewpoints from New York and Washington and not enough conservative opinions from the Midwest was heard from Chicago last night on "News in Perspective" over Channel 13.
Steve Wright, suspended by the Giants two weeks ago for "conduct detrimental to the club," has been reinstated, Steve Wright said yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- James Forman, the black militant leader, took his campaign for "reparations" for the evils of slavery to the National Council of Churches today and promised that the issue would continue to be a "plague on the racist white churches and synagogues."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Nixon Administration urged Congress today to repeal a law authorizing establishment of detention camps for use in internal security emergencies.

WE'RE happy to report this morning that Jack Benny's new look is the same old Benny in a Nehru jacket. The undisputed master of the slow take appeared in his annual special last night on the National Broadcasting Company network and, except for a few younger performers, the cast was the familiar one of George Burns and Eddy (Rochester) Anderson.
If American science is to survive and thrive, it must project a more positive image to the public, Dr. Lee A. DuBridge, science adviser to President Nixon, said yesterday.
Most purchasing executives agree that a business slowdown has begun, but they believe it will be so moderate and so short-lived that activity for all of next year will match or exceed 1969 levels.
ILLUSION, its need and maintenance, is the theme of John Bowen's "Little Boxes," which is called, rather carefully, I suspect, a "comedy in two parts" and opened last night at the New Theater.

AS diamonds go, it's not nearly as big as the 69.42 - carat bauble Richard Burton bought from Cartier's last month to bring a gleam to the eyes of his wife, Elizabeth Taylor. It tips the jeweler's scale at just 16.32 carats, but it's the purest pink and it brings a glow to the cheeks of Henry L. Lambert, chairman of Lambert Bros, who owns it.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- David Hilliard, a Black Panther leader, was arrested here late today on charges of threatening the life of President Nixon.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The British Government took a happy view today of the Common Market leaders' conference in The Hague.

A handful of sound technicians and nonexpert observers came to the informal conclusion yesterday that the world's largest commercial airliner will probably not be as noisy as its smaller predecessors -- just as the manufacturer has claimed.

The Nixon Administration, in urging repeal of the McCarran Act's provision for detention camps for potential saboteurs, has given Congress an opportunity to eliminate one of the truly un-American sections of a generally bad piece of legislation. Although none of the six camps established in 1951 was ever used, two still remain as a reminder of an era of national shame and hysteria.
If the current battle between the Seagram Distillers Company and Consumers Union is to be decided on press releases, then, at the moment, Seagram is ahead.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 3 (AP) -- President Juan Velasco said today that Peru had rejected an appeal by the Southern Peru Copper Corporation for changes in the contract under which the American company would invest approximately $355-million in developing the huge Cuajone copper deposits.
The Newark Evening News, which broke off negotiations with Time Inc. in April, 1968, has found a new suitor in a group of profitable Southern newspapers and radio stations.

Carmine G. De Sapio took the stand in Federal Court here yesterday and repeatedly denied that he had participated in any way in an alleged conspiracy to bribe former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus or extort contracts from the Consolidated Edison Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -President Nixon announced today that Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. would continue to serve as chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. With Judge Haynsworth standing by his side, the President faced newsmen and told them that the attack from the judge's critics on his integrity had been "brutal, vicious and, in my opinion, unfair.
Grandmaster Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., six times the United States chess championship took the lead in the 20th annual United States Chess Championship at the end of the third round.

Ten of the country's largest retail chains yesterday reported higher sales for November over last year, with some noting that the month's operations included a pickup in business during Thanksgiving week and new Sunday openings.
Borden's is going out of the milk business in the metropolitan New York area in mid-January after nearly a century of service.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 -- A guiding principle of Ralph M. Parsons in building a one-man company into the nation's second largest engineering and construction company has been, "Never tell your friends where you shoot ducks."

The crucial importance of safeguarding the natural environment is more widely recognized today than ever before. Until recently only a few conservationists and scientists were concerned about it and they were scoffed at by "practical" people. But now more and more intelligent laymen are becoming aware that runaway technology, if left uncontrolled, may lead to extinction of the human race.

The nation's largest banks plan to hold their prime lending rate at 8 1/2 per cent, despite what they regard as a "clear economic case" for an increase in this minimum interest charge on bank loans to the most credit-worthy corporations.
TRENTON, Dec. 4 -- Republican leaders in the Senate who have traditionally opposed the state income tax refused to rule one out today.
After eight years of hot argument and cold shoulders, a new Brooklyn meat market won the final required city approval yesterday.

WALK through the newly decorated Hotel Pierre, sinking in plush to the ankles, ring the doorbell, braced for one of a crowd of yes-men who will open the door to Jane Fonda's suite. The sex symbol of two continents -- in town to promote her new film, "They Shoot Horses, Don't They?" -- Miss Fonda surely will be late.
THE new enlarged, 373-page edition of the National Geographic Society's "Wondrous World of Fishes," priced at $9.95, would make an excellent gift for the angler in your family.
State cuts in welfare and other programs affecting the poor are called "unjust and insensitive" in a Roman Catholic pastoral letter to be read at all masses throughout the state on Sunday.

To the Editor: There are more than twenty million Americans below the poverty line and nearly $3 billion annually would be needed to close their food gap. Though these estimates come from governmental agencies, they are not based on adequate information regarding the human requirement of calories.
TO conclude a brief tour through the world of potential gift books begun Wednesday:

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 4 -Charles S. (Chub) Feeney was elected unanimously president of the National League today, indicating that major changes in baseball's traditional structure are unlikely for the foreseeable future.

Some 1,500 students, many carrying candles and flashlights, marched for two hours outside the Syrian Mission to the United Nations last evening in protest against the detention of two Israelis in Damascus.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 4 -- The North Atlantic alliance agreed today to challenge the Soviet bloc with a declaration asking the Warsaw Pact powers to show that their proposal for a European security conference would get to the central issue -- mutual and balanced reductions of forces in Europe in terms of areas and numbers.

ROME, Dec. 4 -- The Constitutional Court, Italy's highest tribunal, today struck down two penal code provisions for adultery, which also treated men and women unequally. The judges' decision effectively removed all criminal penalties for marital infidelity, leaving it a civil offense constituting grounds for legal separation.

Governor Rockefeller, whose wishes have been state Republican policy for the last 12 years, is passing the word to his county chairmen that he wants them to give their full support to Senator Charles E. Goodell in next year's election.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- The seven Warsaw Pact countries combined cautious praise of the new Government in Bonn today with a warning that "sober vigilance" must be maintained against what it termed neo-Nazi and revenge-seeking forces active in West Germany.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The West German central bank took an important restrictive step today signaling that Germany can no longer be the world's principal exporter of capital.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The strict quarantine period for dogs and cats entering Britain is to be extended immediately to eight months from six.

Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles will begin the new decade with a new product assignment from a long-time client. It will be Tabby Cat Food and everyone at the agency is purring contentedly as adcats usually do when the billings are over $1-million.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Gay Brewer of Dallas posted a record-tying 65 with an eagle and seven birdies to take the first-round lead in the $125,000 Danny Thomas Golf Classic today despite a struggle in the sand.
Thirty-four prominent jurists proposed yesterday that President Nixon convene a commission "of unquestionable impartiality'' to investigate the alleged massacre at Songmy in Vietnam.

A last-minute substitute call gave Robert Woodhouse a chance to ride in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. And the 19-year-old apprentice came through to a thrilling success, scoring on Nathan Pinsley's 4-year-old Rutland at a mutuel payoff of $79.60 for $2.
In rather heavy trading, prices rallied on the American Stock Exchange yesterday but losses outnumbered gains.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- United States weather scientists think they have probably succeeded in weakening a hurricane by seeding it.

Mozart's "The Magic Flute" is not an opera many people would consider suitable for small-scale performance, but last night the Hunter College Opera Theater showed that the work does very well without the pomp and pageantry that often turn it into a tedious spectacle with pretty music.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- The Rev. Joseph practice, offered a prayer of "no thanks" to God at a session of the White House conference on hunger.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 4 -- The National League of Cities chose as its future president today a young Indiana Mayor, who supports the Nixon Administration's domestic policies, over Mayor Lindsay of New York, who says those policies are grossly inadequate.

In any other year the tentative agreement reached yesterday by the nation's railroads and the unions representing their shopcraft employes would be considered decidedly inflationary. It is a commentary on the mad rush of the wage-price spiral that the three-step 7 per cent increase for next year should seem relatively modest, even though it is more than double the Johnson Administration's old productivity guidepost.
The Christmas bonus, a Wall Street institution for generations, is disappearing this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Negro witnesses and spectators before the Senate Communications Subcommittee told Senator John O. Pastore today that his proposal to ban competition for broadcast licenses is racist legislation to freeze blacks out of the radio and television industry.

THERE was a preintermission Szell and a postintermission Szell last night at the New York Philharmonic concert. The preintermission Szell conducted Verdi's "Forza del Destino" Overture and the Sibelius Fourth Symphony in a meticulous, exact, somewhat reserved manner.

Musical snowmen surrounded by frosted greens and snowballs will be the centerpieces of the banner-bedecked ice blue, gold and white Grand Ballroom of the Plaza next Thursday when the Winter Wonderland Ball is held to benefit the National Hemophilia Foundation.
TUNIS, Dec. 4 -- After weeks of nearly constant rain and floods, Tunisia is facing a recovery task that is expected to take at least five years and cost more than $40-million.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Cold weather curtailed a student demonstration at Boston University this afternoon after about 1,000 chanting, jeering marchers gathered in front of the school's administration building.

Five men, including two brothers in the real-estate and plumbing - supply businesses, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury as members of a ring that allegedly bought $500,000 in stolen city welfare checks at a discount.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- The ice hockey committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association recommended today that the number of foreign-student athletes be limited on each college team beginning with the class of 1971.

COPENHAGEN -- Perhaps the most interesting sociological experiment in Europe is Scandinavia's new approach to sex and unblushing acceptance of pornography as a fact of life. In these respects Denmark leads the northern vanguard.

Public television and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will cooperate later this month in what is to be the first experiments in the use of domestic satellites to transmit television programs.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 4 -- Violence mounted in the Gaza Strip today following a visit yesterday by Defense Minister Moshe Dayan to reinforce Israel's political and security policies in the occupied area.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- Following, as made public today in English by Tass, the Soviet press agency, is the text of a communique on the meeting of leaders of the Warsaw Pact countries, which ended today:
The Xerox Corporation took control yesterday of Rank Xerox, Ltd., in an exchange of stock for majority voting rights.

Mrs. Brown, one of a group that included among others Malcolm Cowley, Matthew Josephson, Eugene O'Neill, Allen Tate, Kenneth Burke and their lady folk, offers an inside look at Hart Crane in the last decade of his life. Though high on hopes and literary projects, these people were broke for the most part, and they shared money, jobs, and housing with a heart-warming concern.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A confidential Post Office survey has disclosed that "thousands" of Americans have secret Swiss bank accounts, a senior Justice Department official said today.
The stock market made Westchester industrialist Edwin C. Whitehead a billionaire yesterday.
A statement by the British Government yesterday set off a further drop in silver futures prices here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -Senate Democrats laid the groundwork today for attaching a 15 per cent increase in Social Security benefits to the pending tax bill. Their objectives were apparently to help speed enactment of the Social Security increase and to make it harder for President Nixon to consider vetoing the tax bill.

NEARLY all hands involved in the pastime of boating are clapping over the proposed Boat Safety Act of 1969 that was introduced in Congress last week. However, the bill, which would consolidate and update the Motorboat Act of 1940 and the Boating Act of 1958 and has been hammered out, revised, rehashed, rewritten and re-introduced during the last two years, is not expected to become workable until 1973.
A Long Island Rail Road diesel engine hit a stalled tractor trailer yesterday at a railroad freight crossing at 56th Road and 49th Street in the Laurel Hill section of Queens.
Governor Rockefeller formally dedicated the new campus of the Lexington School for the Deaf in Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- John Price, a key assistant on the President's Urban Affairs Council, is expected to be named to succeed Daniel Patrick Moynihan as Secretary of the Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Senior United States commanders in Vietnam have reportedly urged the Nixon Administration to make the next troop withdrawal relatively modest -- not much more than 35,000 men -- while awaiting the outcome of an expected enemy offensive in February or March.

Twenty-one of the state's top political, civic and business leaders met yesterday with Arthur J. Goldberg, former United States Representative to the United Nations, and urged that he become a Democratic candidate for statewide office in 1970.

A director of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines testified in Federal Court yesterday that another director had told him that Roy M. Cohn did not learn about the alleged bribery of a city appraiser until November, 1963, almost a year after it began.

DETROIT, Dec. 4 -- The Episcopal Church is one of the few Protestant denominations in the country that still refuses to ordain women, but to Mrs. Cynthia Clark Wedel this policy is more objectionable in theory than restrictive in practice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Raymond H. Lapin, fighting to recover his job as president of the Federal National Mortgage Association, received a severe setback today when a judge here said he had no jurisdiction over a suit brought by Mr. Lapin's attorneys to keep him in his post.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The United States ambassador to Poland and the Chinese Communist charge d'affaires met for the first time last night at a diplomatic reception in Warsaw, the State Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- In their first three weeks of preliminary discussions in Helsinki, the United States and the Soviet Union, it was reported today, have defined broad areas for future negotiations on strategic arms.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 4 -A Superior Court judge today ordered the Providence Teachers Union to end its strike, which closed the public schools here Nov. 24.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Jacques Lemaire scored on a 70-foot shot in the second period to give the Montreal Canadiens a 1-0 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A Senate subcommittee asked today for an explanation of the Army's finding that a series of hearings on abuses in the military club system had produced "insufficient evidence" for prosecutions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The White House Confernce on Food, Nutrition and Health today adopted by acclamation a strong, far-ranging statement of national hunger and health priorities.

A strike by private sanitationmen ended here after four days last night, when members of Local 813 of the Teamsters ratified a three-year contract containing an increase in wages of $40 a week. Increases in pensions of $100 a month and an earlier retirement age were also included in the agreement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The White House has told the Office of Education to slash nearly a billion dollars from its proposed budget for the fiscal year 1971, sources in the agency said tonight.

" YOU make it seem as if this is the only way to look," an admirer told Halston Frowick yesterday in the backstage congratulatory session that is standard apres-fashion show procedure. His spring-summer show also marked his first anniversary as head of his own business.
ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- The Court of Appeals has unanimously upheld the constitutionality of a state law making it a misdemeanor to loiter for the purpose of using narcotics.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Of all the millions of words written about the American universities in recent years, comparatively little has been said about the problems of the teachers. The conflict between the militant students and the embattled administrators is well known, but the teachers, caught between the two, find themselves in an equally strange and difficult situation.
The Soviet-Chinese talks in Peking remain shrouded in secrecy, but in Eastern Europe evidence mounts that the Chinese are seeking to mend fences and improve relations wherever they can.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- The Government's final witness in the Chicago conspiracy trial testified today that several of the defendants expressed willingness to see violence in the streets during the 1968 Democratic National Convention here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Nixon Administration lifted today a seven-month freeze on a controversial urban renewal program affecting more than 300 cities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Nixon warned Republican Congressional leaders today that he would call Congress back into special session the day after Christmas unless all major appropriation bills were passed by both legislative branches before then.
GORGEOUS -- that would be one word for Stephen Porter's restaging of "Private Lives," which arrived at the Billy Rose Theater last night. Delicate might be another word, dazzling if you want a third.

A letter condemning the expulsion of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn from the Soviet writers union is being sent to Moscow over the signatures of 16 intellectuals, including Arthur Miller, Jean-Paul Sartre and Carlos Fuentes.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 -- Jesse Unruh stood in front of his unpretentious, two-story home today to announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination to oppose Gov. Ronald Reagan's re-election attempt next year. He issued a challenge for televised debates.

BONN, Dec. 4 -- Authoritative sources said today that the United States was annoyed with the new West German Government of Chancellor Willy Brandt, which Washington feels has failed to consult it adequately about Bonn's current initiatives toward Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Vice President Agnew crashed his wife's party today and stole the spotlight.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 4 -- The South Vietnamese Government announced tonight that its forces and those of its allies would observe brief cease-fires at Christmas and the New Year, as they have for four years.
The Fifth Avenue Vietnam Peace Parade Committee announced plans yesterday for a demonstrfation against President Nixon when he visits New York on Tuesday to accept an award.

A new office to study the application of modern management techniques to university operations and methods of evaluating the effectiveness of faculty and programs is being started by the City University.

NEWARK, Dec 4 -- New Jersey's controversial $1 head tax on airline passengers on outbound domestic flights from Newark Airport generated a lot of turbulence in Washington, Trenton and this city today, but it failed to get off the ground.
After playing a rather sloppy first half, St. John's basketball team settled down after the intermission and defeated Harvard, 73-62, for its first victory of the season tonight before 4,026 fans.
DETROIT, Dec. 4 -- Mrs. Theodore O. Wedel, a 61-year-old former church executive, defeated a militant black candidate today to become the first woman president of the National Council of Churches.

BEIRUT, Dec. 4 -- Premier Rashid Karami declared today his new Government was determined to carry out an agreement reached with Palestinian commandos Nov. 3. He said the agreement insured Lebanon's sovereignty and security and at the same time provided for support to the Palestinian struggle against Israel.

Several black political and social activists in Harlem are putting together the machinery that they hope will defeat ailing Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. during the Democratic primary elections next year.

To the Editor: Still another suicide has been recorded in our correctional institutions -- to be followed by sighs, studies, and Senatorial diatribe The rapidly approaching Christmas season will, no doubt, assuage the guilt of this community and others when they read about the turkey feasts enjoyed by our inmate populations.

A new state automobile registration law "to prevent New York City from becoming a dumping ground for stolen vehicles" was proposed yesterday by a crime-prevention organization headed by Thomas J. Mackell, Queens District Attorney.

One redeeming aspect of the Senate's approach to the tax bill was its decision yesterday to scrap a Finance Committee recommendation that would have barred private foundations from the kind of voter registration drives that have brought millions of Negroes into polling places for the first time.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Henry Cabot Lodge took leave of the Vietnam peace talks as chief American delegate today in an atmosphere of failure, insult and recrimination.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 4 (AP) -The Midwestern Securities Corporation of New York and its president, Lloyd W. Sahley, filed a $11.1-million libel suit yesterday in Cleveland against the credit-rating concern, Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
VIENNA, Dec. 4 -- A number of Eastern European newspapers are reflecting the view that signs of a political thaw are multiplying on the Continent.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., the conglomerate that operates in 11 different industrial groups, realized a 22 per cent gain in operating earnings on a 6.3 per cent sales increase in the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31.

To the Editor: It could well be argued that the two most momentous decisions of the Warren Court were the antisegregation decision of 1954 and the anti-religious-indoctrination decision of 1963. Both intended to strengthen public education as a democratic institution.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 4 -One of the last of the collegiate variety shows to tour the country, the Princeton Triangle Club's more-or-less annual production opened in the McCarter Theater here tonight with a startling innovation -- real girls in the chorus.
Bob Hope, the comedian, will receive the Gold Tee Award of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association at the group's annual national awards dinner on Feb. 23 at the Americana Hotel.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Fred Hampton, the Illinois chairman of the Black Panther party, and another Panther leader were killed today in a pre-dawn shoot-out with a police raiding party.

The observation was made in these columns last Sunday -- before the Senate began voting on its Finance Committee's version of the tax bill and amending it on the floor -- that the long effort to reform the Federal tax structure was in danger of turning into a fiasco. We take no satisfaction in noting that that dismal prediction is now giving every evidence of coming true.

" WE don't nearly have the snow depths we had last year," said Burr Vail, the general manager of the Bromley Mountain area at Manchester, Vt., "but at least the temperatures are remaining below freezing so that we can keep making snow."
The nation's business leaders were told yesterday that the black community believes that the Government, management and labor unions all are unconcerned over job opportunities for nonwhites.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 4 -- A recommendation that public schools on Long Island refrain from cerebrating religious holidays was made today by leaders of the Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths.
New York University made a strong case last night for one of the worst performances by a Violet team at Madison Square Garden.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 5 -- The five Central American foreign ministers, in an effort to save the region's Common Market, agreed today on a formula for negotiating a settlement of the conflict between Honduras and El Salvador.
If all goes well in union negotiations this weekend, Rudolf Bing said yesterday, the Metropolitan Opera "would hope to open with Aida,' " probably on Dec. 29, with Leontyne Price in the title role.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 4 (AP) -- John V. Kenny, the Hudson County Democratic leader, told a gathering of followers today that he wanted to retire -but they unanimously declared he would be their leader for life.
This weekend Schlitz beer, the country's second best seller, is taking to the sea. At the tiller will be their ad agency for the last seven years, the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago.
Steve Owens stepped nimbly over a snaking television cable, but found himself trapped behind the line of scrimmage by a pursuer with a tape recorder.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The Conservative Party took a parliamentary seat from Labor today in a by-election at Wellingborough, Northamptonshire.

On Wall Street, where hope usually springs eternal, things are about as gloomy as they have been for most of the year. The latest blow to the dwindling crowd of optimists occurred on Wednesday, when the Dow-Jones industrial average, probably the most popular barometer of stock market prices, sank to a new low for the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The railroads and their shopcraft unions settled today on a two-year contract that provides an 11 per cent raise for 1969 and establishes an additional 7 per cent raise as the tentative pattern for all railroad workers in 1970.

MANY European players make a habit of bidding a short suit before a long suit. However, this "canape" idea finds little favor on this side of the Atlantic. The long suit is bid first in standard American methods, and partner knows that he should return to the original suit when he does not have a clear preference for the second suit.

Contemporary brass players, being the whizzes they are, can make almost any kind and amount of sound. In new music, which calls for many changes of character, this virtuosity is fine, but it is not suitable to early brass music.
Price increases for copper and copper alloy products spread yesterday as more and more companies tried to offset higher primary copper prices.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Martin Fromin, the meet's leading rider, guided John Houdry's Astromaster to a 3-length victory today in the feature race at Liberty Bell Race Track.

MADRID, Dec. 4 -- Spanish newspapers used two laconic paragraphs on their front pages today to report that Generalissimo Francisco Franco was 77 years old and would spend the day quietly with his family inside the gray stone walls of the Pardo Palace in the outskirts of Madrid.
Hopes that the Metropolitan Opera could be opened soon brightened yesterday following the musicians' acceptance of a three-year contract

J. Ray McDermott Co. announced yesterday the completion of its acquisition of a 500,000-share stake, or about 10 per cent, of the Reading Bates Offshore Drilling Company, which is active on the North Slope of Alaska and in the Far East.

To the Editor: The Government has just announced it will pay subsidies on exports of chickens to Greece, escalating the cold chicken war with the European Common Market. By Nov. 1 about 21 million pounds had been subsidized at a cost of $3.6 million. Recent subsidies have been running sixteen to eighteen cents a pound.
The stock market snapped back yesterday with a brisk rally, particularly in the final hour of trading, after having dropped Wednesday to its lowest level in nearly three years.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- A Soviet aviation official said today that by next spring three foreign airlines as well as Aeroflot, the Soviet carrier, would be flying from Tokyo to Western Europe across Siberia.
The roar of the crowd in Yankee Stadium will tell you more about Joe Morrison than Joe ever will. The fans have been watching him play for 11 seasons and they know enough to cheer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The United States rebuked Arab and Israeli spokesmen at the United Nations today for using "violent" language and told them that the "international community" could not tolerate "extremism" on either side.
The General Electric Company introduced yesterday its fastest, most powerful computer system, thus making a bid for a bigger share of the large-scale data-processing market.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -Senator Charles E. Goodell urged the broadcasting networks today not to react to Vice President Agnew's criticism "by compromising in any way their responsibility to offer informative and provocative news analysis and comment."

RODIN never succeeded in seducing Isadora Duncan, a failure over which she later lamented in her autobiography and attributed to her youth and American puritanical upbringing. As a man and artist, the French sculptor was often attracted to dancers, particularly Cambodian, Javanese, Japanese and American ones, including Loie Fuller.

IT'S a reasonable assumption that Lance Alworth of the San Diego Chargers will catch at least one forward pass in Sunday's game with the Boston Patriots. When he does clamp his meat hooks on that first thrown ball, he will advance into an area hitherto populated in solitary grandeur by a legend.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Senator Joseph D. Tydings, Democrat of Maryland, released today a report by a commission of 13 legal experts that said "armed crime is on the rampage in the national capital."
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 4 -- Joe Pepitone, the last and most controversial of the old imperial New York Yankees, was traded to the Houston Astros today for Curt Blefary.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 4 -- Eton Tie, ridden by Bobby Kotenko, closed fast in the stretch and won the six-furlong featured eighth race today, giving Millard Waldheim's Bwamazon Farm two straight victories on the Laurel Race Course program.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 4 -- The United States military authorities announced today that the number of American soldiers killed in combat dropped to 70 last week from 130 the previous week. It was the third lowest number of weekly fatalities this year.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved lower yesterday. Small selling and caution reflecting the continued downward trend on Wall Street produced widespread losses.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that a grand jury investigating conspiracy to commit murder may grant a witness immunity from prosecution for murder even though the law does not specifically give this power.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- The San Diego Padres traded Joe Niekro, a right-handed pitcher to the Detroit Tigers tonight for Pat Dobson, a relief pitcher, and Dave Campbell, an infielder.
" I WANT to make the home look more like a primitive cavern," said Jacques Kaplan, the furrier, surrounded by the furnishings he hopes will work the transformation.

The Federal Reserve System maintained its basic policy of sharp credit restraint during the last two weeks, banking data released yesterday showed. Business loans at major New York City banks increased $192-million, their biggest one week jump since September.

Democratic leaders in the state outlined plans yesterday for an intensive drive to elect their candidates in marginal State Senate and Assembly districts next year as part of an effort to control the Legislature.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 4 -- Alexander's, Inc., held the first annual meeting in its 40-year history here today and told some of its 9,000 shareholders that the retail chain had a 15 per cent gain in net income and a 4.3 per cent rise in sales in the first fiscal quarter.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Buddy Baker circled the Texas International Speedway at an average speed of 176.285 miles an hour today to gain the pole position for Sunday's $93,000 Texas 500 stock car race.
The establishment of an East Harlem school district was urged yesterday by speakers from the predominantly Puerto Rican area at a public hearing of the Board of Education.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 4 -- An unusual pretrial hearing in which five Black Panthers accused of murder and kidnapping challenged the state's right to deny them bail ended today after 11 days of testimony.

YONKERS, Dec. 4 -- There were no Laverne Hanovers or Kat Byrds around, so the lesser lights amoung this season's 3-year-old pacers held the stage at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The occasion was the $25,000 final of the Late Closing Series for nonwinners of $30,000 in 1969, through Oct. 11, and the winner was Bobby's Champ.
NAHA, Okinawa, Dec. 4 -- The United States forces announced today a plan to reduce the civilian work force at its bases here by 1,900 to 2,800 persons, many of them Okinawans.
JACKSON, Mich., Dec. 4 (AP) -- The publisher of The Jackson Blazer, a black-oriented weekly, was found slain today in his apartment in Jackson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The insurgent leader in a struggle for control of the United Mine Workers of America filed a damage suit today against W. A. (Tony) Boyle, the union's president, and his top aides, demanding personal restitution to the union of millions of dollars allegedly spent for unauthorized purposes.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- The Amateur Athletic Union gave tentative approval today for another United States national track and field team tour of Europe, similar to the visit of last summer.
A COUPLE of months ago it seemed possible that the deplorable records chalked up by the mutual funds this year would be erased by a vigorous stock market rally. But it didn't happen.
The latest in electric, pollution-free automobiles was demonstrated in Central Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -Capt. Ernest L. Medina, commander of the Army company alleged to have committed a massacre at the Mylai 4 hamlet of Songmy village in South Vietnam on March 16, 1968, emphatically denied today that he had ordered or seen such a massacre.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- New pressure mounted on the British Government today to halt its arms shipments to the Nigerian Government and take the lead in calling for an embargo on weapons to both sides in the civil war.

VACLAV HAVEL'S "The Memorandum," which was produced last year at the Public Theater, was a biting but attenuated satire about the bureaucratic nightmare. His new play, "The Increased Difficulty of Concentration," which opened last night at Lincoln Center's Forum Theater (I saw it at a critics' preview), is a gentler satire about the domestic nightmare.
The corporate bond market may have turned a corner.
When Woody Campbell finished describing his tour in Vietnam for what must have been the 113th time in the last three weeks, he added one point.

Alexander Slobodyanik, a 27-year-old Soviet pianist who made an unusually successful debut at Carnegie Hall a year ago, made his second appearance in that auditorium last night and pretty much repeated his first triumph. A slim, blond, exceedingly handsome youth, with an aloof stage manner, he could become a concert idol on looks alone.
Gen. L. F. Chapman of the Marine Corps says: "It is impossible to enumerate the many services that are perperformed by the U. S. O. for servicemen.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Dec. 5 (AP) -- A twin-engine airplane returning a group to Texas from a pleasure trip in Las Vegas, Nev., crashed in flames on the edge of Albuquerque today, killing all 11 persons aboard.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Senate voted a $6.5-billion annual increase in Social Security benefits today as an amendment to the tax reform bill. The vote was 48 to 41.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Arthur Ashe, the United States professional tennis player, denied charges tonight that he wanted to go to South Africa "not to play tennis but to engage in political activity." The charge against Mr. Ashe who is black, was made by a South African Government official.
Charging the city Health Department with "callous in difference," Supreme Court Justice Harold Baer yesterday ordered an immediate cleanup of two Bronx back-yards.

WASHINGTON, .Dec. 5 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that it had asked the American Broadcasting Company and a toy manufacturer to provide information on a Saturday morning children's program that it calls a 30-minute commercial.

CAIRO, Dec. 5 -- Officials and diplomatic couriers hastened between Arab capitals today in an urgent attempt to prevent the fighting between Saudi Arabia and Southern Yemen over a border outpost from undermining agreement for a conference of Arab leaders, scheduled to convene two weeks from tomorrow.

Carmine G. De Sapio yesterday branded as lies all statements by previous witnesses linking him with an attempt to bribe former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus or suggesting that he discussed money payments that might have eased Consolidated Edison's problems with the city.
Prices and volume dropped on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. At the close, a total of 4,385,435 shares had been traded, compared with 5,273,000 the day before.
The jurors walk in slowly, single file, a slice of New York with a literary agent and a butcher and the wife of a sportswear manufacturer, but Carmine G. De Sapio does not turn around to watch.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -Chief Justice Warren E. Burger appointed 10 Federal judges today to oversee financial and out-of-court activities of all Federal judges except members of the Supreme Court.

The news article, "Success of 911 Puts Strain on Police Here" (Nov. 29), puts a strain on me. It is untrue, as Deputy Inspector Anthony Bouza asserted, that 98 per cent of the calls to 911 are answered within thirty seconds.
VIENNA, Dec. 6 -- Diplomats in Eastern Europe said today that the Soviet bloc's northern tier had split with its more southerly members over West Germany in the Moscow meeting this week.

Harassment, intimidation and ultimate disappointment are the lot of Jews seeking to emigrate from the Soviet Union to Israel, according to a young man who says he spent two years in prison and nine more in social and economic limbo before getting one of the rare exit visas.
MOSCOW, Dec. 5 -- The capital of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is not a culturally deprived area, but neither can it honestly be described as Fun City East.

Three men linked by a Federal prosecutor to organized crime were each sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Milton Pollack to two years in prison following convictions on a Diners Club credit card swindle.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- William R. Ford, director of the Michigan Employment Security Commission, refused today appointment as director of Volunteers in Service to America (VISTA), the domestic Peace Corps.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 5 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a declaration on European security issued today by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at the end of a three-day meeting here of members' foreign, defense and finance ministers:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Senate passed today a bill giving the police and courts in the District of Columbia new powers to combat the soaring crime rate here. The House has not yet acted on the measure.
Another chapter in the slaying of Linda Fitzpatrick and her hippie boy friend, James L. (Groovy) Hutchinson, was written here yesterday in State Supreme Court.

The 33d annual Medal of Merit of the Saint Nicholas Society of the City of New York was presented last night at the organization's 135th annual dinner to Hoyt Ammidon, chairman of the United States Trust Company of New York.

One lap of the automotive industry's Great Gas Turbine Race is scheduled to begin next Tuesday when a 46-passenger Continental Trailways bus pulls out of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 5 -- Several years after the first American use of tear gas here provoked widespread condemnation, the gas is being used routinely by United States and South Vietnamese troops to flush out suspected enemy troops.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Three alderman, the Afro-American Patrolmen's League, the Illinois division of the American Civil Liberties Union and black community groups called today for independent investigations of the slaying of two Black Panthers in a police raid.

Private sanitationmen returned to their jobs early yesterday and began cleaning up a backlog of nearly 24,000 tons of garbage that had accumulated at hotels, restaurants and other commercial establishments as a result of their four-day walkout.

About a thousand persons are expected at the Capri Beach Club in Atlantic Beach, L. I., next Saturday for a $1,000 - a - couple dinner in honor of Simon Cohen, a Long Island industrialist and philanthropist, who has been a major supporter of the Hebrew Institute of Long Island.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- An appelate court upheld today ruling that employes are not entitled to immediate unemployment benefits when locked out of a plant in a labor dispute.

FOR some years now, the sculpture of Anne Arnold has been one of the special delights of the New York art scene. It is special in two senses -- first and foremost, in the sense of being exceptionally accomplished in its own terms, but also in the sense of appealing to a special taste.
A moon rock that weighs three-quarters of an ounce and is less than two inches long broke attendance records last month while on display at the American Museum of Natural History.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 5 -- The trading mart at the winter baseball meeting became a little more brisk today, but, aside from the New York Yankee -Oakland A's transaction, the deals were not of major proportions.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 5 -- Copper has been struck in what may be large quantities at a site now being explored by South Africa's Anglo Transvaal Consolidated Investment Company in Northern Cape Province.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe moved to upgrade the Government's auto safety program today by giving high departmental status to the National Highway Safety Bureau and a newly chosen director, Douglas W. Toms.

LYDDA, Israel, Dec. 5 -- Two Israeli civilians held as hostages by Syria since the hijacking of a Trans World Airline jetliner to Damascus on Aug. 29 were released today in exchange for 13 Syrians held in Israel.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Auto production scheduled for United States plants this week was off 13.3 per cent from the corresponding week a year earlier, the trade publication Automotive News reported yesterday.
The airlines found out long ago, when someone started giving orchids to women passengers, that the little extras often make a big difference in attracting customers.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 5 -- A spokesman for the American Independent party said today that former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama should quit Democratic politics if he wants to be a third-party leader.

THE man ready to move into the driver's seat at the National Highway Safety Bureau is a gregarious, boyish-faced Northwesterner who is as tough-minded in pressing for his principles as he is in pursuing his play.
VIENNA, Dec. 5 -- Col. Emil Zatopek, the Olympic distance runner, was dismissed from the Czechoslovak Army today on charges of illegal activities, apparently meaning advocacy of democratic reform.

ATHENS, Dec. 5 -- The Greek Government is expected to act soon to end the tug-of-war between Aristotle S. Onassis and Stavros Niarchos for a lucrative Greek oil-refining concession by giving each of the shipping millionaires a share of the concession in return for a pledge of investments totaling $900-million.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- The General Board of the National Council of Churches rejected pending nominations for 25 key council posts today and appointed a new nominating committee headed by a Negro woman to draw up a slate with more minority representation.
Officials of the Fresh Air Fund were hopeful last week that with nearly a month to go, the fund would reach its 1969 goal of $750,000 in contributions.
The London Stock Exchange was steadier yesterday following Thursday's mild technical rally on Wall Street. However, prices eased from their highs in late dealings.
Unexpected increases in operating costs are making it "nip and tuck" whether the city will get through this fiscal year without deficit financing, Budget Director Frederick O'R. Hayes said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Gay Brewer, battling laryngitis and Arnold Palmer, increased his lead in the $125,000 Danny Thomas Golf classic to four strokes today with a 66 and a 36-hole score of 131.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- The White House today branded as categorically untrue a report in The New York Times that President Nixon's national security adviser had urged West Germany to go slow on attempting to improve relations with the Soviet bloc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Public discussion on the draft has been confused in recent days by reports that the Defense Department's estimates of the size of the draft pool next year were inaccurate. These reports were based on a mistaken interpretation of the Pentagon's figures.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The French Government, pursuing its expressed preference for "European solutions," turned down today the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's bid to buy a major part of the heavy electrical industry.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- A Rembrandt that sold for $756,000 was among 150 pictures auctioned today by Christie's for $3,236,258, a European record for any sale of old masters.

The Justice Department told the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington yesterday that the Government was "unconditionally" opposed to the proposed merger of the Illinois Central and Gulf, Mobile Ohio railroads.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (Reuters) -- The 23-nation International Tin Council ended a thee-day meeting here today, leaving the world's major producers free of the quotas that have restricted their exports -- and pushed up prices -- for more than a year.

The Administration's most persistent argument against a rapid or complete withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam has been that a bloodbath would take place if American forces were no longer available to protect President Thieu's regime from the National Liberation Front.
The Maritime Subsidy Board approved yesterday the purchase by Prudential Lines of all of the common stock of Grace Line, Inc., for $44.5-million.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--American scientists are finding increasingly strong evidence linking a virus with certain types of human cancer.

Although Jiro Matsuda numbers such potent guitar personalities as Andres Segovia, Alirio Diaz and John Williams among his mentors, he is nonetheless very much his own man. This classical guitarist from Japan is an articulate individualist, as his program last night in Carnegie Recital Hall demonstrated.
A senior European trade official assured Americans here yesterday that an expansion of Europe's Common Market would be helpful to the United States.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 5 -- The main administration building of Harvard University was seized today by 170 black students protesting the college's alleged delay in increasing the number of black workers on the campus and alleged discrimination in hiring.
BOSTON, Dec. 5 -- A longsimmering controversy involving the Boston Symphony orchestra and the music critics for the Boston newspapers has grown more acerbic.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 5 -- Bill Allen, whose 13 Professional Bowlers Association championships in an eight-year career puts him third on the career list, was well on his way to a 14th when he gained a 267-pin lead in the $65,000 national championship last night at Garden City Bowl.
WITH the college football season all but over, the professionals have moved into the Saturday scene as well as Sunday and offer television matinees today and tomorrow.

Officials of .the Scenic Hudson Preservation Committee have attacked the Public Service Commission for absolving Consolidated Edison of blame for delays in building sufficient generating capacity to overcome the New York area's power shortage.

GENEVA, Dec. 5 -- The World Council of Churches opposes the continuation of mercy flights of food shipments to Biafra on the ground that the aid is only prolonging the Nigerian civil war, a council spokesman said today.

Governor Rockefeller's pledge to ask the Legislature for a "full opportunity" higher education program means that open admission is to become a reality throughout the state The Rockefeller plan to offer some form of post-high school education to all New York secondary school graduates would go a long way toward making the City University's open admission promise a manageable reality.

The cost of relief from headaches and other minor pains may be going up. The Monsanto Company announced yesterday that it had raised the price of bulk aspirin and salicylic acid, an intermediate in many organic syntheses, by 2 cents a pound.
HARTFORD, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A 22-year-old student-editor was found guilty today of libeling President Nixon with a cartoon that appeared in the University of Hartford News-Liberated Press a year ago.

The New York Choral Society, founded and conducted by Martin Josman, is celebrating its 10th anniversary this year. Last night it gave the first of three concerts planned for the season in Philharmonic Hall and turned its attention, as it often has in the past, to the music of Bach.
For the second time in six weeks, a Federal judge severely criticized a Mount Vernon, N. Y., draft board yesterday for what he called "blatantly lawless" acts.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- In a drive to combat aerial piracy, member nations voted 67 to 1 today in the General Assembly's Legal Committee to urge governments to insure that plane hijackers will be prosecuted.

HOUSTON, Dec. 5 -- With a dual incentive, the New York Jets will oppose the Houston Oilers tomorrow in the Astrodome. The world champions want to win not only for themselves, but also for the Boston Patriots, coached by Clive Rush, a former Jet aide.
Shell egg prices on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange showed little indication this week that consumer resistance might force them to react after their long, persistent rise.
The Dance Theater of Harlem has been extraordinarily selective in the numbers of performances it has given and in the places where it has given them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of about 40 million capsules of an antibiotic called oxytetracycline.
Prof. William Shockley's Nov. 8 letter and his publications on the innate inferiority of blacks are not only arrant nonsense, as are Arthur Jensen's, but potentially just as viciously harmful.

Notwithstanding that position, however, I recognize now that President Nixon's course is the right one and that any course other than gradual disengagement in the absence of a negotiated settlement would be a complete disaster.
Two 18-year-old Bronx youths were arrested yesterday on charges of felonious possession and sale of narcotics to Taft High School students.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 6 -A meeting of four Nordic foreign ministers, which had been scheduled for a discussion of the prospects for formation of a Nordic customs union, was canceled by Finland tonight.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- The Government completed its case today against the seven men charged with conspiring to incite a riot during the 1968 Democratic National Convention here.

Aaron Thomas, for eight years a leading pass-catcher for the New York Giants professional football team, will tackle a new profession at the end of the current season when he takes possession of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange.

MONTREAL, Dec. 5 (AP) -Jacques Laperriere of the Montreal Canadiens was suspended tonight from his club's next three games by Clarence Campbell, National Hockey League president. The suspension of the 28-year-old defenseman came as the result of an altercation with a referee, Bill Friday, and a linesman, Pat Shetler, here last Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The "Tell It to Hanoi" committee, a New York-based group that supports the Administration's Vietnam policy, presented President Nixon some 350,000 pieces of mail in support of his position today.
TRENTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- New Jersey Blue Cross, which is being granted a temporary rate increase of 28.5 per cent until May 1, asked today for another increase of 35.2 per cent after that.
BERLIN, Dec. 5 -- Walter Ulbricht said on his return to East Berlin today that he was "very satisfied" with the result of the Moscow meeting.
Three influential economists -- all former Government officials -- painted a pessimistic picture yesterday of the chances of getting inflation under control soon.
CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Four Congressmen toured the brig at this Marine base today to investigate a charge that a band of Negroes had made virtual slaves of some white prisoners.
THE 300th anniversary of Rembrandt's death, internationally observed, has at last been recognized in New York with a major exhibition, "Rembrandt: Experimental Etcher," at the Morgan Library.

GENEVA, Dec. 5 -- J. Howard Laeri, vice chairman of the First National City Bank of New York, predicted today that President Nixon would shun political expediency in favor of keeping the United States economy on a deflationary course.

The city announced plans yesterday to open 10 new depots for the troubled surplusfood program, to improve the distribution hours, and to permit the needy to obtain their food every two weeks instead of monthly.

Two young girls, one the daughter of Sabicas, an internationally famous Spanish guitarist, and the other a daughter of a prominent lawyer, were reported missing yesterday in unconnected cases.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- After the alarms and the hopes, the communique and the glosses, the Hague summit meeting has told us at least this much about the European Economic Community: whatever its disappointments, it is now an inescapable premise of politics in Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -David Packard, Deputy Secretary of Defense, voiced concern today about what he described as a substantial increase recently in enemy infiltration in South Vietnam. But, he declared, American withdrawals "are going to continue."

Jack Dreyfus Jr., recently named chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, enjoyed a near-perfect day as an owner yesterday. The Hobeau farm, the nom de course of Dreyfus's racing interests, was represented in four races on the card, and won three of them, including the feature.
The Penn Central railroad announced yesterday the postponement of its planned increase of Metroliner service between New York and Washington from six trips in each direction to nine.

I often wonder what would happen if buyers treated such books as straight merchandise (which they are), returning them if faulty.
