YONKERS, Dec. 6 -- Post time for the eighth race at Yonkers Raceway tonight was more than three hours away, but Rhyl, a 6-year-old Australian gelding, already had moved into next Saturday night's $25,000 final of the Adios Fall Festival.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 6 -- The United States Ambassador, Jack Hood Vaughn, counted up to eight.

Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., a yachtsman of international reputation, will be piped aboard the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana Hotel tomorrow night as guest of honor at the annual People-to-People sports committee dinner.

NOT since Leif Ericson's day has the North American continent had Vikings with such built-in violence as the band of marauders using Minnesota as a base for operations. They will lay siege today to the hitherto unconquered coastal settlement of Los Angeles and it promises to be football warfare of maximum ferocity.

Police detectives seized an estimated $12 - to - $15 - million worth of uncut cocaine and heroin in a midtown hotel yesterday and arrested four members of what they described as an international narcotics ring.

JERUSALEM -- Some Israelis watched Premier Golda Meir with misgivings last week as she completed negotiations for the formation of a new coalition Government. Their minds were on what is likely to be the Government's first order of business -- long overdue economic restrictions.

WASHINGTON -- In a moment of not inconsiderable drama last week, the Republican leader of the Senate, Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, stood on the floor of the chamber and denounced the Administration -- whose floor leader he is supposed to be -- for its failure to back a Republican alternative to a Democratic amendment to the tax bill.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- It was on a December Sunday --
The third in a series of courts-martial following a riot that focused national attention on conditions In the Army stockade at Fort Dix, N. J., is moving toward a conclusion.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 6 -- A rapidly growing group in Sydney is using a strange form of protest against the Vietnam war. Its members are trying to send one another to jail for counseling young Australians to resist the draft.
POTSDAM, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Len Ceglarski of Clarkson said today he thought Harvard, Cornell and Boston University would be the strongest contenders for Eastern College hockey supremacy this season.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 6 -- The Peruvian military Government and a group of United States mining companies are nearing a showdown this weekend that could determine the course not only of foreign investment here but also the direction of Latin American social and economic development.

RIO DE JANEIRO. THE flight from New York to Rio de Janeiro is interrupted, a little after 6 in the morning, by a 30-minute stop in Brasilia, and the night's uneasy sleep and no breakfast made the terminal seem no more than an uninviting shed.
RICHMOND, Dec. 6 -- The Old Dominion Sugar Corporation of Washington will build a $14-million sugar refinery at Portsmouth, Va.
MIAMI, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Hubert Ginn went 22 yards to score and lifted Florida A. and M. to a 23-19 victory tonight over Grambling in the 37th Orange Blossom Classic.
PRAIA DA ROCHA, Portugal -- "Anyone writing about tourism in Portugal today is writing history," a local maxim maintains. "By tomorrow, all will have changed."

AMERICAN ARCHITECTURE AND URBANISM. Vincent Scully. (Praeger. $18.50.) A highly idiosyncratic critique of the building of American cities. "Although this may not be the book that everyone has been waiting for," Ada Louise Huxtable wrote, "it is still a book that everyone should read . . . a special performance from the high-wire artist of architectural history."
CINCINNATI, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The National League made it official today that Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds was the 1969 batting champion with an average of .348.

ROME -- Weak government, fractionalized parties, industry, and public service periodically crippled by strikes, and extreme left wing violence creating a backlash of neo-Fascist vigilante action -- such was the discouraging Italian public scene last week on the threshold of the holiday season.

MOSCOW -- There is a mood of expectation here, bolstered by last week's cautious but conciliatory Warsaw Pact communique, that the European Communist nations, despite East German qualms, are moving closer to a genuine dialogue with West Germany's new Government headed by Chancellor Willy Brandt.

DALLAS CENTER, Iowa, Dec. 5 -- The enormously productive fields of central Iowa were clipped and cleared this week and braced for winter, great beige and black rectangles that have just yielded one of the largest corn and soybean crops on record.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 6 -- Burley tobacco auctions are under way at nearly 400 warehouses in 61 markets of the eight-state burley belt and farmers are surprised at a dip in average prices for the first week. Pre-season predictions by officials had been for higher averages.
City College's fencers won six consecutive bouts late in the match yesterday to gain a 17-10 victory over Yale at the victor's Wingate Gymnasium.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6 -- New Jersey state police made a series of raids on gambling places tonight in coordination with a larger operation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The police arrested 19 persons on gambling charges.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Seven railroads operating out of Chicago are participating in a program offering free education to employees in classes ranging from the primary to high-school grades.

FOR the neediest of New York City, The New York Times today opens its fifty-eighth annual appeal. On this and the three following pages are 100 stories of physical misery and spiritual want. Although these are reports of individual tragedies, they are at the same time representative of hundreds of similar cases and thousands of individuals who will also benefit from the campaign.

THE time is after midnight at Mt. Sinai Hospital on upper Fifth Avenue in New York City. In a small cubicle the size of a walk-in closet a woman in her late twenties sleeps quietly. An array of tiny wires, pasted to her head and other parts of her body, leads into a small switchbox above the bed -- the now-standard electroencephalograph (EEG) apparatus for measuring the activity of the sleeping and dreaming brain.
CHICAGO -- The Black Panther party says there is a national conspiracy to wipe out their leadership and destroy their organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Two major peace groups announced today that they would combine their antiwar activities for the first time in an effort to bring the young and old together on the local level during the December Moratorium.

SANTO DOMINGO PUEBLO, N. M., Dec. 4 -- They say that some of the houses have served the people for 400 years. The adobe of the walls is the same red color as the dust of the streets, for both came from the red earth where the pueblo stands on the bench above the Rio Grande.
The odd thing about a well fed fat person is that he is behaving metabolically like a starving lean person, according to Dr. Walter M. Bortz, a physiological scientist who specializes in obesity.

VIENNA, Dec. 6 -- The Moscow meeting of Soviet-bloc leaders this week "proffered a hand to all nations in Europe for security and progress," the Czechoslovak Communist party newspaper, Rude Pravo, said today.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 -- The Agnew jokes are being replaced in the South by bumper stickers saying, "Spiro is my hero."

I read with interest Jack Gould's analysis of the cancellation of the Leslie Uggams show. The key word is "ratings." Neither I nor any of my friends have a device on our TV sets to show which program is being viewed by us.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 6 -- Concern over the increase in new foreign technical words was expressed here as language experts from 19 Spanish-speaking nations met last week in the first Hispano-American Congress of Lexicography "to strengthen the bonds of the mother tongue that unites us."
COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Jim England sank two free throws with 27 seconds remaining tonight to give Tennessee a 55-54 upset of second-ranked South Carolina.

BEDMINSTER, N. J., Dec. 6 -- F. T. Ch. Dansnith's Gunshot, a 4-year-old dog, owned, bred, and handled by Daniel K. Langhans of Morton Grove, Ill., won the English Springer Spaniel national open championship stake today, after five land series and two water tests.

PALMA, Majorca, Spain -- Improved air and water connections with the Spanish mainland and thrice-weekly direct flights from New York are helping to bring an increasing number of American tourists to the Balearic Islands in the Mediterranean, off Spain's eastern coast.

LOS ANGELES -- In mid-October, sheriff's deputies raided the fortified retreat of a band of youthful wanderers in wild desert country near Death Valley. Several dozen suspects were arrested on charges of receiving stolen property and stealing automobiles, which the group apparently was converting into dune buggies.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 6 -- New Jersey's Freeholders, who run the governments of the state's 21 counties, were assured here this week that the importance of county government was growing and not shrinking under the pressures of state and Federal authority.

PENSACOLA, Fla. -- A new concept in family entertainment, recreation and education has been created near here by the Northwest Florida Zoological Society. It is a combination of an African-type veldt zoo and an area for camping, picnicking, swimming, hiking and other outdoor activities.
The Overbearing Multi-product Corporation and White, Lipped Trembling Advertising have mutually agreed to terminate their year-long relationship.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6 -- United States commanders in Vietnam have been ordered to reindoctrinate their men on the proper treatment of civilians as a result of the alleged massacre at Songmy.

MIAMI, Dec. 6 -- The next time Fast Hilarious runs at Tropical Park you can be certain that he will be wearing blinkers again. Joe Bollero, his trainer, decided to take the blinkers off his colt for today's $15,000 added Gold Coast Handicap and the experiment proved disastrous.

Corporate bond specialists, heartened last week by a strong market rally after top-quality yields touched 9.10 per cent, seem cautiously optimistic about prospects over the next month or so.

Buckley Jr. and repentant former Communists such as Whittaker Chambers be included in the overseas libraries.

The Beethoven bicentennial may not have begun, officially, but Benno and Sylvia Rabinof obviously see no purpose in holding up the celebrations. Lee Roy Yarbrough, who set records for major victories and earnings in stock car racing this season, was named the winner yesterday of the Martini Rossi American driver-of-the-year award. The 31-year-old Columbia, S. C., driver was honored at a luncheon at the Sheraton-West Hotel in Los Angeles.

OTTAWA, Dec. 8 (Canadian Press) -- The fourth constitutional conference of the federal and provincial governments opened today with Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau welcoming Premier Edward R. Schreyer of Manitoba to the conference table.

HAVING successfully made his escape from Montreal, the president of the National Hockey League, Clarence Campbell, said here yesterday, "I'm glad I won't be home for a few days." Perhaps he was speaking with tongue in cheek at the weekly hockey writers' luncheon

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 8 -- The Suffolk Board of Supervisors authorized the county today to coordinate, develop and modernize all the airports in the county and to acquire Suffolk Air Force Base as a general aviation airport.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- Melvin R. Laird and William P. Rogers warned here today that the United States would intensify the build-up of South Vietnam's military strength as an alternative to fruitless negotiation in Paris.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Chief Justice Warren E. Burger disclosed today that he believes the First Amendment grants state officials broad discretion to suppress obscene material.
A member of the Federal Reserve Board called attention yesterday to the fact that the money supply, which did not change at all in the third quarter, recently had begun once again to increase.

If the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center, in this its fifth season at the Vivian Beaumont, still hasn't found total happiness (an elusive goal at best in the theater), at least it appears to have found a sense of continuity that is far more conductive to its growth.
The Cannon Mills Company raised prices by about 3 per cent on all-cotton sheets and pillowcases yesterday. The move was followed at once by other major textile manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Two more Army officers were questioned today by Army investigators inquiring into whether the original investigation of the alleged Songmy massacre may have been inadequate and whether the Army may have covered up the incident.
A joint legislative committee that is preparing a bill to set up a state department of consumer affairs met yesterday at 270 Broadway to get the bill ready for the January Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The free market price of gold continued to crumble today, dropping to within 5 cents of the official monetary price of $35 an ounce.

WHAT we have here is not exactly history written by flashes of lightning, nor in the pitiless glare of kleig lights. It is, rather, a reconsideration under the scholar's slow, steady, sober lamp, while shadowy footnotes creep about the study walls. Indeed, Mr. Ehrman appears to have broken the cipher of fireflies for the light is cold.

A 38-year old widow and her four children received a $665,000 damage award yesterday for the death of her husband in the crash of an American Airlines jet near Cincinnati that killed 58 persons on Nov. 8, 1965.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- The Democratic leaders in the Legislature have begun a fight to eliminate revisions made in the state education aid formulas in the last session. These revisions, they say, will cost local school districts $245-million in the 1970-71 school year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- A group of computer experts and political scientists gathered at the University of Chicago recently to try to figure out what life might be like if there was an "information utility" that could be piped into the house like water or electricity.
DENVER, Dec. 6 -- It was once a fairly easy matter to bring a $65-million plant and 725 jobs into a small town.
A 12-year-old boy, musing about his life behind barbed wire in a Nazi concentration camp for children foresaw his doom when he wrote these lines:
Charlie Johnson is very close to earning a doctorate in chemcal engineering, he can probably predict what properties can be mixed and what properties cannot be mixed.

Harry Litwak, the Temple basketball coach, urged the metropolitan college teams yesterday to form a conference comparable to the Big Five in the Philadelphia area, which includes Temple, La Salle, Villanova, Penn and St. Joseph's.
Edwin D. Etherington, president of Wesleyan University, and John B. Connally, former Governor of Texas, have been elected trustees of the United States Trust Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr. proposed today that as a step toward "disenthralling our foreign policy" Congress repeal four cold war resolutions, including the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution of 1964.

A decade ago this month the Antarctic Treaty was signed by the United States, the Soviet Union and ten other countries. With the passage of time, the example set by this treaty has grown enormously in significance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The State Department appeared to be perplexed today over last week's political mission to Panama undertaken by the former Speaker of the New York State Assembly, Joseph F. Carlino, on Governor Rockefeller's recommendation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department today estimated the weather-battered 1969 cotton crop at 10,080,000 bales, up about 44,000 bales from the November forecast.
The bear market in membership on the New York Stock Exchange touched a 33-month low yesterday when a seat was transferred for $280,000, down $20,000 from the last previous sale on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted today its own "truth in lending" rules for margin and other credit accounts handled by brokers.
David Rockefeller told the Council for Latin America yesterday that the United States will need an increase in the flow of imports as a tool to fight inflation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has protested as "unnecessarily cruel" a news magazine's article on the death of his father, Joseph P. Kennedy.

TOKYO, Dec. 8 -- Rodger Kent Scott, a young American teacher who had participated in demonstrations here against the Vietnam war, left for Honolulu last night with his wife, a Japanese, after a long battle with Japanese immigration authorities and two periods of incarceration in the Yokohama Detention Center.

WARSAW, Dec. 8 -- Western diplomatic sources said today that West Germany had offered Poland the equivalent of $550-million in long-term credits to finance purchases of West German equipment over the next five years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, turned his attention to New York today in his campaign against what he calls "neglected and uncorrected" school segregation in the North.
Ole Singstad, the engineer who was regarded as "the master tunnel builder," died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 1120 Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Nixon said tonight that he would announce within "the next two or three weeks" a further withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam.
Subway turnstiles will be ready by the end of next week to take any fare in coins or tokens from the present 20 cents to 50 cents, a Transit Authority spokesman said last night.
It was a new week on the American Stock Exchange but prices went the same old way -- down, reaching their lowest level in three months.

ROME, Dec. 8 -- Pope Paul VI today lauded the century-old dogmas of papal supremacy and infallibility and said that time and experience had dissolved the "aversion" and "fear" they aroused at their proclamation in 1870.

Villager Industries, Inc., the troubled apparel company now under the management of Jonathan Logan, Inc., has renegotiated its substantial short-term debt with eight banks in an unusual arrangement involving deferment of the $43-million debt for 3 years and waiving of all interest for 18 months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A major split over monetary policy in the Federal Reserve Board was confirmed today.

COSTA-GAVRAS'S "Z," the French film that won the Jury Prize (in effect, the third prize) at this year's Cannes Festival, is an immensely entertaining movie -- a topical melodrama that manipulates our emotional responses and appeals to our best prejudices in such satisfying ways that it is likely to be mistaken as a work of fine -- rather than popular -- movie art.

CAMP LeJEUNE, N. C., Dec. 8 -- Twenty black marines are being returned to this racially troubled camp from active duty in the Mediterranean for investigations into their alleged participation in a series of all-black and unauthorized meetings.
THREE years ago, when New York City was preparing to increase real estate taxes, Mayor Lindsay complained that realty interests were using "high priced talent" to defeat the effort.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko met with Ambassador Helmut Allardt of West Germany for 90 minutes today as talks began on the mutual renunciation of force.

HONG KONG, Dec. 8 -- The General Political Department of the People's Liberation Army, which was paralyzed for more than two years, has been reactivated, and a number of important military appointments have been made by Chinese Communist authorities.

Controversy continued to smolder at City College yesterday as pressure mounted smolder at City College yesterday as pressure mounted against the planned dismissal of eight sociology teachers who backed radical students' de-demands in th edisruption on campuses last spring.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service has granted a nonprofit corporation headed by friends of former President Lyndon B. Johnson a tax exemption that qualifies it to receive surplus Federal land for a nursing home here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Jan. 5 for hearing new witnesses in the proposal of the American Electric Power Company, Inc., New York to acquire the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company.
WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 8 -- Cesare Gennari is a man torn between two counties.
MADRID, Dec. 8 -- The forthcoming election of officers of the Madrid Bar Association is presenting the new Spanish Cabinet with its first sharp political challenge.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Following are excerpts from the statement on civil disobedience by the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence:

CELORON, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- A tank car carrying liquid propane exploded and burned about 6:45 A.M. today in a freight train derailment along the Erie-Lackawanna tracks in this village about four miles west of Jamestown in southwestern New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A bare majority of the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence said today that massive civil disobedience, even the nonviolent kind inspired by Gandhi and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., could lead to anarchy in the United States.
A shareholder's suit seeking to enjoin the Checker Motors Corporation from making taxicabs and automobiles was filed here yesterday in Federal Court for the Southern District of New York.
From a pianistic standpoint, Jung-Ja Kim, the young Korean who played at Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night, belies her age.

Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., who, as White House chief of protocol probably leads the most active social life of anybody in Washington, had a party given to him for a change in New York last night for his talents as a racing yachtsman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Export-Import Bank announced today a new "facility" aimed at helping American suppliers finance the local currency costs of projects abroad.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 -- The Los Angeles police and members of the Black Panther party fought a four-hour gun battle here today following a predawn raid on Panther headquarters. Three policemen and three Panthers were wounded, but there were no fatalities.
Silver futures prices dropped sharply yesterday, and a broker commented that "there is nothing to point a finger at." In other words, the downturn continued a recent trend of weakness.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The nation's manufacturers expect an "appreciable slowdown" in the growth of their sales during the next four months, the Commerce Department reported today.

Wilson Co., Inc., the large meat-packing company controlled by Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., announced yesterday terms of its proposed offer to exchange cash and the common stock of four new subsidiaries for Wilson common stock.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the Federal narcotics laws that make it a crime for peddlers of marijuana and heroin to fail to use official order forms when they sell narcotics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to reduce sharply penalties for the possession and sale of marijuana and other illicit drugs, a prime Nixon Administration goal.
The effect of the Supreme Court ruling, legal experts here said, is to strengthen the city's ability to punish illegal strikes by public employes.
About 1,000 commuters who for years have been unable to board the 8:10 ferry from Staten Island to the Battery made it with ease during the morning rush yesterday.

To the Editor: Your editorial of Nov. 30 advocating Big Four talks as the only hope for Mideast peace is one of those propositions that look good on the surface (for who could be against peace talks?) but when examined more closely threaten to lead us to opposite conclusions.
Nodouble and Gamely were announced as the Thoroughbred Racing Associations' champion older thoroughbreds of the 1969 season yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The general counsel of the United Mine Workers of America accused the Labor Department today of trying to influence the outcome of tomorrow's election for union president by charging the incumbent, W. A. (Tony) Boyle with financial irregularities.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 8 -- At their first meeting since the conference at The Hague last week, the foreign ministers of the European Common Market countries today drew up a list of problems that will have to be discussed before membership talks can start with Britain, Ireland, Norway and Denmark.
A lawyer summed up the defense yesterday for John F. Curtin, a transportation engineer accused of conspiring with Roy M. Cohn and others to bribe a city appraiser.

Someday, owned by the Hobeau Farm, brought a little sunshine into the hearts of the favorite players at gray, sodden Aqueduct yesterday. Established the public choice by the 19,114 hardy players who did not dare miss the penultimate Monday of the local season, Someday registered a thrilling victory in the main event.
Wasting no time, Helen Bonfils and Morton Gottlieb, sponsors of Brian Friel's "The Mundy Scheme," opening Thursday, have bought two contemporary comedies for Broadway this season.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 8 -- Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison said today that he would seek an injunction under the Taylor Law against the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association if a "minority" of its members continued to use illegal means to pressure the county into reopening contract talks.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Dec. 8 -- The sun was bright, the air was sparkling and occasionally a bird twittered from the cacti as the Association of National Advertisers began its 60th annual meeting with a look at the dark side.

It was a gloomy Thursday in Dayton, Ohio, when Arnold Palmer finished the first round in the Professional Golfers' Association championship last Aug. 14. After an 82, the likeable Pennsylvanian admitted that a recurring hip ailment was forcing him to quit the tournament and the pro circuit for a two-month rest.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 7 -- Saudi Arabia acknowledged today that she had resumed aid to the Yemeni royalists in their intermittent seven-year civil war against the republican Government of Yemen, which is based in Sana.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 8 -- Len Dawson, the experienced but damaged quarterback of the Kansas City Chiefs, was pronounced fit today to start against the Oakland Raiders in Saturday's showdown for the Western Division title of the American Football League.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The White House sought today to squelch new's report that Tricia Nixon was about to become engaged to a Harvard law student.
Marina Snow, the 13-year-old daughter of a prominent Long Island woman, returned to her parents yesterday after what she told her mother was a week of riding on subways and sleeping on benches.

A Congressman with an influential voice in hemisphere affairs predicted yesterday that United States relations with Latin America, "on the private as well as governmental level, will get worse before they get better."

A program of three Beethoven sonatas and one by Mozart offers any pianist plenty of rope, and it was not surprising that Jack Brimberg failed to make a complete success of it last night at Town Hall. But Mr. Brimberg did surprise one with the consistency of his playing, which was conscientious but doggedly mediocre.

MILAN, Italy, Dec. 8 -- La Scala, reigning queen of Italian opera houses, opened furtively last night with a new production of Verdi's "Ernani" and the well-received debut of Placido Domingo, Metropolitan Opera tenor.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Sirhan Bishara Sirhan, condemned assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, has been on an I 1-day hunger strike protesting his confinement in San Quentin Prison's death row, James W. L. Park, associate warden, said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 8 -- Enemy troops, stepping up battlefield activity, launched 44 artillery attacks against allied military installations and bases throughout South Vietnam last night, military sources reported today.

Jerome Rose's two earlier recitals in Alice Tully Hall this fall were devoted to the music, respectively, of Beethoven and Schumann. To open his final program of the series last night, the pianist chose the Variations on a Theme of Schumann by Brahms, the composer of the evening, making a nice bridge from the previous recital.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Defense Attorneys moved to dismiss the 110 murder charges against First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. today on the ground that he "cannot be afforded a fair and impartial trial in any U. S. Military Court."

IT WAS the decade of fashion and now it is ending. In the 1960's, fashion spilled out of the closet and into politics, the arts and big business. Politicians' wives and social climbers learned to drop designer names. The proper answer to the formerly impertinent question, "Whose dress are you wearing?" was not, as Lady Bird Johnson, Mary Lindsay and Happy Rockefeller discovered, "My own."

FORT DIX, N. J., Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Pvt. Terry Klug, the third soldier to face a general court-martial on charges growing from the June 5 riot in the Fort Dix stockade, was acquitted of all counts today.

Increasing congestion and delay in court cases on government condemnation of property have led Justice Aron Steuer of the Appellate Division to propose that such cases be turned over to an expert tribunal.
As the holiday season approaches, donors to the 58th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are renewing their commitments to the city's poor and unfortunate.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the United Auto Workers and the Mayor of the town where Fred Hampton grew up joined dozens of black community organizations today in calling for an investigation into the slaying of the Black Panther leader.
TULSA, Okla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Cassius Clay, the deposed world heavyweight champion, will fight Billy Joiner here Jan. 10, promoters said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Anyone who wonders why so many Americans have become skeptical, if not cynical, about the ability of their political institutions to function equitably and efficiently need only look at the mess being made of the tax reform bill by Congress, without much counterbalance from the Nixon Administration.

WHAT happens to synthetic playing surfaces like AstroTurf when freezing rain falls? The Eagles and the Redskins found out at Philadelphia's Franklin Field on Sunday and, as is often the case, man's technology left room for improvement.

The corporate bond market, which perked up late last week after several new issues were successfully placed, tacked on some small gains yesterday. Other fixed-income securities, however, could not keep pace.

The City Investing Company, whose diversified interests include real estate and land development, mobile homes, manufacturing and insurance, realized a 52.9 per cent profit gain in the three months ended Oct. 31 and 103.6 per cent for the first fiscal half-year ended that date.
After nearly three years of litigation, the author of "How to Avoid Probate" yesterday lost a $6-million suit against the bar association that tried to keep his book off the market.
Since the Apollo 12 astronauts sent the ascent stage of their lunar module crashing onto the moon on Nov. 20, seven other objects have apparently hit within 60 miles of the landing site.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The House approved $69.9-billion in appropriations for the Defense Department today after routinely rejecting a move to delay deployment of the Safeguard missile defense system.

Dan Pike, fourth in the first classman (senior) class at the United States Naval Academy and one of the middies' football co-captains, headed a group of 11 scholar-athletes presented at the New York football writers' luncheon at the New York University Club yesterday.
PURCHASE, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- A group of 17 black students barricaded themselves in the main academic building of Manhattanville College tonight.

Hopes of reviving the Metropolitan Opera, whose season has been delayed for three months, continued high yesterday as management and union negotiators met in long bargaining sessions in the darkened opera house.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Institute for Automobiles and Roads has set its sights on building the world's fastest car. The newspaper Pravda Ukrainy reports that engineers are designing a car to reach the speed of sound -- 742 miles an hour.

Blockbusting? Ray Harris, the young, bearded Negro real estate salesman, looked out at Church Avenue through the plate glass of the brightly lighted realty office and laughed gently. "White people move out any time black people move in," he said. "That's plain old racism.''
WEST UNITY, N. H. -- High on a ridge in the unbroken forest that stretches from West Unity to Ackworth, we found tracks of large deer.

The London Stock Exchange closed steady yesterday, showing little reaction to Friday's lower closing on Wall Street. Most leading issues finished firmly around opening levels, although British Match, Rank and Bats gained by fractions of a point each.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Governor Rockefeller plans to announce tomorrow that he will support Sen ator Charles E. Goodell for election to a full term in the United States Senate. The announcement is to be made at a meeting here of Republican party county chairmen.

Dr. Joseph P. McMurray, president of Queens College, suggested yesterday to a group of educators that private colleges and universities should cooperate with the city and state universities in open admissions to disadvantaged students and that the city and state help finance the program.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 8 -- Syrian and Israeli tank and artillery units fought a one-hour battle today along the cease-fire line in the Golan heights.

To the Editor: It is very likely that the new draft lottery system is less random and more selective than is generally believed. This assertion is based upon a probable premise that births are not evenly distributed over the dates of a calendar year and that names are not equally likely to begin with each of the letters of the alphabet.
Don S. Friedkin has been appointed president of Ward Franchises, Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Ward Foods, Inc. He formerly was president of Ted Gotthelf Associates, Ltd.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The defense in the Chicago conspiracy trial began presenting its case today, but its first witness was immediately prevented from testifying.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Announcer: Listen, Hanoi!
This will be a record year for local movie production, it was reported yesterday by municipal spokesmen responsible for implementing Mayor Lindsay's campaign to increase filmmaking here.

John Lahr, 28-year-old drama critic for Evergreen Review and The Village Voice, and author of the recently published biography of his Father, Bert Lahr, "Notes on a Cowardly Lion," has been named winner of the 1968-69 George Jean Nathan award for drama criticism. The award carries a cash prize of $4,500.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 8 -- The Royal Swedish Ballet, over the weekend, gave what it called a double premiere, with different leading couples, of its production of Kenneth Macmillan's "Romeo and Juliet." To attempt this work inevitably invites comparison with the production, internationally known on film as well as on stage, by the British Royal Ballet.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Nevele Pride and Miss Conna Adios were named today the best 4-year-old harness horses of 1969 in a nationwide balloting by harness writers and broadcasters conducted by the United States Trotting Association and the United States Harness Writers Association.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Three Democratic Assemblymen who contend that the state's $6.4-billion budget is illegal urged the Court of Appeals today to resolve quickly a technical problem surrounding their suit so that a ruling on the constitutional issue they have raised can be obtained before the 1970-71 budget is submitted to the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The appointment of a permanent director of public affairs is expected by officials to end a growing turmoil at Peace Corps headquarters here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Mrs. John N. Mitchell, wife of the Attorney General, has been doing some enthusiastic lobbying for the Administration in telephone calls to Senators' wives, it was reported today.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 8 -- The United States economy faces some "bad, bitter medicine" before it can again grow solidly, the Secretary of Commerce warned the nation's lead ing investment bankers today. Maurice H. Stans, a former investment banker himself, presented this cautionary outlook in an address to the opening session of the annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America here.
The executive council of the Eastern College Athletic Conference discussed the case of Jack Langer, a Yale basketball player, yesterday and said an announcement would be made today.
SAN DIEGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Jack McMahon was dismissed today as coach of the San Diego Rockets of the National Basketball Association.
The will of Chester F. Carlson, inventor of the xerography process for rapid copying of documents, has provided $688,000 for the National Sharecroppers Fund.

PARIS, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- Communications experts from 60 countries called today for more exchanges of television programs such as that showing the first men on the moon to a quarter of the world's population.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Governor Rockefeller strongly endorsed Senator Charles E. Goodell today for election to a full term and told Republican county chairmen that the choice of Mr. Goodell would attract new support for the Republican ticket in 1970.

What the New York subway situation needs is less political talk about the twenty-cent fare and more concern with the deterioration of subway service. During the morning rush hour the ride on E and F trains from 179th Street in Jamaica to Lexington Avenue and 53d Street now averages an hour.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y, Dec. 8 -- In the five years he has served here as Malta's first, and only, chief delegate, Arvid Pardo has established a reputation for proposals that are novel, erudite and radical, or a combination of all three.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday it had suspended trading in the shares of the Heli-Coil Corporation to give the Mite Corporation an opportunity to count the Heli-Coil shares it had received under a tender offer.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The Government unveiled today its Whitehall development plans, which will include two new office buildings of modern design and a vehicular tunnel along the Thames in front of the Houses of Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- L. Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Carolina, who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said today that he was not ready to go as far as President Nixon and concede that a massacre had occurred at Songmy.

The bicentennial of Beethoven's death, which falls in 1970, has led to the scheduling of many Beethoven concerts for the 1969-70 music season, one of which was a piano sonata recital played at Philharmonic Hall last night by Claudio Arrau.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 9 -- Roger Nicholson, a 38-year-old Scottish - born Rhodesian journalist, pleaded guilty today to charges of having given secret economic information to an unidentified "foreign agent." He is scheduled to be sentenced by a high court judge here tomorrow.

SOME months ago International Business Machines, Inc., did its "unbundling" bit, moving to separate charges for computer hardware from charges levied for most other services. Wall Street acted at first as if the move would cost I.B.M. shareholders money.

A rally on the American Stock Exchange failed to last yesterday, leaving most issues lower on the session.
Silent Screen, winner of five of six races, was chosen yesterday by the Thoroughbred Racing Associations as the champion 2-year-old colt of 1969.

Laird told a House Appropriations subcommittee in secret testimony, now released, that President Nixon's policies in Vietnam "could lead the way to a military victory in the sense of the South Vietnamese being able to defend their country, even against North Vietnam."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A series of enemy attacks was reported in the Mekong Delta today.

NEWARK, Dec. 9 -- In the aftermath of six days of rioting here in 1967, a 10-member Commission on Civil Disorder named by Gov. Richard J. Hughes suggested that a sense of "pervasive feeling of corruption" by Newark residents of both races had contributed to the city's explosive tensions.
BONN, Dec. 9 -- United States Secretary of the Treasury, conferred here today with West German Finance Minister, Alex Moeller in what was officially described as a courtesy visit.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., does not plan to sell its Paramount motion-picture holding despite a $22-million loss during the last fiscal year, David N. Judelson, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

The recent call for an easing of monetary policy by Prof. Milton Friedman is bound to create some bewilderment for observers of economic events. For since his election President Nixon's advisers have been confident that by a tight money policy, and a taut fiscal endeavor, the inflationary price movement would be checked.

MIAMI, Dec. 9 -- Last September in Havana, Dr. Alberto Garcia performed a minor operation on Cuba's Foreign Minister, Raul Roa. A month later, the 48-year-old urologist arrived in the United States as a refugee, one of some 2,700 Cuban physicians who have left their country since the 1959 revolution.
Bowing to public opposition, the Board of Education announced last night that it would withdraw its proposal to redistrict Bronx schools under its new decentralization program.

The Eltra Corporation achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, essentially reflecting internal growth and despite a substantial reduction in military business, J. A. Keller, president, reported yesterday.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Arts and Letters and Majestic Prince top an impressive list of horses nominated for the $145,000-guaranteed Santa Anita Handicap next March. But whether their great rivalry as 3-year-olds will be renewed in the race remains to be decided.
A drive to raise money for American deserters and draft resisters in Canada was opened yesterday by a group of churchmen opposed to the war in Vietnam.
Automobile owners in the state will have to pay up to $71 more for their basic car insurance under a rate revision that goes into effect Monday.

HANOI, North Vietnam (Agence France-Prsse) -- The Standing Committee of North Vietnam's National Assembly has approved a Government reshuffle apparently designed to streamline national economic management and improve consumer supply.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The winter meeting of the Republican Governors Association scheduled here Thursday through Saturday will focus on Federal-state relations and on the posture of state government in the 1970s.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Three business forecasters predicted today that 1970 would bring increased unemployment and higher prices.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 9 (AP) -- There was a lot of talk about the New York Mets' pitching last season, but official National League averages, released today, showed only two Mets among the top 15 hurlers on the basis of earned-run averages.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The coordinators of the Vietnam Moratorium Committee acknowledged today that they had reached a watershed point in their antiwar organizing.

WHEN Joe Pepitone first joined the Yankees in 1962, the top brass rubbed its hands in glee. The more optimistic dreamers envisioned another Joe DiMaggio, even though the image might have emerged on a slightly reduced scale. But there was so much natural talent there that Pepi was immediately given star-of-the-future stature.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- W. A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers of America, seemed headed for re-election tonight in the first significant voting competition among the nation's 193,000 unionized coal miners in 43 years. Legal challenges to the outcome were expected.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

WASHINGTON Dec. 9 -John W. Gardner said today that the United States was undergoing a "failure of leadership" in domestic affairs, and he urged President Nixon to speak out "more explicitly and with greater urgency" on what was needed to move the nation out of "a kind of paralysis of the will."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- "It's a sort of pioneering feeling, like the first train going across the country," Sister Laura Palka said enthusiastically today as she rode the first transcontinental bus powered by a turbine engine.

In reporting on the Songmy massacre, all the media, including The Times, have been quick to point out that the enemy has been guilty of even worse atrocities. We are reminded that for years it has been Vietcong policy to kill village chiefs and other officials connected with the Saigon regime.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Delegates of 43 major airlines completed a 23-day meeting here today with an agreement on new fares that cuts $50 frrom the basic trans-Atlantic ticket.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -President Nixon disclosed today that he would deliver another report to the nation on the war in Vietnam when he announces the next withdrawal of United States troops.

PELL CITY, Ala., Dec. 9 -- The American Civil Liberties Union has asked a Federal judge to order a halt to what it calls the harassment of Black Muslims trying to establish a cattle farm in northeastern Alabama.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 9 -- St. John's handed West Virginia one of its worst home-court defeats tonight as the Redmen trounced the Mountaineers, 76-60, before a capacity crowd of 6,700.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Longshoremen injured or killed while working on a pier permanently affixed to the shore are not entitled to Federal compensation, the Supreme Court ruled today.
William C. Warren, dean of the Columbia University Law School since 1953, will step down at the end of the academic year, the university announced yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 -The Department of Transportation unveiled today a sleek, two-man research rail vehicle able to travel 250 miles an hour -- almost twice as fast as the fastest trains.
A heavyweight title fight between Cassius Clay and Joe Frazier in Tampa was being negotiated yesterday after Gov. Claude Kirk of Florida had given his approval. It would be held in February or March.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Bertrand Russell issued a statement here tonight repudiating any connection with his former secretary, Ralph Schoenman, or knowledge of his activities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Federal Food and Drug Commissioner will soon be replaced in the first of a series of Administration moves to shake up an agency that has come under increasing attack from consumer groups, private business and Congress.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 -- The Soviet Union is closing out the year with a spurt of diplomatic activity, highlighted by simultaneous negotiations on major issues with Communist China, West Germany and the United States -- the three nations against which the Soviet people only a few months ago were told to be most vigilant.
A jazz concert for "singles" last night at La Martinique, 57 West 57th Street, indicated that this audience would rather dance than listen.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Despite all President Nixon's efforts to clarify his Vietnam policy in the last few weeks, two fundamental questions remain.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- A British Member of Parliament told today how she was arrested on Michigan Avenue during the 1968 Democratic National Convention here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that national banks could not offer armored-car services and receptacles for off-premise deposits in states where state banks were not allowed to do the same.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Miami has now jumped into one of the hottest battles being waged in Washington -- over the site of the exposition for the 1976 bicentennial celebration of the American Revolution.

The sentimental New York Giants are undoubtedly quite sad as they prepare for their final two games because they will be saying good-by to two old rivals who are moving over to the American Football League next season.

Relocation to New York, long regarded as a highly desirable plum by company employes, now is rejected frequently by workers because they consider the city an undesirable place to live, according to the National Industrial Conference Board.

The Prague Chamber Orchestra, which like a few others of its breed performs without a conductor, proved once again last night that such an economy is not necessarily deleterious to good music.
MOSCOW, Dec. 8 -- A top-level United Arab Republic delegation arrived here today for expected policy discussions with Soviet officials on the Middle East.
One of Wall Street's most venerable investment banking firms has moved into the real estate financing field, becoming a joint owner of one of the country's largest national mortgage-banking concerns.

IF the current television season has produced one undisputed hit, it is "Sesame Street," the experimental venture of the Children's Television Workshop. The program for preschoolers has a record rating for noncommercial broadcasting and boasts a lineup of 190 stations.
Irish International Airlines -- Aer Lingus -- announced yesterday it had sold a $20-million issue of Eurodollar 8 1/4 per cent bonds, due 1981.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A group of Mexican-Americans, charging that they have been victims of negative stereotyping on public airwaves, said today they intended to file a complaint with the Federal Communications Commission.

Heyward Dotson, the Columbia basketball star who said he had a poor first half, recovered and sparked the Lions to a 61-42 victory over Rutgers before 1,756 fans at University Hall last night.

Mayor Lindsay expressed concern yesterday over what he termed the lack of progress in contract talks between the Transit Authority and its 35,000 unionized employes.

Y., Dec. 9 -- The Security Council voted 13 to 0 today to "strongly condemn the Portuguese authorities'' for the shelling of the village of Samine in Senegal from neighboring Portuguese Guinea on Nov. 25 and again last Sunday. HANOVER, N. H., Dec. 10 -- Seventeen Dartmouth undergraduates, all of them Negro, have been placed on college discipline, the equivalent of probation, for one term for their role in a handclapping demonstration Oct. 15.

Former Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg is apparently out as Democratic nominee for Governor or Senator and Senator Charles Goodell is in as Republican nominee for the Senate. Both of these developments have significant implications for the state and for its major parties.
At a time of high interest rates and an inflationary pinch on pocketbooks, an American phenomenon -- interest-free Christmas Clubs -- continues to attract deposits with unabashed success.
Details of broad new bargains in trans-Atlantic airline fares, to become effective March 1, were made public here yesterday by the International Air Transport Association.
YONKERS, Dec. 10 -- The post position draw made this morning for Saturday night's final of the eighth annual Adios Fall Festival at Yonkers Raceway placed the Australian-bred Rhyl in the No. 8 slot.
Judge Thomas F. Croake dismissed yesterday a damage suit filed in Manhattan Federal Court by two American League umpires who had been discharged by the league.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The State Department emphasized today U.S. readiness to resume deplomatic relation with Arab states, but cautioned against any expectation of an immediate favorable response to the statement of Secretary of State William P. Rogers on Middle East policy last night.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 10 -- Syrian Army headquarters reported today the biggest battle of land forces with the Israeli Army since the 1967 war. Heavy artillery as well as tanks fired from both sides, the announcement said, but there was no mention of infantry action.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The International Monetary Fund announced today that, through two devices, West Germany has received $550-million representing Germany's past loans to the Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- In what his aides described "as lifting a corner of the curtain on the Administration's priorities for the next decade," President Nixon sent to Congress today a message requesting $40-million, almost double the current amount, for the National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities for the next fiscal year.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 10 -- For the first time in 20 years, Phoenix voters yesterday elected an "outsider" to the City Council.
The daytime television serial, or soap opera, is in the process of going activist.

The Boston Bruins were serenaded by "TALK to the Animals" when they took the Madison Square Garden ice last night. Then the Rangers started to play their own tune, mostly on the heads, necks and shoulders of the Bostonians, and skated off with a 5-2 victory.
The question of how safe the coming jumbo jets will be was raised repeatedly yesterday at a State Insurance Department hearing on air trip insurance premiums.

President Nixon said during his news conference Monday night that he was willing to take his chances on the press, "so long as the news media allows, as it does tonight, an opportunity for me to be heard directly by the people."
Most teams don't use four punters in four years, but there was Dave Dunaway waiting for the snap that would make him the Giants' fourth punter this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A delegation of 10 White House aides met today with 13 moderate Senate Republicans on Capitol Hill in an effort to smooth relations that have been reported strained by recent issues causing sharp divisions across party lines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- An Army helicopter pilot who is reported to have told superiors of unnecessary civilian killings at the South Vietnamese village of Songmy "did not report that" to a Congressional panel today, its chairman said.
MANILA, Dec. 9 -- Expressions of anti-American sentiment in the Philippines have increased in volume and shrillness in recent weeks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Gift suggestions for that man on your list:

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 -- The judge in the Sharon Tate murder case tried to reconcile the rights of free press and fair trial today by placing severe restrictions on out-of-court statements about the slayings.

After being down 14 cents at 2 P.M., prices on the American Stock Exchange rallied in the last hour yesterday to close up 3 cents to $26.22 at the end of the session. This was the first time in four sessions the exchange's index was on the plus side.
DEARBORN, Mich., Dec. 10 -- Henry Ford 2d predicted today that his company would sell as many cars in 1970 as in 1969 in spite of a sales decline next year for the automobile industry.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Dec. 8 -- Pollution has become an issue of widespread concern in this huge province of forests, mountains, lakes and extensive mineral deposits.
Stock prices continued to decline yesterday although a late afternoon upswing took some of the sting out of another broad slide earlier in the day.

Inspection of the draft lottery results clearly shows a systematically increasing number of men being drafted as their birthdate falls later in the year. The odds against this trend resulting from random selection are over 100,000 to one.

The Metropolitan Opera's chorus and ballet agreed yesterday to meet tomorrow and to vote on what one of their union representatives yesterday called a "this-is-it offer thrown down to us" by the management.

DeSapio in their bribery conspiracy trial had, "in the main," told the truth. But, he added, their testimony exonerates Corallo instead of proving him guilty.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Police Superintendent James B. Conlisk today ordered an internal police investigation of the slaying of the Black Panther leader Fred Hampton.

ROME, Dec. 10 -- Italy's national hydrocarbons monopoly, E.N.I., signed today a $3-billion, 20-year agreement to import natural gas from the Soviet Union that may set new pricing patterns and modify petroleum marketing conditions.

PRESIDENT Nixon sent a message of congratulations to Joe Paterno, coach of Penn State's undefeated football team, yesterday, just before Paterno accepted the Lambert Trophy, which goes to the outstanding major-college team in the East.
Goodbody Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, announced yesterday that it was acquiring Richards Co. of Pittsburgh.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- W. A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers of America, claimed victory today in one of the most strenuous union elections in recent labor history.

CLOVIS, N.M., Dec. 10 -- A five-man court-martial jury today convicted Airman 1st C1. August Doyle of willfully disobeying an order to cut his Afro style hair.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Renewing his attacks on President Nixon's Vietnam policies, Senator J. W. Fulbright predicted today that the Administration's "Vietnamization" plan would mean "continuing terror and death for the indefinite future" for the Vietnamese people.

CHANGING times in the National Football League are evident in that two of the four division winners for the second year in a row are expansion teams. The Minnesota Vikings, 8 years old, and the Dallas Cowboys, 9, have qualified for the championship playoffs with fresh management in a season when the oldtime family operations such as the Giants, Bears, Steelers and Cardinals show a combined won-lost percentage of .213.
The Theater Guild will offer "The Forty Year Old Man," a first full-length play by Everett Chambers, as its 220th production.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Pentagon is trying to exorcise the phrase "cost overrun" from its popular position in current political vocabulary here.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- A Cornell graduate student said today she was clubbed by a policeman as she tried to film a police attack on demonstrators outside the Conrad Hilton Hotel here on Aug. 28, 1968.
Bear, Steams Co., a leading institutional brokerage house, announced yesterday that it was entering the field of money management with the formation of Bear Stearns Capital Management.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The free market price of gold moved up from the official monetary level of $35 an ounce this afternoon. Dealers welcomed the small rally as postponing the uncertainities of a drop through the monetary price used in central bank transactions.

In a move to strengthen the administration of City University's 16 colleges, the Board of Higher Education's law committee is drafting a proposal to revert to the pre-1938 system of appointive department chairmen.

The more things change, the more they stay the same. This is fortunately true of the Bach Aria Group, which opened its 22d season last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell disclosed today that "within the next week or 10 days there is going to be a massive indictment" of public officials and gamblers in a state that has been corrupted by organized crime.

Jerome S. Hardy, publisher of Life magazine and a vice president of Time Inc. since 1964, has resigned to become executive vice president of The Dreyfus Corporation, a major investment company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- Soviet officials at the United Nations said today that Secretary of State William P. Rogers's statement last night about the Middle East was a "long overdue" step "in the right direction.
ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Willie (The Actor) Sutton, the bank robber and jailbreaker who has spent 35 of his 68 years in prison, was denied parole today.
HOUSTON, Dec. 10 -- Basking in the sunlight and fresh air, the Apollo 12 astronauts were released today from a 20-day quarantine and moved about freely for the first time in almost a month.

CULPEPER, Va., Dec. 10 (AP) -- J. L. Robertson, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today the board must make people realize the credit crunch will not be eased until inflation is ended, even if "tighter and more painful controls" are necessary.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Dr. Carl Coppolino's appeal of his second-degree murder conviction in the drug-injection death of his wife was dismissed today by the Florida Supreme Court. The court made no comment on the case.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- In a motel room in Beckley, W. Va., last Saturday afternoon, William Anthony Boyle, the leader of 193,000 unionized coal miners, turned down at the last minute an invitation from a television station to appear on a 30-minute interview program beamed to the largest concentration of bituminous miners in the country.

HONG KONG, Dec. 10 -- Some provinces in Communist China have called for the establishment of new party committees on an urgent basis. The move appeared to be aimed at extending the power of the established provincial authorities.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 10 -- Yale won its first basketball game of the season tonight, defeating Brown by 75-65.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that three Democratic Assemblymen would have to start court action all over again in their attempt to have the state's $6.4-billion budget declared unconstitutional.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- The P. O.-Orient liner Iberia limped into Southampton today 24 hours behind schedule at the end of a seven-week voyage from Australia that was beset with troubles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Pentagon said today that the equivalent of two squadrons of B-52 bombers would be pulled out of the Vietnam war in the coming months but that no orders have been issued for their redeployment.

ATHENS, Dec. 10 -- Thirty-one former Cabinet ministers and Members of Parliament publicly defied martial law today to urge the United States Government to proclaim its opposition to Greece's army-backed regime.

Governor Rockefeller endorsed a plan yesterday to change the proposed state office building in Harlem to a "service center" that would house community organizations and Federal, state and city agencies that provide services directly to Harlem residents.

A far-reaching document on relations between Roman Catholics and Jews that recommends reforms including the possibility of joint prayer has been made public by Lawrence Cardinal Shehan, Archbishop of Baltimore.

The Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corporation which is engaged in computer, consulting and financial services, realized a 60 per cent increase in earnings in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the company's report disclosed yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Government announced today that its armed forces had increased by 88,000 men during the last six months. This is believed to be a factor in the third withdrawal of American troops, which President Nixon will announce later this month.
