The Administration's "Southern strategy" has scored another victory in the House by defeating the extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. After hectic, last-minute lobbying by White House and Justice Department aides, the Administration's substitute, which has the endorsement of Southern segregationists, won by a narrow 208-to-203 margin.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11 (AP) -- An increase in enemy action north of Saigon and in the Mekong Delta was reflected last week by heavier casualties on both sides, allied headquarters reported today. The number of Americans killed in action rose to 100, an increase of 30 over the week before, but the United States command said the number of wounded was the lowest in seven weeks.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- The five-nation Association of Southeast Asian Nations faces a critical test next week, when the foreign ministers meet in the Cameron Highlands to consider proposals for cooperation.

SEATTLE, Dec. 11 -- The New York Knickerbockers, playing without Walt Frazier, the agile guard who usually paces their offense, and defense, got into foul trouble late in the game and, largely as a result, dropped a 112-105 National Basketball Association decision to the Seattle SuperSonics tonight before 10,029 delighted fans at the Coliseum.

TRENTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- A truck driver who said he and his wife played Russian roulette "every couple of weeks" because it was their way of life is being held today in connection with her death, according to the police.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- After months of debate on the intricate tax bill, the shape of the final legislation is now in the hands of the few senior Senators and Representatives who make up the conference committee.
DETROIT, Dec. 11 -- A decline in consumer confidence was reported today by the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center in its quarterly poll of buyer's attitudes.
HONOLULU, Dec. 11 (AP) -- On the tiny Pacific island of Pingelap, Polynesian beauty is little more than a colorless blur for some native children born with a mysterious eye ailment.
" Petty holdups and assaults" in the men's rest rooms at the American Museum of Natural History.

" OCEAN racing," Don Aronow once said, "is standing in a speeding boat tearing up $50 bills while someone hits you with a baseball bat." Aronow, a 6-foot 3-inch 210-pound former star athlete at Brooklyn College, not only survived the rugged pounding this year, but also captured his second world offshore championship and third straight national title while set
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Officials of the American Bar Association praised the Federal judiciary today for relaxing rules against off-the-bench activities that the association had termed too strict.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -American business piled up inventories in October by the largest amount in almost three years, the Commerce Department reported today.

A two-day stake-out by nine detectives of the Bronx District Attorney's squad thwarted the attempted burglary yesterday in Riverdale of a $300,000 mansion belonging to a millionaire real estate executive.

SANTA FE, N. M., Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Episcopal Bishop of New Mexico and Southwest Texas stopped financial support to the national church yesterday after learning of its $40,000 cash grant to the Alianza.

The Commonwealth United Corporation now is being operated by management of the Exeter International Corporation. It was incorrectly reported yesterday that the company was being managed by representatives of Investors Overseas Ltd.

New York Telephone, facing a rising tide of consumer irritation directed at both its equipment and personnel, is leaving Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, its ad agency of 35 years. Young Rubicam gets the account on Feb. 27. The billings are estimated at $3.5-million.

Community and university heaters must address themselves to encouraging and developing playwrights if the legitimate theater is to flourish, Frank Gilroy, Pulitzer Prize winning playwright and president of the Dramatists Guild, said yesterday.
MIAMI, Dec. 11 -- The Agriculture Department has announced that the Florida orange crop will be smaller than the department had expected.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Britain consolidated her impressive economic recovery with a merchandise trade surplus of $28.8-million in November, the Government reported today. It was the fourth consecutive monthly surplus.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The Nixon Administration urged the Supreme Court today to allow 250 school systems in the Deep South to put off pupil desegregation until the fall of 1970.
BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- Reacting at the final buzzer as if they had won the Stanley Cup, the Bruins tonight ended the Rangers' unbeaten string at 14 games with a powerful performance and a 2-1 victory.

Eugene H. Nickerson, the Nassau County Executive, announced last night a set of fiscal proposals that he said would increase state aid to localities in the next fiscal year by more than $1-billion, including an additional $653-million for New York City.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 11 -- The Syrian Government reported today that two Israeli planes, both Mirages, had been "seen burning and falling in occupied territory but the pilots came down safely."
The board of TRW, Inc., yesterday elected a new management team.

ATHENS, Dec. 12 -- The Greek Government said tonight that it would consider a cutback in contributions to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization if it was suspended tomorrow from the Council of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- A Congressman said today that the first C-5A jet transport to be delivered to the Air Force next week had wing defects that could kill the training crew. He urged that delivery be postponed until modified planes were ready.

TRENTON, Dec. 11 -- The New Jersey director of the United States Internal Revenue Service, reacting today to Attorney General John N. Mitchell's charge of extensive penetration of the I.R.S. in the state by organized crime, said that a Federal grand jury investigation might turn up the names of several revenue agents.

Paul O'Dwyer, who won the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in an upset last year but lost the election to Senator Jacob K. Javits, announced yesterday he would seek his party's senatorial nomination again next year.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 -- A large building project, involving housing, offices and stores and probably costing hundreds of millions of dollars, will be built on land of the Ford Motor Company in Dearborn, Mich.

A major revamping of the northeastern program of VISTA, the domestic version of the Peace Corps, has been ordered by the new director of the region in an effort to overcome admitted problems of low morale and wasted effort.

Four major investigations are known to be under way now into organized crime in New Jersey. They are being conducted by the United States Attorney's office, the Essex County Prosecutor, the State Commission of Investigation and a special state grand jury.

Some backstage bitterness marred the year-end bliss of the New York Mets yesterday when Ed Charles, released as a player at the end of the season, walked out on a promotional job with the club in a dispute about moving expenses.

The luxury of debarking in ease and comfort from the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth 2 after 12 days of cruising the West Indies was denied to 921 passengers yesterday as a result of a longshoreman's work stoppage.
TOOELE, Utah, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- A small quantity of nerve gas in liquid form leaked from a storage container at the Dug-way Proving Grounds today and forced the evacuation of 200 persons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The State Department asserted today that a majority vote yesterday in a United Nations committee interpreting a Geneva convention as banning the war-time use of all chemicals -- including tear gas and defoliants -- could not be regarded as "international consensus."

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 11 (AP) -- A Federal court ordered the state authorities today to refrain from prosecuting two men arrested in connection with the sale of land in northern Alabama to Black Muslims.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The White House and the State Department declined comment today on the boycott of the Paris peace talks.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- "General striptease" is a characteristic of decadent Western culture, according to a Soviet literary official in a speech to a conference of Soviet intellectuals that ended here today.

Newark's chief municipal judge was suspended yesterday, effective immediately, by New Jersey's Chief Justice, and a Union County judge was arrested, fingerprinted and put under $10,000 bail in the expanding Federal and local investigations of alleged official misconduct and organized crime in the state.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee voted today to grant more than $10-million extra to intensify the Government's drive against marijuana and narcotics.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Demonstrators jammed the steps and lawns of City Hall today in a rally called to protest a police raid on Black Panther headquarters and to demand a full-scale investigation by Federal and city agencies.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 11 -- Premier Golda Meir presented her new Cabinet to President Zalman Shazar today after having settled a last-minute impasse over a domestic policy issue. It was the last day of the time allotted to her to form a government.
The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, the nation's largest producer of specialty steels, said yesterday that prices would be raised on Monday on most of its high-temperature alloys.

James T. Aubrey Jr., the new president and chief executive officer of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., said yesterday that by the end of next month he would have cut the company's overhead $10-million to $15-million.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Joseph A. Yablonski demanded today a Federal investigation into his charges that (Tony) Doyle stole the United Mine Workers election from him.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 11 -- Plans by a church here to operate an integrated day-care center for underprivileged children on its premises have angered many residents of this affluent community.

HISTORY - minded Europeans see special significance in the fact that the West German diplomat who is holding talks with the Russians on a treaty renouncing the use of force was born in the East Prussian city of Konigsberg, now the Russian Kaliningrad.
About 150 students took over Wagner Hall at City College for three hours yesterday to protest the planned dismissal of eight sociology teachers.
The impression that a modest rate of monetary expansion has resumed was strengthened yesterday by financial data published by the Federal Reserve System.

David C. Webster, former assistant controller for the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company, has been appointed controller for the Brooklyn-based brewery. He joined the company ten years ago as a financial analyst.

Wheat futures gained almost a cent a bushel early yesterday in nearby contracts to make new life-of-contract highs. The news that encouraged the rise apparently was a report that Canada was negotiating with the Soviet Union for the sale of some wheat, plus talk that American farmers were holding wheat from markets hoping for higher prices.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 11 -- About 75 black students at Harvard University were summarily suspended from school today after the dean's office, the faculty club and a major construction site had been occupied in a demand for more black construction workers on campus.
MADRID, Dec. 11 -- The closest thing to political drama these days in Spain -- where political life moves in well-planned anticlimaxes -- is taking place on and off the stages of two Madrid theaters.

YONKERS, Dec. 11 -- Most drivers at Yonkers Raceway plan to call it a year when the track ends its meeting Monday night. With the 1970 campaign due to open Jan. 3 at Roosevelt Raceway, most drivers are looking forward to a brief respite.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- The Court of Appeals today reaffirmed that the results of lie-detector tests could not be admitted as evidence in criminal cases because they were not reliable enough "to warrant judicial acceptance."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The major differences between the House and Senate versions of the tax reform and relief bill are outlined below. They will have to be compromised by a joint conference committee of House and Senate members.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

A self-styled "paid informer," draped in a black hood to conceal his identity, testified yesterday that the Mafia had so skillfully stolen "over $1-million" in securities from Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith that the brokerage firm did not know the certificates were gone.

George Poplis, retracting a confession that he had fatally beaten his 3-year-old stepdaughter, denied yesterday at his murder trial that he had ever struck her and instead placed the blame on his wife, Marie, the child's mother.

Livingston Wingate, who had called a convention for this weekend to enable community groups in Harlem to vote on plans for the State Office Building site there, accused the head of the state's Urban Development Corporation yesterday of "violating both the spirit and the purpose of the convention."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Nixon sought advice on foreign policy today from former President Lyndon B. Johnson and later from other elder statesmen.

NEWARK, Dec. 11 -- Local leaders of business, labor, education and social work are agreed that the investigations of alleged corruption in this city have exerted a considerable public impact that could touch off enormous changes in all phases of the city's life.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Cassius Clay and Joe Frazier, apparently shunted out of Tampa by public opposition, may fight their heavyweight championship bout in a domed stadium at Orlando, Fla., two promoters said today.
A Federal prosecutor, summing up his case here yesterday against Roy M. Cohn and two former associates, said "the hard core of truth" was that they had participated in bribery and extortion.
Expenditures for weapons have posed a "financial crisis of the greatest magnitude" for Israel, the head of the Jewish Agency for Israel said last night.
" Yankee Doodle" and bits of Bach and other erudite selections echoed yesterday in the halls of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Despite your Dec. 6 editorial "Inflationary Blackmail," I can see nothing wrong about tacking the 15 per cent Social Security increase onto the tax bill if such an increase is just and can be obtained only in that way.

WHEN the Jets upset the Colts in the Super Bowl last January, a wave of exultation engulfed the American Football League at the attainment of instant equality with the hitherto insufferably superior and condescending National Football League. Untouched by that wave was Al Davis, the dictatorial overlord of the Oakland Raiders.
MINOT, N. D., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Eight persons were indicted yesterday by a Ward County grand jury for allegedly violating various state banking and corrupt practices laws.

HONG KONG, Dec. 11 -- North Vietnam's Defense Minister, Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, has declared that United States attempts to "Vietnamize" the war in South Vietnam will end in tragedy for the South Vietnamese Army and for withdrawing American troops.

Poland's most interesting composer between Chopin and Penderecki, Karol Szymanowski (1882-1937), remains a dim figure for us in spite of proselytizing on his behalf by Artur Rubinstein, who used to program some of the Mazurkas.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Bill Toomey, the Olympic champion, shattered the world decathlon mark today with 8,417 points, breaking the two-year-old mark of 8,319 held by West Germany's Kurt Bondlin.

For a new jazz group, one which had made only five previous appearances, a quartet called the New Art Cartel was extremely well pulled together in its performance last night at Muse, Bedford Avenue and Lincoln Place, Brooklyn.
TO pass on the first round of the auction and then enter the bidding at a high level without any sign of life from partner flies in the face of commonsense.
The Jets had just squeaked by Miami, and some of the players were discussing the Dolphins' quarterback.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Allen Ginsberg, the poet, met Julius Hoffman, the judge, today and the result was a total lack of communication.

TORONTO, Dec. 11 -- Recommendations for sweeping changes in the regulation of Canadian finance companies were issued today in a report by the Royal Commission on the spectacular collapse of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation in 1965.

A busy conductor on the international circuit, Istvan Kertesz is no stranger to this city, but last night he made his first appearance with the New York Philharmonic. The 40-year-old Hungarian's unorthodox program paired masterpieces totally dissimilar in style and orchestral demands: Mozart's Serenade No. 10 for Winds in B flat (K. 361), which uses a dozen or so players, and Bartok's "Bluebeard's Castle," a one-act opera requiring a massive ensemble.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The salaries of white-collar workers increased 5.7 per cent in the business year ending June 30, the Department of Labor said yesterday. It was the third successive year of record advances.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., Dec. 11 -- On land once held by the Delaware Indians of the Eastern Algonquin Confederacy now stands the pale yellow brick home of Anthony (Tony Boy) Boiardo, who is reputed to owe his allegiance to the Mafia.
THE New York City Ballet opened its Christmas engagement of 40 performances of "The Nutcracker" at the State Theater last night -- a run that will continue through Jan. 11.
Practically every day in New York some guillible person signs a contract to purchase merchandise on credit and agrees to conditions that would make most people's hair stand on end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Along writers' row on the second floor of the Executive Office Building a hoot away from the White House, the silence of a Sunday evening is broken often by the ringing of telephones.

Carmine G. De Sapio was described as an innocent, abused man by his lawyer, and as a scheming professional conspirator by a Federal prosecutor yesterday, in summations at the bribery-conspiracy trial of Mr. De Sapio and Antonio (Tony Ducks) Corallo.

Federal efforts to settle the seven-week-old strike against the General Electric Company received a setback yesterday when the two largest unions involved broke off negotiations, charging that the company had steadily refused to bargain.
SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 11 -- A South Korean commercial airline carryiing 51 persons, including a four-member crew, was hijacked to North Korea today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A Federal study recommended today the establishment of a Gateway National Recreation Area, served by low-fare ferryboats, at the entrance to New York Harbor.
Public libraries are asking for $5-million more in operating and maintenance funds next year. The request includes an increase of $700,000 in the allotment for new books.
BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Saigon holds about 30,000 prisoners of war, about 6,000 of them North Vietnamese Army regulars.
The City Council approved salary increases for elected officials yesterday that included a raise from $50,000 to $85,000 a year for Mayor Lindsay, who has said he does not want the increase.
" Someone close to you is on drugs. Can New York City's new program help you do something about it?"
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved ahead yesterday in moderate trading. The chief impetus was the release of improved British trade figures for November.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Two United States helicopter crewmen have been freed by the enemy and have limped into a South Vietnamese outpost on the Cambodian border, the United States command announced today. They will fly home Saturday.

A state hearing into alleged corruption in Yonkers heard testimony yesterday charging that a construction company had made more than a 30 per cent profit on a sewer laying job and that it had given moonlighting jobs to city inspectors charged with supervising its work.

The space agency, in a move expected to help soften criticism that it neglects science, plans to announce next week the first assignment of a scientist-astronaut to train actively for a lunar landing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The Justice Department filed an antitrust suit today to block the proposed consolidation of three Pennsylvania banks. The suit automatically halts the merger.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The Nixon Administration's antitrust chief sought today to urge Congress to raise corporation fines in antitrust cases to $500,000 from $50,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Several big-city Mayors urged today the defeat of a House move to give Governors veto power over Federal poverty programs.

An independent mayoral committee, headed by the dean of the New York University Law School, urged a major relaxation of the city's 26-year-old rent control law yesterday. The panel called also for the establishment of rent minimums and government subsidies to stem the decay of housing here.

" Give me a few millions which I would devote to agriculture and I would transform my country in five years," the President of Dahomey told a visitor last year. But Dr. Emile-Derlin Zinsou was to get neither the "few millions" nor the five years. He has been deposed by an Army faction in Dahomey's sixth coup in ten years of independence -- a record even for coup-prone Africa.

PRAGUE, Dec. 11 -- An investigation into the death in 1948 of Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovakia's last non-Communist Foreign Minister, suggested to day that he had slipped and fallen while sitting on a window ledge during a bout with insomnia.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 11 -New York State's delegation was voted out of the national convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of America tonght.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.
BONN, Dec. 11 -- West Germany decided today to vote to suspend Greece's military regime from the Council of Europe.
RENTON, Wash., Dec, 11 (AP) -- Dr. A. Frans Koome, who is trying to change the state's abortion laws, makes no attempt to cover up his defiance of those laws.
IF THERE is an active investor who is finishing the year without substantial losses, he must be an unusually astute -- or lucky -- individual.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges have issued their latest reports on changes in stockholdings by major stockholders, officers an directors of listed corporations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The House of Representatives, in what was interpreted as a major setback by leaders of the civil rights movement, voted today to terminate the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

CAIRO, Dec. 11 -- The Egyptian press reacted coldly today to the call by Secretary of State William P. Rogers for an Israeli-Arab settlement along the lines of a plan advanced by the United States six weeks ago, declaring that the plan had already been categorically rejected.

The Penn Central Company announced yesterday that the Interstate Commerce Commission has extended for five years to Oct. 15, 1979, the period in which it must dispose of up to 1,071,962 shares of Norfolk Western Railway stock which it holds as an investment.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- North Vietnam kept its chief negotiator away from the peace conference today as a protest against what it called "sabotage" of the talks by the United States.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 11 -- Minie Ball and Hasty Hussy, both trained by James W. Murphy, staged their own private race through the stretch of today's feature at Laurel Race Course and Minie Ball beat her entrymate by a nose.
ATLANTA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- C. B. King of Albany, a Negro lawyer, said today he would be a candidate for Governor of Georgia next year.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday in moderate trading.

Five dollars from a teenager in Maryland; $100 from a mourning mother on the East Side; $1 from a student at Syracuse University; $50 from a recent widow from Long Island . . . from the rich and the poor, on engraved stationery and on scraps of paper, contributions continue to arrive in response to the 58th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund appeal.

Twelve Yugoslav movies made in the last two years, mostly by directors in their 20's or early 30's, have completed showing as the Museum of Modern Art. They reveal a national cinema as attractive (though not as revolutionary) as any to emerge since the French New Wave 10 years ago.

THERE was the night she almost choked to death on a pine nut that was in a "yummy" rice dish that she ate at a Jordanian dinner. Then a black mouse moved into her luxury suite in the Barclay Hotel. (She finally caught it with a trap her husband brought from their California home.)
JERUSALEM, Dec. 11 -- Israeli jet fighters penetrated into Syria today and clashed with Syrian MIG's in a series of air battles that could be seen from roofs in Damascus.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 11 -- Providence's public school teachers voted today to end a 12-day strike by accepting a, new two-year contract.
ROME, Dec. 11 -- Italian bank workers won a sizable pay increase and what could prove the start of a new way of midday life in a labor contract signed here today after all-night talks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A top official of the Justice Department told a private conference of Government lawyers this week that the Nixon Administration intended to eliminate virtually all racial dual school systems in the South by September, 1970, informed sources said today.
Stock prices ended on a mixed note yesterday as the cross-currents of tax selling and switching continued to affect the market.

Gold is playing a diminishing role in the international monetary scene, Nathaniel Samuels, Deputy Under Secretary of State, said yesterday. The problem now, he added, is to keep the price from falling below $35 in ounce.

WE have all seen the spectacle of characters in search of an author. Brian Friel's "The Mundy Scheme" at the Royale Theater last night offered us the no less singular spectacle of scenes in search of a play.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- An official committee on drug safety is warning British doctors that contraceptive pills containing a high content of the hormone estrogen probably carry a greater risk of thrombosis, or blood clots.
The always-tenuous relationship between men and machines deteriorated slightly here yesterday as the Penn Central Company introduced computerized ticket-vending machines for Metroliner passengers.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Charles Manson, known to his hippie cult followers as "God," "Jesus," or "Satan," was arraigned in Superior Court here today for the murders of the actress Sharon Tate and six others.
George Chuvalo, the Canadian heavyweight champion from Toronto, will take his battle-scarred features and limited skills into the ring tonight against Jerry Quarry of Bellflower, Calif.
Columbia found a new hero to replace its built-in scoring punch of Jim McMillian and Heyward Dotson last night at Madison Square Garden before 4,716 spectators.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- The Libyan Government said tonight that it would show no mercy in a court-martial, to a group of military men who were accused last night of having plotted to overthrow the revolutionary regime that has been in power since September.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- The Libyan Government said tonight that it would show no mercy in a court-martial, to a group of military men who were accused last night of having plotted to overthrow the revolutionary regime that has been in power since September.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Man, reputed to be a little lower than the angels, may also be a lot closer to the ape than many experts had thought.
EL SEGUNDO, Calif., Dec. 12 -- The North American Rockwell Corporation is studying the feasibility of building an econometric device that would be a model of the United States economy.

Alabama, one of the nation's most frequent visitors to bowl games, and Colorado, a school with limited post-season experience, meet today in the 11th annual Liberty Bowl football game -- one of five bowl attractions across the country.

The stock market, after weeks of battering, took on a somewhat cheerful aspect yesterday. For the first time since the final Friday in November, the New York Stock Exchange displayed more advances than declines.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Two American helicopter crewmen released by the Vietcong after 38 days of captivity said today they would not go to war again against their captors because of the good care they had received.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 12 -- Shillito's department store wrote to a Negro leader today advising him that the store would include a black Santa Claus in its plans for 1970.
Reports on new-car sales for the first 10 days of December brought a glimmer of cheer to Detroit yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Justice Department ordered a preliminary investigation today of the shooting last week involving the police and the Black Panthers in Chicago.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa. Dec. 12 (AP) -- Mayor Kenneth O. Tompkins said today that he was lifting a blockade of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad here because the railroad agreed to stop sounding diesel horns that have disturbed sleeping residents.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Dec. 12 -- Vice President Agnew accused the Senate today of having "turned tax reform into a Rube Goldberg toy to entertain and attract reluctant voters to fading policitians."
The London Stock Exchange turned slightly easier yesterday on lack of interest. This followed Thursday's sharp rise, when the market took its cue from news of the good trade performance in November.
PISCATAWAY, N. J. -- Selman A. Waksman, the 81-year-old microbiologist who developer streptomycin and neomycin and won the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1952, has collected other tributes as well.

As Jacques Kayal sang a program of popular songs in French, Italian and accented English last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, he seemed to be counting more on the superficialities of traditional French stage charm than on his singing to put him across.

CAIRO, Dec. 12 -- The Egyptian delegation that had conducted talks with the Soviet leaders returned to Cairo this afternoon and drove directly from the airport to President Gamal Abdel Nasser's residence in the Manshiet el Bakery district of Cairo to report on the outcome of their mission.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Under fire on charges of violating human rights, Greece withdrew today from the Council of Europe before she could be expelled. The move came after an impassioned appeal by the Greek Foreign Minister, Panayotis Pipinelis, before the Council's Foreign Ministers.

Nationwide demonstrations against the Vietnam war yesterday, one of the three days in December designated by the Vietnam Moratorium Committee for such protests, were for the most part small and low- keyed.

The Imperial Ballroom at the Americana will be decorated in a space motif on Wednesday night for the Astronaut Ball which will follow the New York premiere at the Ziegfeld Theater of "Marooned," a movie about three astronauts stranded in space.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic agreed today that "urgent and constructive" steps were needed "to eliminate the consequences of Israeli aggression," but they showed signs of disagreement over what these steps should be.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- In an abrupt change of tactics, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee ended today a subcommittee's hearings on the alleged massacre of Vietnamese civilians in Songmy and appointed four members to "go into this matter in depth."
JERUSALEM, Dec. 12 -- Premier Golda Meir accused the United States today of "moralizing" on the subject of Middle East peace.
EXPERIMENTATION in children's programing continues today as the Columbia Broadcasting System interrupts at 12 noon its lineup of profitable cartoons for an hour's original drama set in Harlem.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan put his policemen on a Chicago television station last night to re-enact their version of the raid in which Mr. Hampton and Mr. Clark were slain.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The United States and the Soviet Union, in spite of strenuous combined efforts, have been unable to persuade the United National General Assembly to endorse their joint proposal for a treaty to ban weapons of mass destruction from ocean floor.
THE weekend's big game is the Kansas City-Oakland contest, on television here today starting at 4 P.M., Channel 4.

HUDSON, N. Y., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Virginia O'Hanlon Douglas, whose questions about Santa Claus 72 years ago brought her worldwide fame, has been hospitalized at the age of 80.

VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Michele Jacot of France made two almost flawless descents down the tricky slopes today and beat out Barbara Cochran or Richmond, Vt., for the women's special slalom title in the Criterium of the First Snow ski competition.
KILLEEN, Tex., Dec. 12 -- Staff Sgt. David Mitchell, one of the central figures in the Songmy massacre investigation, today called the charges against him "an injustice."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Senate approved a $1.9-billion foreign aid authorization bill today and sent it to conference with the House to resolve money differences and a number of policy conflicts.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- All the black students enrolled at Holy Cross College packed their bags and drove off the campus today to protest the suspensions of four Negro and 12 white students who demonstrated against the General Electric Company.

Austin S. Murphy, president-elect and chief executive officer of the East River Savings Bank, has been elected a trustee of that institution. He succeeds Edward E. Anderson, who recently retired from the board of trustees.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- The captain and radio operator of the sinking Netherlands supertanker, Marpessa abandoned ship in the Atlantic today, 24 hours after an explosion ripped through the 207,000-ton vessel on its maiden voyage.

Spencer (Ray) Ramsey, a linebacker from Anniston, Ala., and Michael Pyzczymucha, a center from Uniondale, L. I., have been selected co-captains of the 1970 Columbia varsity football team. They succeed Dick and Ken Alexander, seniors.

ST. HELENA, Calif. -- Robert Louis Stevenson and his bride Fanny spent their honeymoon, in the spring and summer of 1880, on the slopes of the great mountain that shades this lovely town in rural northern California. With only eight shopping days left in the Christmas season, retailers across the country are unhappily adjusting to the fact that holiday business is just so-so. An eager-eyed woman shushes her children as she tries on a mink jacket but buys a lower-priced fun fur instead.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday in quiet trading.

YONKERS, Dec. 15 -- World harness-racing betting records toppled tonight nearly as often as heavyweight wrestlers during a tag-team match as the 1969 local season was concluded before 24,176 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

The USLIFE Corporation announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Colonial Acceptance Corporation through an exchange of stock valued at more than $11-million.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Television networks, criticized for their "instant analysis" of President Nixon's speech on Vietnam in November, carried brief comments or none at all following his announcement today of additional troop withdrawals.

Prof. Govind Mudholkar (letter Dec. 9) criticizes the draft lottery system on the grounds that it is selective rather than random. He comes to this conclusion under the premise that births are not distributed evenly over days of the year or by initial letter of last name.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Senate, after a secret debate on American military involvement in the war in Laos, voted today to prohibit the commitment of American ground combat troops in either Laos or Thailand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, said today that, under the Senate-passed food stamp bill, even a millionaire could use Government scrip to purchase countless nonfood items.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Kings, mired in last place of the National Hockey League's Western Division, switched coaches today, with Johnny Wilson taking over from Hal Laycoe.
ATHENS, Dec. 15 -- Premier George Papadopoulos tonight ruled out any possibility of early elections in Greece and insisted that the aims of the army-backed Government must be met first.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Sir Robert G. K. Thompson, a British expert on counterinsurgency in Asia, has recommended to President Nixon a policy of remaining in Vietnam for a "long fight aimed at negotiations," but still maintaining a military presence even if there should be a settlement.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- Stepped-up American industrial representation at international trade fairs in Europe, new trade centers and more trade missions were advocated today for promoting United States commerce abroad.

Arthur Ashe, the top-ranked tennis player in the United States, formally applied to the South African consulate here yesterday for a visa to play in that country's championships next March. Fragmentary but mounting and disturbing evidence on industrial production and employment indicates that an economic recession is imminent or quite possibly has already begun. The 75-minute meeting last week between American and Chinese Communist diplomats in Warsaw represents something of a breakthrough in Washington -Peking relations. The conversations were significant because they were the first of their kind in almost two years. They gained added importance from the speed with which Peking responded to Ambassador Walter J. Stoessel's informal initiative a week earlier, and from the fact that he was invited to the Chinese Embassy for the meeting.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 17 -- Alfred Trevor Gallaher, a Salisbury attorney and prominent member of the governing party, the Rhodesian Front, pleaded guilty today to two charges of breaking the Official Secrets Act and two violating recently imposed counter-espionage regulations. The prosecution accepted the plea and dropped three other counts.
Joe Namath won't decide his football future until early next summer before the New York Jets assemble for training camp.
Jim McMillian scored 35 points and grabbed 12 rebounds last night to lead Columbia to an 80-69 overtime victory over Fordham in the Rose Hill gym.
ZERMATT, Switzerland, Dec. 17 -- There was excitement in this quaint Alpine village yesterday. It had begun to snow and skiers eagerly thronged into two of this community's major ski-lift terminals.
May and Daniel W. Blumenthal, 84 and 94 years old respectively, always were proud and fond of Simon B. Blumenthal, whom they both consider their "kid brother."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The United States Civil Rights Commission is exploring the possibility of investigating shooting incidents involving Black Panthers and the police.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 (AP) -- New York State collected $163,006,074 in taxes this year from racing at three flat tracks and eight harness tracks, Acting State Tax Commissioner Norman Gallman reported today.

A one-act play called "Dope" was presented to 600 eighth-grade pupils at the Jefferson Park Intermediate School at 240 East 109th Street yesterday afternoon. It was unlike most school plays for 14-year-olds.

Tiny Tim, the falsetto troubaduor of forgotten songs, was married to Victoria May Budinger last night in a nondenominational ceremony watched by millions of television fans.
BERLIN, Dec. 17 -- The East German Parliament authorized the Government today to "take the necessary steps" toward negotiating with West Germany to establish relations of "peaceful coexistence."

The basics for the design of a new 12-Meter yacht that will be a candidate for the defense of the America's Cup next summer were just about completed, Olin J. Stephens 2d, the naval architect, said yesterday.

THEODORE GORDON FLYFISHERS, INC., of 24 East 39th Street, New York, N. Y., a 400-member organization of fishermen and conservationists, is opposing the granting of a new permit to the Croton River Realty Corporation, and its president, James E. Ottaviano, to dredge gravel from the Croton River.

The Metropolitan Opera asked its 22,000 subscribers yesterday not to request refund for performances the company will be unable to present as a result of the recently settled labor dispute. At stake is $1-million of the $6-million in subscription money that the Met has been holding since last summer, before the 1969-70 season was postponed.

ATLANTA, Dec. 17 -- A three-judge Federal panel, in a landmark decision, ordered the State Board of Education today to withhold state funds from school districts that have not filed desegregation plans by March, 1970.

The belated efforts of city officials to preserve the 20-cent fare by seeking money from the Port Authority is focusing public attention on the costly, inadequate and crazy-quilt setup of our transportation arrangements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Nixon Administration has decided to maintain intact the limited worldwide network of undercover Federal agents because of the international ramifications of organized crime and the growing contacts of black militants abroad.
The Board of Education, despite objection from spokesmen for supervisory groups, last night approved new procedures for appointing acting principals to fill temporary vacancies.

Parents of Negro, Puerto Rican and other pupils at Public School 198 voiced fear yesterday that the creation of new school districts would destroy the integration that they said had dade their school the envy of the entire city system.

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its latest computerized clearance of "fails" had reduced the number of outstanding items by 28 per cent. The exchange said the procedure had eliminated 8,391 transactions involving 821,611 shares with a market value of nearly $24-million.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- New launching condition restrictions are being formulated as a result of the lightning strikes on Apollo 12's rocket as it lifted off from Cape Kennedy Nov. 14 for the moon, a space official said yesterday.

YONKERS, Dec. 17 -- The State Commission of Investigation was told here today that Yonkers permitted two private carting firms run by Nicholas A. Rattenni, a reputed Mafia leader, to use the city incinerator while its own trucks were forced to dump their garbage elsewhere.
Interest rates, continuing to reflect the malaise of the money and capital markets, again climbed to record heights yesterday, disrupting more major financing plans of cities and corporations.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Jewish chaplains serving at universities throughout the country reported today a substantial rise in counseling on intermarriage and a sharp drop in the number of students seeking their advice on sexual matters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Nixon moved today to oust Robert M. Morgenthau, a Democrat, as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and to replace him with Whitney North Seymour Jr., a Republican.
BUCHAREST, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- After a spontaneous debate unusual in Communist legislatures, the Rumanian Parliament today adopted a law giving more power to the Government.

I suppose as long as some people continue to keep lists of other people, there will always be a danger that those lists will be used for something less innocuous than mailing Christmas cards.

TRENTON, Dec. 17 -- High state Democratic sources said tonight that Gov. Richard J. Hughes had been forewarned about alleged Mafia associations of Ralph DeVita, the Union County District Judge who was appointed to the bench in 1966 by the Democratic Governor and who was indicted last week on charges of bribery in a case involving organized crime.
Aimee Semple McPherson, the late celebrated evangelist and one of the nation's more flamboyant personalities in the period after World War I, will live again in the person of Rosalind Russell.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The House of Representatives passed today catch-all credit legislation containing a number of provisions about which the Nixon Administration is lukewarm or outright concerned.
NORTH CALDWELL, N. J. -- What does a man who has been involved with the production of more than three billion loaves of bread do when he retires?
Anyone interested in pianists would have had a hard time deciding where to go last night.
Tensions between black and Puerto Rican antipoverty leaders deepened yesterday as black community development leaders in South Bronx charged Puerto Rican antipoverty officials with racism.
Mayor Lindsay pledged yesterday to create a "neighborhood stabilization" program to maintain racial and religious harmony in ethnically changing neighborhoods.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The House of Representatives, confronted with the last-minute threat of a Presidential veto, voted overwhelmingly tonight to ignore the Nixon Administration's cost complaints and adopted without change a major revision of Federal health and safety standards for coal miners.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Citing figures to demonstrate that the United States is now in a "weak competitive position" for a wide range of manufactured goods, a leading spokesman for limitation of imports launched a drive today for legislation next year that would effectively control the import share of the United States market for individual products.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Fifty per cent of college students approve of President Nixon's Vietnam policies while 44 per cent disapprove, according to a Gallup poll released today.
Robert M. Morgenthau declined yesterday, at least for the time being, to resign as United States Attorney -- and said that while he considers the question "my staff and I intend to pursue our work."

The activities of organized crime in New Jersey are now being investigated by five separate grand juries.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 17 -- Nassau County consumers may be paying an extra $5-million a year for mislabeled meat bought in virtually all the major food chain stores, County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson charged today.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Britain can attain a huge balance-of-payments surplus next year if she persists in her austere economic policies, the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development said in a report issued today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Senate turned back today a Southern attempt to block some of the Federal Government's most effective means of desegregating public school systems.

A PLAY with a title like "The Brownstone Urge" (which opened last night at the Actors' Playhouse) immediately sets me savoring. With rents rising and buildings falling, I, like many New Yorkers, devour articles, advertisements and stories about owning your own home in Manhattan.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 17 -- King Baudouin opened Belgium's first underground railway today. The two - mile railway links the Common Market's headquarters in Brussels with the city center.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Sirens growling and red lights flashing, half the Brookline Fire Department pulled up in front of Arthur Fiedler's house today as he was leaving for work.

FIXED fights are usually dreary little intrigues cooked up by shabby men on a kind of gentlemen's agreement: My kid can't beat your kid, but we need the payday as much as you need the victory. A worn-out manager once tried to defend the practice by saying it was no worse than a race in which some of the horses were trying to win while others were merely tuning up for more important races.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- An Ohio newspaper editor testified today that a Chicago policeman repeatedly clubbed a young man caught in a revolving door of the Conrad Hilton Hotel.

Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio and nine present or former officials of the municipal administration in Newark were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury with five other persons, among whom was Anthony (Tony Boy) Boiardo, a reputed member of the Mafia.
BUCHAREST, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- The first pop music festival in Rumania opened last night to 600 cheering students, while another 100 charged the baricade trying to get in.

CAPE KENNEDY, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Apollo 12's astronauts returned to their launching site today. They thanked thousands of workers for their role in America's second perfect moon landing mission and called for continued care to keep the lunar program successful.

The board of directors of Marine Midland Banks, Inc., yesterday named Charles A. Winding, a 62-year-old dark horse, to be chairman and chief executive of the $7-billion statewide bank holding company.

Alfred S. Bloomingdale, who was a co-founder of Diners' Club almost two decades ago, announced his resignation yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer to devote himself to "a number of new challenges."

Mrs. Vincent Astor and Mrs. Lila Acheson Wallace have been elected to the board of trustees of the New York Zoological Society, it was announced yesterday by Laurance S. Rockefeller, president. They are the first women ever to serve as trustees of the 74-year-old institution.
Elie Abel, the diplomatic correspondent for the National Broadcasting Company, has been selected as the new dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, it was disclosed last night.

A real estate broker accused of blockbusting on Staten Island told a state hearing officer yesterday that owners had offered to sell three one-family houses to him for $15,000 apiece, or $7,000 less than each one was worth.
Christmas nears. Each day New York is engulfed in the deepening throes of the holiday, stirring the disparate moods of the city.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- The 24th session of the United Nations General Assembly adjourned today after 13 weeks of frequently hot debate that made it clear that the small nations of the world were more determined than ever to force the big powers to heed their views.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Pyle says that he is utterly undistinguished. In the hall he taps you on the shoulder and says, "I am just as plain as an old shoe." WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The White House believes that perhaps its greatest single achievement during President Nixon's first year in office has been to embark on a serious program of Federal reform and thus to restore a measure of public confidence in the ability of government to match its performance to its rhetoric.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 17 -- Differences between Washington and Moscow over the site of the full-scale negotiations on the limitation of strategic weapons may keep the Helsinki talks going until next week.
PARIS, Dec. 17 -- Andre Malraux has broken his silence to appeal for the amnesty of Regis Debray, the French revolutionary intellectual now serving a 30-year prison sentence in Bolivia.

TOKYO, Dec. 17 -- "I have never fought an easy election in my life," says Mrs. Yukiko Motojima, a veteran fighter for women's rights who is running for her fifth term in Parliament as a representative of Tokyo's populous Third District.

Tom Seaver is such an admirable young man on so many levels that it seemed only fitting that he receive a remarkable offer yesterday from Johnny Murphy, vice president and general manager of the Mets. It has been suggested at a meeting of the American Geophysical Union in San Francisco that a small nuclear device be detonated on the moon, so that the various quiverings and wobbles that would be set off would tell the instruments that have been planted on the lunar surface what is inside the old ball of cheese.

Stock-car racing will receive substantially more television exposure during the next three years as the result of a $1.5-million contract announced yesterday by the American Broadcasting Company and the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing.

THE National Football League, which has been coasting with all four of its division titles long decided, closes its 50th season on Sunday and the nationwide television offering will be "the game that was supposed to be."
