Ten players have averaged more than 31 points a game in the opening three weeks of the major college basketball season, and Pete Maravich of Louisiana State is in his familiar place at the top through games of last Saturday.

Aside from a mild resolution calling for sterner action against aerial hijackers, one of the most notable achievements of the 24th session of the United Nation General Assembly which has just adjourned was to approve plans for a 25th anniversary celebration next fall and for expanding U.N. headquarters at Turtle Bay. Unless the U.N. can do better than it did this fall, there will be little justification for celebration or expansion.
MIAMI, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Jacinto Vasquez booted home three winners at Tropical Park today, including Eneas II in the $5,500 allowance feature of of 1 1/16 miles.
The backs change and the linemen change, but the offense remains the same. The guard in the brown and orange uniform pulls out of the line, bolts to the outside and tries to knock somebody down.

The Western Bancorporation, the nation's largest multibank holding company, announced last night that its Washington subsidiary, the National Bank of Washington, Tacoma, had agreed to consolidate its business with the Pacific National Bank of Seattle.

SOME of us who came of reading age in the nineteen-forties read the comic books. A lot of us. Older people -- the ones who started reading in the thirties -- seem to have read big-little books as well, the ones in which you animated the margin drawings by flipping the pages. Younger people had television.

CONCURRENTLY with the first concert this season of Evenings for New Music, last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, came the announcement that Carnegie Hall has received a grant to implement the series. The National Endowment for the Arts has given $15,000 not only for a continuance of the series, but also for a parallel series to be given at Rutgers University.

A decline in farm equipment sales was a major factor in the 15.4 per cent drop in earnings of the International Harvester Company in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, Harry O. Bercher, chairman, reported yesterday.
Richard A. Brown, a Democrat strongly backed by Stanley Steingut, minority leader of the Assembly, was named yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as his legislative representative in Albany.

Newark, Dec. 18 -- The Federal grand jury that indicted Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio and 14 other persons yesterday on charges including extortion and income-tax evasion is looking into the activities of several more municipal officials, a Justice Department source indicated today.
A Federal judge who has rebuked draft boards recently for unfair procedures, has acquitted a draft resister of a criminal charge of failing to submit to induction into the armed services.

HUNTINGTON STATION L.I., Friday, Dec. 19 -- A woman and her 4-year-old son were dead and her husband and two daughters were in critical condition early today after all were found shot in their home here.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its best performance in nearly three months yesterday as pieces advanced sharply in stepped-up trading.
Nineteen members of the faculty and administrative staff of Notre Dame College on Staten Island have resigned in the wake of the dismissal of four teachers.

Gold has lost a battle but not the war. It is near the $35 an ounce level -- the same rate for the last 35 years despite a general price increase of between 50 per cent and several hundred per cent depending on the product and the country.

" It's not black, it's not wood, and I haven't made it," said Louise Nevelson, standing in front of her new construction, "Nightsphere-Light," a sculptural wall of black-painted wood more than 47 feet long and 8 feet high.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 -- The golden wreaths trimmed with silver bells and red and yellow lights that blink in the darkness hang from the light standards along both sides of 103d Street in Watts.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- The director of "Oh? Calcutta!" and the judge of the Chicago conspiracy trial differed today on how to direct a courtroom drama.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- A former adviser to Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's Rhodesia Front party was sentenced today to four years in prison after being found guilty of passing secret economic information to an unidentified agent.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy led a chanting throng through the downtown area today, kissed his son goodby and walked into the Shelby County jail to be arrested on charges stemming from a school boycott.
The New York Yankees continued their face-lifting operation yesterday when they obtained Pete Ward from the Chicago White Sox.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- A Biafran negotiating team flew off for home today without waiting to see whether a delegation from Nigeria would meet them for peace talks here.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 -- The Standard Oil Company of California announced today a new gasoline additive that the company said would sharply reduce the hydrocarbons in automobile exhaust.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- War has become so sophisticated a dramatic subject that a piece as old-fashioned as Robin Maugham's "Enemy" exerts an almost pastoral charm; proclaiming, as if for the first time, that fighting men are brothers under the skin and perhaps the real enemies are the people at home. The play is at the Saville Theater.

A top official in the United States Department of Labor said here last night that the problem of religious discrimination against Jews and Roman Catholics in executive-level positions "needs immediate attention."
ATHENS, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- W. J. Bright, a British pilot in a twin-engine Britten-Norman BN-2A Islander, was the first to complete the initial leg of the London-Sydney air race that began today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Enemy combat forces in South Vietnam consist of 100,000 North Vietnamese, 100,000 guerrillas and 40,000 "main force" Vietcong, the Defense Department said today.

Louis F. Polk Jr., of Minnesota, has filed a $4-million damage suit against Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., alleging that "coercion, threats and unlawful acts" led to his replacement as president last Oct. 21.

I greatly deplore the action, including petition in court, that the American Jewish Congress has taken in protest and prevention of the display, in Washington, of a nativity scene to be inaugurated by President Nixon.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Portugal's delegate walked out of a Security Council meeting today to protest the Indian representative's being allowed to speak on the question of Portuguese territories in Africa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Federal officials agreed today to send investigators to Crystal City, Tex., to investigate a 10-day-old boycott of public school classes by about 1,600 Mexican-American students.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Officials of the Avco Corporation appeared before a Senate subcommittee today seeking Federal dollars and sympathy for a pilot magnetohydrodynamics plant. They got the sympathy.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Dec. 18 (UPI) -- A University of Missouri School of Journalism poll showed today that the majority of Congressmen who replied to the survey agree with Vice President Agnew's criticism of television network news reporting.

CAIRO, Dec. 18 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and King Faisal of Saudi Arabia, representing the revolutionary and traditionalist poles of the Arab world, met here today to discuss proposals to put before a high-level Arab meeting that opens on Saturday at Rabat, Morocco.

The Metropolitan Opera's backstage wheel of ill fortune took a turn for the better yesterday. The notorious non-turning turntable, which collapsed under an overload during a rehearsal before the new house at Lincoln Center opened in 1966, has been rebuilt.
A 60-foot Christmas tree from the Adirondacks blazed with sparkling lights last night as Mayor Lindsay led the ceremonies at the annual Christmas tree dedication in City Hall Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Personal income rose $3.2-billion in November, $200-million more than the October increase but considerably below the average monthly gain for the first eight months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Foreigners visiting the United States are most interested in New York, San Francisco, Washington, Florida and the Grand Canyon. They are also more interested in America today than in the country's history.

Joseph M. Katz was ousted yesterday by the board of Odell, Inc. a diversified consumer-goods producer, after only two-and-a-half weeks as chairman and chief executive officer. J. Allan Schur, vice chairman and a former president, was elected to fill Mr. Katz's post.

ATLANTA, Dec. 18 -- The Georgia Board of Education announced today that it would comply with what could prove to be a landmark decision by a Federal tribunal here. The decision ordered the state itself to insure school desegregation by next fall.
BONN, Dec. 18 -- A letter from Walter Ulbricht, the East German chief of state and Communist party leader, was delivered to President Gustav Heinemann of West Germany here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Nixon sent out 37,000 -- a record. Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin sent 500. George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, didn't send any. Neither did David M. Kennedy, Secretary of the Treasury and, like Mr. Romney, a Mormon.

DALLAS, Dec. 18 (AP) -- In a settlement in Federal District Court here yesterday, the Lockheed Aircraft Company of Burbank, Calif., agreed to pay $214,199 to survivors of the crew killed when a Braniff Electra propjet crashed near Dawson, Tex., on May 3, 1968.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that Robert M. Morgenthau would be given "a reasonable period of time" to resign as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.
A judge yesterday ordered a German shepherd named Oliver to use the service elevator leading to the luxury Fifth Avenue apartment house of its owner.

GREAT NECK PLAZA, L. I., Dec. 18 -- Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said today that he was prepared to start with the development of commercial and business facilities on air rights over the long Island Rail Road Station here.
ALBANY, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Two tickets held by New York City residents and one from Connecticut were picked for $100,000 prizes today in the monthly state lottery drawing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Wholesale prices took the biggest jump in six months in November including a 3 per cent rise for food that is likely to make Christmas turkeys and eggnog more expensive.

On weekends throughout the year, and now during Christmas vacation, parents take -- often drag -- their children to a variety of entertainments. The parents often are bored. What they don't realize is that the children are often bored too -- that is, if they aren't frightened out of their wits.

VALGARDENA, Italy, Dec. 18 -- The 1970 Federation Internationale de Ski world Alpine championships are to be held in this historic Dolomites region in February, and there is no doubt that the local organizers of the classic will be ready.

A loan shark who included among his victims James L. Marcus, the former Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court yesterday to four counts of attempted usury.

OTTAWA, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The health committee of Canada's House of Commons recommended today not only an end of all cigarette advertising and sales promotion but also a halt in production of cigarettes that exceed present health maximums for tar and nicotine.

FREDERICK BRISSON'S friends from stage, screen and fashion rallied round last night to make the opening of "Coco" a historic occasion. They did their best to make the clothes in the lobby rival the ones Cecil Beaton made for the stage.
YET another Chanel revival on the way? It would seem so.

Over cocktails, hors d'oeuvres, a two-tiered party cake and warmly shared reminiscences going back 50 years, more than 100 friends of the New School for Social Research last night honored Dr. Alvin Johnson, the school's president emeritus, on his 95th birthday.

LUCHINO VISCONTI'S "The Damned" may be the chef d'oeuvre of the great Italian director ("La Terra Trema," "Rocco and His Brothers," "Sandra") -- a spectacle of such greedy passion, such uncompromising sensation and such obscene shock that it makes you realize how small and safe and ordinary most movies are.
The Securities and Exchange Commission charged in Federal court here yesterday that the Continental Connector Corporation had violated antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws.
An officer of the Black Panther party who allegedly distributed dynamite to fellow conspirators to terrorize the city last spring jumped $25,000 bail yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 18 -- Fighting was reported to have dropped last week, slightly reducing the number of American and enemy combat deaths, but qualified officials said today that the enemy was continuing to build toward the capacity for a major offensive early next year.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The death penalty was permanently abolished in Britain today when the House of Lords approved a Government motion ending hanging for murder.

ONE nagging injury after another hampered Mike Garrett's efficiency a year ago. None was of particlarly grave consequence, but the accumulation robbed the little Kansas City ball-carrying marvel of much of his maneuverability. His rushing production was reduced to almost half of his eye-popping 1,087 yards of the previous season.

NEWARK, Dec. 18 -- Black Democratic and civic leaders said here today that the charges of widesperad corruption in the administration of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio had improved the chances of electing the first black mayor of this city next year.

TRENTON, Dec. 18 -- Representative William T. Cahill, the Republican Governor-elect, who will take office Jan. 20, named a new state Attorney General today to lead a consolidated statewide attack against organized crime and official corruption in New Jersey.
JERUSALEM, Friday, Dec. 19 -- An Israeli commando unit crossed the Suez Canal last night to attack an Egyptian Army camp in the manner of recent forays by Egyptian commandos.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- When a political party is out of power, it is supposed to have time for re-examination and renewal, but there is no evidence of this regenerating process among the Democrats. They are down and out -- the saddest sacks in Washington.

Rhody McCoy, administrator of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville experimental school district, tried unsuccessfully to bring his case for retaining the demonstration school district before the State Board of Regents at the board's monthly meeting yesterday.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 18 -- State Senators who passed it May 27 call it the self-defense law. Gov. Norbert T. Tiemann, who vetoed it, only to have that veto overriden under unusual circumstances, says the act returns to Nebraska "a system of vigilante law enforcement -- escalating the breakdown of law and order."
Sirens and air horns screamed and blasted from fire trucks parked at Columbia University's Baker Field yesterday in the interest of a quieter future.
Most of the assets of Amott, Baker Co., a financially troubled member of the New York Stock Exchange, will be acquired by Charles Plohn Co., another member firm, in a distress sale.

MINERAL WELLS, Tex. -- The number of South Vietnamese troops training at military installations throughout the country is being tripled in the current fiscal year as part of President Nixon's effort to "Vietnamize" the war.

The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that exploratory drilling on mineral holdings in Nevada had outlined bodies of about 250 million tons of ore containing 40 per cent iron and 0.3 per cent copper.
The Jets have that old Super Bowl feeling this week and they held a players-only meeting to pass it on to the un-initiated.

Much of the credit markets perked up yesterday after Arthur F. Burns, in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, voiced a hope that tight credit conditions could be eased if tax-reform and Federal budget developments came out right.
Clergy and Laymen Concerned About Vietnam, an antiwar group, handed over more than $5,000 yesterday to support American deserters and draft evaders living in Canada.
COLOGNE, West Germany, Dec. 13 -- After five centuries or so a weathered old favorite -- the "halve Hahn" -- is being scratched off the menus in the cafes in Cologne.

One more attempt to launch preliminary talks to end the Nigerian civil war has foundered for reasons most of the world will regard as incredibly capricious. Emperor Haile Selassie hoped to get the two sides together quietly in Ethiopia but word of his effort leaked, with dismally familiar consequences.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 18 -- A calculated experiment in defiance of the Supreme Court's denial of prayer and Bible reading in public school classrooms was ordered ended here today by a Federal judge, but the dispute continued.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A bipartisan Senate civil rights bloc that includesthe Republican leadership is reasonably confident that it can force President Nixon and Attorney General John N. Mitchell to accept a compromise voting rights bill that would retain what the coalition regards as vital provi sions of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A national day of prayer on Christmas Eve, sponsored by the Vietnam Moratorium Committee, was announced today by the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr., the next Episcopal Bishop of New York, and Mrs. Cynthia Wedel, president of the National Council of Churches.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 18 -- Enthusiasm and aid for the Palestinian guerrilla movement is widespread in Morocco although the moderate government, far removed from the front lines, still hopes for a peaceful Arab-Israeli settlement.

Spiro Agnew would be more acceptable to many of us if he saved his diatribes for the more glaring evils of our society: the outrage of our criminal underworld eating at the foundations of American life, the horrors of our ugly city ghettos, the racial bigotry poisoning our national blood stream, the contamination of both air and water that threatens our very health.
A moving van, brought to Liberty Island by derrick and steam lighter, ended an almost idyllic city existence for a forest ranger yesterday.

Walter Vandermeer, the 12-year-old boy who died in a Harlem bathroom Sunday of an overdose of heroin, was eulogized at his funeral last night by his family as a lovable child whose "search for love and affection" brought death.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18 -- The judge who presided at the conspiracy trial of Clay L. Shaw earlier this year was arrested last night at a "stag show" in the DeVille Motel here.
Eight persons, seven of them children of the same family, were killed in Brooklyn early yesterday when a flash fire raced through the second floor and attic of a small frame building.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on a catch-all credit bill including nonmandatory authority of the President to impose controls on all forms of lending, including interest rates.

The letter by David Caplovitz and Bogdan Dentich (Dec. 10) makes the familiar assumption that the struggle in Vietnam is a civil war fought along classical nationalistic lines, whereas in fact wars of this nature are no longer possible in a shrunken world whose least part is geopolitically and technologically bound up with every other.
A man sought in connection with the attempted burglary last week of a $300,000 Riverdale mansion was arrested yesterday in the Bronx by detectives of the Bronx District Attorney's squad.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Academic Senate of the University of California's nine campuses has voted to throw out its own 1950 rule banning Communist party members from teaching posts.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Xuan Thuy, chief of the North Vietnamese delegation, stayed away from the Paris peace talks today for the second week in protest against what a spokesman termed the downgrading of the talks by President Nixon.

JACKSONVILLE Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Georgetown University Coach Jack Magee pulled his team off the floor with 1 minute 23 seconds left in the first half tonight, giving undefeated Jacksonville University a 41-26 forfeit victory in a battle-scarred basketball game.
A coalition of civic groups that had been set up to block attempts to run highways through the city opened a united campaign yesterday to strike three routes from state highway maps.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The Air Force has removed the manager of a noncommissioned officers' club in Greenland after discovering financial irregularities during a surprise audit.
Arthur F. Burns, the nominee for chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, touched off an explosive rally in the stock market yesterday with his comments on tight monetary policy.
Harry (Bud) Grant, the coach of the once-beaten Minnesota Vikings, was named by The Associated Press and United Press International yesterday as National Football League coach of the year.

Chuck Wepner of Bayonne, N. J., who knocked out Forest Ward two years ago, and Pedro Agosto of Puerto Rico, who was knocked out by Ward last August, meet in a scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout in the Felt Forum tonight.
PRODUCE a new car, boat, airplane or some other mechanized vehicle for Americans and it won't be very long before they organize a race.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Seven cast members and the producer of "Oh! Calcutta!" surrendered to the police yesterday on warrants charging them with lewd conduct and indecent exposure. They were released on $625 bail and will stand trial on a date to be determined.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The French Defense Ministry has agreed to sell the revolutionary Government of Libya about $400-million worth of modern arms, diplomatic sources said today, including more than 50 Mirage jets and 200 heavy tanks.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 18 -- The Chicago Bulls nearly dissipated a 22-point lead tonight, but held on to defeat the National Basketball Association's Western Division leaders, the Atlanta Hawks. 114-112.

KATMANDU, Nepal -- About 20,000 Tibetan and Chinese prisoners are reported to be rushing completion of a jet airfield in southeastern Tibet, less than an hour's flying time from a valley that is the scene of a confrontation between Indian and Chinese troops.

YONKERS, Dec. 18 -- Among the 2,000 prospective purchasers at today's closing session of the Old Glory Winter Sales at Yonkers Raceway were such leading drivers as Vernon Dancer, John Chapman, Frank Popfinger and Carmine Abbatiello.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 18 -- The Egyptian Army landed two commando units last night on the Israeli-held eastern shore of the Suez Canal, it was announced here today.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange finished lower yesterday, reflecting the trend on Wall Street. Several Australian nickel issues ran counter to the trend and scored sizable gains.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 18 -- John J. Gilligan, a former Democratic Representative, announced today his candidacy for Governor.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The heavyweight title match between Jimmy Ellis and the challenger, Gregorio Peralta, continued to be shrouded in doubt today over whether it would be held as scheduled Saturday night.

SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 11 -- El Salvador, in a demonstration of business resourcefulness, is making a strong economic recovery from her war with Honduras, which resulted in the loss of markets there and the blockade of the Pan-American Highway to Salvadorean products.

PANAMA, Dec. 18 -- Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos, commander of Panama's military force, announced today that a civilian group would take over the presidential functions in the revolutionary government before the end of the month.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 18 -- With the gentlest of diplomatic hand slaps, the Indian Government has told the Soviet Embassy that it cannot open a cultural center that the Russians started building in a southern state a few months ago despite Indian regulations.

MOSCOW Dec. 18 -- British and Soviet negotiators today initialled an agreement to allow British Overseas Airways Corporation to open a new service to Tokyo via Moscow and Siberia. The route will cut about two hours off the time of the present polar route.

The New York Yacht Club cruise will begin and end off Newport, R. I., next summer and will include limited competition for the 12-Meter yachts that will be candidates for the defense of the America's Cup later.
BEAUFORT, S. C., Dec. 18 -- Dr. Donald Gatch went to jail today.

VIETIANE, Laos, Dec. 18 -- The wives of two United States airmen, one lost over North Vietnam, the other over Laos, arrived this afternoon to meet with Communist officials in hope of obtaining their husbands' release or at least sending them supplies.
A Federal grand jury indicted five men yesterday on charges that they conspired to transport $4-million in stolen securities from brokerage houses in the Wall Street area.

BOSTON, Dec. 18 (AP)-- Reggie Jackson of Oakland won the American League's individual slugging title this year with a .608 percentage, while Boston edged Baltimore's pennant-winning Orioles in team slugging, .415 to .414.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Ignoring last-minute objections from the Nixon Administration, the Senate sent to the White House tonight the most stringent coal mine safety bill in history.
Mrs. Robert F. Wagner said yesterday that she and her husband, the former Mayor and former Ambassador to Spain, had separated but that she still hoped to "patch things up."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- The Bostwick brothers, Pete and Jimmy, of New York, retained the United States open court tennis doubles championship today by defeating the Philadelphia team of Jimmy Dunn and William T. Vogt, 5-6, 6-4, 6-0, 5-6, 6-4, at the Racquet Club.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- A letter signed by 31 distinguished writers appearing in The Times of London today appeals to the Soviet Union to stop "persecuting'' Alexander Solzhenitsyn or face the calling of an international cultural boycott.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 18 -- A former Taipei city councilman and eleven other defendants accused of conspiracy to overthrow the Chinese Nationalist Government and establish an independent Taiwanese republic have been convicted after more than two years of confinement.

Four South Carolina players came home to New York yesterday to prove they were playing for the best college basketball team in the nation. For almost 40 minutes then ran, controlled the boards, displayed a dazzling fast break and played almost precision defense in crushing Long Island University, 89-52, at Madison Square Garden.
DETROIT, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Lynn A. Townsend, Chrysler board chairman, predicted today that 1970 sales of new cars will be "strong but not quite as strong as in 1968 and 1969."

YONKERS, Dec. 18 -- Nicholas A. Rattenni, the reputed Mafia leader whose private carting firms were allegedly involved in a deal said to have defrauded Yonkers of $1-million a year, refused to answer questions today before the State Commission on Investigation on the ground that to do so might incriminate him.

FRANCHISES International, Inc., one of the City Investing Company's early acquisitions when City Investing was preparing to join the ranks of the conglomerates, is apparently being hobbled by the parent company in its long-range plans through a lack of financial support.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

VIENNA, Dec. 18 -- The chief of the Prague city Communist party, a pro-Moscow hard-liner, disclosed today that more than 200 functionaries and political workers had been ousted. The events he described amounted to a major overhaul in the capital's government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell today cited the crackdown on numbers operations in Newark as evidence of the effectiveness of the Nixon Administration's tactic of striking at the Mafia's "bankroll" -- gambling.
MOSCOW, Dec. 18 -- The Soviet Union charged today that the Middle East peace plan disclosed last week by Secretary of State William P. Roers was unbalanced in favor of Israel.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 12 -- "Life is hard for us, but we are used to it," explained Hoang Thep, the slightly built night watchman at a Government guest house on Nguyen Du Street.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 18 -- Kasarino, a Chilean-bred 6-year-old owned and trained by Jack M. Murray, came from far off the pace and caught Kummel in the final stride for a nose victory in the featured Prince John Purse at Laurel Race Course today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Rushing toward adjournment, the Senate took the unusual parliamentary step today of approving foreign aid appropriations before formally setting the limit on aid policy. Authorization legislation, which defines programs and sets a ceiling for appropriations, is normally passed before the appropriations bill.

Escadrille, the private club that 25-year-old Geoffrey Leeds began to organize last May because he was "bored with everything in New York, including Raffles," opened its somewhat exclusive doors for the first time last night, and the place was anything but boring.

LONDON -- Having been twice rebuffed in its efforts to enter the Common Market, Britain today is even warier than it was a few years ago when it decided after long and hesitant tergiversation that it wanted to abandon insular policy and join "Europe."

The next two games may reveal whether or not New York Knickerbocker fans have reason for concern. The Knicks play in Chicago tonight, with the game televised to New York on Channel 9 at 9 P.M., and face Baltimore tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.
THE Winter Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association, which begins today at the New York Hilton is the annual testing-ground for experiments in scoring and organization.
NEWARK, Dec. 18 -- "Newark," mourned a tavern biddy in Anita Loos's 1947 comedy "Happy Birthday," "has lost its charm."
The Transport Workers Union presented its case yesterday for a 30 per cent wage increase for 35,000 bus and subway workers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Federal Communications Commission yesterday sharpened its focus on the question of whether and how largely corporate interests affect the content of broadcast programing.
The cumulative stress imposed by a full year of monetary restraint was clearly evident in banking data published yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 19 -- President Nixon told Congress last night that he would have to veto its second largest appropriation bill -- for the Labor and Health, Education and Welfare Departments and the Office of Economic Opportunity -- because it was inflationary.

DENVER, Dec. 18 (AP)--I Spencer Haywood scored Denver's first 7 points in an overtime period and the Denver Rockets went on to drwn the New York Nets. 108-105. tonight in an American Basketball Association game. i

WHAT is a first meeting with George Francis Kugler Jr. like? "He would just look right through you and you would never lie to him." "A firm handshake; he looks you right in the eye and you know immediately where you stand."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The general commanding the American troops who allegedly massacred Vietnamese civilians at Songmy in March, 1968, was aboard a helicopter monitoring radio conversations at the time, the Defense Department said today.

Arno Press announced yesterday the start of the Arno Series of American Music, a project that will make available rare, historical and out-of-print music limited until now to restricted collections at a few major libraries.
Fifth-grade mathematics pupils of Public School 41, 116 West 11th Street, fed programs they wrote into a computer yesterday and watched as the computer replied to them.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 18 (AP) -- he Soviet Union officially presented today the application of Moscow for the 1976 Summer Olympic games, gambling that by that year South Africa and Rhodesia would be excluded from Olympic competition.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A provision granting Governors absolute veto over legal services for the poor was stripped today from a bill extending the Federal antipoverty program.

An officer of a company that did an annual business of $12-million with the city's Department of Social Services was indicted yesterday on charges of lying to a Federal grand jury about payments to employes of the department.

It was a day of expirations on the Chicago Board of Trade. The December soybean meal contract expired as expected with another show of strength, hitting a new life-of-contract high of $90.50 a ton and then closing around $88 a ton, which was its previous high.

The Los Angelese Rams and Dallas Cowboys dominated the National Football League All-Stars teams selected for The Associated Press by a 48-man panel of sports writers and broadcasters from the 16 league cities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- With Administration support, the House rejected today a controversial legislative amendment designed to curb the Federal Government's power to force integration of public schools.
PARIS, Dec. 18 -- A Westinghouse Electric Corporation spokesman said today the company had decided to go ahead with plans to set up a "European entity," despite a rebuff by the French Government.
MEMPHIS, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Two Negro advisers were named today by the Memphis School Board in a compromise move designed to give the black community a stronger voice in school affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Justice Department filed an antitrust suit today to prohibit local real estate boards from setting and enforcing uniform sales commissions on real estate transactions.

IF you haven't yet found the appropriate Christmas gift for the boatman on your list, here are some hurry-up ideas for nautical items priced under $10 that can be found in marine outlets or department stores and bought with little worry as to their usefulness or suitability.

AHMADABAD, India, Dec. 11 -- "Things are back to normal now," a leading Hindu said the other day about his city. Ahmadabad, which was torn three months ago by the worst Hindu-Moslem bloodshed since the partition of India and Pakistan in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A Senate-House conference committee approved today a compromise version of the tax bill that would provide tax cuts for everyone, increase Social Security benefits by 15 per cent and make scores of changes in special provisions of the tax law, including a reduction in the oil depletion allowance to 22 per cent.
An ambulance taking a woman to Kings County Hospital and a station wagon collided at a Brooklyn intersection yesterday, injuring several persons.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Liberty Bell Park anticipates a crowd of 22,000 or more tomorrow for its first Saturday racing program since the New York thoroughbred season ended.

Higher prices for food, especially eggs and vegetables, set the pace for another overall increase in consumer prices across the country and in New York in November, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

HONG KONG, Dec. 19 -- China urged the Vietcong today to persevere in "protracted war" until they achieved a final victory against the United States and the Saigon Government, reaffirming the Communist Chinese position that the Vietnam war should be settled on the battlefield.

Robert S. McNamara recently said: "At the present rate of increase, a child born today would end up in his 70's contending with fifteen billion [people], and his grandson would share this planet with sixty billion."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from the levels achieved at the previous auction last Monday, the Government reported late this afternoon.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange increased in the month ended Dec. 15 for the second consecutive month, according to figures released by the exchange yesterday.
Dr. Andrew W. Cordier was installed yesterday afternoon as the 15th president of Columbia University.

Trans East Air, Inc., which operates Bangor (Me.) International Airport, has named Salvatore E. Manzo to be its president and chief executive officer. He goes to the alternate stop on the trans-Atlantic routes from two years as director of aviation for the city of Houston.

YAMAGATA, Japan, Dec. 18 -- "Talk about the rice problem!" a heckler shouted at Premier Eisaku Sato from the back of the hall crowded with farmers and their wives in khaki work clothes or padded kimonos.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Attempting to reconcile its cultural responsibilities with the requirements of a Christmas show, the National Theater has come up with "The Travails of Sancho Panza" by James Saunders, a piece that suggests an upper-class equivalent of London's family-audience pantomines: the main difference being that instead of loading the text with jokes about television commercials, it goes in for passages of archaic speech and Shakespearean quotation to pacify culture-fancying parents.

March wheat futures jumped hopefully ahead yesterday, spurred by a report that the Government might relax trade restrictions with Communist China.
A Queens man has applied in Federal District Court in Brooklyn for an injunction that would declare American participation in the war in Vietnam unconstitutional.

Janis Joplin, the Texas-born girl who has become one of the leading blues and rock singers over the last two years, gave an excellent performance before a near-capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The attempt on President Obote's life is another sign of the pressures at work in the seemingly tranquil hilltop capital of Kampala.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A television engineer has invented equipment for broadcasting two programs simultaneously in the same channel and separating one for pay-TV. Walker, a consulting engineer of Edison, N.J., was granted Patent 3,484,544 this week, assigning it to Charger Electronic Systems, Inc., of New York.

REMEMBER Pennsylvania Station? McKim, Mead and White, 1903-07. Imperial Roman gateway to New York in travertine and granite. Demolished 1965-66. Removed in truckloads to New Jersey where noble column fragments and cornice pieces turned the Secaucus meadows into a Roman nun. Later bulldozed into a pit and buried by a real estate company to entice commercial or industrial construction on the "prepared" site.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, says "water pollution-causing phosphates in detergents" can be eliminated, and he has prodded Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel to join in a campaign to induce the detergent industry to accept phosphate substitutes.

WINTERTHUR, Switzerland, Dec. 22 -- Three members of the Palestinian Liberation Front were each sentenced by a Swiss court here today to 12 years in prison on a murder charge in the machine-gun attack on an Israeli airliner at the Zurich Airport last February.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 -- "Vote for Kosaka, the man who believes in the possibilities of youth," the loudspeaker blares as the station wagon with the bright blue - and - white signboards cruises down streets filled with early-morning shoppers and office workers hastening to their commuter trains.
John G. Duba, the $35,000-a-year Administrator of Municipal Services, yesterday became the third superagency head to resign from the Lindsay administration since Election Day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Judge Julius J. Hoffman today upheld the Government's contention that the alleged beating of a newsman by the police at the time of the 1968 Democratic National Convention was not relevant to the trial of seven men charged with inciting rioting during convention week.
A low-keyed and protracted labor dispute between National Airlines and its mechanics has blocked the start of United States-flag jet service on the important new Miami-London route.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Congress moved fitfully toward adjournment today, leaving a Presidential legislative package virtually untouched and quarreling with the Administration over future priorities for the nation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Pressing its campaign against the exploitation of "shell corporations" with few or no assets, the Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading today in stocks of seven companies and prepared to file a lawsuit against two of them.

In a few weeks, some 800 retailers and executives in the resident buying office industry will meet to honor a Negro Baptist minister who has been responsible for the training of about 40,000 young blacks in industrial skills.
BONN, Dec. 22 -- The Polish Government, in a note presented this afternoon to the West German Foreign Ministry, expressed its willingness to begin talks on a variety of issues.

In the quiet of the Houston Oilers' locker room, Pete Beathard was trying to button his shirt with stiff, bruised fingers. The quarterback had been battered six times for losses during Sunday's 56-7 massacre that propelled the Oakland Raiders into the American Football League championship game Jan. 4 against the Kansas City Chiefs.

THE Chicago Bears and Pittsburgh Steelers, teams that came within on defeat of losing the most games in one season in the history of pro football, will go through a coin-tossing procedure to determine which one will choose first in the annual draft of college play ers on Jan. 27.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Charles M. Manson, who is accused of murder in the killings of Sharon Tate, the actress, and six others, won a delay today in entering a plea.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell and officials of the Black Solidarity Day Committee urged New Yorkers yesterday to protest proposed bus and subway fare increases by paying their fares in pennies next Monday.
The two-day rally on the American Stock Exchange ended abruptly yesterday as prices as well as volume dropped sharply.

WITHIN a period of six days Jack Kuhnert, the Power Memorial Academy coach, will learn whether his basketball team deserved the national acclaim it has been receiving. The school that Lew Alcindor made famous will play in the Cambria War Memorial tournament in Johnstown, Pa., Dec. 29 and 30 and four days later will oppose Boys High, the best in the Public Schools Athletic League, at Madison Square Garden.

The report that France plans to sell $400 million worth of military equipment to Libya, including 50 Mirage jet fighters and 200 heavy tanks, would, if true, be another blow at efforts of the Big Four, presumably including France, to promote peace in the Middle East. Libyan denials that any such deal is under way find few convincing echoes in Paris.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Dec. 22 -- North Korea refused today to return immediately a South Korean airliner hi-jacked to the North with four crew members and 47 passengers on Dec. 11.

SAN JOSE, Calif. Dec., 22 (UPI) -- Donald Cox, Black Panter Field Marshal, put in a tardy court appearance on a gun charge today but Federal Judge Robert Peckham decided against ordering the militant's arrest.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Israel and the United Arab Republic exchanged 330 Arab civilians and two bodies across the Suez Canal today, the Israeli military command announced.
DETROIT, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The chairman of the American Motors Corporation predicted today that the rate of economic growth would be slower in 1970 but that the market for automobiles would be strong.

Malcolm Bailey, a young painter who is black, has had the kind of break most artists yearn for. At 22, he's landed a show in a new exhibiton facility -- the Cinque Gallery on Lafayette Street.

Addonizio whose assignment was that of liaison between City Hall and the Puerto Rican community was indicted today along with a court interpreter on charges of having demanded and accepted money from persons for whom they had interceded in criminal cases.

A city correction officer and eight prisoners were arrested yesterday in a continuing investigation by the Bronx District Attorney and the Correction Commissioner into alleged beatings, sexual abuse and suicides on Rikers Island.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Dec. 22 -- Secretary General Thant declared today that he expected a breakthrough in the diplomatic stalemate on the Middle East "before the end of January."

Meade H. Esposito of Brooklyn, the most powerful Democratic county leader in New York State, proposed yesterday that party county leaders "keep hands off" in the selection of state candidates in 1970.

A young woman was captured in a bank in downtown Brooklyn yesterday after the police said she attempted to flee following an unsuccessful attempt to cash three stolen checks. A male accomplice escaped after kicking a policeman and spraying a chemical solution in his face, according to the police.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 22 (UPI) -- A Federal judge ordered the Department of Agriculture today to release surplus food commodities to more than 10,000 destitute persons in California's Central Valley.

He was talking about the minority-group employment in the building trades unions that is the goal of the so-called Philadelphia Plan supported by the Nixon Administration.

ANNA GUILLERMOPRIETO sighed and vowed that "A mole for Christmas in Mexico is traditional, and it should be made with turkey, but in all the Manhattan markets they're too bloody big." As she spoke she added cocoa to the dish that simmered in a fine Mexican earthenware casserole and explained that for this Christmas season she's using chicken.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -International diplomacy takes on a precise and concrete meaning in Room 5420 of the State Department. This is where the actual documents -the treaties, the "instruments of ratification," the proclamations -- formally reside.
The New York City Ballet will present world premieres of two ballets -- George Balanchine's "Who Cares?" and Jerome Robbins's "Night" -after its current run of "The Nutcracker."

But it wasn't until he saw all the youngsters in their bells and Indian scarves flying from their necks and tied around their waists that Bill Thomas decided Indian influences were a relevant part of the fashion scene.
The Board of Education announced yesterday its final plan for dividing the city into 30 decentralized, largely autonomous, community school districts.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 22 -- The first cautious steps toward a federalized Western Europe were taken early this morning in this capital city of the European Economic Community. Beginning in 1975, the six member states agreed, the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, will have the final say in budget matters.
MADISON, Wis., Dec. 22 (UPI) -- John Jardine, assistant coach at the University of California, Los Angeles, was named today as Wisconsin's football coach.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- Keisuke Sawaki, a 26-year-old Japanese physical education teacher, today was rated the early favorite to win this year's Sao Sylvestre cross-country race now that Gaston Roelants of Belgium has decided not to seek his fifth victory in the event.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- Unseeded Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., pulled off the day's major upset at the Orange Bowl international junior tennis championship today by beating eighth-ranked Jean Lovera of France, 6-2, 6-4.
WHEN the stock market pares away nearly three-quarters of the apple it would seem that a stock -- any stock -- had seen virtually all the selling it was likely to get.

A welfare case investigator was arrested yesterday and charged with being illegally on welfare himself.

Business plans for spending on new plant and equipment -- which now loom as the greatest single source of strength in a rapidly cooling economy -- may be greatly overstated, according to the Federal Reserve.

Roman Gabriel, the quarter-back of the Los Angeles Rams, was voted the National Football League player of the year this season by United Press International.

VIENNA, Dec. 22 -- Traffic on the international highway at Spielfeld on the snowbound Austrian - Yugoslav border backed up for seven miles today with thousands of migrant workers in recently bought cars impatient to go home to Balkan countries for Christmas.

Motorists who are covered by the state's assigned-risk plan will now be allowed to increase their liability insurance and also acquire coverage for fire, theft and other mishaps under new regulations that went into effect yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 22 -- The Suffolk Board of Supervisors today removed George Pettengill from his post as executive director of the Suffolk Human Relations Commission and replaced him with Charles A. Robert M. Morgenthau, who has served for more than eight years as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, resigned yesterday, effective Jan. 15. For upstate New York and New England ski area operators, it will be a merry Christmas. Most received their holiday gift three days early as six to 18 inches of snow fell yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- Sing Sing, in Ossining, will cease to be a state prison and will become an adult reception center to handle the assignment of prisoners, according to plans announced today by the State Crime Control Planning Board.

Dressed in black slacks and black turtleneck sweater, Lauren Bacall began rehearsing yesterday for her first Broadway comedy musical role. She will appear in "Applause,'' based on the film classic, "All About Eve."

The election of John C. Helies as president of the Scovill Manufacturing Company, Waterbury, Conn., was announced yesterday. Malcolm Baldridge, formerly president, becomes chairman of the board and chief executive officer.

Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said last night that the Long Island Rail Road would wind up the year with an operating deficit of more than $16-million -- the biggest loss in the line's history.

PARIS, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union today granted France the first trans-Siberian commercial air traffic rights between Paris and Tokyo in exchange for rights for Soviet airliners to fly onward from Paris to North and South America.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 16 -- The United States Central Intelligence Agency has become nearly as potent a political target in Chile as was the Communist party in the United States during the era of the late Joseph R. McCarthy.

TOKYO, Dec. 23 -- The people of Tokyo, with a national election Saturday, appear less excited about politics than about preparations for Christmas and New Year.

Cahill.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A former Democratic Assemblyman, Marvin D. Perskie, said today that a crime syndicate ran gambling, prostitution and narcotics rackets in this resort city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Another big United States wheat crop is expected next year despite government attempts to head off rising stockpiles by cutting farm acreage allotments for 1970 to the smallest in history.

The annual Soviet announcement of the size of the defense budget is a ritual guided more by political and propaganda considerations than by desire to help either Soviet citizens or curious foreigners know the magnitude of the Kremlin's military expenditures. Traditionally, one over-all figure is issued without supporting detail and without numerical reference to planned changes in either manpower or equipment.

Willie (the Actor) Sutton, whose bank robberies, jailbreaks and disguises made his name a household word to generations of Americans, returned to New York yesterday, a free man for the first time in 17 years.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Los Angeles trainer and the Minnesota head groundkeeper destroyed today the adage that insists everyone talks about the weather but no one does anything about it.

The well-orchestrated unveiling of State Department plans for the Middle East which bargain away all negotiating cards of Israel and the disclosure of strong behind-the-scene pressures by oil-cum-banking interests, make one wonder.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 25 (UPI) -- President Nasser and Premier Nimeiry arrived here today to meet Colonel Qaddafi. They had conferred earlier in the day in Algiers with President Houari Boumediene of Algeria.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 25 -- Israel intensified her aerial offensive against the United Arab Republic today with a record assault of eight and a half hours on positions along the Suez Canal.

LONDON -- A man was lounging about the other day, thinking of nothing in particular, when he realized there was something different about life. It was silence. Not a single aircraft engine had screamed through the sky for hours.

November sales of chain stores and catalogue houses rose 8.3 per cent from the corresponding month of 1968, a survey by The New York Times disclosed yesterday. During the first 11 months of this year, sales went ahead 11 per cent.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 26 -- Jerry West's torrid second-half shooting picked up the wilting, aching Los Angeles Lakers tonight and spurred them to a 114-106 victory over the New York Knickerbockers at the Forum.
The new-issue market retreated again in light trading during the week ended Wednesday, but the declines were not so widespread as in the preceding period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Army inquiry into the original investigation on the alleged Songmy massacre divided into two groups today, one heading for South Vietnam for 10 days and the other remaining at the Pentagon to question witnesses in the United States.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 27 -- Japan began voting this morning in the nation's 11th postwar general election.
LA PAZ, Bolivia -- One indication of the high level of illiteracy in this land today is the continued friendliness that so many Bolivians manifest toward North Americans.
Honor Tracy's analysis of the North Irish situation in your Dec. 13 issue presents a most biased approach.

Stuart Burrows, a Welsh tenor, will make his debut with the Metropolitan Opera as Tamino in "Die Zauberflote" during the company's third week of the season, beginning on Jan. 12. Tickets for the following performances will go on sale at the box office tomorrow at noon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The $4 monthly premium for Medicare will go up to $5.30, starting next July 1. The rise was announced today by Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. He said the current $4 premium rate, set in December, 1968, was "too low to cover costs during the current premium period."
HIROSHIMA, Japan, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Hiroshima Atomic Bomb Hospital said today that none of its patients died from leukemia or were treated for the disease this year.
A slowdown -- but not a recession -- is the forecast of economists who pooled their predictions for the National Industrial Conference Board.
The Federal Reserve System maintained its policy of severe monetary restraint during the last two weeks, banking data published yesterday showed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Former President Lyndon B. Johnson says he has no doubt whatever that he could have been re-elected last year and thinks Hubert H. Humphrey's defeat was largely due to the Vice President's mid-campaign concessions to dovish sentiment on the war in Vietnam.

Is is difficult to imagine the madcap Marx Brothers as teen-agers. But the first steps toward seeing them fresh out of kneepants were taken yesterday morning in a spacious, mirror-lined room at the Clark Center for the Performing Arts, at 51st Street and Eighth Avenue.

The city's Borough Presidents -- irritated by reports that Mayor Lindsay might reject their proposed salary increases and dissatisfied over their continuing lack of power -- are planning to go to the public with a plea for increased authority.

CHERBOURG, France, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Five gunboats built for Israel but held under a French government arms embargo slipped quietly out of this Atlantic port in the early-morning darkness yesterday. Several hours after their disappearance was reported today, the French Defense Ministry said they had been sold to a Norwegian commercial concern.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 -- A panel of four leading scientists called today for international disarmament as the worlds largest scientific meeting opened here amid signs of growing unrest and militancy among scientists over the arms race and environmental problems.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Bart Starr, the long-time quarterback of the Green Bay Packers, is old as professional football players go, but he is putting his money on youth.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- A high official of the United States Information Agency has urged Soviet officials to stop jamming Russian-language broadcasts of the Voice of America on the ground that it is costing both sides more money.

Bob Lanier and Rick Mount, two of the most heralded All-America candidates, and three undefeated teams -- St. Bonaventure, Pennsylvania and Manhattan -- go on display as day and night double-headers mark the opening today of the eight-team Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festitival at Madison Square Garden.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 26 -- The South Korean Government today rejected a North Korean offer to bargain with trade unions and other "non-official" associations in South Korea for the return of the passengers on the airliner hijacked Dec. 11.

VIENNA, Dec. 26 -- Informed sources in Prague said today that the Central Committee of the Czechoslovak Communist party would meet soon after New Year's Day, presumably for a showdown with the ultra-militant pro-Moscow faction that has been challenging the party chief, Dr. Gustav Husak.
The Tokyo stock market continued to advance yesterday and reached a new high on a turnover of 250 million shares.

The snowfall yesterday forced postponement and cancellation of several sporting events in the Northeast.
Prices advanced on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in the lightest trading in almost three months.

The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday it planned to increase prices for bulk and packaged antifreeze. The new levels become effective Jan. 1 for spot customers and on Feb. 1 for contract customers.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 26 -- The Arab world's leftist political leaders are depicting King Faisal of Saudi Arabia as the man who caused the failure of the conference of Arab leaders at Rabat, Morocco, this week. The Saudis and the right-wing press, however, are blaming President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- Leeds United's hopes of retaining the English League First Division soccer title today suffered a serious setback when it bowed, 2-1, to the European Fairs cupholder, Newcastle United.
Drivers were reminded yesterday by State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Vincent L. Tofany that mixture of medication and alcohol could make them a hazard on the highways.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Liberals in the scientific establishment triumphed over conservatives today when the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science took up a full-scale discussion of unidentified flying objects.

THERE is a class of Chinese ware described as "made for the Persian market" that was produced for the export trade starting late in the last century. It resembles the Chinese porcelains created for export in the 18th century and the early 19th century, but the quality is far lower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Texas Instruments, Inc., Dallas, has introduced a "Master-Slice" technique that has nothing to do with golf. It is a simpler and cheaper way of producing the integrated circuits in tiny wafers that make electronic instruments compact and reliable. Patent 3,484,932, issued to the company this week, covers the method. Tile inventor is Charles R. Cook Jr.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 27 -- Fighting remained at a low level, the American military command reported today after the end of allied and Vietcong Christmas truce periods that were marked by sporadic violations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire said today he thought President Nixon would back down on his threat to veto the health and education money bill. He added that the Senate might be able to override a veto.

City officials got the Christmas gift they wanted least, a snow that accumulated to six inches and more by yesterday morning. Happily, a coordinated over-all planning effort by the municipal authorities, plus a magnificent response by individual sanitation workers and an assist from the rain, kept the snow largely under control. The momentum of the metropolis was slowed, but not stopped.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Defense Department has decided to cut the armed forces by 200,000 to 300,000 men in the next budget year, starting July 1, according to ranking Pentagon officials.

BOMBAY, India, Dec 26 Reuters -- Food Minister Jagjivan Ram -- unofficial leader of India's 75 million untouchables, who under the outlawed caste system were one of the lowest castes -- today became the president of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's faction of the governing Congress party.

A 30-year-old housewife who lives on the third floor of a slum tenement in the South Bronx has kept her apartment and those of 15 of her neighbors from the cancerous spread of the area's deterioration.

MIAMI, Dec. 26 (AP) -- David Baker, a 20-year-old apprentice jockey from Kings Park, L. I., brought home the first winner of his career today at Tropical Park, but had to wait out a stewards' inquiry before his victory aboard Three Circles in the seventh race became official.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 26 -- A spokesman for the United States Embassy here said today that 2,400 American military personnel had been withdrawn from Thailand since October, leaving United States military strength in this country at 45,600. WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today he would continue to seek out transcripts of television news commentaries.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 26 -- Uruguay, an Atlantic coast nation, has joined the three Pacific coast countries of South America -- Peru, Chile and Ecuador -- in extending her territorial waters 200 miles out into the sea. SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The Australian sloop Fidelis, and the cutter Crusade of Britain, set the early pace today in the Sydney-to-Hobart yacht race, which attracted a record fleet of 79 craft for the 680-mile voyage.

Yet the many disappointments in such operations have caused no abandonment of the quest for life extension through the shift of vital organs from a dying person to one who still has a chance to live.

A Harlem citizens committee and a group of black clergymen called on the nation yesterday to observe the birthdate of the late Dr. Martin Luther King -- Jan. 15, 1970 -- as Martin Luther King Day.
