MANILA, Dec. 30 -- Vice President Agnew, who has been less than mellow toward antiwar demonstrators at home, brushed off his first encounter with demonstrators abroad as a "tactic of modern life" that free nations will have to learn to live with.

What puzzles so many helpless onlookers of the transit negotiations is if a settlement is indeed reachable without a strike tomorrow, why the parties could not have reached it without again going to the brink.

Net earnings of the Grand Union Company for the 13 weeks ended Nov. 29 increased 14 per cent from the 1968 period and were the highest third-quarter net income in the company's 97-year history, Charles G. Rodman, president, reported yesterday.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 30 -- The five coastal vessels that Israel is reported to have acquired in a bizarre military transaction are expected to fill a role planned for them nearly three years ago.

It's the holiday season and the streets of the city are filled with shoppers and sightseers. Tourists and college students flood the mid-town area and slosh through the melting snow and the grime in the streets.
The Government increased yesterday the legal ceiling on home mortgages that it insures or guarantees to 81/2 per cent, effective next Monday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Roy M. Cohn, the lawyer and financier, has been secretly indicted by a Cook County grand jury on charges of violating the Illinois Bank Company Holding Act.
Mayor Lindsay has taken up residence at the Americana Hotel, and all the straphangers have to do now is hold their breath until they find out how much it is going to cost them.
For the first time since its founding more than a century ago, the American Association for the Advancement of Science has elected a woman, Dr. Mina S. Rees, to its presidency.

The General Electric Company and two unions bargaining nationally adjourned negotiations here early yesterday until next Monday. Thus, the strike by 133,000 G.E. employes at plants in 135 cities will extend into an 11th week.

The Arnold Krakower Hematology Foundation, which will be devoted to the study of blood diseases, was established yesterday in memory of a lawyer who died of a blood disease last spring at the age of 53.
Yesterday was a delightful between-holidays afternoon at Madison Square Garden for the New York Knickerbockers and 19,500 of their fans.

TRENTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The State Department of Banking and Insurance said today that New Jersey savings and loan associations "may not have legal authority" to conform to a Federal ruling allowing them to raise their interest rates from 5 to 6 per cent for some depositors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- President Nixon, just before leaving for a California vacation, signed today a measure appropriating nearly $70-billion for the Department of Defense and military departments.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -Peaches Bartkowicz of Hamtramck, Mich., was upset by Corinne Molesworth of Britain, 6-4, 4-6, 8-6, in the third round of the East Province tennis championships today.
PARIS, Dec. 30 -- The United States handed over to the Communist side at the peace talks today a list of 1,406 names of American fighting men missing in action in Southeast Asia as of Dec. 24.

To most New Yorkers, Forest Hills is the neighborhood in Queens where famous tennis players meet once a year to compete, where Tudor-style homes evoke a quiet past, and where new luxury apartment houses attest to an affluent present.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Federally required information on automobile safety performance will be available starting today in dealers' showrooms, but it may disappoint the comparison shopper.
His hand on a Bible, 74-year-old Abe Stark was sworn in yesterday for a third term as Brooklyn Borough President in a chandelier-lighted office redolent of the past.
Bob Lanier came to play not to practice last night.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 31 -- The American command reported today that a three-day New Year's cease-fire called by the Vietcong deteriorated into sharp fighting by both sides yesterday and this morning.

NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Dec. 30 -- Bobby Hull is averaging more than a goal for every two games, and Stan Mikita is doing his usual point-a-game scoring. But the Chicago Black Hawks, who meet the Rangers at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, have returned to respectability by finding something they lost the last few years defense.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- In a still-secret report, a Presidential study group has sharply criticized the Federal Government's role in the Model Cities program to aid urban poverty neighborhoods.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Gover nment closed Haile Selassie University today after three students were killed and five wounded in a gun battle with riot police yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -The following list of American military personnel missing in Southeast Asia was presented today to the North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegations at the Paris talks on Vietnam and was made available here by the State Department. Only the names, ranks and service numbers were given.

Frederick Wiseman, a controversial filmmaker who produces, directs and edits his own films and manages to outrage various segments of society in the process, has turned out a 90-minute examination of New York City's Metropolitan Hospital, which will be broadcast over the National Educational Television network on Feb. 2.

Bill Toomey's name appears after all on the ballots for the 1969 James E. Sullivan Award. They were mailed yesterday from the Amateur Athletic Union's national headquarters here to a nationwide panel of voters.
The spy trial which was held in Saigon points out the political narrow-mindedness of the Saigon regime, or more specifically of Nguyen Van Thieu.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- When Mina Spiegel Rees was a mathematics adviser to the Navy, she had a distinct advantage over her colleagues. As she says today with a smile, "I could sass the admirals as the men couldn't." Dr. Rees is still charming men.

FIFTY-THREE people paid $62,000 so that Pearl Wong could open her own restaurant and continue advising them on what to eat. They did it partly out of loyalty to Pearl and partly out of loyalty to their own stomachs.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation, merged into the Atlantic Richfield Company last March, was found liable yesterday for a breach of its obligations to minority stockholders of the Sinclair Venezuelan Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -This is bound to be a time of reflection for President Nixon. He has almost completed his first year in the White House. He will be 57 years old on Jan. 9, and he undoubtedly has more support at home and abroad now than he had when he took the oath of office.

I shall not reply to the Rev. Milton A. Galamison's inflammatory call [letter Dec. 24] for black "resistance" to local school board elections in New York City, since this leads only to unresolved political recrimination.

NEWARK, Dec. 30 -- A Federal grand jury investigating corruption in this city today heard a former convict refuse to answer questions about alleged payoffs to the police, gambling operations and "business transactions" with Newark's Police Director, Dominick A. Spina.
Businesses here are setting up their own transportation and reserving hotel space for executives and key personnel in event of a transit strike early tomorrow.

ARCADIA, Calif. Dec. 31 (UPI) Renewed negotiations to end a strike of service employes against Santa Anita and Bay Meadows get under way Friday under the auspices of the California State Conciliation Service, a union spokesman said today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 31 (AP) Trailing by as many as 16 points in the first half, the University of Michigan used a full-court press in the second half and went on to register an 80-72 victory over Princeton tonight in a nonconference basketball game.
When it appeared the Rangers would be shut out for the first time in 100 games, they turned brutal scoreless duel around last night to score a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

THROUGH no conceivable fault of my own I ac quired a scarred youth. The lot of the man who is a compulsive theatergoer we second-hand voyeurs finding himself at either of the English universities of Oxford or Cambridge is not altogether a happy one. For three years he is destined to see most of the great plays of all times quite disgracefully acted.
Governor Rockeleller announced yesterday his appointment of William F. Walsh, whose term as Mayor of Syracuse expired last night, as a member of the State Public Service Commission.
The Coast Guard said yesterday that its annual winter ice reporting service had become operational.

IN 1956 Joyce Scott-Paine visited her native England, where she bought an English cocker spaniel, Ricmour Crystal Dawn. "On the voyage home," she recalled, "I was trying to think of a good call name for her. Another passenger suggested Folly. Now I have 40 dogs at my Ancram Kennels. Perhaps
The American Stock Exchange ended the year in a bullish manner yesterday as the list advanced on the largest daily volume in the exchange's history. Turnover was so
After five years of negotiations, Pan American World Airways will finally take over operation of Teterboro Airport, starting today.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Dec. 31 President Nixon today designated a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, George M. Stafford, as acting chairman of the 11-member commission, pending the appointment of a new permanent chairman of the reorganized agency.
BRAZZAVILLE, Republic of the Congo, Dec. 31, (Agence France-Presse) This leftist nation today changed its name to the People's Republic of the Congo. The "Internationale" becomes its national anthem.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 1 A proclaimed 24-hour allied cease-fire for New Year's was, shattered last night by 30 significant violations that the United States command said claimed the lives of five American soldiers and 40 of the enemy.
VANDERHOOF, B.C.--Americans, some of them restless, land-hungry or politically disillusioned, have been moving to Canada in record numbers.

PEKING, Dec. 31 (Agence France-Presse) The official newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao played up what it termed were "revolutionary" developments this year in three capitalist countries, France, Japan and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec.31 The old year, going its unmourned way amid so many clamors and defeats, closed on at least one note of welcome generosity. After a year in intellectual and political exile, former Secretary of State Dean Rusk is, as he puts it, "going home" to Georgia as a member of that state's university faculty.

The Beatrice Foods Company reported yesterday net earnings of $13,127,723, equal to 51 cents a common share, for the three months ended Nov. 30. This was up 16 per cent, from $11,342,877, or 49 cents a share, earned in the corresponding third fiscal quarter a year earlier.
The bond market wound up 1969 with a modest advance in prices yesterday and then it shut down early to toast the end of a trying year that had driven rates to the highest levels in 100 years.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm yesterday as interest was still centered on Australian nickel issues.

MADISON, Wisc., Dec. 31 Federal Judge James E. Doyle denied today a request for a temporary injunction to restrain the Selective Service from drafting men under the new lottery plan. Judge Doyle, however, denied a motion by Government lawyers to dismiss the suit, which charges the lottery is biased against men whose birthdays fall late in the year.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 31 (AP) Doug Dickey accepted a five-year contract as Florida's football coach today after resigning as coach at Tennessee.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin called today for new national policies to promote "unprecedented growth" in rural areas.

A Federal Judge here yesterday dismissed the complaint by Pepsico, Inc., against W.R. Grace Co. and Philip Morris, Inc., over the sale of Grace's 53 per cent interest in Miller Brewing Company to the cigarette manufacturer.

SELECTING the best tournament performers in a calendar year is a difficult task. Perhaps the best criterion is the three major national championships, and on this basis the honors for 1969 go to three New York experts.
The Inter American Bank an- nounced yesterday it had approved loans totaling $96.4-million to help finance projects designed to improve transportation in Argentina, Mexico and, Paraguay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 Another hungry year appears to lie ahead for the Federal health budget.

The first session of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's New Congress party in Bombay did little to fulfill the promise of a more vigorous drive for social and economic progress that Mrs. Gandhi made when she broke with the old guard of the Congress party earlier last year.

Albert Shanker, president of ' the United Federation of Teachers, yesterday asked the State Supreme Court to reconsider the 15-day jail sentence and $250 fine handed him as a result of the 1968 teachers' strike.

GULFPORT, Miss., Dec. 31 Gov. John Bell Williams bowed, to pressure from many sources today and appointed three Negroes to a previously allwhite panel that had been set up to control all Federal money for the redevelopment of the section of the Mississippi Gulf Coast ravaged last summer by Hurricane Camille.
"At this stage there are no periods when we sit and wait. If we're not talking to negotia- tors or to Mayor Lindsay, we're' talking among ourselves."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 Each soldier, as he arrives in Vietnam for a tour of duty, is handed a small white card that he is instructed to study and carry with him at all times.

Group life insurance, which often constitutes the largest part of an individual's potential estate, has a brand new tax aspect. And since many people don't realize this, a good New Year's resolution for an employe would be, to investigate it.

ATLANTA, Dec. 31 (AP) Lou Hudson scored 29 points and four of his teammates hit for double figures tonight as the Atlanta Hawks gained a 122-111 National Basketball Association victory over the Baltimore Bullets.

The Western Electric Company, the manufacturing and supply arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has received a $230,400,000 Army contract for radar for the Safeguard antiballistic missile system.
John Vliet Lindsay was sworn in for a second term as Mayor in an icy, needle- sharp rain on the City Hall steps yesterday, at noonday ceremonies that stressed humility and conciliation.

In an internal reorganization at the Chase Manhattan Bank, David Rockefeller has decided to assume the role of elder statesman, while retaining the title of chairman and chief executive officer. He became chairman last March.

TRENTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) A New Jersey court official confirmed today that Long Branch city officials had been asked to meet Jan. 13 with the Stated Supreme Court concerning operations of the city's Municipal Court.

WHEN he was 21 years old Mordechai Limon, sea captain and commando, was organizing the illegal entry of thousands of Jewish refugees fresh from Nazi concentration camps into Palestine along the dark, deserted Mediterranean coast beaches.
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 31 (UPI) Oh. the basis of consistent high performances, Jack Nicklaus and Kathy Whitworth were the top professional golfers of 1969, a golf magazine said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Congressional investigations and legislative action were promised today in the wake of an announced increase in the maximum interest rate on Government-backed home mortgages.

The confirmation of Dean Rusk's appointment to a chair of international law at the University of Georgia represents a victory for the institution's academic leadership over the forces of bigotry. One need not agree with the policies Mr. Rusk espoused as Secretary of State to recognize his eminent intellectual qualifications or the extent to which these were buttressed by extraordinary experience and unassailable integrity.

BONGSON, South Vietnam, Dec. 29 "I emphasize to my troops that we no longer are preoccupied with chasing and killing the Vietcong and North Vietnamese Army in unpopulated jungle and mountain areas. More important, body count is no longer the criteria for success."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 A nation whose diet is already nearly half composed of processed or synthetic food must develop a comprehensive policy regarding the "breadness" of bread and the "meatness" of meat, President Nixon has been told.

The New York Rangers have revised their schedule for three home games, Emile Francis, coach and general manager of the club, said yesterday. Originally slated for the evening, the games will be played in the afternoon, each starting at 2:05 o'clock.
Following is the text of a transcript of Mayor Lindsay's inaugural address at City Hall yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 31 The Texas industrialist H. Ross Perot announced tonight that the Soviet Union would not allow him to enter the country to send supplies to American prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

VANDERHOOF, B.C., Few American Negroes have migrated to Canada, whose population is less than 1 per cent black, and few of the draft evaders and deserters are black. On the other hand, a number of American Negro athletes who came to Canada to play professional football have settled here.

To Norman McLaren, brevity is the soul of screen art. Eleven of his films are being shown in a 120-minute program at the Guggenheim Museum. Because of the public response, the museum has extended through January the weekend showings of short subjects by the Academy Award winning filmmaker. The screenings are given at 2 and 4 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec, 31 Mr. Bechtle, a 41-year-old native of Philadelphia who was named United States Attorney for Eastern Pennsylvania last May, said he hoped that the clearance of traditional Federal court district boundaries would help law enforcement in the PhiladelphiaCamden-South Jersey area.
HAIFA, Israel, Dec. 31 Five unarmed gunboats ended a 3,000-mile journey from Cherbourg, France, here tonight but their arrival did little to unravel the mystery of their departure.

PARIS, Dec. 31 (Reuters) French gold and foreign currency reserves declined by 719million francs to 17.77-billion francs in the week to Dec. 25, the Bank of France said today. This was the first decline in nine weeks, the bank said.

It's New Year's Day and thousands of people celebrated the passing of the old year with friends and loved ones. In nightclubs and homes throughout the country enthusiastic crowds toasted the new year and honed for better days.
Top-level executive appointments were announced yesterday by two of Wall Street's largest brokerage houses.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 31 (Reuters)--Israeli warplanes today flew across the Suez Canal to strike at Egyptian military targets in the region of Suez at the southern end of the waterway, a military spokesman announced here.

LONDON, Dec. 31 Biting assessments of leading Americans made by the British Ambassador to Washington just before the outbreak of World War II in 1939 were disclosed today in hitherto secret Foreign Office documents.
The city's critical transit negotiations moved toward a climax early this morning, but the 20-cent fare already appeared doomed.

PARIS, Dec. 31 European central banking sources said today the most significant feature of a gold agreement between the International Monetary Fund and South Africa was that it would ease pres sures on American gold reserves.
IN ALMOST every respect where food is concerned, the past decade was by far the most impressive since the one that produced the Boston tea party.

HARRY PETER (BUD) GRANT, coach of the new glamour team of pro football, the Minnesota Vikings, is one of those tall, silent types with a hidden personality and aggravating self-control. He likes crow shooting and family picnics (the Grants have six children).

ALTHOUGH the Rev. William James Lombardy of St. Mary's Church, the Bronx, did not take first place in the recent United States championship in New York, the 32-year-old grandmaster recorded an impressive performance in the 12-man round-robin.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 31 Among the many on queen Elizabeth's New Year's honors list was David Owen, a Welsh economist who financed the early days of United Nations operations with a 30 loan from his London bank account.

NEWARK, Dec. 31 The United States Attorney for New Jersey, Frederick B. Lacey, said today that he would seek a meeting with Whitney North Seymour Jr. as soon as Mr. Seymour took office as the United States Attorney for New York's Southern District. The purpose of the meeting would be to map a joint strategy for investigating interstate organized crime.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The Army announced today that it would try S. Sgt. David Mitchell on charges of assault with intent to murder 30 Vietnamese civilians in connection with the alleged massacre at Songmy last year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The Treasury will receive tomorrow a New Year's gift of about $850-million of brand new, usable international money.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the United States Commissioner of Education, said today that his personal goal for 1970 was to lead education to "the top of domestic priorities" within the Nixon Administration.
Jimi Hendrix, a New Year's Eve noisemaker if ever there was one, played to a capacity crowd last night at the Fillmore East.

The American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday a new and more restrictive admissions policy that will bar all children under the age of 18 from the museum on school days unless they are accompanied by an adult.

It is hard to believe that popular prophets at the close of l959 were hailing this now faded decade as the "Golden Sixties." The label no doubt was another of those triumphs of hope over experience without which the human race might find it hard to keep going. But it had a certain plausibility, too.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (UPI) Mississippi, ranked 13th in the nation, will rest its hopes for an upset victory on the passing arm of Archie Manning tomorrow when the Rebels meet third-rated Arkansas in the 36th annual Sugar Bowl football contest.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that the Navy's Poseidon nuclear missile program had developed a $3.6-billian cost overrun.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 Cook County Coroner Andrew J. Toman today appointed Martin S. Gerber, a former Assistant United States Attorney, as a specialty deputy coroner to preside over an inquest into the shooting of two Black Panther leaders on Dec. 4.
One of the rarest artifacts in the world and, for its size and weight, conceivably the costliest, will be sold here in March.
Three major promotions within the consumer products group of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company were announced yesterday by Robert T. Wieringa, group president.

Dr. Theodor Reik, one of the first students of Sigmund Freud and later the author of many books on psychoanalysis including "Listening With the Third Ear," died yesterday at the age of 81 in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx.

Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld, of the Court of Appeals, New York State's highest court, gave the Queens prosecutor yesterday the right to appeal the Appellate Division's reversal of the 1968 manslaughter conviction of Mrs. Alice Crimmins in the strangling of her 4-year-old daughter, Alice Marie.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Dec. 31 President Nixon signed the $1.9-billion foreign aid authorization bill today but promised "extensive renovation" of the program in the years ahead.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission asked the nation's major stock exchanges today for more detailed information on their views of proposed changes in the commissions they charge.
THERE is no book of rules, and certainly no consensus, on how human beings should change years. If there were violations would have been rampant here last night.
Spectacular individual performances, basically formful results and one major local disappointment marked the conclusion of college basketball's holiday-tournament orgy Tuesday night.
THEY may never be big in New York, although there are a few on Fire Island, but out in the hinterlands, hex signs have become popular in both interior and exterior decor.
Louis d'Almeida, a corporation executive, was indicted yesterday in the death of a 20-yearold youth in a private six-car garage at 160 East 82d Street last Oct. 2.
Criminal summonses for two city housing officials have been obtained by tenants of a South Bronx apartment house that has allegedly been without heat for more than a month.
Commodity futures traders left yesterday on a four-day New Year's holiday, following a shortened trading session on most exchanges.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 1 Vice President Agnew flew to Saigon unanounced this morning for a one-day visit to the nation whose lengthy war stimulated the Nixon doctrine of Asian self-reliance.

Johnny Dill, a troubled, 38- year-old meat-market clerk, died yesterday in his Harlem tenement apartment, the target of a six-hour police siege after he had fired a shot through the door at two patrolmen.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 31 On New Year's Day 'the island commonwealth of Puerto Rico becomes the fifth place in the world to adopt a compulsory auto accident compensation plan that covers the entire population.
Bernard Feinstein, an artist, died Dec. 20 of a heart attack at his home, 501 Surf Avenue, in the West Brighton section of Brooklyn. He was 64 years old.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 31 Mrs. Nancy Mills Becker was married at noon today to Dr. Robert L. Fardelmann, a surgeon.
MIAMI, Dec. 31 Mrs. Eugenie A. Mentschikoff of Chicago died of a heart attack yesterday in Mercy Hospital here. She was 84 years old, the widow of Roman Mentschikoff.
HOUSTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) Jim Stating ran for 184 yards and two touchdowns to lead the University of Houston to a 36-7, victory over Auburn tonight in the 11th annual AstroBluebonnet Bowl game.
Dr. J.C. Sluder has been appointed executive vice president of the Nestle Company, Inc., White Plains, N.Y.

PARTICIPANTS The public agencies directly involved in the contract negotiations at the Americana Hotel, are the Transit Authority and its subsidiary, the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority They operate the city's publicly owned subway and bus lines Both are arms of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that also oversees operations on the Long Island Rail Road and the city's bridges and tunnels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 Hilary Sandoval Jr., head of the Small Business Administration, said today that the agency had approved $73-million in disaster relief to victims of Hurricane Camille and that he expected the total to reach $200-million.
Castleton Industries, a diversified company based in Boca Raton, Fla., is engaged in negotiations seeking disposal of its banking interests valued at an estimated $12-million.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 1 Noel Coward, the 70-year-old playwright, composer and actor who says he keeps fit on lots of aspirin and marrons glaces, received a knighthood on the New Year's honors lists issued today by Prime Minister Wilson.
PARIS, Dec. 31 France suspended two high defense officials and ordered the recall of Israeli diplomats today as five French-built gunboats entered the Israeli port of Haifa.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 A new law goes into effect tomorrow that will enable California's 20 million residents one of every 10 Americans to gain a divorce virtually on demand.

PARIS, Dec. 31 R. Treno, publisher and editor of one of the world's most successful satirical journals, Le Canard Enchaine, died today following an operation. Mr. Treno, whose real name was Ernest Raynaud, was 68 years old.
DALLAS, Dec. 31 The eyes of Texas will be focused upon the 34th Cotton Bowl game tomorrow afternoon between the unbeaten Longhorns and Notre Dame.
Sleet and freezing rain coated the metropolitan area with a slick film of ice yesterday, causing snarls in highway and rail transportation as well as slippery inconvenience to pedestrians.
The reputed leader of an East village radical group testified in Federal Court yesterday that he had made, damaging admissions to the Federal Bureau of Investigation about bombing Federal property.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 31 Mr. and Mrs Clarence A. Grimmett Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rebecca Grimmett, to Thomas Daniel Steiner, son of Dr. and Mrs. S. Daniel Steiner of Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

Special to The New York Times PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 31 Finance Minister Nicolaas Diederichs declared a victory for South African gold in a statement today outlining the new gold marketing arrangement endorsed by the International Monetary Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The manufacturer of Pall Mall Gold and Silva Thin cigarettes lost the last of three preliminary skirmishes today in a court battle in defense of television commercials that the Federal Trades Commission had branded as misleading.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 William Hamilton, a Cleveland real estate dealer, says the 1968 Federal Fair Housing Act has made little or no difference in getting Negroes into the nearly all-white suburbs, that ring Cleveland.
VIENNA, Dec. 31 The Czechoslovak Communist party announced today yet another broad purge to oust exponents of what it termed petit bourgeois views in its ranks.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 31 Gov. Ronald Reagan today granted the State of Connecticut's request for the extradition of the Black Panther leader Bobby G. Seale on kidnapping and murder charges.

The 21st annual Bal Blanc, at which members of the local Russian colony and their friends ring in the New Year according to the Russian calendar, will be held on Jan. 13 in the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.

Yes, Virginia, there is a yearend rally. It arrived yesterday, amid the rain and sleet whistling through Wall Street, in the form of briskly rising prices and the heaviest volume in two and a half months.
McAFEE, N.J., Dec. 31 In-state skiing appears to be the in-thing for many of northern New Jersey's school set.

Ted Bonanno of Marietta College stroked the New York Athletic Club senior eight-oared shell to a one-third length victory over the West Side Row- ing Club of Buffalo on the Orchard Beach Lagoon yesterday in the sixth annual New Year's Eve Regatta of the New York Rowing Association.

The Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company joined in the latest round of increases for basic copper prices yesterday, although two of the three major American producers continued to "study" the changes without matching them.

The national director of the Jewish Defense League charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's office was responsible for the league's confrontation with the police Tuesday night outside the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

MEXICO CTTY, Dec. 31 (UPI) The second largest sulphur producer in Mexico, Compania de Azufre de Veracruz, S.A., a subsidiary of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation of Houston, will shut down operations tomorrow.

BEL-AIR, Calif., Dec. 31 (UPI) J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, former New York gangland lawyer, died of a heart attack in his home here yesterday, after learning that two masked gunmen had bound his wife and grandson and had stolen jewels, furs and cash. He was 65 years old.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 31 Prime Minister John Vorster dealt a blow tonight to hopes for relaxation of apartheid in multiracial sport.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 31 A Federal task force is forming here in preparation for the opening Monday of more than 200 public schools ordered to integrate their classrooms completely.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 31 The Legislature approved a $255-million business tax package today, ending a year-long deadlock over the state budget for the current fiscal year.

The Columbia Broadcasting System petitioned the United States District Court yesterday for permission to pay for such music as it uses of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and Broadcast Music, Incorporated rather than pay an over-all percentage of the network's net gross.

Proceeds from the Quadrille Ball, to be held at the Americana on Jan. 16, will be divided between the Germanistic Society of America and the Institute of International Education for a scholarship fund for the exchange of American and German graduate students. Mrs. Peter J. Kessler is chairman for the 10th annual event, which is under the sponsorship of Lutthansa German Air Lines.
PETER L. BERNSTEIN, author, lecturer on finance and investment management consultant, believes that the wrong question is being asked about the economy.

Melvyn Kaufman, a builder and owner of Manhattan office buildings, was arrested yesterday on charges of first-degree perjury arising from an alleged effort to bribe a member of the City Planning Commission.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31 (AP) Keith McCreary slammed in two goals as ahe Pittsburgh Penguins defeated the Montreal Canadians, 4-2, in a National Hockey League game tonight.
OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) Joe Namath, quarterback for the New York Jets, was named today the American Football League's most valuable player for the second straight year by the league coaches.
Kenneth N. Hargreaves, managing director of Avco Embassy Pictures' British operations, died in a London hospital Saturday.

GENEVA, Dec. 31 Vice President Agnew's attacks on newspapers and television were 1969's "most serious threat to the freedom of information in the Western World," the International Press Institute said today.

Salvatore Baccaloni, the popular bass who sang here with the Metropolitan Opera for 22 years, died last night at St. Clare's Hospital following deterioration of a number of organs. He was 69 years old.
RYE, N.Y., Dec. 31 Miss Pauline Adoue and Francis J. Scanlon, will be married Feb. 14 in Bennington, Vt., where they are serving as VISTA volunteers.

The Rev. Dr. Elmer J.F. Arndt, head of the Theological Commission of the United Church of Christ and a professor at the Eden Theological Seminary in St. Louis, died Tuesday evening in a St. Louis hospital after a long illness. He was 61 years old.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 (AP) The Chrysler Corporation, whose earnings hit a new seven-year low for the third quarter, will pay no executive bonuses for 1969.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP) John Havlicek, Tom Sanders and Don Nelson sparked a strong fourthperiod rally today as the Boston Celtics overcame an 8-point deficit and went on to a 124-121 National Basketball Association victory over the Detroit Pistons.

Customs collections in the New York region last November dropped slightly from the total collections in the corresponding month in 1968, Michael Stramiello Jr., Regional Commissioner of Customs, said here yesterday.
SAN JUAN, Dec. 31 (AP) The New York Athletic Club team won the third annual invitation water polo championship today, defeating Jamaica, 11-6, in a sudden-death playoff game.

IN "Part of Our Time," Murray Kempton suggested that each decade creates its own myth, and that succeeding decades wait, with knives in their hands, to kill the old myth and carve a new one. The end of the line as active ships does not spell the end of useful life for two vessels that evoke memories of the old days here and at Boston.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 31 The engagement of Miss Susan Annan Guernsey to Duke Nordlinger Stern has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Taylor Guernsey, of Rye and Edgartown, Mass. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Antoinette Stern Ames of Chicago and the late Harold Gordon Stern of Richmond.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (UPI) Members of the West High School band of Columbus, Ohio, quietly watched the Sugar Bowl parade in which they were supposed to march today.

PASADENA, Calif. The Rose Bowl's two most successful clients, the Universities of Michigan and Southern California, will tangle tomorrow in the 56th production of the oldest of the New Year's Day extravaganzas.
Dr. Gottfried Heindl, for the last three years director of the Austrian Cultural Institute in New York City, has been named chief of the Austrian State Theater Administration.
Lee Shippey, a newspaper columnist and author, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Encinitas, Calif., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to give school systems in six Deep South states until next fall to desegregate their class rooms.
Lowering skies, slushy streets and the threat of a transit strike notwithstanding, there were heightened holiday spirits in the city last night as New Yorkers gaily greeted a new year
Richard L. Benoit, an author and editor of law textbooks, died Tuesday at his home in New Hartford, N.Y., near Utica. He was 71 years old and lived in New York until he retired last year.

Preparing for a possible rise in the subway fare, the Transit Authority has already begun moving new tokens from storage in the Navy Yard and other places to its headquarters at 370 Jay Street in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) Farm prices ended the year on a rising note by registering an increase of one-third of 1 per cent for the month ended Dec. 15 the highest level since September, 1952 the Agriculture Department reported today.

TOKYO, Dec. 31 "The whole idea of creating a show, of creating a musical, is new here in Japan," Joe Layton, the Broadway director and choreographer, mused during a break between rehearsals at the T.B.S. television studios the other day. "That's why this is such a challenging assignment," he said.
The Greater New York Blood Program appealed again yesterday for volunteer donations to meet its seasonal shortage.
SOME 1970 resolutions for guilty sportsmen: Never claim a bird at which you shot but which may have fallen to a companion's gun, even though he has been claiming your birds all day long.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) The Government said today that the United States would begin the new year with a population of 204,334,344 a gain of 2,067,000 in, 1969.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 Despite vigorous protests by defense attorneys, Abbie Hoffman was questioned closely today about his alleged plan to "kidnap" a high-ranking Chicago police official.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 (UPI) Archie Clark and Hal Greer set the pace today as the Philadelphia 76ers used a 34point third quarter to defeat the Chicago Bulls, 129-109, in a National Basketball Association game. The loss was the fifth in, a row for Chicago.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 31 After two days of boisterous debate, a narrow majority of the House of Representatives decided today that three of its members had engaged in procommunist activities.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 31 Dr. and Mrs. Donald McKay Shafer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Brady Shafer, to William Arthur Beale. His parents are Mrs. William Nelson Beale Jr. of Baltimore and the late Commander Beale, U.S.N.
Honeywell, Inc., announced yesterday the formation of three new divisions aimed at speeding the company's growth in the computer-communications and data-products fields.

ONE of the consistent prize-winners of the last decade has been the Brazilian pianist Nelson Freire. He is now 25 years old and much talked-about, and he was launched in this country by an album of concerto recordings. Last night he finally made his first New York appearance, playing the Rachmaninoff Piano Concerto No. 4 with the New York Philharmonic under Rafael Fruhbeck De Burgos.
WHEELING, W. Va., Dec. 31 Miss Sarah Louise Oliver and John Stanley Bodkin Jr., 1969 graduates of Wheeling College, have set June 27 for the date of their wedding.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 "Welcome, fellow sufferers, to yet another depressing decadeend roundup. Here with me to round it up in terms that will make us all sorry we were ever born is a panel of distinguished correspondents. Could we start off, Bucky Shores, with some peculiarly depressing observations from you?"
The Metropolitan Opera certainly had its share of trouble in 1969, but as the year ended last night the company put on a performance of Puccini's "Tosca" that showed no signs of strife.

MONTREAL, Dec. 31 (AP) Lorne (Gump) Worsley, 40-yearold goalie of the Montreal Canadiens, has indicated he will retire rather than accept a demotion to a farm team, the National Hockey League club said today.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 31 Richard Frankenfelder died at his home here last night. Until his retirement in 1959 he was executive vice president of Cameo Beauty Departments, a chain of concessions, later merged into Seligman Latz, Inc. He was 68 years, old and lived at 10 Old Mamaroneck Road.

GARMISCH PARTENKIRCH(UPI) Jiri Raska of Czechoslovakia, an Olympic gold medal winner, added another triumph to his international record today by winning an international ski jumping event on Garmisch's big Olympic jumping hill.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan 1 (AP) Fifteen thousand men and boys pranced up Broad Street today in this city's annual Mummers Parade, and thousands of spectators braved temperatures in the mid twenties to watch.

WASHINGTON, San. 1 The Federal Communications Commission is considering new hearings on a California TV license dispute to determine whether the signature of one of President Nixon's aides was forged on a stockholder list in 1965.

MIAMI, Jan. 1 (AP) Penn State has a friend in Dan Devine, the Missouri football coach. "If I had a vote, I might vote a tie for No. 1 between Texas and Penn State," he said. "I can guarantee you that I wouldn't vote Penn State No. 2 under any circumstances.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 1 Israel tonight denied any violation of the French arms embargo against her and said that Paris's criticism of her in the case of the transferred gunboats was unjustified.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 1 (AP) The job of cleaning up began today, after a 13-alarm waterfront lumberyard fire that caused about $250,000 damage last night.
The S.S. Kresge Company registered sales of $351,000,000 in the four weeks ended Dec. 27, the chain announced yesterday. Sales were 24.9 per cent over those in the like period of 1968.

MIDLAND, Tex., Jan. 1 (AP) James N. Allison Jr., deputy chairman of the Republican National Committee, says a task force studying oil imports is expected to recommend an increase in such imports. But he said two Administration members are against more foreign oil.

Benjamin Van Doren Hedges, a former executive vice president of the National Big Brothers of America and a silver medalist in the 1928 Olympic games at Amsterdam, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 62 years old and lived at the Columbia University Club, 4 West 43d Street.

Governor Rockefeller's disclosure that he will support an increase of roughly $300 million in state aid to education should not be taken as an indication that anything like this sum in fresh money will be available to local school districts. The greater part of it will merely restore the $245 million in school aid cuts imposed by the Legislature on the Governor's recommendation last spring.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) Distraught relatives of Mrs. Alexander McKay, believed to have been kidnaped Monday, called in two mediums today to help find the ailing 55-yearold wife of the acting chairman of News of the World.

ROME, Jan. 1 Charges of murder and torture of political opponents by Brazil's militarydominated government have been presented to Pope Paul VI with the endorsement of 61 prominent European Roman Catholics.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 1 (Reuters) The Zambian copper mining industry officially came under state control today, but few major changes are likely for several months.

EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., Jan. 1 Clutch shooting by Tom Kelleher and Bob McLaughlin led Hofstra to a 76-71 triumph over Muhlenberg tonight in the first round, of the Pocono Classic basketball tournament.

"They Shoot Horses, Don't They?" the adaptation of the 1935 Horace McCoy novel about marathon dancers of the nineteen-thirties, has been named the best film of 1969 by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures. The organization, which has been selecting top movies for 49 years, chose a Swedish drama Ingmar Bergman's "Shame," as the year's outstanding foreign-language feature.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 1 (Reuters) Israel today established its fourth settlement in the occupied Jordan Valley.
DETROIT, Jan. 1 (AP) Truck production in the United States has set a calendar-year record, but auto output in 1969 trailed the 1968 total by 617,225 units, Automotive News reported yesterday.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Jan. 1 (UPI) Two Los Angeles residents have admitted at a pretrial hearing they were carrying a ton of marijuana to California when they landed their rented plane near Guadalajara.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 1 pressure within the Roman Catholic Church for social reform in Brazil has brought the church into conflict with the country's conservative, mili-, tary-dominated Government.

Mrs. Anne Semler Curtis of New York and Blue Hill, Me., and Dr. Charles Pelham Curtis of Fairfield, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Amory Curbs, to Peter Brinton Rankin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harley Rankin of Haverford, Pa. The couple plan to be married in June.

The RCA Corporation has developed a new solid-state device that, company, spokesmen ay, may lead to TV-type remote controls for home appliances, heating systems, office equip ment and industrial tools.
TORONTO, Jan. 1 The sugary vision of selling more goods to mainland China, a country of 700 million inhabitants, dances before Canadian exporters and Government officials as the new year breaks.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 2 Allied and enemy forces were expected to resume full-scale offensive operations this morning following the expiration of a widely violated New Year's truce period.

PARIS Perhaps the most significant American foreign policy failure over the past decade came neither in Vietnam nor at the Bay of Pigs but in Laos. Had U.S. diplomacy plugged the Laotian sewer already being exploited by Communist guerrillas ten years ago, the sordid drama that subsequently tortured external and internal U.S. relationships might have been avoided.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) Glenn Cannon, Mississippi safetyman, recovered a fumble in the final quarter to stop a Razorback drive, as the Rebels staved off an Arkansas rally and hung on for a 27-22 victory today in the 36th annual Sugar Bowl football game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) The United States economy will grow at an annual rate of about 7 per cent for the first half of the new decade, reaching a gross national product of $1.4-trillion by 1975, the Commerce Department predicted today.

B UENOS AIRES, Jan. 1 (AP) The police said that five well-dressed hijackers, one a woman, seized a Brazilian jetliner at gunpoint tonight shortly after it left Montevideo, Uruguay. They forced the pilot to refuel here and to take aboard navigation maps with routes to Cuba, the police said.

Police and Fire Department officials announced yesterday a campaign against parking violators especially those who impede access to fire hydrants in fine area of lower Manhattan known as Hell's Hundred Acres.
A $375,000 program to assist in the recording of serious contemporary American music has been established by the Ford Foundation.

As one of the most powerful members of the United States Senate, 57-year-old Henry Martin Jackson enjoyed a number of triumphs last year involving one of his two chief concerns the extension of America's nuclear and military powers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 Top officials of the Nixon Administration have tentatively agreed to seek expansion of the Safeguard antiballistic missile system, according to knowledgeable sources. Approximately $1.5-billion has been earmarked for an enlarged program in the new defense budget that goes to Congress later this month, the sources said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 The nation's newest computer-based forecast of the economy projected today no recession in 1970 but a continued slowing of the economy with a rise in unemployment to an average of 4.4 per cent of the labor force.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 1 (UPI) The White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, doesn't like everything he reads about himself. But he was consoled today by the highest source in the land President Nixon.

Cruise passengers will get a new point of view when the 18,000-ton liner Song of Norway, launched recently in Helsinki, Finland, enters service out of Miami next November. A circular, enclosed observation lounge, extending from the rear of her large smokestack, will be reached by a staircase from the topmost passenger deck aft.
LIVINGSTON, Tex., Jan. 1 (AP) Robert Fulton Battise, 60 years old, known in cast Texas as one of its finest woodsmen, donned the headdress of chief of the Alabama-Coushatta Indian tribe today.

ROME, Jan. 1 Pope Paul VI prayed today that the world be forgiven for the fact that "giant industries" prosper on "the diabolical capacity to produce arms" and powerful nations base their stability on "trading arms to poor nations lacking plows, schools and hospitals."

Harry (Heresch) Konner, retired Jersey City merchant and philanthropist, died Wednesday at the Hebrew Home Hospital. He was 82 years old.

TRENTON, Jan. 1 (AP) New Jersey's passenger railroads, on the way to extinction just three years ago, are in a building boom that will modernize them over the next five years and prepare them to handle 40 per cent more riders than they carry today.
Representative Edward I. Koch, back from a two-day trip to Canada where he spoke earlier this week to a score of expatriates who went there to avoid the draft, says he recommends amnesty for them.
LONDON, Jan. 1 "Darling! Now that we're 18 we can do something we've always wanted to do," the girl says coyly to the boy on the cover of a pop art greeting card sent out by the Labor party.
Forty-three newspaper editors and executives were named journalism jurors for the 1969 Pulitzer Prizes yesterday by Columbia University.

The film year just ended was not a vintage one "from any point of view," according to the National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures, the Roman Catholic film reviewing group formerly called the Legion of Decency.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 Glenn (Bo) Schembechler, Michigan coach taking his first team to the Rose Bowl, went to the hospital instead today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 Thousands of American industrial concerns violate the Federal Government's occupational safety and health requirements every year, but the available penalties are almost never invoked against corporate offenders.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 1 (Reuters) The parity of the Argentine peso was technically changed today from 350 pesos to a dollar to 3.50.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 In the planning for the seventies in the United States, one thing is clearly missing a definition that can be understood by the American people of where they stand with one another and the rest of the world.
CAIRO, Jan. 1 (UP) A Cairo newspaper said today that an Egyptian naval vessel had sunk the Israeli submarine Dakar, which disappeared with 69 aboard in the Mediterranean on Jan. 25, 1968.

ATHENS, Ohio, Jan. 1 (UPI) Two small brothers, apparently abandoned by their mother who recently underwent treatment for a mental disorder, were found dead today along Ohio Route 100 near here.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation looks for "a strong increase in sales in 1970," Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president, said in a statement pre pared for release today. He said that I.T.T. expected to report sales and revenues for 1969 of about $5-billion and that they should rise to about $6-billion in the present year. This woud compare with the $4.1-billion reported for 1968.
ATHENS, Jan. 1 Greece's new press law took effect today, and all but two of the 12 national-circulation newspapers immediately raised their prices to cope with the economic impact.

The Transit Authority and its two unions agreed on new contracts yesterday that will cost $120-million over the twoyear life of the pacts and that are almost certain to necessitate an increase in bus and subway fares.

In 1959 Enrico DiGiuseppe, a tenor from Philadelphia, made this professional debut with the New Orleans Experimental Opera Theater. Last fight, Mr. DiGiuseppe began the New Year with his Metropolitan Opera debut, the goal of all young American singers who give themselves to opera.

LONDON, Jan. 1 The British Government lifted tonight its unpopular restriction on the amount Britons could spend on vacations abroad.
Early morning fires on New Year's Day took the lives of five men at a Nyack, N.Y., boarding house and of a woman in a Bronx apartment. The woman's two children were seriously injured.
DALLAS, Jan. 1 There was never any doubt what play Texas would use when, the Longhorns reached the Notre Dame 10-yard line in the closing minutes, Darrell Royal said today.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) Four black players quit the South team today and apparently left town without a word to officals of the American Bowl.

Two days before the end of 1969, the British pound soared above par for the first time in twenty months. On the last day of the year, Britain repaid $200 million on postwar debts to the United States and Canada. And the British Government celebrated the New Year by abolishing the $120 individual foreign travel allowance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) Allowing elderly people to earn all they can and still collect full Social Security benefits would help relatively few retired people and would re quite increased taxes for all workers, according to a study by the National Council of Senior Citizens released today.
Mrs. Irving M. Loth, former president of the True-Vue Optical Company, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a three-month illness. She was 67 years old.
THE latest book by John K. Terres, a naturalist, ("From Laurel Hill to Stiler's Bog", Alfred A. Knopf, 227 pages, illustrated, $6.95) is nature writing and reportage at its best.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 2 Vice President Agnew consoled wounded American servicemen here today and said his 24-hour visit to South Vietnam had "confirmed to me the wisdom of our policies."

VIENNA, Jan. 1 In a subdued New Year broadcast, President Ludvik Svoboda of Czechoslovakia called on the Communist party today to work "wisely and prudently" and with "a sensitive approach to people."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 The President is off in California watching football on television. The Vice President is off in Southeast Asia. Congress has scattered, and the Supreme Court is out of sight.
Edward Falk, who on Christmas Day received a heart and two lungs in a single transplant operation, died early this morning at New York Hospital.
H. Ross Perot expressed disappointment yesterday over his failure to deliver a planeload of "badly needed supplies" to American prisoners of war in North Vietnam but vowed, "I'm not giving up."

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Jan. 1 (UPI) The Navy abandoned today all plans to salvage the deserted munitions ship Badger State, which has been floating for a week in the mid-Pacific.

The marriage of Miss Susan Cohen, daughter of Mrs. Alvin Gallant of New York and the late Edward Cohen, to G. Martin Wexler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Wexler of Kings Point, L.I., took place yesterday afternoon in the Versailles Suite at the St. Regis-Sheraton. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony.

Manuscripts and printed treasures from one of the great libraries of the world the Bodleian Library of the University of Oxford are on loan outside of Britain for the first time. They are on exhibition here at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 (UPI) Eddie Joyal scored two first-period goals and Leon Rocheford added the clincher early in the second period as the Los Angeles Kings topped the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-3, tonight.
Miss Katharine Allen and Steven Heywood Kelley, 1969 graduates of Northwestern University, have made plans to be married next summer.

Thomas A. Johnstone, a composer and lyricist who wrote a number of musicals for the Broadway stage in the nineteentwenties, died last nght at the Teaneck Nursing Home in New Jersey. He was 81 years old and, until last year, had lived at the Actors Fund Home of America in Englewood, N.J.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 1 (Reuters) The militant An Quang Buddhist faction published today an account of the alleged massacre at Songmy, containing charges that almost 600 men, women and children were shot and piled four deep in a ditch.
A power failure in the Fresh Meadows section of Queens cut off electrical service to about 1,000 homes last night, according to a spokesman for the Con Edison Company.
ATLANTA, Jan. 1 (UPI) William I. Ray Jr. has been named general manager of Atlanta Newspapers, Inc., which publishes The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution.

Narcotics arrests in New York City increased sharply during 1969, according to the Police Department.
Two champagne corks popped across a 45th-floor room of the Americana hotel at 7 A.M. yesterday, ringing down the curtain on the city's biennial transit drama.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 1 (UPI) Hinson Stiles, managing editor of The New York Mirror from 1935 to 1958, died in Palm Beach on New Year's Eve. He was 76 years old and lived in Florida for the last eight years.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) Two passengers who had been feared killed along with four other persons in the crash of a light plane last night were found safe in Sebring today.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan .1 (AP) Gov. Ronald Reagan plans to announce his candidacy for a second term between March 1 and March 15, sources close to him said today.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 1 (AP) A 6-week-old girl from Flint, Mich., is under treatment at University Hospital for a rare abdominal condition in which she was slowly starving to death, according to her physicians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) The Justice Department promised today a prompt review of the dismissal by the Air Force of A. Ernest Fitzgerald.
HONG KONG, Jan. 1 The possibility of worldwide nuclear war was a dominant theme of a New Year editorial appearing today in the Peking publications Jenmin Jih Pao, Hung Chi and Chiehfang Chun Pao.

LAUREL, Md., Jan. 1 Miss Keymar, a surprise winner against good colts in her previous race, turned in another upset today when she won the $10,000 Jolly Time Purse before a crowd of 12,482 at Laurel Race Course.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 1 (AP) A committee of Mississippi religious leaders called today for efforts to make the state's public school system a model for the nation in the face of court-ordered desegregation.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 1 Lee Alexander, the first Democrat in 16 years to be mayor here, was sworn in today at the foot of the spiral staircase in the main hall of the Everson Museum.

PARIS, Jan. 1 France took an apparently mild measure against Israel today by asking for the recall of only one of her representatives here, Adm. Mordechai Limon, head of the Israeli arms purchasing mission.

GAINES, Pa., Jan. 1 (AP) A 15-year-old boy was charged with murder today in the shotgun death of a girl hunting companion a few miles from this rural community in northern Pennsylvania, the state police said.
