President Nixon, in rebuking Congress for its ill-considered demand that university administrators cut off Federal subsidies for students engaged in campus disorders, has reiterated his sound objections to placing the Federal Government in the role of campus policeman. The vindictive provision, which also requires institutions to report periodically on punitive actions they have taken, is contained in a $2.4-billion appropriations bill for the Departments of State, Justice and Commerce.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 The Southern California Trojans, scoring on a 33-yard touchdown pass from Jimmy Jones to Bob Chandler, upset the favored Michigan Wolverines, 10-3, today before a record crowd of 103,878 spectators in the 56th Rose Bowl game.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 1 Israeli leaders expressed today what appeared to be a final warning to Lebanon to restrict the activities of Arab guerrillas operating against Israel from Lebanon.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where indicated.

The Anaconda Company announced yesterday implementation of the understanding that had been reached on June 26, 1969, between the Government of Chile and Anaconda's operating subsidiaries in Chile, the Chile Exploration Company and the Andes Copper Mining Company.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 1 (AP) A group of coffeehouse operators announced plans today for a national drive to prevent the Shelter Half Coffeehouse near Fort Lewis, Wash., from being placed off-limits by the Army.

MIAMI, Jan. 1 Penn State's mighty defense played the most magnificent game in its amazing recent history, holding an explosive Missouri time and again and grabbing a record seven interceptions to enable the undefeated Nittany Lions to beat the Tigers, 10-3, in the Orange Bowl tonight and extend Penn State's undefeated streak to 30 games over a threeyear span.
"Instructions for the Running of Trains, Etc. on the Erie Railway to Go Into Effect Monday January 1, 1862."

RACINE, Wis., Jan. 1 (UPI) Douglas La Follette, a 29-yearold chemistry professor who is a grandnephew of Robert M. La Follette, said yesterday he would seek nomination as a Democratic candidate for Congress in the First District.
The police began yesterday to ticket taxis not painted the proper color in accordance with a local law that went into effect with the New Year.

MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif., Jan. 1 (UPI) Divers found the body of a teen-aged girl today, and her father, her boyfriend, her brother, two sisters and a niece were missing and presumed drowned in a boating accident.
MONTGOMERY, Ala. Not surprisingly, George Corley Wallace sees the 1970's as the time when George Corley Wallace will have his greatest impact.

A sale of more than $39million in Israel bonds for last year in the greater New York area was reported last night at the third and final performance of the Hanukkah Festival for Iserael at Madison Square Garden.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 1 George M. (Dooie) Isdale Jr. of the host club took a 22-point lead today in the opening of the annual New Year's invitation Dyer dinghy frostbite regatta at the American Yacht Club. The three-day event ends with racing Saturday and Sunday.
THIS may be the year; 1970 may well see a victory for the United States in the world team championship for the first time since 1954.
DALLAS, Jan. 1 Texas began the new decade the way it left the old today, gambling for a late victory.
Donald H. Karshan, a print collector and writer on the graphic arts, has been appointed the first director of the New York Cultural Center in Association with Fairleigh Dickinson University.
BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP) A Boston policeman was seriously injured today when he was sucked into an open manhole by the draft caused by a fire in another manhole 50 feet away.

The board of directors of Chesapeake Industries, Inc., has agreed to acquire all the outstanding stock (230,800 shares) of Stiles, Allen Reimer Sheet Metal, Inc., a manufacturer of metal doors and frames with plants in Mesa, Ariz., and Purcell, Okla.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 1 (Reuters) President Nixon telephoned today the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, J. Edgar Hoover, to congratulate him on his 75th birthday. Later he said that he knew of no plans for the controversial F.B.I. chief to retire.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 1 (UPI) Argentina ousted off the topseeded South African team today and advanced to the final of the Sunshine Cup tennis tournament against the winner of tomorrow's competition between the United States and Czechoslovakia.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1 Two skippers from the Larchmont Interclub fleet, James Brickell Jr. and Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr., set the pace in the 39th annual Frostbite Yacht Club's New Year's Regatta after five races were sailed today.

GRAND JUNCTION, Colo., Jan. 1 (UPI) American Metal Climax, Inc., has announced it is shutting down uranium operations in Colorado and Utah because of weak demand for uranium and no prospect of improvement in the years ahead.
Mayor Lindsay began an 11th-hour drive yesterday to limit an apparently imminent increase in the transit fare to five cents.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (AP) About 5,000 young New Year's revelers went on a windowsmashing and store-looting rampage for two hours early today on a popular boulevard in East Los Angeles.

PARIS, Jan. 1 (Reuters) Regis Debray, a French intellectual serving a 30-year jail sentence in Bolivia for guerrilla activities, appealed tonight to his supporters to forget him and to work for prisoners in Brazil.
A burst of sales in the final week before Christmas pushed December volume up by 9 per cent in New York department stores over the level of the year before.

Governor Rockefeller's administration has at last reluctantly conceded that the total cost of the Albany South Mall project may exceed $1 billion. This is more than four times the original estimate for the 98.5-acre complex that will stretch from the State Capitol south for five blocks almost to the Governor's Mansion.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Charter Company, which through its subsidiaries is engaged in the mortgage, loan, real estate and banking business.
Train commuters suffered a series of delays here yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Saturday, Jan. 3 Israeli commandos removed a seven-ton radar installation last Friday night from an Egyptian coastal position at Ras Ghareb on the Gulf of Suez and brought it back to Israeli-occupied Sinai.
EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., Jan. 2 New Hampshire earned the right to meet Mount St. Mary's in tomorrow night's Pocono Classic final by topping the Hofstra five of Hempstead, L.I., tonight, 76-63.

Even in a period when all costs are rising, the decision of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to raise the subway and bus fare from twenty cents to thirty cents is a cruel blow to the pocketbooks of millions of New Yorkers.
Activity in the new-issue market slowed to a snail's pace this week, reflecting a seasonal let-up of new offerings.
Dennis R. Allen, formerly managing editor of The Des Moines Register and Tribune Syndicate, has joined The New York Times News Service as assistant to its editor-manager, Rob Roy Buckingham.
GUILFORD, Conn., Jan. 2 Dr. and Mrs. William J. Harold Jr. of Sachem's Head have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Anne Harold, to Douglas Brewster Reed.

ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 2 (UPI) The University of Georgia, which had little offensive punch this season, signed Fred Pancoast today. He is credited with having helped turn the Florida Gators to a mighty scoring machine.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) President Nixon announced today a sharp reduction in tariffs on imported Wilton and velvet carpets and rugs of oriental design.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 2 Bud Grant, coach of the Minnesota Vikings, and Blanton Collier, his Cleveland counterpart, reflected today the roles cast for their teams in Sunday's National Football League championship game.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2 (AP) Carlos Denegri, one of Latin America's best known journalists and a reporter for the Mexico City newspaper Excelsior for 32 years, was shot to death in his home last night.

A RETIRED lawyer and widower, Benjamin Esk witt, slowly surveyed one of two model apartments that recently opened at Kittay House, which will have 249 units designed for older, but still self-reliant people.
The American Stock Exchange made its biggest advance in five months yesterday as volume slumped from Wednesday's record daily total.
Demand for bank loans continued to increase and the Federal Reserve continued to pursue its effort to restrain credit, banking data published yesterday indicated.

Morris Rosen, chairman of Morris Rosen and Sons, Inc., one of the largest mason contractors in the East, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 2465 Palisade Avenue, Riverdale.

Curt Flood, whose challenge to baseball's reserve clause may set in motion major changes in the organization of professional sports, is in New York to tape a television show and begin conferences with Arthur Goldberg, who will represent him. Flood arrived last night from St. Louis, accompanied by his attorney, Allen, Zerman.

The bear market took a heavy toll among the most actively traded issues on the New York Stock Exchange last year. Many old favorites were back on the list, and some newcomers joined the ranks, but the net results were generally disappointing to traders.

MIAMI, Jan. 2 (AP) A Cuban gunboat fired warning shots at a Liberian cargo ship off the Cuban coast last night and ordered her toward port, the ship's owners reported today. The vessel, the Deep Freeze, later was allowed to continue on her way before reaching a Cuban port.

TOKYO, Jan. 2 A star was born or rather reborn at the Imperial Theater here tonight when Sakura Jinguji received an ovation for her performance in the title role of "Scarlett," a new musical based on "Gone With the Wind," the Margaret Mitchell novel.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP) Only three days before the inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne, a book has been published theorizing that Senator Edward M. Kennedy was not with her when she died in his car last summer on Chappaquiddick Island.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) Britain got its first titled policeman today. Lord Strathnaver, 21-year-old heir to a 90-room castle and one of the largest estates in Scotland, is going to pound a beat.

A union representing lay teachers broke off contract negotiations yesterday and said it would strike the 301 schools of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York on Jan. 19 unless Cardinal Cooke reopened the talks.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 2 (AP) Nigerian troops, after months of bitter fighting, have cleared vital roads through Biafra, cutting the enclave into three parts, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.
BUFFALO, Jan. 2 (AP) Seven patrol cars cruised throughout Erie County today looking for motor vehicles that were polluting the air. Inspectors reported spotting 41 of them.

RICHMOND, Jan. 2 (AP) Gov. Mills E. Godwin Jr. issued a conditional pardon today for Frank P. Lavarre, a 20-year-old student whose 20-year prison sentence on a marijuana possession conviction had received wide publicity.

F.S. Smithers Co., an 113year-old New York investment banking concern, announced yesterday its incorporation and the election of Arthur D. Lewis as chairman of the board and chief executive officer and W. Truslow Hyde Jr. as president.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania Robert Seidman, professor of law at the University of Wisconsin and at University College, Dar es Salaam, puts a case of witchcraft to his students to indicate some problems of legal method in a developing country. It is based on an actual High Court decision in what used to be British Africa.
Al Kooper, who became one of the most important figures in the rock of the last few years, gave two concerts last night at Town Hall.
State Supreme Court Justice Charles Marks, who in 32 years on the bench dealt vigorously with the courtroom conduct of defense and prosecution lawyers and unruly spectators, retired yesterday.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 2 Twelve persons accused of having planned a coup d' tat in February, 1966, were acquitted today by a jury.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. Piderit Jr. of Richmond Hill, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Celeste Mary Piderit, to Lawrence Patrick Murphy Jr., son of State Assemblyman and Mrs. Murphy of Brooklyn.

By next Tuesday, Katherine Hepburn is expected to make known to the management of "Coco" her decision as to whether she will agree to an extension of her contract with the musical based on the life of Gabrielle Chanel, the designer.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 2 (AP) In the first sharp ground action of 1970, an American patrol clashed in a four-hour battle with North Vietnamese infiltrators near the Cambodian border, military spokesman reported today.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 2 (AP) Clifton R. Wharton Jr. took charge of Michigan State University today.
The stock market started out 1970 with a crisp rally yesterday, thanks partly to its release from the tremendous pressures of tax-loss selling in December.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2 A spokesman for United States Steel here said tonight that the management decision of the Fairfield Works in Alabama closing its gates to foreignmade cars is "not corporate policy."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) The State Department said today that it was ready to continue talks with the Soviet Union on the Middle East despite Soviet rejection of the latest American proposals for a settlement.
MELLRICHSTADT West Germany, Jan. 2 (AP) Three West German border guards risked their lives last night to rescue a 17-year-old East German in danger of bleeding to death in an East German minefield.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 2 (AP) The police said today there was a 31 per cent decline in the number of sexual offenses reported in metropolitan Copenhagen in 1969 the year all restrictions on pornography in Denmark were lifted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 Following are excerpts from the summary of findings and recommendations of the report of Harlan Reed Ellis dealing with relaxation of security procedures for parttime personnel at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare:

PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 2 Dr. Albert Hertzog, an ultraright-wing Member of Parliament, was given a suspended sentence of a 29 fine ($69.60) or 50 days in jail for refusing to give evidence to an inquiry into state security.
JAFFREY CENTRE, N.H., Jan. 2 Leonard Garland Hunt, a founder and former senior vice resident of Emery Air Freight, died Wednesday at his home here. He was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 The value of new construction activity fell substantially in November to an annual rate of $92-billion from a revised rate of $93.9-billion in October, the Commerce Department reported here today.
A 28-year-old gypsy-cab driver was shot and seriously wounded last night when he hit one of two patrolmen with the other's nightstick while they were giving him a summons.
A group of young Puerto Rican militants refused yesterday to comply with a court order requiring them to vacate an East Harlem church they seized last Sunday.
The Transit Authority raised the bus and subway fare from 20 cents to 30 cents yesterday to provide additional revenue to meet an increasingly serious deficit.
THORNWOOD, N.Y., Jan. 2 (AP) A Westchester County parkway policeman shot his estranged wife and sister-inlaw yesterday following an argument, the Mount Pleasant police charged today.
Six men seated around a cluttered conference table made the final decision yesterday that raised the transit fare here to 30 cents.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 2 The old order, Democratic, passed in this city today, but it did not give way to the new, Republican-dominated administration without a struggle that took the form of words and, briefly, of a spirited contest for possession of the Mayor's gavel.
TOKYO, Jan. 2 (UPI) Japan's exports in fiscal 1970 may reach $19.35-billion, an increase of 15.7 per cent over the current fiscal year, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.
CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 2 James R. Hoffa, teamsters union president, today lost another effort to get a new trial. He is serving an eight-year prison sentence for jury tampering.

AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 2 A spokesman for Al Fatah, the largest Palestinian commando group, reports that "certain Arab states" have told his organization that they are "willing to receive" back Jews who emigrated to Israel and now wish to return to their countries of origin.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 2 Midway through their second season, in the National Basketball Association, the Milwaukee Bucks finally managed to defeat the New York Knickerbockers tonight before a capacity crowd of 10,746 at Milwaukee Arena.

A major witness against Coy D. Smith, a member of the "Durham Mob" indicted for allegedly stealing more than $500,000 in antipoverty funds, was shot at last week and has been placed under 24-hour-aday guard.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 A Yippie-made film about events at the 1968 Democratic National Convention was barred from evidence today at the Chicago conspiracy trial.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) The Library of Congress, which has the greatest collection of books ever assembled, is facing its worst crisis since 1814, when the British burned the United States Capitol and destroyed the infant Library's entire stock.
The 20-cent transit fare was pronounced dead yesterday and its mourners were legion.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) Britain announced today that it is heading into the New Year with its reserves of gold and foreign currency showing an increase of $24-million in December.
The Franklin Award for Distinguished Service will be presented to Governor Rockefeller at the 1970 Printing Week Dinner on Jan. 22 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 2 Members of the new Suffolk County Legislature took their oaths of office and held their first meeting today, officially ending a form of government that has ruled the county for 287 years.
HAVANA, Jan. 2 (Reuters) Cuba observed the 11th anniversary of Premier Fidel Castro's revolution on a note of austerity today and with extra efforts to harvest the important sugar crop.
TOKYO, Jan. 2 (AP) The Bank of Japan announced today that it had formally returned to the Bank for International Settlements headquartered in Basel, Switzerland.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 (UPI) New York State's 200 national banks are now subject to state and local sales and use taxes, Acting State Tax Commissioner Norman Gallman said today.
The taxi industry expects to ask the City Council for a fare increase by midyear so that it can remain competitive with the subway and bus system in attracting drivers.

WHAT would Christmas be without "The Nutcrack- er"? For that matter what would "The Nutcracker" be without Christmas? However the year-end rituals of New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater are now settled in their ways, and "The Nutcracker" and Christmas go together like witches and hemlock.
PARIS, Jan. 2 A leader of the liberal trend in Western Communism assailed the French Communist apparatus today in its own newspaper, the daily L'Humanit .

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 2 United States Steel began today closing the gates at its Fairfield Works to drivers of foreign-made vehicles here in a move apparently aimed at encouraging more domestic buying.
The State Insurance Department yesterday announced a rate increase averaging 27 per cent for subscribers of Blue Cross in northeastern New York. It is effective March 1.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I. It looked a little like the year 2000 with Plexiglas mazes and sloping semicircles of white Fiberglas and curved, softly lighted bays along the walls but it was really a big playroom, designed very much for today.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 2 Dinner had been scheduled for 6:30 in the Banquet Room of the Santa Barbara Inn, where the Kansas City Chiefs have been lodged this week. When the steaks were slow in arriving last night, most of the Chiefs were content to watch the Orange Bowl game on the color TV set perched atop a table.

A casque hornbill, a large reddish-gray bird distinguished by a grotesque helmet-like growth on top of its head, escaped from the bird house at the Central Park Zoo yesterday while its cage was being cleaned.

DALLAS, Pa., Jan. 2 Mr. and Mrs. J. Houston Day have announced the engagement of Mr. Day's daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Day, to Robin Sheldon Balding. He is a son of Mrs. Martin A. Quirk of Rumson, N.J., and the late Gerald M. Balding of Weyhill, England.

The Democratic party in Queens united yesterday to celebrate the retention of the Borough Presidency by a party officeholder, finding occasion in the induction of Sidney Leviss, a chief policy maker in the borough administration for 11 years, as head of the country government.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday an $87-million cut in long-distance rates to offset a previously anounced rise in charges for teletype and other specialized services.
ATHENS, Jan. 2 Political prisoners in the Greek Government's largest detention camp appealed today for medical care and the release of "the seriously ill, the invalid and the aged."
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Jan. 2 Led by Jack Ferguson and Jim Webber, C.W. Post College rallied from a 14-point second-half deficit tonight and defeated Cortland State 80-73, at Conolly Gym.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) The International Monetary Fund said today it had completed the first distribution of the new money substitute known as "paper gold."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 A New Rochelle, N.Y. in ventor who has one battery on exhibit at the Smithsonian Institution was awarded a patent this week for another.
Out of public view at City Hall, months of political infighting have delayed the formation of a quasi-independent agency that must take over the 18 city hospitals by July 1.
Henry Fried, 69-year-old millionaire contractor, surrendered yesterday in Federal Court to begin serving a two-year prison term for conspiring to bribe former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP) Jerry West and Keith Erickson led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 125-95 triumph over the San Francisco Warriors tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare relaxed for part-time personnel today the security clearance procedures that had led to the blacklisting of scientific consultants to the Government and the animosity of many intellectual societies.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 2 Miss Elizabeth Jean Skinner and James William Walkup Jr., who received degrees last June from the Princeton ...

PARIS, Jan. 2 L on Cotnareanu, former co-owner of Le Figaro, the conservative Paris daily, and retired chairman of the Coty Perfume Company, died yesterday after a long illness in Geneva. He was 78 years old.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 2?A local law under which civil penalties of up to $500 could be imposed in cases of consumer fraud was proposed today by Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

Three singers will make their Metropolitan Opera debuts in Mozart's "Die Zauberflote" on Jan. 19, during the fourth week of the company's season. Edith Mathis, soprano, will appear in the part of Pamina, Judith Blegen, also a soprano, will be Papagena, and Ivanka Myhal, mezzo-soprano, will be the Third Genie.

WHEN Dr. Karl Blessing stepped down on Dec. 31 as president of West Germany's central bank to make room for Dr. Karl Klasen, it was with the conviction that the threat of an "imported" inflation had been removed.

BOWLING GREEN, Ky., Jan. 2 (UPI) Ed A. Diddle Sr., the colorful Western Kentucky University basketball coach who retired in 1964, died this morning at a hospital here after suffering his 13th heart attack. He was 74 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 2 "The best Nguyen Van Thieu could hope for," an experienced Western diplomat was saying the other day "would be another year as good as the last."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 2, (AP) A rolling hook shot by Wes Unseld with 50 seconds to play, followed by Kevin Loughery's key steal, gave the Baltimore Bullets a 118-116 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight.
Charles F. Berlitz, grandson of the founder of the worldwide language schools, is getting his first lesson in a language that his new to him legalese.

LAUREL, Md., Jan. 2 James A. Bayard's Cherrybird, the even-money favorite in the field of five Maryland-bred fillies and mares, justified the confidence of her backers in the crowd of 10,122 at Laurel race course today when she easily won the $13,750 All Brandy Handicap.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 Chief Justice Roger J. Traynor of the California Supreme Court announced his retirement today after 30 years on the bench.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Peabody Marks have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jennifer Peabody Marks, to John Douglas Peck, son of Mrs. Mahlon F. Peck of Rocky Hill, Conn., and the late Mr. Peck, who was a professor of psychology at Western Maryland College.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2 (AP) The world's largest railroad car, 177 feet long, left today with a 760,000-kilowatt generator for the Turkey Point nuclear power plant in Florida.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 2 State Senator Edward L. Marcus of New Haven, majority leader of the State Senate, is scheduled to announce next Thursday his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in opposition to Senator Thomas J. Dodd.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 2 (AP) The Chatham County Commission has passed an ordinance imposing a business license fee of $10,000 a year on movie theaters showing films rated "X" and "R."
MIAMI Jan. 2 (AP) Morris Wexler's Beerich closed with a rush to win today's seventh race at Tropical Park before a crowd of 9,155.
Thirty ships, halted by a frozen drawbridge, over Newark Bay, started sailing yesterday afternoon after waiting for 42 hours for the bridge to thaw out.

Three archeologists, whose discoveries and scholarly writings have added significantly to history of the ancient world, were honored this week with the gold medal of the Archaeological Institute of America.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2? After a full year in the seat of power, the Nixon Administration's imprint on the social life of the capital is so faint as to be almost wraith-like.

ATHENS, Jan. 2 Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus, conferred with leaders of Greece's military-backed Government here today in renewed efforts for a formula of peaceful coexistence for Cyprus's Greek and Turkish communities.
PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 3 (AP) Air France canceled most of its European flights and two flights to New York yesterday because of a strike by stewardesses and stewards. A flight to Tokyo was delayed.

The New York State Department of Insurance announced yesterday that it had authorized a 17 per cent rate increase for coverage written through the New York Property Insurance Underwriting Association, known also as the "Fire Pool."
Abraham D. Beame, beginning a new term as City Controller after a four-year break, gingerly rubbed the small of his back and explained to a visitor yesterday:

The Chesapeake Ohio and Baltimore Ohio Railroads reported yesterday that their consolidated profits for 1969 eased slightly to $52.5-million, or $6.05 a share, from $53.9-million, or $6.21 a share, in 1968.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that black extremists fomenting racial turmoil killed at least seven policemen in the last six months in more than 100 attacks.

PARIS, Jan. 2 France is understood to be pursuing arms trade with Iraq. An Iraqi ship is reliably reported to be headed for Cherbourg to pick up military supplies, including machine-gun ammunition manufactured by an Alsatian concern, Manufacture de Machines du Haut-Rhin, which is based in Mulhouse.

The 15 largest New York City savings banks experienced a net outflow of $116,621,000 in the three-day grace period at the end of 1969, according to data supplied yesterday by the Savings Banks Association of New York State. This compares with an outflow of $82,667,000 in the year-earlier period.
AN expert can usually judge quite quickly the caliber of an opponent who is unknown to him. It is reasonable to assume that a player who makes a good play has not done so by accident.

Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan said yesterday that he had received the support of 12 state legislators from Manhattan for a bill preserving the borough's six school districts, which are to be reduced to five under a Board of Education policy implementing the state education law.
The Police Department said yesterday that it had increased the number of homicides it recorded in the city this year as a result of closer statistical liaison with the Medical Examiner's office.

Readers and viewers in this country who think journalists have problems because of occasional pressure from Washington to tell it like it isn't ought to consider the plight of journalists in uniform in Vietnam who must try to serve two masters the Army and free expression. In most cases the military version dominates the news in official publications and broadcasts.
HANOI, North Vietnam In the curiously relaxed atmosphere of wartime Hanoi, there are a few loudspeakers scattered through the streets and some people rise at 5 A.M. to do exercises.

Lester Rice, former golf editor of the old New York Journal-American, died of a heart attack yesterday in Doctors Hospital, Freeport, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived at 452 Archer Street, Freeport.
DETROIT, Jan. 2 A nationwide gambling syndicate reputed to involve widely known sports figures was the target of a series of New Year's raids by Federal agents around the country.
LUBBOCK, Tex., Jan. 2 (AP) Jim Carlen, whose West Virginia football team lost only to Penn State in the season just ended, became head football coach of Texas Tech today.
RONALD SANDERS has written an exemplary account of that Jewish, selfcontained compound that made up New York's Lower East Side in the half century that ended with World War I.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) It was a heart attack that kept Bo Schembechler, coach of the University of Michgan football team in the hospital during yesterday's Rose Bowl game with the University of Southern California, doctors said today.

LONDON. Chroniclers of the calendar make a big fuss about the turn of a new decade but those of us who have seen the turn of a century are a little more blase. We still measure time for ourselves, family and friends by something much more personal birthdays.

EVEN in mid-winter, hairdressers are thinking spring and flowers. "Small blossoms on long stalks" is the way Pierre Henri, style director of the Saks Fifth Avenue salon, describes the way he thinks women should start looking before the first crocus peeps out.

An executive of the United Church of Christ demanded yesterday that chaplains in the armed services be instructed to support officers and enlisted men who refuse to carry out orders they deem "in error, immoral or in violation of the laws and customs of war and a crime against humanity."
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 2 Harness racing bounces back onto gait here tomorrow night on a new rubber track supposedly almost as resilient as a horseplayer's bankroll.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 2 Henry C. Strippel, an authority on genealogy, died today after a long illness at White Plains Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 86 Caterson Terrace Hartsdale, N.Y.

Pope Paul's New Year's Day criticism of advanced nations which reinforce their economies by "the trading of arms to poor nations lacking plows, schools and hospitals" leaves few, if any, of the industrialized countries untouched, but it particularly hits home in the United States.
CAIRO, Ill., Jan. 2 (UPI) The predominantly Negro United Front Organization today asked Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie to impose martial law in this racially troubled river town.
Major oil companies are continuing their production of raw materials relative to their refining requirements, according to a survey released yesterday by the First National City Bank.
Willie Sutton's release from prison this holiday season recalls the internationally known bank robber's indirect contribution to medical education a guide to doctors known as Sutton's Law.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 2 Miss Gretchen Lorraine Frank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Frank, was married at her parents' home here today to Jeremy Paul Kagan, a filmmaker-director at the Center for Advanced Filmaking of the American Film Institute in Los Angeles. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Jerrold Goldstein.

Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams, angered by what he called Governor Rockefeller's "disgraceful acquiescence" to the transit fare increase to 30 cents, asserted yesterday that mass transit should be "totally free to New Yorkers," as are police, fire and sanitation services.
BONN, Jan. 2 A record 138 West German companies, with annual balance sheets totaling $4.9-billion, merged in 1969, the Federal Cartel Office announced this week.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 2 (AP) Merrymaking over Texas's victory in the Cotton Bowl turned violent late last night with the police arresting 25 persons, mostly for throwing rocks, beer bottles and firecrackers.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 2 Local 31 of the Web Pressmen's Union struck the city's three newspaper publishers tonight over higher wages.

ENCINO, Calif., Jan. 2 The engagement of Miss Jean Daly McConnell to John Raymond Smiley, a senior at Princeton University, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Findley McConnell. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wilson Smiley of Pittsburgh.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 2 Miss Wendy Carol Cordtz, a senior at Middlebury College, and Second Lieut. Samuel Knox Eaton Jr., U.S.A., a 1969 graduate of Middlebury, have chosen June 13 as the date for their wedding here.
WILTON, N.Y., Jan. 2 A mother, father and six children died early today when a fire destroyed their farmhouse in this hamlet near Saratoga Springs.
A 15-year-old girl, paroled for the Christmas holiday from the Juvenile Center in the Bronx, died on New Year's Eve of an overdose of heroin.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firmer over a broad front yesterday as buying turned more active on news of the easing of travel restrictions.

Although the bicentenary year of Beethoven's birth has scarcely begun, the celebrations have already started. And what is in store for the rest of the year will make even the stanchest Beethoven-lover cringe. The truth is that it is hard to know how to honor the man. There hasn't been a time when his music wasn't played and endlessly.

JERUSALEM, Saturday, Jan. 3 An Israeli commando unit entered a Lebanese village this morning and captured 21 Arab prisoners, presumably to exchange for a 54-year-old Israeli watchman kidnapped on Thursday.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 2 (AP) The Army defense attorney for Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and the prosecution officer left today by plane for personal investigations at Songmy, scene of an alleged massacre.
PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 2 The police said today that they were still seeking a motive in the slaying of a labor union official on New Year's day.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 2 (UPI) President Nixon finished his bill-signing chores today and began locking up the Federal budget for the 1971 fiscal year.

MIAMI, Jan. 2 (UPI) The Los Angeles Rams and the Dallas Cowboys will vent their wounded pride against each other tomorrow afternoon in the National Football League's Playoff Bowl for a consolation payoff of $700 extra to each winning player.
John W. Allyn and Milton A. Speicher have been named senior partners of the investment firm of Francis I. duPont Co.
Complaints by the thousands poured into city offices yesterday from tenants whose apartments were without heat a chronic winter problem and the most acute symptom of housing decay here.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 Comely Tex, a former stable pony, captured the feature at Liberty Bell Park today.

WATERVILLE, Me., Jan. 2 Richard J. Dubord, a former Maine Attorney General and a Democratic National Committeeman for 12 years, died early today in a Boston hospital at the age of 48. He had undergone surgery yesterday for a ruptured blood vessel in the head.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan 2 (UPI) Undefeated North Carolina State, with Vann Williford scoring 27 points, rolled to a 91-57 victory over Maryland tonight in its first Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.
BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP) Members of the Boston Stock Exchange are to vote Jan. 12 on admitting three more Japanese concerns as members, the exchange announced today.

NEWARK, Jan. 2 Simone Rizzo DeCavalcante, a reputed Mafia chieftain known as Sam the Plumber, and 16 other persons pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges that they conspired to operate a $20-million-a-year numbers racket.
Through the entire season, scoutes condemned James Street, the Texas quarterback, as a baseball pitcher who couldn't throw a strike on the football field.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 (UPI) Sub-zero cold clutched much of upstate New York for the second day in a row today, with Albany having the lowest temperature reported by the United States Weather Bureau in the 48 contiguous states.
MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Jan. 2 (UPI) Joseph Laurita, a crusading county prosecutor, was seriously injured today when his booby-trapped automobile exploded as he turned on the ignition.

AMARILLO, Tex., Jan. 2 (AP) A North Texas State University football player said he and three other blacks quit the South team two days before tomorrow's second annual American Bowl game in Tampa, Fla., because of a racial incident at the hotel where they were staying.
Rabbi Matloub Abadi of Shaare Zion Congregation at 2030 Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn died Thursday in the Community Hospital of Brooklyn. He was 80 years old and lived at 2039 Ocean Parkway.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) A strike force is being established by the Justice Department to help combat crime and racketeering on the West Coast. The headquarters will be in Los Angeles.

SUNNYVALE, Calif. The Navy's first undersea ambulance a vessel designed to dive deep into the sea and rescue submarine crewmen stranded on the ocean floor is being prepared for launching late this month.

The new year is only three days old and in many homes throughout the country the signs of Christmas are being removed. Discarded Christmas trees are already a nuisance on the streets, and ornaments and artificial trees are being stored away.

VIETNNA, Jan. 21 A new state Commission for the Protection of Air Purity started its work in Budapest this week, exemplifying rising concern throughout Eastern Europe over the deterioration of the environment.
The shiny new 30-cent subway token between the size or a nickel and a quarter went on sale last night at change booths in all 484 stations of the rapid-transit system.
PHOENIX, Jan. 2 (AP) Johnny Kerr, who could not make the Phoenix Suns a winner despite the addition of superstar Connie Hawkins, resigned today.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 2 (AP) Colgate upset Michigan Tech, 9-4, tonight in the opening game of the second annual Syracuse invitation hockey tournament.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 2 The persistent snows of the North Country have cost the Vikings $75,000 in the last six weeks and they also cost Dick Ericson one sprained ankle.
ZANZIBAR, Tanzania, Dec. 29 The Revolutionary Council of Zanzibar has decreed that no off-islander may marry a Zanzibar girl unless he pays a tax of 56,000 East African shillings, about $8,000.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 2 The Oakland Raiders, a pro football version of the Central Intelligence Agency, are up to their pre-championship, supersecret tricks, but the only thing Daryle Lamonica is hiding is the plays the Raiders might spring against the Kansas City Chiefs.
The election of Dr. William A. Wexler of Savannah, Ga., as chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations was announced yesterday.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2 The Henry Morrison Flagler Museum at Whitehall, the mansion Mr. Flagler built in 1901, is proof that fine craftsmanship was still strong at the century's turn.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 3 Vice President Agnew conferred privately this morning with President Chiang Kai-shek of Nationalist China less than 24 hours after Mr. Agnew said the United States would seek "meaningful dialogue" with Communist China.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) The flu epidemic hit soccer teams today and caused postponement of four games in the third round of the English Cup slated for tomorrow. Three league games also were called off.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 3 (UPI) Howard Porter scored a career high of 38 points and grabbed 17 rebounds today to lead Villanova to a 106-70 rout of Canisius.

WASHINGTON. THE career of the Ameri- can painter Milton Avery, who died on January 3, 1965, at the age of 71, was one of the most astonishing in the art of his time. It was a career without interruptions, digressions, or climaxes.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 3 (UPI) A society to honor the late President Dwight D. Eisenhower has been formed here.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 3 (AP) Carolina blew a nine point half-time lead but rallied in the final period on the shooting of Bob Verga for a 100-91 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Tests of a fishnetlike restraining device have aroused the interest of Federal safety experts concerned about miscarriages in automobile crashes.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 3 Miss Ellen Ross Davidson was married here this afternoon to Robert Samuel Page, a student at the Boston Architectural Center. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Hugh Livengood, assisted by the Rev. David R. King.
